In the time from September 6, 2023 till September 9, 2023 I have been in Paris. It‚Äôs been the first time since 1996 and my first trip alone since visiting Moscow in 2011.
Before I booked my journey I already began learning some French with Duolingo. The French people were known to be very proud of their language and that they barely spoke or knew any English. And it shows some respect for the country you are visiting if you know at least some words in their language. Unlike Russian language French was far more related to Latin, English, Spanish, and German, the languages that I either speak natively or that I have learned in school.
My goal was to travel sustainable and on a budget. Means that I didn‚Äôt want to spend a lot of money and to avoid traveling by car or plane. I took a Flixbus from Bielefeld (Germany) to Paris (Bercy-Seine).
The good point here was that it was an overnight-ride from 10pm to 7:30am. I was solely worried about the Bercy Seine Bus Station which had terrible reviews on Google, just mentioning safety, cleanliness, and drugs. Just in case, I bought myself an Apple Tag before leaving for the bus if somebody would deliberately or accidentally take my luggage. But there‚Äôs no need.
After two stops in D√ºsseldorf and Cologne we arrived and I was postively surprised about the bus station. And Paris. After taking my luggage I went up the stairs left from the outdoor gym and I Paris as I would have never imagined it in my dreams.
What I saw was a Paris that mixed old and new, history and modernity. It was a nice ‚ÄòBienvenue‚Äô to somebody who just arrived in Town.
It was time to walk to the Tourist Office at H√¥tel de Ville to pick up my Paris Visite metro ticket. With the ticket I am able to travel by train, metro, and bus in different zones of Paris. I have picked it for 5 days (4 days weren‚Äôt available and mixing 3 day tickets with a 1 day ticket made no sense financially) for the zones 1 to 3.
Because the office opened at 10am I decided to walk around and saw more of the beauty of Paris, but also its shadowy sites: Notre Dame and old, beautiful buildings, but also homeless people and the ‚Äútraces‚Äù the homeless left in the night. With that in my mind while standing in front of the logo of the Olympic Games ‚Äî and thinking of the reviews about Bercy-Seine ‚Äî I hope that the municipiality of Paris will not chase away the homelss, but offer them real help to find a safe home and a job again.
While crossing the Pont d‚ÄôArcole I already saw the towers of the Cath√©dral de Notre Dame. The cathedral from the 12th century was still under reconstruction after a fire threatened to destroy it. Paris wants to restore Note Dame for the Olympic Games in 2024.
After some walking around I entered the Tourist Office of the City of Paris and received my metro ticket. It was just a little piece of paper, but it was powerful and it‚Äôs worth the price.
The people at the entrance were nice and so were the people in the office. Some spoke English, that‚Äôs helpful. With the ticket in my back I entered the Metro Parisiean and travelled via Metro Line 1 from H√¥tel de Ville to Ch√¢teau de Vincennes, switched to a bus that brought me to Eug√®ne Voisin ‚Äî March√© from where I would arrive at my hotel Ibis Budget in Saint Maurice after a short walk. Saint Maurice, I must say, looked like a stereotype of a French suburb with the small businesses, its architecture and all. I just loved it. The hotel, by the way, was affordable when I booked it in late July 2023 with 86 EUR a night. It offered a bed, a bath-room, and a window. That‚Äôs fine. Two stars were enough for a hotel where I‚Äôd spend the time just to sleep and to take a shower.
After the check-in, unpacking, and changing clothes I was ready to explore Paris.
Due to Google Maps I knew that the next train station was not too far away. The train station Joinville Le Pont was just a bit more than half a kilometer away. While I was walking the way I had the first cutlural shock when I saw people crossing the street while the traffic lights were red. Unimaginable if you live in Germany. But if you don‚Äôt want to look like a tourist, do it like the natives.
Originally I wanted to see the Champs Elysee first. However, I decided to ride further. To La Defense. It was a good decision.
La Defense is a modern business district, according to Wikipedia ‚ÄúEurope‚Äôs largest purpose-built business district‚Äù , will blow you away if you weren‚Äôt already from the first impressions you got from the way to the Tourist Office.
What makes this district so special is not just the purpose of the district nor the skyscrapers everywhere, but that it‚Äôs aligned to the the Arc de Triomphe and the Place de la Concorde. Sitting on the top stair of the Grande Arche, you can spot the Arc de Triomphe at the end of the Avenue Charles de Gaulle.
And the Arc was my goal. I then though that the Avenue Charles de Gaulle was the famous Champs Elys√©e. Today I know that the Arc separates two avenues.
But I didn‚Äôt go straight to the Avenue. I went left and right to take photos everyhwere. It was fascinating to see the modern buildings just kilometers away from the historic center of Paris. Modern architecture next to history. And both co-existed very well, expressing France‚Äôs own understanding as a Grande Nation that is aware of its history but still advances through sciences and trades.
One thing that I wanted to do this time, unlike during my previous travels, was buying food and beverages in supermarkets rather than ‚Äútourist‚Äù stores. This, of course, was easier in Paris than if you are travel maybe in Montego Bay. In Paris you will always find a Franprix, Carrefour, or others. It‚Äôs also cheaper than buying water from the many street vendors selling you the .30 EUR bottles for 2 EUR or more. It was great to know that there‚Äôs always a store around the corner when walking in Paris during severe heat warnings. Whenever you need it, you just buy one or two bottles of water et voila, you have the supplies you need.
At Arc de Triomphe I had to realize that I didn‚Äôt eat enough for the day. I‚Äôve been walking at least 15km then. Some medics in the metro helped me to regain energy. Obviously, I wasn‚Äôt the first one struggling with the heat that day. I decided to eat now rather than later and had dinner near the Arc.
The next day I wanted to start with a French breakfast: a baguette. Across the street was one of many ‚Äúboulangeries‚Äù (bakeries). It cost less than a Euro. With the baguette in my backpack I started today‚Äôs tour: l‚Äôavenue Champs-Elys√©e. However, I didn‚Äôt go straight, but left at Chatelet Les Halles.
The coolest experience when taking a ride in Paris‚Äô public transport system is what you see when you leave the station. You see castles, beautiful buildings, parks. At Les Halles I saw Le Bourse de Commerce right accross a modern building under which you arrive when riding to Chatelet Les Halles, a shopping mall.
Here I saw one of the other nice things Paris has to offer: water cooling. Everywhere in Paris you find cooling islands, water dispensers, or fog creators. On days like these where it is 33¬∞C hot in an urban environment, cooling is important. More important, you can refill your water bottles for free! This is great even for the homeless.
Generally, you‚Äôll recognize that Paris tries to make the shift from traditional city to a modern city and wants to be sustainable. It has many parks to offer, it offers a well-planned public transport system with trains, subways and electric or bio-gas-fueled busses and many bicycles. Apropos bicycles, if you visit Paris for the first time, you will realize that bikes have their own lanes and their own traffic lights. As a pedestrian you will not just cross the street, but also the lane for bicycles.
The trains and subway trains are coming regularly and the stations are well organized. I don‚Äôt say that you don‚Äôt need to walk a bit more, but due to the system in Paris you usually can‚Äôt take the wrong train, because every line has its own platform. And It‚Äôs a pleasure to sit in the trains which are clean and rarely too crowded.
Walking through the streets you will find little restaurants everywhere, often crowded and pouring on the charm of a France that we know from the movies.
Au caf√© ‚Äî On voit n¬¥importe qui ‚Äî Qui boit n¬¥importe quoi ‚Äî Qui parle avec ses mains ‚Äî Qu¬¥est l√† depuis le matin ‚Äî Au caf√©
√Ä Paris by Francis Lemarque
Though I wanted to visit the Champs, I also had another destination in my mind. The Louvre. Home to Mona Lisa and other paintings. Traveling on a budget and with few days in Paris I didn‚Äôt buy a ticket. But you can get into the Louvre if you just want to see the famous pyramide. You only need a ticket for the museum itself.
After walking around the streets near Palace d‚ÄôElys√©e ‚Äî well protected by the local police (and surely the military is also there) ‚Äî I soon made it to the Avenue Champs Elys√©e. It went straight to the Place de la Concorde which was surrounded by installments for the Rugby World Cup that happened in France two days later.
But it looked awesome. The avenue‚Äôs wide with many trees on each side and you could easily spot the Arc de Triomphe. It felt so different to walk there in comparison to other streets, famous or not.
Walking up the street with an ice-cream in my hand I was amazed by the beauty of the buildings. Paris conserved the charming of its history and mixed it with modern life.
People there were both, tourists and native Parisians who did some window shopping or dined in the restaurants. And there were the stores run by luxury brands like Cartier, LVMH, Victoria‚Äôs Secret, and others. Definitely nothing for a budget trip, but impressive, specifically when you see the waiting line in front of one or two stores.
In the smaller streets you will also see other expensive brands, some seem to be only known if your checking account is several digits long.
Aux Champs-√âlys√©es. ‚Äî Aux Champs-√âlys√©es. ‚Äî Au soleil, sous la pluie, ‚Äî √† midi ou √† minuit, ‚Äî il y a tout ce que vous voulez ‚Äî aux Champs-√âlys√©es.
Les Champs-√âlys√©e by Joe Dassin
Changing the street side, I got another ice-cream. Yes, it was hot and the city of Paris recommended to drink a lot and to eat some cooled stuff. Or ice-cream.
I took a short metro ride and left at Louvre. This station was cool. The station was mostly covered by black, marble-like stone and had some expositions, like sculptures of, a.o. Marie-Antoinette, the wife of France‚Äôs last king before the French revolution of 1794.
What I definitely wanted to see in Paris was the nation‚Äôs national soccer team, also known as Les Bleus. France‚Äôs male team around Coman, Griezmann, and Mbapp√© played really well and on this day they had a match against Ireland in the Parc des Princes, the stadium of Ligue 1 champion Paris St. Germain. Originally, I think, France would have played in the Stade de France in the north of Paris. But this was being needed for the Rugby World Cup (the opening match between France and New Zealand‚Äôs All Blacks was nice).
Shortly walking around, talking to some Irish fans wondering about a German who cheers for France (and Ireland ‚Äî French jersey, Irish wrist), I entered the area with my ticket and I witnessed two surprises. The text on my ticket said that the ticket (le billet) must be printed. However, others just used their phones. Also, I read not to take a backpack to the stadium. Surprise, some people took their backpacks into the stadium. With their laptops!
After the national anthems ‚Äî Amhr√°n na bhFiann and La Marseillaise ‚Äî the game began and immediately the atmosphere changed. Was it already great and cheerful, the audience began to push its team and commented every action on the pitch.
The Irish fans, though clearly a minority in the stadium, were audible and didn‚Äôt give up the team, even after the lagging behind 0‚Äì2. But Ireland fought hard and was a respectable opponent for the two-time world champion.
A little advice: when in the stadium and you are thirsty, you may buy a drink once for 6 EUR or more. But then you can do it like everybody in the stadium did. Refill your cup over the sink in the restrooms. This is literally Eau de Toilette, but far cheaper than paying so much for drinking.
After the much the stadium emptied quickly and the audience split up into smaller groups crawling through the many small streets around the stadium. It still was very warm and you can imagine that, when you are entering the crowded metro, air quality won‚Äôt improve.
Maybe one of the best known landmarks of Paris is the Eiffel Tower (Tour Eiffel). The tower was built for the world expo 1889 and wasn‚Äôt so popular among Paris‚Äô inhabitants first. But over the first it became more and more popular and turned into a symbol for the city by the river Seine.
I went from Arc de Triomphe straight to the Eiffel Tower, crossing a bridge and while walking it wasn‚Äôt difficult to spot the tower once you are now longer on a street lined by high but beautiful buildings (a.o. the Yves Saint Laurent Museum).
Before I left town for my trip I have already booked tickets to get onto the Eiffel Tower. You can choose between the first, second, or third level, between stairs and lift. And be aware: when I have been in Paris you could only book tickets for the top online and it was recommended to buy tickets in general on the Eiffel Tower page. The first impression however was some kind of disappointment, because the tower‚Äôs area is surrounded by walls. It‚Äôs not like you can easily go from one side to the other by just walking under the tower. You need to go through security checks and it‚Äôs recommended not to bring large backpacks or even strollers.
But before I went around the tower and ‚Äî be aware ‚Äî there are young ladies trying to get your data (signature, address etc.) for ‚Äî as they say ‚Äî deaf people. I told them that I don‚Äôt sign but that I will donate once back home. Well, the lady who I was talking to tried to push me. No chance. My advice: don‚Äôt sign anything.
After the security check it was time to get up. As sporty as I am I took the stairs to make it to the second level. However, I forgot that I don‚Äôt always feel good in higher altitudes, though you had grid structure and (hand)railers everywhere, it was like ‚Äúoh no, next time I take the lift.‚Äù But it‚Äôs worth it. The view is awesome and just thinking about the achievements of engineers and workers in the 1880s leaves you with awe. Also leaving you with awe are the prices if you buy something to drink. As you can imagine, taking up something to drink is not allowed. A little smoothie bottle then was expensive. Let‚Äôs not talk about the prices.
I took the stairs for the second floor. And It‚Äôs unbelievable what you can see. You can see a Paris that ‚Äî despite of La Defense ‚Äî is not crowded with skyscrapers, but almost ‚Äúflat‚Äù. And you can spot all the different arrondisments, the mixture of old and modern architecture. Sous le ciel de Paris‚Ä¶ You can spot Sacre Coeur, you can look over the roofs of the buildings that have witnessed centuries of history.
Back on the ground I crossed the Pont d‚ÄôI√©na bridge and went to Trocad√©ro. Though not really understanding what Trocad√©ro really is, a castle, originally a museum, was it nice to have a look at the Eiffel Tower again. But it was finally time to return to the hotel and to grab my bag. I still had destinations to visit.
I wanted to visit Montmarte, Sacre Coeur, and eat in a French restaurant again. And I decided to visit a Breton restaurant, La Cantine Bretonne in the 19th Arrondisment.
As usual, first it was a bit complicated to order some food without proper French, but the gentleman did his best to communicate with me in English and I did my best to speak French. Voila, it worked. And I promise to come back with better French skills.
The urban environment between the restaurant and the Stalingrad metro station (no joke, the station‚Äôs name really is Stalingrad) is beautiful. Urban art in many places, little parks and you can walk aside a bassin. And because it was the day of the Rugby World Cup opening you saw groups of French people everywhere, wearing the jerseys of their team. And me, wearing the jersey of France‚Äôs national soccer team, was expected to cheer. The reaction was funny when I told the people that I don‚Äôt understand most of their sentences and that I am from Germany. But I guess they liked to see that ‚Äî looking back in our history ‚Äî somebody from Germany cheers for le grande nation.
After reaching the bassin‚Äôs end ‚Äî I wouldn‚Äôt be surprised if Paris would use it for some kind of competition ‚Äî I entered the metro in Stalingrad again and went straight to Sacre Coeur.
My former neighbors told me that Sacre Coeur and Montmartre are beautiful spots in Paris. When you leave the metro and reach the surface again you will very soon spot a crowded, busy street with lots of tourist shops selling mostly the same stuff. I didn‚Äôt buy it as I didn‚Äôt want to look like a tourist.
At the end of the street you can spot the famous Basilique du Sacr√©-C≈ìur de Montmartre. The basilica was built in 1914 and lies directly to Montmarte, a famous quarter for artists.
Going up the stairs (there‚Äôs also a lift) you come across some street vendors. Be aware of the ones who start tying a cord around your arm. They don‚Äôt stop and ask you for ‚Äúpaper money‚Äù. I was so lucky that I didn‚Äôt have any paper money with me.
I didn‚Äôt go inside Sacre Coeur. Instead I went to Montmartre (if you view the image of the basilica above again, it‚Äôs on the left on the image). First, you will see narrow side streets with smaller than usual houses built in another century. Second, you will recognize that today‚Äôs tourism has taken over Montmartre. It wasn‚Äôt what I expected, a district or quarter for independent artists, but mostly a beautiful quarter that was filled by stores selling almost the same stuff that I saw in the street when I left the metro station. It‚Äôs a pity, because I can imagine that in the past this little piece of Paris was indeed inspiring for artists from around the world.
But I liked the view on Paris. Did this spot look not that high when standing on the second floor of the Eiffel Tower, I then got another look and saw the roofs of Paris again.
After the trip to Montmartre I wanted to go back to the center of Paris. With Paris‚Äô good public transport I arrived at La Nation. I was already curious where the station is ‚Äî where in Paris. The station was decorated with photographies and stories from France‚Äôs successes in sports (mostly soccer I‚Äôd guess), so I thought it‚Äôs somewhere near a stadium or the headquarters of the French Football Federation. But no, I was totatlly wrong. La Nation, the name came from the woman leading the masses, the revolution on a famous painting. It was the young, blonde woman with the red cap.
La Nation‚Äôs statue was located inside a park inside a huge roundabout. People gathered there to relax, play, listening to music, and to exercise.
With no real destination in my mind I was walking around, exploring the streets and alleys of Paris at dusk. It was a nice play between dimming sunlight and shadows and seeing people getting ready for the weekend.
Paris is a large city, a big city, but wherever you are, it felt like home everywhere. It wasn‚Äôt like Berlin, Dubai, or Moscow where you are walking around and people are living for themselves. No, here, that was my feeling, people are a community in every street.
And the city is very diverse. You find Asians, Africans, Arabs, you see Hindhi, Jews, Muslims, and Christians.
After some kilometers I wanted to find a place to sit and to eat. Bars were already crowded, some advertised that they have airconditioning. I thought it would be a nice idea to watch some rugby with the French, or people from New Zealand who‚Äôd play against France tonight.
I picked Le Bastille, a restaurant directly at the Place de la Bastille and ordered my first ever Cesar‚Äôs Salad. Tasty. I was just surprised by the price of the meal in comparison to what I have paid for my order at Le Vin Coeur at the Arc de Triomphe. Anyway, it was great and I enjoyed the evening and the chance to sit.
The day of my departure has come. And it meant that at least I wanted to see some locations on my list before I leave. It was a good choice to pick Flixbus, because the bus would depart at 10pm, so that I could still spend the day in Paris.
I had to check out before 12pm and my idea was to leave early so that I can walk while its not that hot. And it was time to walk ‚Äî marcher ‚Äî straight to Nogent. Why? I wanted to see a place where you find something France is famous for and that is not the Eiffel Tower, not LVMH, no cheese. No, it was la L√©gion √âtrang√®re, the French Foreign Legion.
The Legion is known for hard, rigorous training, home to those who leave life and past behind them. This is the romantic description of an elite unit that accepts foreigners to serve in the French military. Those who do this have to train hard (two-day Kepi march, between 60 and 80 kilometers) and quickly learn French. The Legion is about determination.
When I stood in front of Fort de Nogent in Nogent sur Marne, I was in awe. Though a high, ancient wall stood between me and the fort, I was able to hear somebody who probably was a drill sergeant shouting. Two or three times les ports opened and cars left. I sat there for a couple of minutes, packed with a sports bag and a backpack, wearing only my black shorts and a shirt. Some local residents passed by. How many young men have they seen who joined or wanted to join the legion? Did they think I wanted to join?
Before I left a gentleman left the fort. Out of curiosity I‚Äôve asked him if he‚Äôs a Legionnaire. He wasn‚Äôt, but he was a regular French military servicemen (L‚ÄôArm√©e de Terre). We soon have recognized that talking was a bit complicated, because his English was barely existent and my French wasn‚Äôt sufficient yet. But: Google is your friend. We picked our smartphones and began to write our texts into Google Translate. It was helpful and better than talking with hand signs.
Returning to the station Nogent sur Marne, I was thinking about the Code d‚ÄôHonneur, the Honor Code and it‚Äôs meaning.
Chaque l√©gionnaire est ton fr√®re d‚Äôarme, quelle que soit sa nationalit√©, sa race, sa religion. Tu lui manifestes toujours la solidarit√© √©troite qui doit unir les membres d‚Äôune m√™me famille.
Article 2 of the Code d‚ÄôHonneur de L√©gionnaire
It means that legionnaires have to treat each other respectfully, like a family member, regardless of nationality, ethnicity (or race, if you want to call it so), or religion. And that they support each other.
The one point, ‚Äúregardless of his religion‚Äù mattered when I arrived at my next location: the Great Mosque of Paris.
The Municipiality listed the Mosque among many places to cool off (‚ÄòIt‚Äôs hot in Paris‚Äô, Paris je t‚Äôaime, accessed October 17, 2023).
And indeed, the Grande Mosqu√©e de Paris in the 5th Arrondisment was a true beauty. It was a nice, bright place and you got free water from dispensers to cool down, so you could enjoy the ornaments everywhere, mosaics.
But the highlight was the courtyard with its green and blue. Just seeing it made you peaceful and relaxed. And the fountains allowed me to cool my hands and arms. I stood there for maybe half an hour before I left.
I went on, because I still had time to spend. I walked through les Jardins des Plants, a huge park at Seine River with a zoo included. In the park I was sitting for a while again. Carrying two bags in the head wasn‚Äôt comfortable. After a quick meal I went westward along the river and the Institut du Monde Arabe that was part of the prestigious Sorbonne University.
Crossing may previous route again, I saw four huge men wearing camo uniforms. I looked at the patches on their arms. L√©gion √âtrang√®re. These soldiers were legionnaires. And they looked impressive. Huge, strong guys. Voluntarily you wouldn‚Äôt attack them, comparable to the police units that I have seen in Panama City.
I spent the rest of the day walking through the city and walked through a neighborhood that looked a bit like Chinatown in Paris. But I also saw the areas of Paris that weren‚Äôt so beautiful. But they were, they are the reality of Paris. Paris is not just luxury, not just landmarks, but also average people living day to day or living a normal life in a capital city.
It was time to return to Bercy. In the park I saw how tourists and homeless people shared access to water dispensers. The tourist needed water to brush his teeth, the homeless refilled the bottles with water before trying to sleep, and I washed my hands, cooled my wrists.
At the open-air gym young men exercised. Each already had a muscular torso. One saw me looking at the sixpack. I pointed at it and pulled up my shirt to show him my onepack. We both laughed. And my journey ended where it began. In Bercy Seine. And I hope to return one day. Paris is a beautiful city. Merci, Parisiens.

un philosophe assis
deux musiciens, quelques badauds
puis des gens par milliers
Sous le ciel de Paris
jusqu‚Äôau soir vont chanter
l‚Äôhymne d‚Äôun peuple √©pris
de sa vieille cit√©

I‚Äôve been to Paris twice ‚Äî the first time I was in high school, so I don‚Äôt recall much of that trip, but I had the opportunity to visit the city again last month.
Though the layouts of the cities are different, Paris feels like European New York City to me. Paris is all angles ‚Äî cobblestone roads crisscrossing pavement in front of stone buildings and foot bridges, not like the grid blocks of New York City. The Paris skyline spreads out more than up. Still, the sights and sounds of the cities are similar. Crowds bustle as car horns beep and the smell of garbage and smoke waft through the air.
I was fortunate to be in Paris during preparations for the Olympics. The Eiffel Tower boasted the Olympic rings, and down the steps leading from the Eiffel Tower to the Seine, a countdown clock told passerby the number of days, hours, and minutes until the Olympics and Paralympics begin. All around the city were banners with ‚ÄúParis 2024‚Äù written across them and people setting up structures for different events.
While Paris isn‚Äôt among my favorite European cities, there are things to love about it. Here are four‚Ä¶

When my girlfriend and I visited Paris in January 2020, we noticed something more than pretty old buildings and romantic restaurants: It‚Äôs quite creepy at night.
Some districts in Paris are quite poor.
Our hotel was in such a neighborhood. I wouldn‚Äôt book a hotel room in that area again. But it was cheap.
Getting to our hotel was a struggle on its own. It was above a French pub, and it was full of drunk people who didn‚Äôt speak a word of English, and we needed to get our keys. In the end, the hotel owner opened a vague door somewhere, and we were able to get in.
And a side note you probably need to know: people scare me, a lot. I‚Äôm quite introverted ‚Äî which doesn‚Äôt make these things easy at all.
That first night I got bothered by some pimp in the streets near the Moulin Rouge. The guy invited me to some shady-looking place. I declined friendly by pretending I didn‚Äôt speak any language at all.
I just wanted to get some McDonald‚Äôs.

Title: Paris: An Amazing City with Amazing Food

I took my daughters (10 & 13) to Paris last week and we LOVED it! Parisians seem to prioritize life differently than Americans. They optimize for taste, beauty, relationships, and leisure, while we optimize for career and money. It was an entirely refreshing look at how to live and I am taking note. I thought I‚Äôd share a bit about my experience for those of you thinking of traveling to Paris soon.
Nothing else about Paris is more delightful than the food. Parisians take great pride in their food and in eating. My cousin, Nick, who has been living in the city for the past three years tells me that they have banned certain foods like high fructose corn syrup and meats from the US because they value taste and good ingredients. France is an agricultural state and a lot of what they serve is grown nearby. Croissants really do taste better in France and though there are many reasons for this, the local flour and artesian butter in France, which is much higher quality than most ingredients we get in the US, may be the reason they are so darn good.
The downside to food in Paris is that it is very expensive, except for the baked goods. We could stop into a boulangerie (bakery), buy six croissants or pain au chocolat, and spend around 10‚Äì12 Euros ($11-$13 USD). Whereas lunches or larger brunches would run the three of us around 70‚Äì80 Euros and up if we were in a tourist area or fancy restaurant. Dinners were almost always well over 100 Euros.
We had an amazing French dinner at a restaurant called Georges that sat at the top of the Centre Pompidou, Paris‚Äô modern art museum. It had an amazing view, lots of outdoor seating, and food/drinks that were to die for! We did an entire French dining experience which started with cocktails, and an appetizer of escargot. Followed by a main course, a bottle of wine, dessert, and then digestifs (alcoholic beverages you sip after your meal to ‚Äúcut through the grease‚Äù). I was a fan of everything except the digestifs.
We had many more leisurely cafe experiences in Paris as well. You really can‚Äôt beat an open air patio seat, a croissant, and some tea. We loved our experience at Les Deux Magots, a higher-priced stop, but one with some history. Hemingway and other artists / authors used to be regulars here.
I was nervous about communicating in Paris as my French is very limited. It turns out, I didn‚Äôt really need it. The French seem to appreciate a ‚Äúbonjour‚Äù when you enter and ‚Äúmerci‚Äù. I even tried to order a few times in French. But, the reality is that your English will get you wherever you need to go.
We stayed in an AirBNB near the Saint Lazare train station and either used the trains or walked the entire time we were in Paris. The trains are wonderful and even on weekends always come within 5 minutes. Nick told us to avoid the buses as they typically run late. For the trains, you can get per-trip paper cards, day or week passes, or for 2 Euros you can purchase a plastic card that you can load up with several trips at once.
Paris has train zones, so take care to pay the proper fare if you are traveling between zones. We did not do that when we went to the La D√©fense Arena and got stuck for a second at the train station. If you‚Äôre headed to Versailles you can buy tickets specifically for Versailles at the various train stations that service that route.
Paris is a large city, so, while you can walk many places, when we chose to do that, by the end of the day we were very, very tired!
My least favorite thing about Paris was how crowded it got at the famous tourist sites. You need to purchase tickets ahead of time for almost anything you‚Äôd like to see. The Eiffel Tower sells tickets 60 days in advance. They come out at midnight Paris time and are gone in minutes. Versailles‚Äô tickets are easier to get, but the palace gets so crowded inside, you can‚Äôt even move at times. Try to visit as early in the day as you can. The gardens outside are far more my style and offer enough space for everyone to enjoy!
You need to get Louvre tickets well in advance too. When we showed up last Monday for our 9am ticket slot, they weren‚Äôt letting anyone in due to a maintenance issue. They recommended we return in two hours. We chose to wait instead and an hour and 15 minutes later, we got in. Because so many people left the line, we were one of the first inside and got a front-row spot to see the Mona Lisa. That was rad!
You would do well to purchase Arc de Triomphe and Catacombes tickets early too. The Catacombes allows you to buy tickets just seven days in advance and they sell out within minutes as well. I had read that you don‚Äôt need to buy Arc de Triomphe tickets ahead of time, but the line to the top when we arrived was a mile long. We ended up skipping it.
The parks in town are a much-needed (literal) breath of fresh air. They‚Äôre still covered with people, but you don‚Äôt need timed tickets and you still get some space to enjoy the outdoors at your leisure. Each park, from the Jardin des Tuileries to the Jardin du Luxembourg to the gardens outside Versailles Palace are impeccably landscaped and stunning. They are all well-worth a visit.
I can‚Äôt imagine what the crowds are going to be like this summer during the Olympics. After all, May is supposed to be a shoulder season for Paris and I felt like we were always packed into attractions like sardines. Throughout the city, they‚Äôve set-up temporary stands and venues so you‚Äôll see those everywhere this summer. Some of them are blocking off key views. We couldn‚Äôt see through the Jardin des Tuileries to the Louvre like you typically can, for example.
We stayed in a typical Paris apartment with a view into the inner courtyard. It was really small with a loft that my 10-year-old couldn‚Äôt even stand up in. But, Nick told us that it was actually quite spacious for the city. His apartment, he said, is smaller. It was comfortable too. The appliances were easy to use and the water stayed warm for a couple of showers, then got cold. I‚Äôm guessing that is pretty typical too.
Shopping is not our thing, but it‚Äôs a pastime that many tourists and Parisians really enjoy. You can buy any luxury item you want on the Champs-√âlys√©es or in the smaller department store boutiques like Samaritaine. You can also go second-hand shopping in a number of places. We had a lot of fun in this shop on our last day as we were hiding from the rain.
All-in-all, we loved our petit Parisian girls‚Äô weekend and would 100% go back. Next time, I will spend all of my time strolling through the streets, visiting the gardens, and, of course, eating!
This post first appeared on amberrfield.com. If you‚Äôre interested in similar updates you can follow me here or there!

I know this sounds crazy, but, to me, traveling is more than snapping a few photos of iconic sites. It‚Äôs a chance to ditch the crowds and authentically connect to the people and culture of a new place.
That‚Äôs why, for my upcoming trip to Paris, I‚Äôm not staying near the tourist traps in the Left Bank or Right Bank. No, I‚Äôm going to rent a cute little place way off the beaten path near a regular old bank with a name like, La Banque de Paris.
Down the street will be a charming little caf√© run by a woman named Fran√ßoise. Each morning, I will sit at the same table and flip through a copy of Le Monde while sipping my caf√© au lait. When Fran√ßoise asks if I am Parisian and I tell her I am not, she will say, ‚ÄúMon Dieu! But you read the local newspaper here every morning like a Parisian!‚Äù And I will shoot her a wry smile and say, ‚ÄúTrompe l‚Äôoeil, madame.‚Äù And we will laugh and then exchange handwritten correspondence for the rest of our lives.
Later, skirting the crowds at the Pompidou, I will pick a street completely at random and walk door-to-door until I find a kindly elderly couple who will invite me in to flip through old newspaper clippings and reminisce about post-war Paris: the misery of the forties, the renaissance of the fifties, De‚Ä¶

**A Day in Paris: The City of Lights**
Paris woke up slowly, bathed in the soft light of the early morning sun. The streets of Montmartre, quiet at dawn, were beginning to stir with life. I had always dreamed of visiting the city of lights, and now that I was finally here, it felt like I had stepped into a painting. The cobblestone streets, the quaint caf√©s, and the iconic rooftops made Paris feel like something out of a dream.
I started my day at a small caf√© near Sacr√©-C≈ìur, where I ordered a caf√© au lait and a croissant. The smell of fresh coffee and baked pastries filled the air as I sat outside, watching the city wake up. Locals passed by with their morning papers, while tourists, like me, admired the charm of Montmartre. The calm, easy pace of life here was a welcome change from the rush of daily life.
After breakfast, I made my way up the hill to the Basilica of Sacr√©-C≈ìur. The view from the top was breathtaking. From there, the entire city stretched out before me, the Eiffel Tower standing tall in the distance. Paris seemed endless, and for a moment, I felt like I could stay there forever, gazing at the city below. The charm of Paris wasn‚Äôt just in its monuments, but in the little details ‚Äî the flower-filled balconies, the narrow alleyways, the gentle murmur of life.
The morning was still young, and I decided to explore the artistic heart of Montmartre. Place du Tertre, with its lively atmosphere, was a haven for artists and performers. Painters lined the square, their easels set up, capturing the essence of Paris with each brushstroke. I watched in awe as they created masterpieces in minutes, bringing the city to life on canvas.
By midday, I wandered down to the banks of the Seine River. The sun was high in the sky, and the reflections of the bridges and boats on the water shimmered like magic. Walking along the Seine, I felt like I was part of a story one where love, art, and history intertwined seamlessly. The street vendors, selling old books and vintage posters, added a touch of nostalgia to the walk.
For lunch, I stopped at a cosy bistro in the Latin Quarter. The lively atmosphere was contagious as students, locals, and tourists filled the streets. I ordered steak frites and a glass of wine, savouring the rich flavours of French cuisine. With his charming French accent, the waiter made the experience even more memorable. It was the kind of meal that made you want to linger, soaking in the ambience of the city.
After lunch, I visited the Mus√©e d‚ÄôOrsay, an art lover‚Äôs paradise. Housed in a former railway station, the museum‚Äôs collection of Impressionist art was astounding. Standing before works by Monet, Renoir, and Van Gogh, I felt a deep connection to the artists who had captured the soul of Paris with their strokes of colour and light. Each painting told a story, one that felt timeless.
As the day turned to evening, I made my way to the Eiffel Tower. Watching the sunset from the Champ de Mars was a surreal experience. The sky turned pink and orange as the Eiffel Tower lit up, sparkling like the jewel of Paris. I sat there, taking it all in the beauty, the romance, the magic of the city.
Paris had a way of making you feel alive. Its streets, art, food, and history wrapped around you like a warm embrace. As I walked back to my hotel that night, I knew this day would stay with me forever ‚Äî a perfect memory of a perfect day in the City of Lights.

Title: Paris may not need defending, but I‚Äôll do it anyway
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Paris is such an interesting city, ask your friends that have been and you‚Äôll likely get one of two responses ‚Äî they either love it or think it‚Äôs the most overrated place ever, dirty and overpriced.
The only other cities that seem to instantly elicit such strong feelings are London and New York, and interestingly all 3 places do have a similar vibe and fast paced beat to life about them. But back to Paris, I feel like it goes through cycles of different representation, both negative and positive, from iconic movies like Amelie, the more recent Midnight in Paris and even more recently, the runaway Netflix hit Emily in Paris.
But with shows like Emily in Paris, while great for more exposure for the city, definitely add to this unrealistic, romanticized view of Paris that a lifelong Parisian probably laughs at, before taking a puff of their cigarette (because seriously the French love to smoke). And here lies the problem, not just in recent years but with decades of Hollywood and French cinema painting this idealistic picture of Paris, it will never live up to the image that people may have in their mind of the place.
My last trip to Paris was in 2022, making it my 2nd time there (I‚Äôm definitely due a return trip) and I did quite enjoy it, knowing the places to go, what I wanted to see and the reputation of the city, for better or worse and I think you need to take Paris with a grain of salt. Is it a filthy, rat ridden city? Well not really, if you go out of the city centre, into the arrondisements that make up the outer Paris suburbs, you‚Äôll find areas are a bit more run down for sure but that‚Äôs same with pretty much any major capital city. In fact, I don‚Äôt find Paris much noticeably dirtier than London, which itself can get a bit grim in parts of greater London as well as notoriously in central London in places like Soho and Kings Cross (which has improved in recent years).
While didn‚Äôt really interact much with Parisians going about their days but when I had to, to ask for directions or advise on travelling, people were to the point and helpful. I‚Äôd say that Parisians are blunt and to the point, a generally French mannerism ‚Äî they‚Äôll tell you what you think, rather than smile at you and tell you a lie as may be more common in places like Britain and the USA. This way of being more straight up with communicating feels foreign and ‚Äòrude‚Äô if you‚Äôre coming from a more openly friendly and passive aggressive country but I still don‚Äôt feel that it‚Äôs inherent rudeness.
The locals may not being winning any competitions for being friendly, but in truth a lot of people in major cities are busy and don‚Äôt necessarily want to stop to talk to a tourist, and if you‚Äôre commuting on a normal week in your city you probably feel the same. The always on, busy life of Parisians did come across to me but this was also because it was summer. And caf√©s everywhere were full with people chatting away and enjoying their time outside and smoking, as the French do.
‚ÄúThe historical feel to the city feels well preserved‚Äù
I will also say that Paris is stunning, the roads around the centre are wide, with very symmetrical streets and the city itself feels like it was designed to deliberately look appealing. From the Parisian buildings with their stand out facades and windows to the trees dotting the streets, everything feels very ordered and clean ‚Äî to me at least. And iconic places like the Louvre just highlight the cities fantastic design. There‚Äôs a simplicity about Paris in the centre and in a word it‚Äôs charming, without massive skyscrapers (which is by design), huge bridges or weirdly shaped buildings designed by quirky architects, there‚Äôs a pleasant uniformity to its skyline and the historical feeling to the city feels well preserved.
Paris and Parisians are actually quite social, it seems to be a thing in Paris/France generally to sit outside in nice weather for lunch, meet at a cafe and for dinner and so on, big meals with big groups seems the norm and it‚Äôs a great way to unwind at the weekend or in the evenings. And another thing I do like about Paris is getting around, the metro is relatively cheap, mostly on time and crowded like any underground subway system, but I do think it competes with the Tube in London for basic efficiency, and with mobile data on all lines.
You can zip around Paris fairly quickly on the Metro if you know your way around it and due to the city centre being not that big either, travelling doesn‚Äôt take too long, and if you‚Äôre feeling adventurous you could see 3 or 4 major sights in a day. Though you should avoid taking Ubers there, unless you plan to spend a fortune.
Paris of course has some a lot of history, and history nerds like myself love to see sights like the Bastille, Sacre Cour, Arc de Triomphe and of course the Eiffel Tower, though these can all be enjoyed by anyone travelling there. But aside from the major sights, there‚Äôs a bustling arts and fashion scene, with some cool art galleries, exhibits and museums dotted around the city. Emily in Paris is a slightly exaggerated depiction of a socialite-adjacent experience in the city but I will say that there does always seems to be something going on.
All in all, Paris is a city with a lot going for it, some people will be lukewarm on it but most will love or hate it, but I feel in the most Paris way possible, I imagine the city shrugging its shoulders and carrying on, remaining one of the most visited cities in the world and for reasons named above. No, it doesn't need mine or anyone's approval but I‚Äôll give it a shoutout anyway, so c‚Äôest la vie!

If you haven‚Äôt already, join us over at The Issue for the Serious Stuff, if you want to understand the future, climate change, the economy, why the world‚Äôs melting down.
Every decade or so, the title of world‚Äôs coolest city changes hands. That‚Äôs sort of a rule, given the currents of culture and the tides of economics.
Today, Paris is the world‚Äôs coolest city. I know, I know, you might protest, and say, Paris has always been cool. Sure, it has. So you can add: again, if you like to that. Way back when, Art Nouveau exploded across its avenues, and of course, you can still take all that in today. Paris has always been many things: the world‚Äôs most literate, sophisticated, enlightened city. But ‚Äúcoolest‚Äù‚Ä¶I mean in‚Ä¶a slightly different way.
In modernish times, the world‚Äôs coolest city has shifted and changed. In the 2000s, it was a toss-up between London and maybe Tokyo. London was the pulsing epicenter of global creativity and culture, from music to literature to film‚Ä¶

I have been living in Paris for two years. As I moved from the end of my studies to the beginning of my career, I was able to meet Parisians of all ages.
I saw the Eiffel Tower every day on my morning bus ride to work. Even if I should have been used to the scenery after living there for so long, I never did. The Eiffel Tower is as beautiful as the day I arrived here. Many foreigners dream of living in the world‚Äôs most visited and romanticized city. On the other hand, so many tourists express their disappointment once they arrive in Paris. In France, Parisians have a bad reputation for being‚Ä¶rude. But what‚Äôs the reality? What‚Äôs the real Paris like? What‚Äôs romantic about the city, and what‚Äôs disappointing?
My first moment of happiness of the day is when I leave the house to go to work. At this time, the sun isn‚Äôt even up yet.
Parisian streetlamps light up the city, and there‚Äôs no one in sight besides me and the garbage collectors who are starting their day of work. Even with the garbage trucks passing by in the early morning, I consider it breathtakingly calm compared to Paris in the daytime‚Ä¶

Paris is the city of the dead.Spirits sprout in spring from tombstone-houses,bland as dogwood blossoms, drifting likepunch-drunk dandelions in their linens.
The limestone here that every street is lined withreminds me of the gaping quarry holesback home, like long forgotten mossy molars.But mostly they remind me of the flower-painted graves on Independence Day.
Now I understand why it‚Äôs so lovely here ‚Äî why folks who worship Antoinette and prayto posters portraying Van Gogh‚Äôs madness wantto gamble off their lives and die in Paris.
One day when some other life flies byto see what wreck we‚Äôve made of this fine Earth,out of all the cities strung acrossthe seven continents, they‚Äôll say that Parishas to be the place we made our stand ‚Äî where we realized it was over, and wherewe buried ourselves, our hopes, and our dreams.And isn‚Äôt that a work of art worth dying for?
Meanwhile, the immortal gar√ßons will smokememorial pillars made of phoenix feathersoutside of Le Caf√© des Mus√©es of Us,looking so distracted, but waiting forsome other sainted tourist to pierce the skyand settle down outside to waste their time.

Content:

‚ÄúParis is more than a beautiful city‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs a story.‚Äù Chills. When our tour guide shared that, in response to why he will never leave Paris, I knew I‚Äôd always remember that sentence. You always hear ‚ÄúParis is the city of love‚Äù ‚Äî but I like his definition better. It truly is a story.
We spent 4 days in Paris + it wasn‚Äôt nearly enough. But it was enough to make me fall in love with the city, + desire to go back for 1 month [at least!] to explore every single district [arrondissement] of Paris. They all have such unique characteristics ‚Äî check out this post on the vibe of the different districts.
If I were to do it over again, I would have mapped out our days to encompass 1‚Äì3 districts every day‚Ä¶ *including* a walking tour [if possible!], so that I would be able to get to know as many districts as possible. There‚Äôs so much to see! I labeled the districts, so it would be easy for you to see what‚Äôs closest to you!
#1] Noir: Hands down the best coffee shop we went to. [8]
#2] Leandres: Loved the vibe of this cafe‚Ä¶ so cute! It was also next to an Acai & You, so you can grab coffee + then an acai bowl! [9]
#3] The Cafeotheque Of Paris: Apparently this coffee shop started the ‚Äúartisan coffee movement‚Äù in Paris. It had so, so many options [one of the only cafes that had iced coffee that we saw]. Grab a coffee to go + the head across the river to Ile Saint-Louis to wander the streets‚Ä¶ such a cute little area! [4]
#4] Le Peloton: Cute coffee shop in my fav neighborhood hat also offers bike rentals, + does bike tours! Close by is a popsicle shop, La Paleteria that I loved. [4]
#5] Cafe De Flore: The most famous French cafe in Paris. We didn‚Äôt go, but wanted to include this as it‚Äôs one of the oldest coffee shops in Paris, well known for being the ‚Äúhang out spot‚Äù for high profile writers, philosophers, + creatives of the time. Visit for the history + fun for people watching. [6] *Other ‚Äúfamous‚Äù Paris spots are Laduree [macroons] + Angelina [hot chocolate]
#6] Partage Cafe: We stopped in here on our way to the Eiffel Tower to grab a quick bite + coffee, + it was the perfect treat. [15]
#7] ‚Ä¶ honestly go into any bakery ; ). Get a croissant, baguette, quiche, or whatever looks good to you! There are so many incredible bakeries ‚Äî on every corner!
For next time: Fresh Bagel + Juice [11], Acai & You [9 + 11], Jozi Cafe [5], Good News Coffee Shop [15], Zia [7], Soul Kitchen [18], Bleu Olive [7], Fringe [3], Komborebi [9], Grainette [9]
#1] Terra: Our favorite meal in Paris! Beautiful space + amazing grilled meal. All of their entrees are for two people to share![3]
#2] Marso & Co: Loved this trendy mediterranean restaurant, + the owner Ludo was *so* nice. So many incredible flavors. [13]
#3] Ya Bayte by Hebe: Lebanese takeaway restaurant. Go here for lunch + then sit on the river! [5]
#4] Veggie Tasty: Vegan bowls + wraps. Great if you are in the area + want something healthy + tasty! [9]
#5] Les Epiciers: Loved this wine + cheese bar! One of the best chaucerte spreads I‚Äôve ever had ‚Äî with *warm* bread! YUM. [3]
For next time: Ev Brochettes + Mezzes [5], Green Deli [5], Balls [11], Today Tomorrow [Vegan, 11], B.BETTER [Vegan, 4], Numero 220 [Veg, 5], L‚Äôen K [5], Sol Semilla [Vegan, 10], Chantoiseau [18], Restaurant CHANG [1]
#1] My new fav french word is fl√¢ner ‚Äî meaning ‚Äúto stroll‚Äù, get lost + wander around for the sake of simply enjoyment. This is essential to do in Paris!
#2] Siam Spa [14]: Loved this thai massage spa! I also really wanted to check out Spa & Hammam [5], it‚Äôs a spa + tea house just for women!
#3] Picnic in all the gardens + parks. Need I say more ; )
#4] Go on biking tour! We absolutely loved our biking tour ‚Äî Paris‚Äô Best Kept Secret. Highly recommend!
#5] Something to note ‚Äî boutique fitness studios are hard to come by + apparently crazy expensive. One of our friends lives in Paris + that‚Äôs what she said!
#1] Eiffel Tower ‚Äî obviously! Make it your first + last stop if you can! Try to see it at night when she sparkles : )
#2] Walk to the highest point of Paris, Saint-Pierre De Montmartre church at sunrise or sunset. On your way, check out the Wall Of Love ‚Äî ‚ÄúI love you‚Äù is written in 250+ languages!
#3] Walk down every single street in Marais. This was my favorite district of Paris‚Ä¶ so trendy, romantic, + tons of amazing boutiques/eats!
#4] Visit the Catacombs ‚Äî get a ticket online prior to going!
#5] If you can make a trip to Versailles +/or Monet‚Äôs Garden‚Ä¶ do it! Both are outside Paris, but absolutely incredible to see [+ relatively close!].
#5] Tours on tours on tours! Google ‚Äúwalking tours‚Äù in Paris based on what you what to see‚Ä¶ you‚Äôll be guaranteed to find plenty! Airbnb Experience also has a lot of fun tours.
#6] See how many of these 50 sites you can visit ; )
We stayed at Hotel Henriette, which was absolutely adorable + had great breakfast ‚Äî but, if was far from our favorite areas]. It was close to the Latin Quarter though! Next time, I‚Äôd want to stay in Marais ‚Äî just because that was my fav district!
#1] Don‚Äôt expect people to speak English. Download a tanslator app on your phone! I used the Google Translate app.
#2] Use public transportation! It‚Äôs so easy, + will take a lot less time than ubers/taxies [+ cheaper!] train.
#3] Check out HiP Paris ‚Äî I loved exploring this blog all about Paris!
#4] Watch Midnight In Paris to get you in the mood prior to going [or during your trip!]. Such a feel good movie! + love seeing all the sites!
#5] Are any of these absolute musts? No! [Okay, other than Eiffel Tower lol that is a must in my book!] This is the first time I‚Äôve probably said this in a wellness guide but it‚Äôs true‚Ä¶ there‚Äôs *so* much to see in Paris + so many incredible spots. It really just depends on what area you are in!
Ugh, Paris is so alive + I LOVE IT! I‚Äôm ready to go back now! Did I miss any of your fav spots? Let me know!
xx
Elisabeth

Title: Busting 5 Misconceptions about Paris
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

This publication is dedicated to learning about the world around us. The topics covered here range from travel and geography to languages and cultures.

--
Listen
Share
Like many people, Paris is somewhere I‚Äôve always wanted to visit. The landmarks, the architecture, the ambiance, and that certain je ne sais quoi. So after returning from my Parisian debut, here I‚Äôve busted 5 common misconceptions about Paris to convince you to finally book that trip in 2025.
Parisians have a rather harsh reputation for being aloof and often rude. But especially for someone practicing her A-Level French skills, the Parisians were kind and accepting. They responded in French as if I too were a Parisian, and kindly clarified in English when I didn‚Äôt understand, before resuming in French as if nothing had happened. For someone who‚Äôs always had a fear about speaking a foreign language among native speakers, it was a huge confidence boost.
And the magic of Paris isn‚Äôt lost on them. At the end of our first day in Paris, the irony was not lost on me that I had not yet seen the iconic symbol due to the thick fog overhanging the city. But, at the edge of the Tuileries my travelling companion noticed that the Eiffel Tower was behind me. I twisted and ran towards it as she emerged from the fog, twinkling elegantly. Nothing prepared me for seeing her for the first time ‚Äî something inside me glowed. Two Parisian men had been walking behind me and stopped to revel in the magic I was experiencing. By the twinkle in their eyes, I knew they too were struck by her beauty.
Paris has a reputation of being dirty and for people urinating on the pavements. Of course, I travelled over New Year so on NYE especially there were some suspicious liquids sliding slowly down the sloped streets, some of which were definitely urine going by their unique odour. But for the most part, in terms of cleanliness, Paris is like any other major city. It was no dirtier than London or New York. And as is always the case, it depends which parts of the city you visit. I was staying in the 18th Arrondissement not far from the Gare du Nord, and there was definitely a lot more rubbish discarded there. But in the touristy areas like Montmartre, the Latin Quarter and the Champs-Elysees, it was noticeably cleaner.
It‚Äôs Paris, one of the most visited cities in the world, of course there will always be tourist traps. We were hungry in Montmartre so decided to eat in the Place du Tertre following a recommendation from a guide. The restaurant was packed, a good sign for any experienced traveller. But even experienced travellers can make mistakes. The moules were flavourless and frites stone cold, even after sending them back. The service was lacklustre: we had to fight to get the meal taken off the bill after sending it back to the kitchen a second time and refusing to eat it.
So lesson learned ‚Äî ask for recommendations from local people, for places that they would eat and tourists would never go. Don‚Äôt be fooled by a packed restaurant, only eat there if the crowd is clearly local.
But one brand that had queues for good reason is Pierre Herm√©. The famous macaron chain is worshipped for good reason. You can‚Äôt go wrong with their signature Mogador; a delightful symphony between milk chocolate and passionfruit. For the brave, try their ever changing seasonal macarons such as eglatine, fig and foie gras or honey and fir pepper.
As a Brit used to the ‚Äòtap in tap out‚Äô system of the London Underground, the Paris Metro seemed bureaucratic. But once you get your head around the tickets, it‚Äôs super simple.
Instead of just tapping your bank card you need a Navigo Pass. Of course there are still packs of regular tickets, but to save fishing around in your pocket and inevitably losing one, the Navigo Pass is the easiest option.
Whether you choose the physical version (think London Oyster Card) available for 2 euros at most metro stations, or the electronic one loaded into your apple wallet, it works like a ticket holding device. You buy tickets using the Navigo or BonjourRATP apps, and they automatically load onto your card. I was in Paris for 4 days and my pack of 10 tickets (cheaper than buying individually) lasted me perfectly.
Navigating any metro system is an art, but going from A to B in the Paris metro is an easy art to learn. There is no northbound, southbound nonsense and each platform only serves one direction and final destination: no confusing branching off. Helpfully, on the newer trains, the maps have LED dots which easily show where the train is, saving the hassle of scanning the map multiple times just to find that you‚Äôve missed your stop.
As well as the traditional metro system, in Paris there are also RER trains which serve the suburbs. For travellers, they are a relatively cheap and easy option to get from the Paris Airports, notable Orly and CDG. It‚Äôs important to note that you need a separate ticket for these trains which need to go on a separate Navigo Pass. Moreover, only one such ticket can be loaded onto the pass at once ‚Äî you can‚Äôt scan for multiple people!
Going up the Eiffel Tower: the non-negotiable. Yet I beg to differ. Sure, the panoramas from the top are nice, but the iconic skyline is missing ‚Äî why, because you‚Äôre in it! Instead, go to Trocadero at dusk to see the majestic iron and steel structure twinkling for the first 5 minutes of every hour.
Of course the Louvre is a must. But with 16km of galleries, you‚Äôre not going to see everything in a lifetime, let alone a day. Make sure you get an early time slot, and arrive at least 40 minutes before hand to make sure you get inside on time. In terms of what to see, the Mona Lisa is a must, but brace yourself for the crowd. Other pieces of note are the Venus De Milo, Liberty Leading the People (right around the corner from the Mona Lisa) and the French Crown Jewels.
Notre Dame, only recently opened on the 8th December 2024 after the devastating fire in 2019 is also a must see. The craftmanship that has gone into rebuilding the cathedral is just breath taking. But again arrive early. We arrived at 10am with only a short wait, but by 11am the queue snaked around the whole square outside.

Title: An American Planner in Paris (and Copenhagen and Barcelona and‚Ä¶)
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Follow publication
Sharing our collective experience in creating active, healthy communities.
Follow publication
--
Listen
Share
by Ryan Johnson, Planner, Alta Planning + Design
I recently returned from a two-week trip to Europe, and I obviously spent a lot of time observing pedestrian and bicycle culture and infrastructure. Rather than simply envy our neighbors across the pond for their walkable and bike-friendly cities and believe that we Yanks could never match their high active transportation mode shares, I was constantly thinking how I could translate my experiences and observations into on-the-ground change here in the U.S. I also realized that we have some progressive transportation infrastructure on our own soil to be proud of.
We first made the pilgrimage to Copenhagen ‚Äî the Promised Land for many Americans in the bicycle/pedestrian profession‚Ä¶ And it lived up to the hype! The comprehensive network of physically separated cycle tracks was incredible and refreshing, of course, but I was more impressed by how easy it was to walk around the city. Several of the major streets were actually pedestrianized, with motor vehicles prohibited. While some examples of this concept exist in the U.S. ‚Äî including Santa Monica‚Äôs Third Street Promenade ‚Äî they feel rather manufactured and not organic.
Even with the dreary weather, we were sad to leave the playground of Copenhagen. But Paris was awaiting us! I had a mental image of Paris as the small, charming town along the river that is shown in films and travel magazines. However, I was immediately made aware of the city‚Äôs sprawling size and wide, auto-clogged boulevards. In a way, I was reminded of my hometown of Los Angeles, except that Paris‚Äôs Metro system blankets the region. In a flip from my experience in Copenhagen, I had gone to Paris expecting a walker‚Äôs paradise, but instead saw a budding cycling haven. The city had already squeezed cycle tracks along many of the major boulevards, and the famous V√©lib‚Äô public bicycles were as common a sight as sidewalk caf√©s and baguettes. The bicycle network appears set up to help Parisians close the ‚Äúfirst mile/last mile gap‚Äù that often exists in a trip using public transit. I would love to see Los Angeles and other U.S. cities with mass transit networks pursue a similar course.
Finally, we ended our vacation by hanging out in the pedestrian paradises that are old Spanish cities. Barcelona, our first stop, was seemingly built to make walking a pleasurable experience, with interesting side streets, promenades, and commercial districts around every corner. Barcelona and other Spanish cities like Granada and Toledo also make good use of shared streets, or woonerfs, to make streets safe in constrained neighborhoods.
Finally, the many plazas and parklets in Spain‚Äôs cities were a never-ending source of resting space and excellent people watching.
Although very different in many ways, Los Angeles can and should follow the lead of European cities by creating safe and pleasurable spaces for people to walk or bike and be outside enjoying our near-perfect weather. And I‚Äôm proud to say that the LA region is beginning to seriously take on that mission. Both Long Beach and Temple City now have cycle tracks. LA County Metro is planning a regional bike share program. And through the LA Department of Transportation‚Äôs People St. program, several plazas and parklets have been created or are planned for previously underused road space. I‚Äôm excited that our leaders are beginning to push for progressive changes to restore some balance to how we move around our own cities.

Paris is, perhaps, the most beautiful city in the world. This might seem almost too obvious to write given how widely acknowledged and thoroughly documented its beauty is. On one hand, that‚Äôs fair. It‚Äôs a magnificent city that enjoys near unanimous admiration from around the globe. More than 44 million people visited Paris in 2022, with nearly 20 million of those tourists coming from outside of France. Depending on what data you look at, this would be good for the 3rd or 4th most visited city in the world by international tourists. For those who aren‚Äôt able to make the journey to Paris, images of the city are seared into the minds of most people from an early age, serving as the de facto model of what a wonderful city should look like. Its bistros, baked goods, and culture have been exported world wide.
But you‚Äôll have to excuse my writing out the obvious, and walking down already well trodden paths to explain the beauty of Paris, as I believe it extends far beyond what we‚Äôve been told of it, or shown. I‚Äôd like to argue that Paris isn‚Äôt properly appreciated for all that it is, and I doubt that it ever could be. You might say this is just excitement talking, and that‚Äôs partly true ‚Äî I‚Äôm still glowing from my recent quick trip‚Ä¶

Title: Paris Neighborhood Guide: the 11th Arrondissement
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Helping You Adapt to Life in France

--
Listen
Share
When most tourists visit Paris, places like the Eiffel Tower, the Louvre, and the Moulin Rouge are often on the itinerary. There‚Äôs nothing wrong with that ‚Äî especially if it‚Äôs your first time in the City of Light. But, those of us who live here know that there is so much more to discover.
Many of those places can be found in one neighborhood in particular: the 11th arrondissement. Located to the east of the Seine River, it‚Äôs nestled between the Place de la Bastille, P√®re Lachaise, Belleville, and Place de la Nation. Lots of locals hang out in the 11th (read: good restaurants, few tourists) as opposed to, say, the 1st. The crowds are young, cool, and possess an actual je ne sais quoi that everyone‚Äôs always going on about.
Known amongst Parisians for its nightlife, concert venues, and restaurants, there is much to see and do in the onzi√®me.
There are small quartiers (quarters) within every arrondissement in Paris. Don‚Äôt get confused just yet ‚Äî it‚Äôs similar to the American practice of designating separate villages within certain cities or towns.
Let‚Äôs begin with the most well-known quarter of the 11th arrondissement: Bastille. Home to the Place de la Bastille, a square that once held the famous Bastille prison. Said prison was stormed on July 14, 1789, an event that would mark the official beginning of the 18th-century French Revolution, a topic that will get my fellow TAIP author Stephen going, if you‚Äôre up for a coffee or a whiskey.
Today there is a monument called the Colonne de Juillet in the center of the place. After you‚Äôve admired it up close, turn to see the Op√©ra Bastille, but know that the opera house is technically in the 12th arrondissement.
From there I recommend heading to the March√© Bastille if it‚Äôs a Thursday or a Sunday ‚Äî the market is open from 7am on both days. Take a shortcut through the picturesque cour Damoye to head to the rue de la Roquette. Continue to wander the small, winding cobblestone roads until you get lost.
When I was an au pair, Oberkampf was the place to go out. Drinks and food are cheap, there are a ton of young people, and there are several venues for live music. If that sounds like your vibe, head to the rue Oberkampf to start.
Keep your eyes peeled for street art as there is plenty of that in the area. The Bataclan is amazing for live shows ‚Äî you likely recognize the name as it was unfortunately the target of a terrorist attack in 2015. Don‚Äôt let that keep you from buying tickets for a show. There is now a small memorial out front that‚Äôs dedicated to those who were lost if you‚Äôd like to pay your respects before you go inside.
My favorite Italian restaurant of all time is located in the Oberkampf area. It‚Äôs unassuming and very easy to miss and you must make a reservation if you hope to get in. No, it‚Äôs not the ultra-Instagram-famous Ober Mamma. It‚Äôs called L‚ÄôOsteria Dell‚ÄôAnima and the quality of the meals I‚Äôve enjoyed there rivals actual Italian food I‚Äôve eaten in Italy. Yes, it‚Äôs that good.
If you do want to go out and hit the town running, head to Oberkampf any time after 9pm and you‚Äôll find students, au pairs, and other young people bar hopping. Follow the sound of laughter and the smell of cheap beer ‚Äî you‚Äôre in the right place.
Charonne holds a special place in my heart. I spent a lot of time there with my now-husband when we first got together, as in a former life I frequently cleaned an Airbnb property there. It‚Äôs quaint, lively, and full of terraces that are perfect for people-watching.
It‚Äôs another Parisian neighborhood that‚Äôs made up mostly of locals. Duke, a caf√© on the corner of rue de Charonne and Boulevard Voltaire, is located just outside the Charonne metro station and is a great option for coffee.
Le Palais de la Femme further down the street is a homeless shelter for women that often hosts large vintage sales and other indoor markets to raise money. Waly Fay on rue Godefroy Cavaignac is one of my favorite places for West African food in the city. Septime La Cave, just a few minutes away on rue Basfroi, is my go-to wine bar in the 11th. If you want to get fancy, you can go to the Michelin-starred Septime (same owners, different location), but keep in mind reservations are weeks out, so you can‚Äôt just rock up and hope to get a table.
On the other side of the Boulevard Voltaire there‚Äôs Comets, a caf√© and vinyl store that I‚Äôve spent many a rainy afternoon in. Bar Outland, on a small side street, specializes in beer on tap and natural wines ‚Äî it‚Äôs a fun place for a first date.
When you‚Äôre done, continue to stroll down rue de Charonne until you reach the P√®re Lachaise, and officially cross the border into the 20th arrondissement, which is also full of sites to see. But, that‚Äôs another neighborhood for another blog article.

Some months ago, at the height of the transportation strikes, several well-meaning acquaintances messaged me with concern or asked on behalf of friends who were considering travel plans whether it was indeed safe to visit Paris.
These people didn‚Äôt need a speech from me, I thought. My safest answer was, ‚ÄúYes; don‚Äôt believe everything you hear from the mainstream media, whose business is built on chaos.‚Äù
But by the third time I was asked, I blurted out, ‚ÄúThe people asking this live in the country which must be the most dangerous one for children in the entire developed world.‚Äù My fellow Americans, blissfully self-absorbed and aloof from the world, wonder if it‚Äôs safe to travel to Paris, which was dealing with strikes and riots (nothing new, something I‚Äôve experienced regularly since moving to France). Yet in America, children are regularly gunned down in classrooms and people are choked to death on subways or on routine traffic stops. Those things don‚Äôt happen in France.
My unsafe answer concluded, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs certainly safer to visit France than an American elementary school.‚Äù
Do the trite words of ‚ÄúThoughts and prayers,‚Äù which automatically and thoughtlessly escape the lips of many of my fellow countrymen after every tragedy simultaneously obliterate their common sense to such a degree that they consider the glossy‚Ä¶
