Title: Travel Tips and Guide: Exploring the Wonders of Paris
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Paris! The city of lights, love, and a maze of delectable experiences just waiting to be discovered It‚Äôs a place where every cobblestone street tells a story of history, every caf√© smells like freshly brewed coffee, and every corner reveals an architectural marvel that takes your breath away. This is a living, breathing work of art, not just a city. But don‚Äôt get carried away by Paris‚Äô poetic allure just yet. We‚Äôre all here for a reason, aren‚Äôt we?
My fellow globetrotters, the goal of this blog post is to provide you with the best tips and tricks for exploring Paris like a seasoned traveler. Not the kind that just takes a selfie with the Eiffel Tower and leaves, but the kind that delves deep into the city‚Äôs soul, savors its flavors, and emerges with a heart full of stories.
‚ÄúWhy should I trust this guide?‚Äù you may be wondering. So, please allow me to introduce myself. I‚Äôm your friendly neighborhood world traveler, a culture connoisseur, a gastronome of global cuisines, and an adventurer who‚Äôs walked on every continent. I‚Äôve had tea with Bedouins in the Sahara, tango danced in Buenos Aires, and hiked the Great Wall of China. But no matter where I go, I am always drawn back to Paris.
So strap in, because we‚Äôre about to take a virtual stroll through the streets of Paris. We‚Äôll navigate the city‚Äôs intricate metro system, discover hidden gems tucked away in charming neighborhoods, savor the finest French cuisine, and even pick up a few etiquette tips. You‚Äôll be ready to pack your bags and book your next flight to Paris by the end of this guide.
But keep in mind that this isn‚Äôt just about checking off items on a tourist checklist. It‚Äôs all about immersing yourself in the Parisian way of life, getting to know the city‚Äôs rhythm, and making memories to last a lifetime. So, are you ready to discover Paris‚Äôs wonders? Let‚Äôs get this party started!
Oh, the trip to Paris! It‚Äôs the first step in your epic journey, and it‚Äôs just as important as the destination. There are now several ways to get to the city of lights, each with its own unique charm and quirks. Let‚Äôs get into the specifics, shall we?
Flights are the most common mode of international transportation. Paris has two major airports: Charles de Gaulle, a bustling hub that welcomes flights from all over the world, and Orly, a quieter sibling that‚Äôs popular with European travelers. Here‚Äôs a pro tip from a seasoned traveler: If you‚Äôre flying from outside Europe, you‚Äôll most likely land at Charles de Gaulle. However, if you need to connect within Europe, try to book it through Orly. It‚Äôs smaller, less crowded, and has a charm that larger airports frequently lack.
For those traveling within Europe, trains are the preferred mode of transportation. The French rail network is an engineering marvel, connecting Paris to major cities throughout the continent. Isn‚Äôt there something magical about sipping a cup of coffee while watching the French countryside fly by? If you‚Äôre in a hurry, take the TGV, France‚Äôs high-speed train, and you‚Äôll be in Paris in no time.
Let us now discuss transactions. The golden rule of travel is to plan ahead. The earlier you book, the better the bargains. But here‚Äôs a secret: the best deals are sometimes found at the most unexpected times. Late-night flights, mid-week trains, and off-season seasons are your allies. Accept them, and your bank account will thank you.
Finally, keep in mind to check multiple booking platforms. Each has its own set of deals and discounts, and a little digging can go a long way. Skyscanner and Kayak are excellent flight search engines, while Trainline and SNCF are excellent train search engines.
That‚Äôs all there is to it. The journey to Paris, explained Remember that whether you choose to fly through the clouds or race across the countryside, the journey is just as important as the destination. After all, as the saying goes, a trip to Paris is always a good idea!
The sweet quandary of deciding where to hang your hat in Paris The city is teeming with lodgings of all kinds, each offering a distinct slice of Parisian life. But don‚Äôt worry, I‚Äôm here to help you navigate the maze of Parisian accommodations, from the grandest hotels to the coziest apartments.
Let‚Äôs start with the best of the best: the hotels. Some of the world‚Äôs most luxurious hotels can be found in Paris. Consider this: You‚Äôre relaxing in a luxurious suite with a view of the Seine, sipping champagne as the Eiffel Tower twinkles in the distance. Doesn‚Äôt it sound lovely? That is the allure of Parisian hotels. They are more than just places to sleep; they are experiences in and of themselves. The Ritz, the George V, and the Shangri-La are all names synonymous with luxury and opulence. But keep in mind that luxury comes at a cost. If you‚Äôre willing to splurge, these hotels provide an experience that is well worth the money.
But what if you‚Äôre looking for something a little less expensive? Enter hostels and low-cost hotels. These are the unsung heroes of Paris lodging. They may not provide champagne or river views, but they do provide something far more valuable: the opportunity to meet other travelers. Parisian hostels are known for their lively atmospheres and welcoming staff. They are places where you can share travel stories over a communal dinner, explore the city with new friends, and live like a local. What‚Äôs more, what‚Äôs the best part? They‚Äôre also inexpensive.
Apartments are now the way to go if you value privacy and want to live like a true Parisian. Paris is full of charming apartments that you can rent for your stay. Imagine waking up in your own Parisian apartment, brewing a cup of coffee in the kitchen, and watching the city come to life from your balcony. It‚Äôs a different kind of luxury, allowing you to explore the city on your own terms.
Let us now discuss location. Paris is divided into 20 districts, or arrondissements, each with its own distinct personality. The city‚Äôs heart, the 1st arrondissement, is home to iconic landmarks such as the Louvre and the Tuileries Garden. This is the place to be if you want to be right in the middle of things. If you prefer a quieter, more local atmosphere, head to the outer arrondissements. For example, the 20th arrondissement is known for its bohemian vibe and vibrant street art.
The price range is entirely dependent on what you‚Äôre looking for. A night in a luxury hotel can cost several hundred euros, whereas a bed in a hostel dorm can cost as little as 20 euros. Apartments fall somewhere in the middle, with prices varying according to size and location. My recommendation? Make and stick to a budget. In Paris, there is accommodation for every budget; you just need to find the one that is right for you.
So, my fellow travelers, there you have it. The decoded world of Parisian lodging Whether you choose to live in luxury, embrace the communal spirit of hostels, or appreciate the privacy of an apartment, keep in mind that your lodging is more than just a place to sleep. It‚Äôs your Parisian home, where you‚Äôll unwind after a day of exploring, share meals with new friends, and fantasize about the adventures that await. If you make the right choice, your Parisian home will become a treasured part of your travel memories.
Getting around Paris, my friends, is an adventure in and of itself. The city‚Äôs public transportation system is intricately woven and connects every corner of the city, much like a giant spider web. It‚Äôs an architectural marvel, a testament to the city‚Äôs dedication to accessibility, and, if I may add, a joy to use.
Let us begin with the Metro, the backbone of Parisian public transportation. The Paris Metro is more than just a transportation system; it‚Äôs a part of the city‚Äôs identity, with its unmistakable Art Nouveau entrances and labyrinthine network of tunnels. It‚Äôs quick, efficient, and surprisingly simple to use once you get the hang of it. Each line is identified by a number and a color, with the name of the last station on the line indicating the direction of travel. So get a map, plan your route, and you‚Äôll be zipping around town like a local in no time.
Then there are buses. While the Metro transports you underground, buses allow you to explore the city on the ground floor. They are slower than the Metro, but they provide a scenic route through the city. They‚Äôre also an excellent way to discover lesser-known neighborhoods and landmarks. Just remember to double-check the bus routes and schedules before boarding.
Then there are the bicycles. With dedicated bike lanes and bike-sharing programs like V√©lib‚Äô, Paris is a bike-friendly city. Cycling through the city with the wind in your hair and the cityscape unfolding around you is incredibly liberating. It‚Äôs an experience I wholeheartedly recommend.
Now, for some pointers on how to get around efficiently, Get a Navigo card first. It is a reloadable card that can be used on the Metro, buses, and some V√©lib‚Äô stations. It will save you the trouble of purchasing tickets each time you travel. Second, if possible, avoid rush hour. During peak hours, the Metro and buses can become congested, so plan your journey accordingly. Finally, don‚Äôt be afraid to take a walk. Paris is a walkable city, and it is sometimes the best way to explore it.
That‚Äôs all there is to it. The ins and outs of getting around Paris Whether you travel by Metro, bus, bike, or on your own two feet, keep in mind that the journey is just as important as the destination. So, take your time, take in the sights, and let the city lead the way.
Paris, the city of love and lights, is a treasure trove of iconic attractions that have captivated travelers‚Äô hearts for centuries. Each monument, each landmark, tells a story ‚Äî a quintessentially Parisian story of history, art, and culture. Let‚Äôs take a tour of these must-see attractions, shall we?
The Eiffel Tower, or La Dame de Fer (The Iron Lady), as the French call it, is the symbol of Paris. With a height of 330 meters, this iron lattice tower provides a breathtaking panoramic view of the city. The Eiffel Tower is a sight to behold at any time of day, whether you choose to climb to the top or admire it from the ground. But there‚Äôs something magical about seeing it twinkle against the night sky, in my opinion.
The Louvre, the world‚Äôs largest art museum and a historic monument in Paris, is next on our list. It‚Äôs an art and history treasure trove, housing thousands of works from all over the world, including the enigmatic Mona Lisa. Walking through the Louvre is a journey through the annals of human civilization that is both enlightening and awe-inspiring.
The Notre-Dame Cathedral stands on an island in the Seine, not far from the Louvre. This French Gothic architectural masterpiece bears witness to the city‚Äôs rich religious history. Its intricate facades, towering spires, and breathtaking stained glass windows are breathtaking. And if you don‚Äôt mind a bit of a climb, the view from the top is well worth it.
Let us now discuss how to make the most of your visit to these top attractions. The key is to plan ahead. These attractions are popular for a reason, and they can become congested, particularly during peak tourist season. So, here are a few pointers to help you avoid the crowds and have a good time during your visit.
To begin, go early in the morning or late in the afternoon when there are fewer people. You‚Äôll not only avoid the crowds, but you‚Äôll also get to see these sights in a new light. Consider watching the sunrise from the top of the Eiffel Tower or admiring the Louvre‚Äôs glass pyramid as the sun sets. Doesn‚Äôt it sound lovely?
Second, consider purchasing tickets ahead of time. Many of these attractions provide online ticketing, which can save you a significant amount of time. Some even sell ‚Äúskip-the-line‚Äù tickets that allow you to avoid the long lines.
Finally, take your time. These attractions are full of detail and history, and rushing through them would be a waste of time. Take your time, take in the details, and let the beauty of these sights wash over you.
So, fellow travelers, these are the top Paris attractions. They‚Äôre more than just sights to see; they‚Äôre experiences to cherish and memories to create. So pack your bags, put on your walking shoes, and prepare to discover the wonders of Paris. Best wishes!
Paris, the City of Lights, is a treasure trove of previously unknown treasures. Aside from the iconic Eiffel Tower and the magnificence of the Louvre, there is a world of lesser-known attractions that offer a truly unique and authentic Parisian experience. Let‚Äôs go on an off-the-beaten-path adventure, shall we?
The P√®re Lachaise Cemetery is in the 20th arrondissement of Paris. You might be wondering right now, ‚ÄúIs it a graveyard? Really?‚Äù But believe me when I say this isn‚Äôt your average cemetery. It‚Äôs a peaceful haven in the heart of the city, where history and peace coexist. Here, you can pay your respects to famous people such as Oscar Wilde and Edith Piaf while also getting lost in the maze of cobblestone paths and ancient tombs.
Next, let‚Äôs visit the city‚Äôs thriving street art scene in the 13th arrondissement. Local and international artists turn the streets into an open-air museum by painting on them. Don‚Äôt miss the BnF Fran√ßois-Mitterrand, which features stunning murals on its towering walls.
If you enjoy literature, go to Shakespeare and Company in the 5th arrondissement. This charming bookstore has been a haven for writers and book lovers since the 1950s. Browse the book shelves, go to a reading, or simply enjoy the literary atmosphere.
How do you go about discovering these buried treasures? The key is to keep an open mind and a keen eye. Don‚Äôt be afraid to deviate from the tourist trail and explore the city‚Äôs lesser-known neighborhoods. Insider information is best obtained from locals. Use social media and travel blogs to find recommendations. Above all, be open to the element of surprise. Some of the most fascinating discoveries occur when you least expect them.
Remember that finding these hidden treasures isn‚Äôt about crossing things off a list. It‚Äôs about being present in the moment, whether it‚Äôs the peaceful solitude of a cemetery, the vibrant colors of street art, or the cozy comfort of a bookstore. Allow the city to reveal its secrets to you as you take your time and enjoy the moment.
So, fellow travelers, are you ready to unearth Paris‚Äôs hidden treasures? The city awaits you, full of surprises and stories to discover. Have a great time exploring!
Paris, the world‚Äôs gastronomic capital, is a food and drink lover‚Äôs paradise. The city‚Äôs culinary scene is a delectable symphony of flavors that is as diverse as it is delicious. French cuisine is a culinary journey that will tantalize your taste buds, from the humble baguette to the decadent escargot.
Let‚Äôs start with the fundamentals, the foundation of French cuisine: bread. Bread is more than just food in Paris; it‚Äôs a way of life. The baguette, with its golden crust and soft interior, is a Parisian household staple. Combine it with some cheese for a simple yet satisfying meal. Not to mention the croissant, a buttery, flaky delight that goes perfectly with a cup of coffee.
When it comes to coffee, Parisians take it seriously. Coffee is an essential part of Parisian culture, whether it‚Äôs a quick espresso at the counter or a leisurely caf√© cr√®me at a sidewalk caf√©. A hot chocolate at Angelina is also a must for those with a sweet tooth. It‚Äôs a chocolate lover‚Äôs dream come true ‚Äî thick, creamy, and decadently rich.
Let us now explore the world of French cuisine. Escargot, foie gras, and coq au vin are just a few of the dishes that have put French cuisine on the map around the world. But French cuisine is more than just these classics. Each region and city has its own specialty. The steak-frites, a simple dish of steak and fries, is a testament to the culinary philosophy of Paris: quality ingredients cooked to perfection.
There‚Äôs also the wine. France is one of the world‚Äôs largest wine producers, and Paris is the ideal location to sample the country‚Äôs extensive wine selection. There is a wine for every palate, from the full-bodied reds of Bordeaux to the crisp whites of the Loire Valley.
So, where should you eat and drink in Paris? The city is teeming with cafes, restaurants, and bars, each with their own distinct charm and personality. Caf√© de Flore in Saint-Germain-des-Pr√©s offers a classic Parisian caf√© experience. If you‚Äôre looking for a gourmet meal, Le Comptoir du Relais has a delectable menu of French classics. A visit to Le Baron Rouge wine bar is also recommended for wine enthusiasts.
But keep in mind that the best culinary experiences are frequently found in the most unexpected places. That little bakery might just have the best baguette you‚Äôve ever had. That tiny bistro around the corner may have the best coq au vin. So don‚Äôt be afraid to venture out and try new things.
Finally, some words of wisdom. The experience of French cuisine is more than just the food and drink. It‚Äôs about the pleasure of sharing a meal, the art of conversation, and the pleasure of savoring each bite. So, when you‚Äôre in Paris, eat like a local. Take your time, enjoy the food, and let the culinary magic of the city enchant you.
Are you ready to embark on a culinary adventure in Paris, my fellow travelers? The city‚Äôs cafes, restaurants, and bars are waiting to tempt your taste buds and fill your heart with gastronomic delight.
When you enter Paris, you are not simply entering a city; you are entering a rich tapestry of culture and tradition that has been woven over centuries. The French, particularly Parisians, are known for their strict sense of etiquette and customs. Understanding these nuances will enhance your experience and enable you to navigate the city like a local.
Let us begin with greetings. The French are formal in their interactions, and it is customary to greet people with ‚ÄúBonjour‚Äù (Good day) during the day or ‚ÄúBonsoir‚Äù (Good evening) at night. A firm handshake is the norm when meeting someone for the first time. However, it is customary among friends to exchange a kiss on both cheeks, a practice known as ‚Äúla bise.‚Äù
Let‚Äôs move on to dining etiquette. The French take their food seriously, and mealtimes are regarded as a time to unwind and socialize. Before beginning a meal, it is customary to say ‚ÄúBon app√©tit.‚Äù Remember to keep your hands (but not your elbows) on the table and wait for the host to begin eating or toasting before you do. And, of course, take your time eating; rushing through a meal is considered impolite.
Another important aspect of French culture is language. While many Parisians speak English, they appreciate it when visitors attempt to communicate in French. A few simple phrases can go a long way toward demonstrating respect for the local culture. And if you have any questions, don‚Äôt be afraid to ask. The French are proud of their culture and enjoy sharing it with others.
Parisians are known for their fashion sense when it comes to dressing. They dress more formally than residents of many other cities. While there is no strict dress code, it is best to dress neatly and modestly when visiting churches or other religious sites.
Finally, in France, punctuality is viewed differently. While being a few minutes late is usually not a big deal, it‚Äôs polite to call and notify someone if you‚Äôre going to be late.
Here are some suggestions for how to respect the local culture. First, pay attention. Take note of how the locals act and follow their example. Second, be courteous. Recognize the importance of customs and traditions to the French and respect them, even if they differ from your own. Third, keep an open mind. Accept the differences and relish the opportunity to learn about a new culture.
Remember that traveling is more than just seeing new places; it is also about experiencing new cultures. You‚Äôre not just being a responsible traveler when you understand and respect French customs and etiquette; you‚Äôre immersing yourself in the French way of life. And who knows what else? You might fall in love with the Parisian way of life, just like I did.
As you prepare to explore the wonders of Paris, remember to bring not only your suitcase but also your sense of etiquette. Respect the local culture, embrace the Parisian way of life, and allow the city of lights to warmly welcome you. Best wishes!
To ensure a safe and enjoyable visit to Paris, as with any major city, a certain level of awareness and precaution is required. While the city is generally safe, it is always a good idea to be prepared and informed about potential hazards and how to deal with them.
Pickpocketing is a common problem for travelers, especially in crowded tourist areas and on public transportation. Always keep an eye on your belongings to avoid becoming a victim of such incidents. Use bags that close securely and stay in your line of sight. Displaying expensive items, such as jewelry or high-end electronics, may draw unwanted attention.
Another piece of advice is to exercise caution when exploring the city at night. While Paris is famous for its vibrant nightlife, some areas can be dangerous after dark. Avoid walking alone in unfamiliar areas and stick to well-lit, busy streets. Using a reputable taxi service or rideshare app for late-night transportation can be a safer option.
It is critical to know who to contact in the event of an emergency. In France, the general emergency number is 112, which can be dialed for any type of emergency. You can dial 15 for medical emergencies only. The number to dial if you need the police is 17. It‚Äôs a good idea to save these phone numbers before your trip.
Finally, keep a physical and digital copy of all important documents, such as your passport and travel insurance. In the event of loss or theft, having these copies on hand can speed up the replacement process.
Remember that safety does not happen by chance. It is the result of careful planning and sound decision-making. So, as you take in the sights and sounds of Paris, keep these safety precautions in mind. They‚Äôll make sure your memories of the city are nothing but positive.
As we conclude this guide, take a moment to reflect on the journey we‚Äôve taken together. We‚Äôve waded through the intricate web of Parisian public transportation, discovered hidden gems tucked away in charming neighborhoods, savored the flavors of French cuisine, and immersed ourselves in the city‚Äôs rich culture and etiquette. We‚Äôve learned how to make the most of our Parisian adventure by exploring the city from the ground up, from the iconic Eiffel Tower to the bustling local cafes.
Paris is a city that promises an unforgettable experience with its blend of history, culture, and modernity. It‚Äôs a city that begs you to explore, discover, taste, and fall in love with it. So, dear travelers, I urge you to take the leap of faith. Pack your belongings, put on your walking shoes, and allow Paris to sweep you off your feet.
Here are some additional resources to help you on your journey: The Paris Tourist Office‚Äôs official website (www.parisinfo.com) is a wealth of information, ranging from upcoming events to practical advice. The RATP website and app for public transportation provide real-time updates and route planning services. For foodies, the Michelin Guide is your go-to guide for the best dining experiences in town.
And, of course, this is only the beginning. Paris is a city that is always changing, and there is always something new to discover. So, dear readers, I invite you to share your own advice and experiences. Your contributions and stories are what make this guide truly comprehensive.
If you‚Äôve got the travel bug and aren‚Äôt sure where to go next, how about Rome? With its ancient ruins, stunning architecture, and delectable cuisine, the Eternal City rivals Paris for a one-of-a-kind experience. It‚Äôs a city that, like Paris, combines the old and the new in a distinctively unique harmony.
https://medium.com/@lonestarglitztravel/when-in-rome-getting-lost-and-found-in-the-eternal-city-8f86e2807f7
So there you have it: a comprehensive guide to discovering Paris‚Äôs wonders. But keep in mind that the true magic of travel is found not in the destination but in the journey. It‚Äôs in the excitement of stepping off a plane in a new city, the delight of trying a new dish, the awe of standing in front of a historical monument, and the connections you make along the way. So go forth and explore, because the world is a book, and those who do not travel only read a page. Best wishes!

Title: A Waiter in Paris ‚Äî Book walk and ‚Äòin conversation‚Äô with Edward Chisholm

Listen
Share
On a sunny Spring afternoon, UCL Postgrad Urbanists went on a book walk through Regent‚Äôs Park discussing Edward Chisholm‚Äôs A Waiter in Paris (2021).
We were joined by PhD researchers across UCL departments including Geography, The Bartlett School of Architecture, Institute of Education, and Engineering. In this piece, Postgrad Urbanists Sidra Ahmed (PhD, UCL Geography) and Yichang Sun (PhD, UCL The Bartlett School of Architecture) share reflections from the walk and a post-walk Q&A we had with the author Edward Chisholm.
The Book Walk
A Waiter in Paris is Chisholm‚Äôs memoir of his seven years in Paris. It opens with Chisholm as an English graduate in Paris with little to no prospects and hardly any money, but the guts to wait it out and figure out what Paris has in store for him. The book is an underdog narrative that follows an English waiter, (or rather, ‚Äòwaiter-in-waiting‚Äô who starts out as a restaurant runner), experiencing Paris via the stage of the fictional ‚ÄòLe Bistrot de La Seine‚Äô restaurant and its backstage gang of waiters, cooks, and management.
We‚Äôre taken on Chisholm‚Äôs story from passing as a waiter barely speaking French, navigating the kitchen politics of Le Bistrot de La Seine, to yes, becoming a waiter. Through Chisholm‚Äôs observations, we encounter a Paris that is dynamic, multifaceted, and deeply human. Below we share a few highlights from our discussion during the walk.
We opened the book walk by asking everyone to share moments in the book which were amusing. Our favourites include a moment when Chisholm, as a runner at that time, figures out how to manipulate the waiter politics to finally earn tips in the chapter ‚ÄòThe Rise of the Runner‚Äô and avenge the stealing of his tips from a previous shift:
‚ÄúThe role of the runner, it turns out, is a corrupt one. This is my source of prestige, I realize. If the waiters are bounty hunters, constantly chasing tips, then the runner is a mercenary, a gun for hire, His allegiances are to no one, only the person who pays him best. The waiters know that, if the runner is working with them, then he‚Äôs not working with anyone else.
At the end of the evening there‚Äôs no need to ask the waiters for the three euros. They all give more. It‚Äôs like protection money.
I‚Äôve noticed a change in the others, too: they see me as an equal, as one of them ‚Äî no longer a plaything. That‚Äôs what they were waiting for, perhaps, to see if I had enough grit to stick it out.‚Äù
‚Äî A Waiter in Paris (2021: pp.132‚Äì133)
Another encounter involves the procuring, preparing and delivery of olives for a special group of diners ‚Äî only Chisholm, his fellow waiter, and the reader know the journey those olives took. We also mused on ‚Äòlive where the tomatoes are good‚Äô, a piece of layered life advice fellow waiter Salvatore gives Chisholm. Sidenote, we did end up discussing where the tomatoes are actually good ‚Äî Croatia and Italy were two suggestions.
As we carried and referenced our copies of the book during the walk, we also interrogated the title itself. A Waiter in Paris activates a social role coupled with one‚Äôs urban imaginations of a city such as Paris; it makes you want to fill in the story. Other book titles and song names that made us feel the same came to mind, especially those from the perspective of the outsider. Sting‚Äôs single Englishman in New York. Mark Vanhoenacker‚Äôs Imagine a City: A Pilot Sees the World (2022). We were even reminded of a past Q&A we had with Geographer and Author Giada Peterle who described ‚Äòurban spaces as narrative archives‚Äô. A Waiter in Paris is one such archive of life in Paris activated by Chisholm‚Äôs writing:
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not really my story; I was merely an observer passing through. ‚ÄòA camera with its shutter open‚Äô, as Christopher Isherwood wrote of his time in Berlin.‚Äù
‚Äî A Waiter in Paris (2021: p.3)
As we follow Edward‚Äôs journey from runner to waiter, we find ourselves rooting for him as he navigates the complexities of the restaurant world. To read a book titled A Waiter in Paris is to also gain an insight into how waitering is an art form, requiring a delicate balance of humanity, decency, and sometimes manipulation.
We talked about how the scene of the Parisian restaurant became the author‚Äôs tiny window to observe urban life. As a ‚Äúthird place‚Äù in the city, as described by author Ray Oldenburg in The Great Good Place (1999), the restaurant is not merely a place to eat in. It works as an everyday melting pot of different cultures generating interpersonal and communal interaction of people from all walks of life. We commented on the ‚Äòplace ballet‚Äô of La Bistrot de La Seine, it was an intersection of different groups of people‚Äôs spatial and temporal routines. For the workers, the restaurant was a daily grind and seasonal challenge; for tourists and diners, a one-off adventure immersed in the performance of the front stage of the restaurant. They are all experiencing a different Paris.
We reflected on the ballet of behaviours we saw in the lower and upper kitchens of La Bistrot de La Seine, scenes that are usually invisible to diners and revealed to the reader. As readers we feasted on the time pressures and anxieties that came with waiters fighting it out to get their orders completed, putting food that had fallen on the floor back on the plate, or cleaning a spill with anything that came to hand be it a sleeve, napkin or something out of the bin. As we walked and talked, we were reminded of The Bear TV series which also depicts the intensity and chaos of a Chicago restaurant kitchen with the constant shouting of ‚ÄúBEHIND‚Äù, anxieties of completing orders on time, and colourful characters.
Along with facing the restaurant and the city, we thought about how Chisholm faces himself with the city and Philosopher Georg Simmel‚Äôs Metropolis and Mental Life (1903) on how one mentally navigates the city. We‚Äôre taken on twists and turns through Parisian restaurants, different accommodation, dark streets and hidden spaces as well as through the twists and turns of Chisholm‚Äôs own mentality in navigating being homeless, jobless and an outsider.
The metropolis, or the magnificent city, has a unique way of fragmenting our mentality, leaving us staring nakedly into the abyss. Yet, at the same time, it has the power to heal. This duality is beautifully captured in the book. One such expression of this is in a moment from the chapter ‚ÄòA Taste of Restaurant Life‚Äô where Chisholm writes about his own gaze on Paris:
‚ÄúEven when you‚Äôre exhausted, broke and hungry, there‚Äôs still an indefinable magic of the place. And no matter how much your feet hurt after a never-ending shift, how physically dead you feel as you walk up the Avenue de l‚ÄôOp√©ra at night, or across the Seine under the shadow of Notre-Dame, inside, you can‚Äôt help but feel intensively alive. Because you‚Äôre in it, you‚Äôre in the film. You‚Äôre not watching, you‚Äôve got a walk-on, speaking part. And everything feels possible. Besides, when you‚Äôre in Paris you couldn‚Äôt care less about anywhere else. Your world shrinks; it‚Äôs the centre of the universe. There is nowhere else.‚Äù
‚Äî A Waiter in Paris (2021: p.204)
Edward, thank you for answering our questions. We had a wonderful walk through Regent‚Äôs Park discussing A Waiter in Paris. As urbanists, we couldn‚Äôt help but dwell on the spatial imaginings and way in which the grit of urban life was portrayed in this account of your time in Paris. So that is the perspective from which we would like to ask our questions.
You wrote about how within Paris it may be possible to find all of France and that the scenes and stories you observed are indicative of urban life in other cities too. George Orwell‚Äôs Down and Out in Paris and London (1933) was also one of the books you mention travelling with you when you moved to Paris.
How would you compare the ‚Äòdark heart of Paris‚Äô to the ‚Äòdark heart‚Äô of London? Or equally, to anywhere else you have lived?
It‚Äôs hard to compare, in the sense that both cities are a reflection of their histories. For example, one thing you notice immediately is how former colonies play a huge part in the ethnic make-up of the city. In France, the majority of people working at the lower end of the social ladder are North African or from sub-Saharan French-speaking African countries. In London South Asia is much more represented.
That said, London also feels more international, more cosmopolitan, you find the whole world there; whereas Paris feels distinctly French, particularly intramuros, outside of the peripherique it is a different story, there‚Äôs a distinct division there. Whereas in London, which is more a collection of joined up villages, everybody is more spread out.
We mused on the title during our walk too and asked our attendees what it was about the book title that made them want to join us. The title contains a fusion of spatial and personal identity. In the book, you mention publishing ‚ÄòNotes from a Parisian kitchen‚Äô in The New York Times.
When did ‚ÄòNotes from a Parisian Kitchen‚Äô become A Waiter in Paris? And why this title?
Notes from a Parisian Kitchen was the title given to the article by the NY Times editor, probably inspired by Dostoyevsky‚Äôs Notes from Underground. My working title for the manuscript was always The Waiting Game, because the double sense of waiting intrigued me. However this was never particularly liked, and in the end the publisher wanted something that didn‚Äôt need to be deciphered, and that‚Äôs where A Waiter in Paris was born. There was some discussion whether it should be waiters, plural, but in the end it stayed singular.
Paris itself is a main character. And we say character because of the way in which your writing personifies Paris as human and as female. You describe Paris as ‚Äòquiet‚Äô with ‚Äòher avenues empty‚Äô in the opening. During the snow, Paris is ‚Äòreplaced by a soft memory‚Äô. Paris ‚Äòcares little‚Äô for the workers that keep the city running ‚Äòfor she has seen them all before and will see many more‚Äô.
Can you reflect on this personification? What image and experience of Paris does it help depict?
It‚Äôs almost a clich√© to refer to Paris in the feminine, and initially I tried to avoid it, but coming from London, and essentially comparing it with London, the personification became more apt. London feels distinctly masculine in my mind‚Äôs eye. Whereas Paris more feminine. Maybe it‚Äôs the intimacy of central Paris, the presence of more organic forms on building fa√ßades or metro entrances. It‚Äôs also no doubt informed by other writers. But there‚Äôs something more austere and concrete based about London, which obviously suffered a lot more damage during the war.
You‚Äôve shown us a really delicate description of the urban spaces of Paris at various scales, touching upon both the outdoor city and the interior world of the Parisian restaurant. As readers, we‚Äôve encountered urban life in Paris‚Äô alleys, courtyards, trains, parks, a car and so much more. We‚Äôve been presented with the socio-spatial hierarchies of restaurant kitchens and cafes as well as the experience of being together yet feeling alone at the Bistrot de la Seine.
Can you share an insight into your writing process for distilling and capturing this array of spatial dimensions?
That‚Äôs very kind, thank you. I have to admit that this was a huge part of the writing process. So much ink has been spilled describing Paris that I was keen not to fall into the same trap and employ the usual tired tropes to describe the city. Giving a sense of the size of the city, the macro experience helps place the reader in the intoxicating experience of being somewhere new, and all of the 19th century changes to Paris (wide boulevards, square, and public spaces) for this upon you. But it is very superficial, in the sense that you quickly step from this ceremonial world to something much smaller, more intimate, and often forgotten to the mists of time. The interior spaces are, especially in the less glamorous areas, often dilapidated after years and years of neglect. So choosing the right details to express this hopefully gave the reader a rich idea of what these places were actually like.
We opened the book walk by asking everyone if there was a moment in the book that made them laugh. And we would love to ask you the same. Is there a memory from the book that still makes you laugh when you recall it?
There were many moments that made me laugh, in fact the whole experience was probably much more joyous than written. The writing process tended to bring out the feeling of injustice I felt about the experience and the people that are going through it. So in the second draft I was keen to rectify that by adding more of the humourous exchanges that were the day-to-day of life in a gang of waiters.
We are part of UCL Urban Lab and we wanted to use the term ‚Äòurban lab‚Äô to launch our last question. You are currently working on a second book project about Paris. Can you tell us a bit about your next book and why Paris is your ‚Äòurban lab‚Äô for writing stories?
I imagine it‚Äôs because I amassed such a wealth of experience from the seven years I lived there that I have a rich well from which to draw upon. I love the idea of being able to transport someone there through words.
As for the next book, it is slightly different in that I will be recounting the story of something that happened in the late 60s. So I will need to draw on my own experience but also plenty of primary sources. To be honest, I am still working through how I will do it, but I am hoping that the research will illuminate the way.
This piece was written by Sidra Ahmed (PhD, UCL Geography) and Yichang Sun (PhD, UCL The Bartlett School of Architecture) with thanks from UCL Urban Laboratory

Title: Rainy days in Paris
Content:

Paris in the rain is glorious, especially if the rain isn‚Äôt hard and unrelenting. My wife Gaywynn and I were in Paris, staying in the 16th arrondissement at our friend Philippe‚Äôs grand apartment in May. Philippe‚Äôs place is on the rue Raynouard, not far from the Seine, within walking distance of Trocad√©ro. We stayed a week. We stayed long enough so that we fell into a kind of domestic routine. That included shopping for food. It‚Äôs a lovely way to experience Paris, and we were grateful.
Some days it rained. It never stopped us.
Philippe walked us around his neighborhood, showed us where he shopped for food, greeting all the shop owners who clearly knew him. Later, we followed in his footsteps. We cooked a few meals for Philippe, and so we needed to buy food.
We did our shopping mainly on the rue de l‚ÄòAnnonciation, a narrow pedestrian street that flows into the broader, longer rue de Passy. We walked it many times, up and back, passing by all those shops and stores that truly sustain a neighborhood ‚Äî butcher, produce, wine, bakery, seafood. Each is its own world, pulsing with tradition and high standards. Paris is a city of shops. (How many cities do you know still are?) They give you intimacy. They individualize you.
Sometimes, we would eat at A√©ro, a brasserie at the end of rue de l‚ÄòAnnonciation on the Place de Passy, where we could sit outside. We came to think of it as our brasserie. That‚Äôs what happens when you stay for a while in Paris. You find a place to call your own. You make an attachment to it. It belongs to you, and you belong to it.
After a week, we belonged to our neighborhood and to Paris.
We bought meat at Les Bouchers Doubles at 43 rue de l‚ÄôAnnonciation. We bought vegetables at March√© Couvert de Passy. We bought pastries at Aux Merveilleux de Fred ‚Äî yes, I know, ‚ÄúFred‚Äù doesn‚Äôt sound French ‚Äî and bread at Aux Pains de Manon, both on rue de l‚ÄôAnnonciation. Did any of the people behind the counters recognize us by the end of the week? I‚Äôd like to think, or to pretend, they did. They always smiled, in any case.
Some days we went to Monoprix, a store I like very much. The name, Monoprox, is not very romantic. It‚Äôs a practical place, with a practical name, and I always feel practical shopping there. You don‚Äôt shop at Monoprix for souvenirs, but you do find things you need. For splendor, Gaywynn and I went to La Grande √âpicerie de Paris on rue de Passy, where we found the best France has to offer. It was amazing to see what they considered exotic produce from America ‚Äî they sold Reese‚Äôs Peanut Butter Cups, for example.
It rained several days while we were there. I never minded. I think rain brings out a stunning aspect of Paris. It makes the city moody, and me as well. I feel I‚Äôm a poet when I walk rainy Paris. Rain is disparaged too much, more than it should be. People talk about rain as if it were some kind of setback. It‚Äôs rain. That‚Äôs all. You can get wet. It‚Äôs all worth it when the rain is falling in Paris, and the gray light makes everything the best black and white film you‚Äôve ever seen, and you smell the damp air and hear car tires hissing on the wet streets.
I think you can be a citizen of Paris by right of passion.
When it rained, we might dart into the Librairie Fontaine, a sweet bookstore on rue de l‚ÄòAnnonciation. We discovered one of the young employees, who spoke flawless French, was American. I‚Äôd never heard any American speak French as well as he did. What I wouldn‚Äôt give to be able to work in a French bookstore! Well, here‚Äôs to reincarnation.
I speak French passably. If a Parisian speaks, as they do sometimes, at the speed of light, then I‚Äôm lost. If the conversation is at a reasonable clip, though, and it‚Äôs just the two of us, I can manage. Speaking a language not your own and that you don‚Äôt speak fluently is a lesson in humility and error. But when you speak French in Paris and are understood, that‚Äôs a chest-rising feeling. So, I jump in. I never mind being clumsy. They‚Äôre not going to report me.
Returning after a long day on the Left Bank, we walked from our M√©tro station, Passy, up the long hill to rue de Passy. We didn‚Äôt have the climbing energy the students who disembarked with us had. Never mind. There was Desgranges bakery waiting at the top, on rue de Passy, with something weight-increasing, but God did it taste good. That gave us the motivation we needed.
Then home to rue Raynouard, into the small, slowly-rising elevator, off at our floor, inserting the key Philippe had given us, opening the door, throwing ourselves onto his couch, restoring ourselves, and then ready, in a while, to venture out again.
Our corner of Paris. It‚Äôs in our heart.
--
--
Author of French Dirt: The Story of a Garden in the South of France, A New York Memoir and co-editor of The Gulf South: An Anthology of Environmental Writing.

Title: Friend or Foe? Speaking English in Paris; A guide for tourists who can‚Äôt speak French in Paris
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
‚ÄúDon‚Äôt come to Paris if you can‚Äôt speak French, they will ignore you right away‚Äù
‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you ever speak English in Paris, they‚Äôll be mad, trust me‚Äù
As an English Education student, those sayings always overwhelmed me whenever I wanted to go to Paris. Well, as an English Education Student, it is my basic talent to at least speak and communicate with people using the English Language. However, I am always curious about those sayings. Is it actually true? That Parisians hate people who speak English? Will they get mad at you? or will they be harsh on you?
Here are some facts that you need to know about English in Paris based on my experience as a Student Exchange of a short course program at SciencesPo, Paris, France.
Parisians have high nationalism about their country
When I arrived in Paris for the first time, there was a man who communicated with me and talked about politics after a piece of news came from a television in a lobby hotel. He talked about how he disagreed with the new American president. He said that it is such a shame that people don‚Äôt actually use their rights to vote for the right president.
At first, I was shocked when I heard his story about politics all of sudden as soon as I arrived at my hotel. Second, I was shocked because he literally used English directly to talk with me. Third, it turns out he didn‚Äôt even care to talk about such things even though I am a hijabi, since I heard that some Parisians are Islamophobic.
Lots of questions in my head right after 5 minutes I arrived. Yet, as a Gen Z, me and my curiosity couldn‚Äôt even stand to ask those questions to the man.
So I asked him,
‚ÄúWait sir, before we continue, I am actually amazed, because however, you are French, and you are talking to me in English, it‚Äôs just‚Ä¶you know...I often heard Parisians hate tourists, especially people who speak English. Then how do you just naturally speak English right away?‚Äù
Then, he answered
Haha, it‚Äôs funny because however, it‚Äôs not actually 100% correct. Do some French speak English? yes. But do they hate it? well not all of them. You know what, we actually not that bad.
Since it‚Äôs not answering all of my questions, I asked him once again.
Okay, got it, so it‚Äôs only a stereotype right? but why do ‚Äúsome‚Äù of them hate it? I mean what is wrong with using English in Paris? and one more question, Do Parisian hate Muslims? Because i am a hijabi and to be honest i am afraid that people will don‚Äôt like my hijab sir.
He smiled and said,
You know what young lady, we are not that bad once again. I mean, yea some of us still hate people who don‚Äôt ‚Äúact‚Äù like us. Why? it‚Äôs because we do realize how hard we achieve our condition to be independent and win the war. We‚Äôve come this far, then,
‚Äúhow come people use another language in our country?‚Äù
‚Äúdon‚Äôt they be proud of our language? why they use another language if they came here?‚Äù
Back then, let me tell you that we are so open to people. For example, Chinese. We always welcome tourist whocame. But day by day it seems that they ‚Äútry‚Äù to domain the land. They start to sell their products, feels like they want to conquer our land. That‚Äôs why, perhaps, not all French are friendly when they saw another people. Especially if it seems that they try to domain the land.
I was amazed, mesmerized by his answer, and nod right away.
French people have high nationalism towards their country. I did realize it after I came to Arc de Triomphe on November, 11th 2024. When it‚Äôs a day of remembrance. This day commemorates the armistice that ended World War I, signed between the Allies and Germany in Compi√®gne, France on the 11th hour of the 11th day of the 11th month. Since 2012, the day has also served as a remembrance for all of France‚Äôs war dead.
Under the Arc de Triomphe, there is a Rekindling of the Flame. This ceremony takes place every evening at the tomb of the Unknown Soldier. The Flame Committee rekindles the Flame of Remembrance to honor the soldiers who died in World War I and other conflicts. The remains of an unknown soldier are buried beneath the Arc de Triomphe. The tomb features an eternal flame that burns in memory of the soldiers who died in both world wars.
On that day, they also raise a giant flag in the middle of the Arc de Triomphe
When I went there, I was amazed by how people mourn and truly remember the history behind it. All of them gather and give some flowers and respect those who died in honor back then. Then I realized that Paris, indeed, is a city full of history.
In a nutshell? English in Paris, is it a friend or foe? I can loudly say that it is actually a friend. When I was there I literally used 90% English and 10% messy French. Yet, most of them still smiling and answering my questions.
However, here are some tips and tricks if you want to speak English safely in Paris.
Most Parisians will appreciate how you say something if you add some French to it! Even though it is as simple as ‚Äúmerci‚Äù. I usually use ‚Äúexcusez-moi‚Äù and ‚Äúje ne parle fran√ßais, je parle anglais‚Äù which means ‚ÄúExcuse me, I can‚Äôt speak french, I can speak English‚Äù. After that, they will usually say that my French accent is good even though I said that I can‚Äôt speak French. Then they will also try to answer my questions in English since it seems like I have the intention to ask my questions in their language even though I can‚Äôt.
2. Keep smiling no matter what
As what ‚Äúthe man‚Äù said in my previous story, it is obvious that all people will welcome your English. So, keep smiling no matter what, so that they realize you already tried your best to ask something in French.
3. ‚ÄúBonjour‚Äù and ‚ÄúMerci‚Äù is the key
Every time you want to ask something to someone in English. Always remember to say at least Bonjour and Merci. Especially in the Supermarket. I realize that people in supermarkets like Carrefour mostly are not welcome whenever we use English to communicate with them. Especially in those hectic moments at the cashier. I think they are just too tired to talk more in English. That‚Äôs why, you could encourage them to talk with you by at least, saying ‚Äúbonjour‚Äù and ‚Äúmerci‚Äù.
And those are some tips and tricks to survive with your English in Paris! Trust me, Paris is not that bad for tourists. I mean, France has the highest number of tourists from all over the world. If I can describe it in a sentence, I would say that Paris is such a beautiful, magical, and endearing city. So, come to Paris and feel the atmosphere of love and historical value from the architecture. Trust me, you won‚Äôt regret it.
enchant√© Paris! Merci!

Title: Paris Neighborhood Guide: the 10th Arrondissement
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Helping You Adapt to Life in France

--
Listen
Share
Ah, le dixi√®me. One of my favorite Parisian neighborhoods (after my beloved Montmartre, of course), you‚Äôll often find me there on a given weekend. It‚Äôs one of the least ‚Äútouristy‚Äù areas in the city ‚Äî I lived in Paris for a full six months as a student back in 2012 and never even knew it existed ‚Äî and I love spending time in these small pockets of unspoiled places in Paris. Well, maybe not completely unspoiled but you get the idea.
And while I‚Äôd love to keep the 10th arrondissement all to myself, I‚Äôm no gatekeeper. For those of you coming to Paris to visit, or maybe Paris residents who, like me in 2012, never ventured up to the tenth, here are some spots to add to your to-see lists.
The Gare du Nord and Gare de l‚ÄôEst aren‚Äôt necessarily ‚Äúsights to see,‚Äù but they are in the 10th arrondissement and you‚Äôll likely need to access them at some point if you plan on doing some traveling.
Both are known as being on the ‚Äúsketchy‚Äù side but I have never personally had any issues there. Pay attention and keep your belongings close and you shouldn‚Äôt have a problem. Gare du Nord will get you to places in northern Europe (as well as merry old England) and Gare de L‚ÄôEst will get you to places in eastern Europe (and beyond), respectfully.
If you have spent time in the 10th arrondissement, I‚Äôm willing to bet it was along the Canal Saint Martin. This little waterway that flows from Bastille all the way up to La Villette in the 19th arrondissement has often been a sanctuary for me, particularly on those sweltering August nights, as the leaves begin to fall in autumn, and even during a drizzle in the colder months.
When the weather cooperates, there are plenty of places to sit down next to the canal with a good book. If you don‚Äôt feel the need to be directly on the canal, there‚Äôs a lovely park called the Jardin Villemin with lots of grass to sit on.
My yoga studio is along the canal (Jivamukti Yoga Paris if you‚Äôre interested), and I will often make the 40-minute walk from my place in the 18th arrondissement to get there.
The bar Le Comptoir G√©n√©ral is a vibe and is my go-to when I want to impress friends in town visiting. Chez Prune is a bit more on the casual side (and more authentically French, in my opinion), and I‚Äôve shared many a glass of wine/charcuterie board there over the years. Ten Belles for coffee, always, and Maria Belza for tapas. Trust me.
For those who love a good story, the Canal was also where Earful Tower host Oliver Gee heard the story that led to his first children‚Äôs book, Kylie the Crocodile in Paris. It makes a fun gift for kids who might be interested in the City of Light.
There are a myriad of march√©s (markets) to be found in Paris ‚Äî some are static, like the rue Mouffetard or le march√© des Enfants-Rouges, while others set up shop just a few times a week.
Like le march√© des Enfants-Rouges, le march√© Saint-Quentin is a covered market. It‚Äôs one of the largest and oldest markets of its kind in the city (first built in 1835, destroyed in 1852, and rebuilt in 1866), and is home to produce sellers, butchers, florists, fishmongers, cheesemongers‚Ä¶there are even places to buy beer and wine.
While this isn‚Äôt my favorite march√© in the city (I have a penchant for rue Mouffetard myself), it‚Äôs worth a visit if you get there early enough to beat the crowds. Doors open at 8am every day.
The 10th arrondissement is not short on nightlife. I like places that are cool and cozy with a big enough terrasse to fit me and all of my friends. I first started hanging out on the cour des Petites √âcuries because a friend of mine worked at a small bar there. That was about five years ago and I often find myself returning on a Thursday or Friday evening.
The street is tiny, only about 850 feet long. Nestled along the cobblestones are about a dozen caf√©s, bars, and restaurants to discover. And, if you venture off the street you‚Äôll find dozens more. It‚Äôs a good option if you like to bar-hop and wander. Most places are very affordable if you‚Äôre on a budget.
Like most Parisian neighborhoods, the 10th arrondissement is also a wonderful place for a stroll. Use the places I mentioned above as a jumping-off point and then explore on your own. You just may get lost for a few hours, but that‚Äôs never a bad thing in Paris.
Photo by Florencia Potter on Pexels

These tips help support our efforts to keep TAIP an ad-free environment. Just as at a cafe, the tips are split evenly among the team.Originally published at https://theamericaninparis.com on October 5, 2023.
