Title: Sous le Ciel de Paris
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Authenticity, vulnerability, awareness & growth through storytelling, sharing of personal experiences, and knowledge on spiritual matters.

Member-only story
--
19
Share
Victor Hugo, Marcel Proust, F. Scott Fitzgerald, and many others have captured the essence of Paris in their writing, and numerous poets have used this city as their muse. For artists and creators, Paris is a city of sensations, of layers, of contrasts and defies easy categorisation.
Walking the streets of this city, I felt all the hopes, aspirations and fantasies that are often excluded from my conscious personality in everyday life come alive‚Äîthe determination never to be disappointed by life, to see only what is beautiful, good and kind.
I had strangers smiling at me and that lively ‚ÄúBonjourrrr‚Äù. I admired Parisians going about their daily lives, running up and down the path beside the Seine. I watched a group of French women having their passionate intellectual debates in a restaurant before going to their yoga class. I watched people wandering through the Sunday flea market in search of the perfect vintage garment. I have admired femininity and the art of true seduction, the very definition of naked couture at a cabaret show, reminiscent of a simpler time when natural beauty was cherished.
For artists who have often felt left out or like they don‚Äôt belong because their upbringing or culture doesn‚Äôt support the arts or embrace creativity, Paris is a breath of fresh air. Going to a country where the government itself has a history of supporting the arts and culture makes you feel seen and understood.
Sous le ciel de Paris, I was reminded that what I do matters, and for the first time I didn‚Äôt feel that my romanticism was being challenged or stifled. I didn‚Äôt feel at war with myself.
I felt at peace.

Title: The Best (and Worst) Month to Fly to Paris on a Budget in 2025
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
A Data-Backed Travel Guide
After binge-watching Emily in Paris (no judgment, please), I‚Äôve been dying to stroll along the Seine, bite into a flaky croissant, and soak in the city‚Äôs magic ‚Äî art, love, history, the works. But I‚Äôm also a data nerd who loves a good deal, so I wasn‚Äôt about to splurge on flights.
I gathered flight prices from Singapore (SIN), London (LHR), and New York (JFK) to Paris (CDG) to study travel patterns from different corners of the world ‚Äî Asia, Europe, and North America ‚Äî and find the cheapest month to visit Paris in 2025. What I found surprised me: a secret sweet spot where prices drop, crowds thin, and Paris still sparkles ‚Äî plus a month so overpriced and packed it made me rethink my plans.
Paris reinvents itself with each season, and timing can make or break your trip ‚Äî especially if you‚Äôre budget-conscious. Here‚Äôs the quick rundown:
Timing matters because each season shows a different side of Paris ‚Äî and impacts your wallet.
November is your golden ticket.
Flights from LHR averaged $125, SIN $350, and JFK $300 ‚Äî the lowest I found all year. Why? It‚Äôs late fall in Paris (6‚Äì11¬∞C), meaning fewer tourists clogging up the Louvre or the Marais. My price trend plot confirmed it: November was the cheapest across the board. Sure, it‚Äôs chilly ‚Äî pack a scarf and a jacket ‚Äî but imagine this: you‚Äôre sipping hot chocolate by the Seine, golden leaves falling, and you didn‚Äôt break the bank to get there. That‚Äôs November in Paris.
If November‚Äôs too cold for you, consider September to October. My daily price trend plot showed prices stabilizing during this period ‚Äî before spiking again in late October. Wonder why the stability? Summer‚Äôs rush (think families on school break) fades, and demand drops as kids head back to school. September‚Äôs still mild (13‚Äì21¬∞C), with fewer crowds and scenic fall vibes ‚Äî perfect for a bike ride along the Canal Saint-Martin. October cools down (9‚Äì16¬∞C) but keeps the charm, with autumn colors popping in the Tuileries Garden. Just watch out for late October ‚Äî prices start creeping up as holiday travel looms.
Here‚Äôs the month I‚Äôd dodge like a tourist trap: August. My price trend plot showed a steady climb through the month, peaking near the end. Why the spike? It‚Äôs peak summer (16‚Äì25¬∞C), and Paris is swarming with tourists soaking up the sun. Plus, many Europeans (including Parisians) take their annual holidays, so the city‚Äôs packed with visitors while locals escape to the coast. If you hate crowds (and overpaying), August is a hard pass.
My price trend plot revealed a wild ups and downs from June to July. What gives? June is the tail end of shoulder season ‚Äî still warm (14‚Äì23¬∞C), but demand hasn‚Äôt peaked. Come July, summer hits full swing: school holidays kick in, Bastille Day (July 14) draws crowds with its parades and fireworks, and Paris becomes the place to be. More demand, higher prices ‚Äî it‚Äôs simple economics, but it stings.
Here‚Äôs the deal: book your 2025 Paris trip for November. You‚Äôll save big, enjoy a quieter city, and still get that Parisian magic (pro tip: pack a scarf ‚Äî it‚Äôs chilly).
Have you visited Paris during an off-season month? Did you find hidden deals, or do you think the summer hype is worth it?

Outline of a talk at the Critical University 15 May 2021
If we go back to March 18th, and look at the famous imagery of the National Guard on their barricades, we‚Äôre only seeing one half of the story. This is the French labour movement as it saw itself: orderly, respectable and quite obviously gendered ‚Äî the men have the guns, flags and uniforms, the women and children stand to the side.
The battalions were rooted in local communities but, as Martin Phillip Johnson shows, there was a lot of crossover ‚Äî so that a man in one area might actually travel to be with friends in another area‚Äôs battalion. Which suggests they were based both on community and workplace.
But March 18th itself, and the subsequent trajectory of the Commune as a revolutionary government, involved a completely different demographic: la canaille, the mob: the shanty-dwelling ultra poor, including migrants from outside Paris, overlapped with the classic bohemia of artists, impoverished law students, registered sex workers, slum children‚Ä¶ and nobody took their photos, although they drew them.

Title: Why Saying ‚ÄúBonjour‚Äù in Paris Feels Like a Sensual French Ritual
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

We are a group of ordinary yet extraordinary travel lovers sharing our experiences of exploring the world with the world.

--
3
Listen
Share
I think the way French people say, ‚ÄúBonjour!‚Äù is sensuous. Just two syllables. Or two musical notes, rather.
Shopkeepers, waitstaff, and bartenders all seem to sing when they greet me with ‚ÄúBonjour!‚Äù or ‚ÄúBonjour, monsieur!‚Äù
Nothing about me asks to be serenaded. I‚Äôm an older American male of Chinese ethnicity, not immediately charismatic, nor sharply dressed, nor classically good-looking, nor anything. On my better days, I could perhaps pass for an expatriate, but more often, I probably come off as a seasoned tourist, which, at least, is accurate.
Everyone gets this greeting, not just me. But alas, not everyone responds in a way that matches the greeter‚Äôs sensuality. They should. We could all use a bit more sensuality in our lives, no matter how small.
I wish to blend in, to ‚Äúlive like a local‚Äù as many travelers like to say. So, whenever I‚Äôm greeted, I feel the need to respond in kind. Thus, I reply, ‚ÄúBonjour!‚Äù in the best French I can muster, which causes me to mimic that same songlike quality. ‚ÄúBonjour!‚Äù I feel better just saying, er, singing it.
For example, I found myself singing at 9:15 am as I entered La Cr√©maill√®re 1900 in Montmartre on a chilly, misty April morning. Still sleepy, and before my morning coffee.
Singing ‚ÄúBonjour!‚Äù in response to the server uplifts me. Sure, it‚Äôs only two notes, but it‚Äôs two more notes than I sing when I enter a caf√© near my home in New York City.
By the way, I wrote my first draft of this story in this caf√©, and all the photos in this article are of this establishment.
If you must ask, I had the ‚ÄúPain perdu au caramel beurre sal√©‚Äù or ‚ÄúSalted butter caramel French toast.‚Äù Yes, it was as sensuously decadent as that reads.
Some say that ‚ÄúParis est un village,‚Äù and I can see why. Few other large cities I‚Äôve experienced greet me like I‚Äôm in a small town, but people here do this naturally.
I found out later that all of French society conspires to do this, not just Parisians. French children are consistently taught to say ‚Äúbonjour‚Äù and ‚Äúau revoir‚Äù to their peers and adults. Some say it‚Äôs a way to acknowledge another‚Äôs humanity.¬π
I live in New York City, where we value efficiency. We can‚Äôt be bothered with fussy things like greetings, especially with strangers. Often just a direct, ‚ÄúDo you have the time?‚Äù or ‚ÄúI‚Äôd like a matcha oat latte, please!‚Äù
But is it really that fussy? It‚Äôs not like I‚Äôm being asked to say, ‚ÄúGood day to you, madame. You look quite well today.‚Äù Saying ‚Äúhello‚Äù is only two syllables, just like in French!
I‚Äôm resolved to acknowledge my fellow New Yorkers‚Äô humanity when I get home. I will sing ‚ÄúHello!‚Äù to all of them, even if things get awkward. Maybe I‚Äôll get a side job at a caf√© or a Lululemon shop. Just for the practice.
Back in Paris, at bustling, understaffed restaurants, harried servers move quickly and efficiently. They don‚Äôt smile. They acknowledge me just long enough to indicate, yes, take any available seat. Maybe I‚Äôll get a menu soon, maybe not.
But I always get a tonally cheerful ‚ÄúBonjour!‚Äù paired with firm, if fleeting, eye contact.
The Middle Eastern immigrants working the kebab stalls greet me with a lilting ‚ÄúBonjour!‚Äù The Chinese housekeeping staff at my hotel: ‚ÄúBonjour!‚Äù Service workers who don‚Äôt even seem happy with their jobs, at least at that moment: ‚ÄúBonjour!‚Äù
It‚Äôs as if those weary service workers are saying, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm unhappy right now, but I‚Äôm not taking it out on strangers. And so, I will sing because singing is good for my soul. Even if it‚Äôs just two notes.‚Äù
And if singing one‚Äôs troubles is good for one‚Äôs soul, does that mean complaining in French is more therapeutic than complaining in English? I‚Äôve heard people complain in French many times, and it‚Äôs the cutest thing ever. I feel cathartic just listening to them, and I don‚Äôt even know what they‚Äôre saying most of the time!
French certainly sounds better than the flatter tones of my American English. In my home country, I hear the French language‚Äôs relative musicality exert its influence.
Does it sound more meaningful to say you‚Äôre a ‚Äúhustler‚Äù or an ‚Äúentrepreneur‚Äù? (Bonus: Say ‚Äúentrepreneur‚Äù in proper French, with a crooked half-smile and a gleam in your eye for a self-effacing, satirical effect.)
What feels better to say after you emotionally process a major setback? ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs life!‚Äù versus ‚ÄúC‚Äôest la vie!‚Äù
If you and your partner want to invite a prospective new lover to your bedroom, would you coquettishly propose a ‚Äúthreesome‚Äù or a ‚Äúm√©nage √† trois‚Äù?
I‚Äôm not an enraptured newbie √† la Emily in Paris. This is my seventh time in Paris. I‚Äôve been to other parts of France. I‚Äôm actually a sometimes-jaded traveler. I‚Äôve studied French on and off for years.
While I‚Äôve always loved French culture and people, after all these visits, I‚Äôm finally noticing and loving the soulful quality I hear in the French language.
That‚Äôs all I have about French greetings. Though, we haven‚Äôt discussed French farewells, which I find similarly lyrical. I guess you‚Äôll just have to use your imagination when I say (sing):
Au revoir! Bonne journ√©e!
As mentioned, all photos in this article were shot inside this caf√©:
La Cr√©maill√®re 1900 (Yelp, Google Maps)

Title: You Won‚Äôt Regret Discovering the Street Art in Le Marais, Paris
Content:

There‚Äôs an eclectic, egalitarian art gallery hiding in plain sight in Le Marais district in Paris. Its art pieces coexist with the chic boutiques and charming restaurants this area is known for.
Throughout these winding, intimate medieval streets, perched on walls above eye level (or below, sometimes) are street art pieces.
I love finding them amongst the teeming throngs of tourists. So many tourists. But who am I to hate on them? I‚Äôm a tourist myself, and I love Le Marais, just like them.
Several years ago, I did a street art tour of this neighborhood. The tour guide told me that residents here tended to be more tolerant of graffiti and street art. Artists, Bohemians, gays/lesbians, and other groups have at times occupied this area since the late 20th century.
I went back this year.
Just like years ago, it did not disappoint.
All photos in this article were taken by me in Le Marais during my April 2025 trip ‚Äî except for this one below from December 2017, where I actually caught a street artist in the act!!
I‚Äôve done my best to attribute the artworks that I know.
Back to this year.
I discovered this cute piece below.
I wondered if the raccoon stencil was part of the original piece or if another artist added it later. Did the original artist get annoyed or grudgingly accept it?
You had to walk down a nondescript residential street to find this one:
I don‚Äôt know why these artists are into vintage video game characters, but I find them cute.
On the left below is Super Mario by Invader (Official website, Instagram). That famous artist of those Space Invaders video game characters rendered as tile art throughout Paris and beyond.
Did you know there‚Äôs a FlashInvaders app that lets you ‚Äúcollect‚Äù sightings of Invader‚Äôs works? It‚Äôs totally a thing.
Below is more street art. I love the various forms and mediums this art can take.
Some pieces were stunningly intricate, as shown below. For pieces that clearly require so much effort, I sometimes wonder if artists seek permission from the building owners first or hope that the virtuosity of the piece earns enough respect to spare its destruction.
Le Marais is already delightful with its shopping, food, and vibes. You would not be faulted for enjoying only these things.
But there‚Äôs a playful, subversive layer if you slow down and look closely enough.
Next time you‚Äôre here, let your gaze wander more.
Or take a detour down that nondescript alley.
You may be rewarded with some artistic surprises!

Title: Paris Women & the City of Lights
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Artful storytelling helping inspire women to learn and grow

--
Listen
Share
I love the ‚ÄúCity of Stars‚Äù music from the recent Oscar-nominated movie, La La Land. Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling tenderly whisper their dreams and hopes to the stars, praying for a city of lights filled with love and happiness.
When I hear this song my heart escapes to a magical place where my dreams are admittedly sentimental and gooey. For me, my city of lights shines brightly in Paris.
Every time I‚Äôm in Paris I succumb to its winding streets and famous arrondissements. While I have yet to go beyond the city, venturing into Versailles and Fontainebleau, who can blame me? Paris if filled with an endless selection of bottomless bread baskets, silky cheeses and overflowing red wine on almost every Parisian corner. These culinary delights stimulate my blissful escape into the fascinating world of Parisian stories, stretching my imagination across time and well beyond the city‚Äôs center at Notre Dame.
Historical French women call out to me like Joan of Arc, from her gable perch on the Sacr√© C≈ìur Basilica, and Josephine Bonaparte, as I walk the cobblestone streets in front of Notre Dame. Paris is alive thousands of monuments to women, whose contributions have changed history and opportunities for other women.
In Montmartre, fifteenth century Joan of Arc is one of my favorite musings. She sits to the left of a triumphant King Louis IX. Joan is best remembered for her role in preserving France‚Äôs religious faith and national unity. During the Hundred Years War when the English occupied parts of France and threatened its sovereignty, Joan claimed to hear God‚Äôs voice telling her to lead the embattled crown prince Charles VII to victory at Orl√©ans.
Joan of Arc‚Äôs victorious charge and horrific death as a heretic burned at the stake sealed her fate as one of France‚Äôs most cherished saints. But what if Joan had ignored her dreams or had been too afraid to take up the sword, especially since women leading in war front was unheard of at this time?
Joan‚Äôs mystic legacy as a great leader and savior of the church is honored in thousands of statues throughout Paris, and to this day she continues to be a subject of great scholarly fascination.
More personally, the golden image of Joan riding on a horse into battle inspires me to feel like anything is possible in life, if you stay true to your beliefs and convictions amidst doubt and controversy.
Of all the fascinating French women of Paris, I could not write their stories without including the most famous one living in the Louvre museum.
Before you say the Mona Lisa shouldn‚Äôt be included because she isn‚Äôt technically French born, and is only an Italian subject of painter Leonardo Da Vinci‚Äôs, hear me out.
I include the Mona Lisa among the most inspiring and transformative French women for two reasons: her portrait was commissioned by the King of France in 1530 and, most importantly, she is the most visited, studied, and best known work of art in the world whose place in Paris is solidified. Essentially, there are no plans for the Mona Lisa to emigrate anytime soon.
Her resting place in the Louvre is an interesting one, after her picture first hung in the gallery of King Francois I at Fontainebleau. Napoleon Bonaparte moved her to his bedroom wall in his Tuileries apartment in 1800 before she took official residence in the Louvre four years later. The Mona Lisa has continued to live in Paris well over 200 years now, and my fixation with her place there is shared with the world.
No doubt her mysterious smile or what the Italians call, sfumato (meaning blurry, ambitious and up to the imagination) is a perfect reflection of the mysterious allure that French women exude. It is an allure that can‚Äôt be defined, any more than Nat King Cole tried in his hit song about Mona Lisa‚Äôs smile or Columbia Pictures‚Äô attempt to classify her in the 2003 movie, Mona Lisa Smile.
The potential for women to reach new heights and to dream beyond traditional roles is enough to hold me captive. Mona Lisa reminds us of the power of the imagination, even for any doubters who know that Da Vinci predicted many future inventions from flying machines to water inventions.
Mona Lisa is more than a 16th century painting of Lisa Gherardini, wife of Francesco del Giocondo. Her stature goes far beyond the millions of people who have flocked to see her. She embodies that powerful combination of strength, mystery, creativity and individualism in French women that inspires me to be even more than I already am.
French history is filled with further examples of complex female figures, the last which must be included to understand revolutionary France. During the French Reign of Terror in 1793, Josephine Tascher de La Pagerie was married to a prominent Viscount named Alexandre de Beauharnais. Alexandre was executed by guillotine for being an aristocratic sympathizer but his wife Josephine was saved from the same fate thanks to her quick intellect.
Parisian women still recount Josephine‚Äôs ingenious escape. Josephine walked up the steps of the platform to meet her death but fainted in front of a huge crowd gathered at Notre Dame. Claiming she was with child, she knew the Catholic laws protected the execution of an innocent child so her life would be spared. Able to wait out the political unrest in jail Josephine was released when the final coup d‚Äô√©tat ended.
Josephine would reappear on these same steps of Notre Dame to be crowned Empress years later when she married Napoleon Bonaparte. After her prison release she became a popular leader in Paris society and caught the fancy of Napoleon, a young rising officer in the army. She used her position to advance his political fortune, and when they married in a civil ceremony Josephine insisted on a second ceremony at Notre Dame after his coronation as Emperor on December 1, 1804.
During their reign, Josephine fought for social and political reforms and joined a movement of women called the Society of Revolutionary Republican Women, whose demands included equal rights for women and economic reforms in Paris. Participating in a march that included over seven thousand armed women, Josephine took to the streets and protested at the Hotel de Ville and later Versailles.
Josephine secured her title as Empress with Napoleon even after he divorced her because she could not produce an heir. Despite her new status, she remained politically astute and helped assuage the marriage of her daughter, Hortense, to Napoleon‚Äôs brother Louis, and her son Eugene‚Äôs marriage to the daughter of the King of Bavaria.
When you consider Josephine‚Äôs historical legacy, her ancestry of five dynasties still reigns in Northern Europe, in the ruling families of Sweden, Norway, Denmark, Belgium, and in Luxembourg. In fact, she is even connected to Princess Diana and her son William, who will become the next King of England. How‚Äôs that for a city of lights and an Empress of all Empires?
Parisian women have changed the course of history in France and throughout the world. The new reign of terror attacks are not enough to dampen my appetite for Paris, as I stand in solidarity with them. The French commitment to helping America in its struggle for independence lives on in our Lady Liberty statue, a gift from the French designed by Auguste Bartholdi.
As she clutches the Declaration of Independence and steps out of the British chains that lay at her feet, I know France will always have a special place in my heart. This power is underscored by its women and captured in a diary entry by Napoleon to his future wife, Josephine. In it, he writes to her saying,
‚ÄúI awake filled with you. Your portrait and yesterday‚Äôs intoxicating evening left no repose for my senses. Gentle, incomparable Josephine, what a strange effect you have on my heart!‚Äù

Title: Anne Hidalgo: Transforming Paris into a Green Metropolis for a Sustainable Future
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
‚ÄúWhen you make a decision as a mayor, you immediately see positive and negative effects.‚Äù says Ms Anne Hidalgo, Mayor Paris
Since becoming the first female Mayor of Paris in 2014, Anne Hidalgo has championed an ambitious vision to make the French capital a global leader in sustainability and urban environmental innovation. Her policies, rooted in combating climate change and enhancing the quality of life for Parisians, have reshaped the city‚Äôs landscape, reduced its ecological footprint, and set a benchmark for cities worldwide. Hidalgo‚Äôs work reflects a commitment to nature, social equity, and a forward-thinking approach to urban living, earning her international acclaim, including a spot on TIME‚Äôs 2024 TIME100 Climate list. This article explores her transformative efforts to foster a greener Paris and secure a better future for its residents.
A Vision for a Greener Paris
Hidalgo‚Äôs tenure has been defined by bold environmental policies aimed at reducing pollution, prioritizing sustainable mobility, and reintegrating nature into urban spaces. Her overarching goal is to make Paris a ‚Äú15-minute city,‚Äù where essential services‚Äîshops, schools, workplaces, and green spaces‚Äîare accessible within a short walk or bike ride. This concept, championed by Hidalgo and urban planner Carlos Moreno, seeks to reduce car dependency, enhance community living, and mitigate climate impacts.
Her initiatives reflect a holistic approach to urban planning, balancing ecological resilience with social inclusion.
Revolutionizing Urban Mobility
One of Hidalgo‚Äôs most transformative achievements has been her push to reduce car dominance in Paris, a city historically shaped by automotive culture. Since 2014, her administration has added over 1,300 kilometers (800 miles) of bike lanes, making cycling a viable and safe option for commuters. The ‚ÄúPlan V√©lo‚Äù initiative has expanded cycling infrastructure, with dedicated lanes and bike-sharing schemes like V√©lib‚Äô becoming integral to Parisian life. Posts on X highlight the scale of this transformation, noting that Paris has built ‚Äú+800km new bike paths‚Äù and reduced car traffic by 40% under Hidalgo‚Äôs leadership.
Hidalgo has also pedestrianized key areas, transforming the Seine riverbanks into car-free zones reserved for walkers and cyclists. The ‚ÄúParis Respire‚Äù (Paris Breathes) initiative bans traffic in certain areas on Sundays and holidays, encouraging residents to reclaim public spaces. Major roads, including stretches along the Seine and iconic plazas like Bastille and Nation, have been redesigned to prioritize pedestrians and public transport. These efforts have led to a 40% drop in air pollution since 2014, significantly improving environmental health.
To further deter car use, Hidalgo introduced policies targeting high-polluting vehicles. Diesel vehicles have been banned from Paris by 2024, with all fossil fuel vehicles phased out by 2030. A parking tax on gas-guzzling SUVs and mandatory emissions stickers for cars entering the city reinforces these measures. These policies not only reduce emissions but also incentivize cleaner transport alternatives, aligning with Paris‚Äôs goal of carbon neutrality by 2050.
Greening the Urban Landscape
Hidalgo‚Äôs commitment to nature is evident in her ambitious tree-planting and urban greening programs. Since taking office, Paris has planted over 200,000 trees, with a pledge to add 170,000 more by 2026. Urban forests are being created near landmarks like the H√¥tel de Ville, Gare de Lyon, and Op√©ra Garnier, with plans to cover 50% of the city with planted areas by 2030. A notable project is the transformation of the area from the Trocad√©ro to the Eiffel Tower into a 56-hectares wooded park, set to become a ‚Äúgreen lung‚Äù for the city.
In 2022, Hidalgo announced plans for a 3.5-hectare urban forest in the 20th arrondissement, planting over 2,000 trees to combat heatwaves and enhance biodiversity. Her administration has also relaxed building codes to encourage residents to plant trees in their neighborhoods, fostering community-driven greening. These efforts address urban heat island effects, with Paris preparing for projected heatwaves exceeding 50¬∞C (120¬∞F) in coming decades.
Hidalgo‚Äôs vision extends to iconic landmarks. The Champs-√âlys√©es, one of the world‚Äôs most famous avenues, is being reimagined as a ‚Äúfantastic garden‚Äù by 2030, with wider sidewalks, more trees, and reduced car lanes. These projects not only enhance Paris‚Äôs aesthetic appeal but also improve air quality and urban resilience.
Making the Seine Swimmable
A hallmark of Hidalgo‚Äôs environmental legacy is her commitment to cleaning the Seine River, a symbolic and practical endeavor. Decades of pollution rendered the Seine unsafe for swimming, but Hidalgo promised to make it swimmable by the 2024 Olympic and Paralympic Games. Her administration invested heavily in wastewater treatment and stormwater management, resulting in a cleaner river. In July 2024, Hidalgo herself swam in the Seine to demonstrate its safety, a highly publicized moment that underscores her commitment to environmental progress.
The Olympics provided a platform to showcase sustainable urban practices. Temporary venues minimized new construction, single-use plastics were restricted, and equipment was redistributed for reuse. These efforts halved emissions compared to the 2012 London Olympics, aligning with Paris‚Äôs carbon-neutral ambitions.
Global Leadership in Climate Action
Hidalgo‚Äôs influence extends beyond Paris through her roles in global climate networks. As chair of C40 Cities from 2016 to 2019, she advocated for urban climate leadership, emphasizing the role of cities in meeting Paris Agreement goals. In 2023, she was appointed a Global Ambassador for the Global Covenant of Mayors for Climate & Energy, where she pushes for city-level climate financing and ambitious emissions targets. Her work with figures like Michael Bloomberg and other mayors has fostered international collaboration on green policies.
Hidalgo‚Äôs leadership during the 2015 COP21 summit, where the Paris Agreement was adopted, cemented her reputation as a climate advocate. She co-hosted the Climate Summit for Local Leaders, empowering cities to set bold emissions targets. Her global advocacy underscores her belief that local actions drive systemic change, a principle reflected in Paris‚Äôs recognition with a UN Climate Action Award at COP26.
Visionary Leader
Ms Hidalgo argues that her policies, though polarizing, are necessary to address the climate crisis, a stance echoed by supporters like the former U.S. Vice President Al Gore, who called her a ‚Äúvisionary leader.‚Äù
A Legacy for the Future
Her decade-long tenure has left an indelible mark on Paris, transforming it into a model of sustainable urban living. From reducing emissions by 25% between 2004 and 2018 to creating 45 kilometers of new parks and 180 car-free ‚Äúschool streets,‚Äù Hidalgo‚Äôs policies have prioritised nature and human-centric urban design.
Her work has inspired cities globally, proving that bold local action can address planetary challenges. As Paris prepares for a future of climate resilience, Hidalgo‚Äôs legacy‚Äîbike-filled streets, verdant parks, and a swimmable Seine‚Äîstands as a testament to her unwavering commitment to nature and a better future. In her words, ‚ÄúWe have to dare, because tomorrow it will be too late.
Regards and a respectful salute to this great Climate Leader and Citizen Of Mother¬†Earth, Ms Anne Hidalgo. It is because of the climate action by world citizens and leaders like you, life on Earth is safe for all living beings.

Before I moved to France, I used to think that French people were arrogant about their food.
Now that I‚Äôve lived here for almost four years, I ‚Äònow‚Äô think that French people are very arrogant about their food.
It‚Äôs not that people here aren‚Äôt open to other cuisines. Heck, they seem to rate Italian and Japanese food pretty highly.
And it‚Äôs not that people from other countries don‚Äôt hold supremacist views of their own ‚Äî at least as far as food is concerned.
But when it comes to questions about culinary sophistication, French people, by and large, take it as self-evident that French food is in a league of its own.
In a country where everything is subject to debate, questions as to French food‚Äôs superiority remain, ironically, off the table.
I‚Äôm painting in broad strokes, of course; not everyone thinks this way. But given how many times I‚Äôve been privy to French people talking merde about other cuisines, I feel pretty confident about making this claim.
Make no mistake ‚Äî I love France and the French people. It‚Äôs just that French arrogance about food is a tad annoying.

Since learning that the Louvre is undoubtedly the biggest art museum in the world, I have always been keen to visit this famous sight. My partner and I are both artists, and he wanted to see the Louvre, too. The only problem was that neither of us had any desire to visit Paris, and in fact, we were both a bit intimidated by it.
I can‚Äôt say exactly why this was. Maybe it was purely the fact that Paris is the most visited city in the world, and we tend to try to stay away from tourist traps as much as possible. Maybe it was because we heard that Parisians hate foreigners who don‚Äôt speak French.
It also might be because we heard that Paris is one of the pickpocket capitals of the world. And, oh yeah, we had heard that people were rude and unwelcoming.
Whatever the reasons were, they are long lost in my memory now because I can firmly say that Paris was not one of the stereotypes we had heard, and both of us were pleasantly surprised by the city and its residents.
I‚Äôve said it before, and I will say it again: traveling to a place and experiencing it yourself is the only way to truly understand it. Trying to decide if‚Ä¶

Title: Family-Friendly Paris? Oui!
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

--

Listen
Share
Prior to parenthood, I lived in Paris, married a Frenchman, and enjoyed la bonne vie in our 12th arrondissement neighborhood between the Bastille and the Gare De Lyon. I buffed up my French, eked out a living writing and leading walking tours, and frittered away many a glorious day in open-air markets, museums, and cafes. Then came a move to America after several years in France, and before I knew it, ten years had passed without a trip back to my favorite city. I decided that the time had come to rediscover Paris ‚Äî and that my young daughter would make a perfect traveling companion. Not that Camille would be inclined to spend hours admiring Picassos or sampling French cuisine. Like many kids, she pooh-poohs art museums and ‚Äúweird‚Äù food. Rather, her raison d‚Äôetre in Paris was to rocket to the top of the Eiffel Tower. So, with that in mind, we kissed Dad goodbye, reiterated cat-care instructions, and set out to spend two weeks in France.
My mission when traveling long distances with my daughter is to plan activities that she will look forward to, then have a backup in case Plan A unravels. During our first days in Paris, we stuck close to our flat in the 2nd arrondissement and saved exuberant excursions for the mornings, when we had more stamina. We began with a 10-minute walk to the Centre Georges Pompidou, also known as Beaubourg.
‚ÄúPompidou! Is there really someone named Pompidou?‚Äù giggled Camille, gaping at one of the three most widely visited cultural site in the France.
‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù I replied. ‚ÄúPompidou was a French president who liked modern art.‚Äù
‚ÄúIs that modern art?‚Äù she gasped, staring at the tangle of pipes and tubes looming above our heads.
People flock to Beaubourg for various reasons‚Äìthe mishmash of modern architecture, the dance and theatrical spaces, the cavernous modern art museum on the fourth floor‚Äìbut foremost, it is a fine family venue. Admission is free for kids, and there is plenty of room to move around, with a stew of mimes, musicians, jugglers, and portrait artists to entertain everyone standing in line. Our favorite part of the visit, though, was the panoramic view from Pompidou‚Äôs glass escalator.
‚ÄúThere it is, Mom,‚Äù shouted Camille, spotting the Eiffel Tower.
‚ÄúAnd over there is Notre Dame and Quasimodo‚Äôs bell tower,‚Äù I pointed out as I thought about lunch. Because of the time change, Camille and I always seemed to be hungry. Outside, we grabbed two seats at one of the creperies surrounding the Fontaine Stravinsky, which boasts an array of whimsical figures that spiral and spit water in the air.
Feeling very French, I ordered a salmon crepe for me and a sugar one for Camille.
‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs that?‚Äù cried my daughter, glaring at the thin, speckled brown pancake being placed in front of her. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not like the crepes we eat at home!‚Äù
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a French buckwheat crepe from Brittany,‚Äù I explained.
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt like it, Mom. It looks strange.‚Äù
In a city where food is art, eating would become our biggest challenge. A litany of complaints accompanied each meal: The cheese smelled like bad breath, the mustard was the wrong shade of yellow, and the cr√®me fra√éche wasn‚Äôt real whipped cream.
‚ÄúEat,‚Äù I implored, sounding like my mother. ‚ÄúThere is no better food on the planet than here.‚Äù
After the crepe meltdown, we agreed on a culinary compromise, starting with croissants and cocoa for breakfast. Two blocks from our flat, we hit the croissant jackpot on rue Montorgueil. This cobblestone lane is a quintessential slice of French life. Vendors proudly hawk pretty produce from wooden carts as Frenchmen, heads buried behind Le Monde, sip thimble-size cups of coffee at sidewalk cafes. The bonus on the block, though, is La P√¢tissier Stohrer, the oldest family bakery in Paris, boasting crusty croissants that are considered by many the best in the city.
Lines! If the Guinness Book of Long Lines existed, the Eiffel Tour would top the chart. Rain or shine, there‚Äôs always a huge crowd winding around the tower.
‚ÄúAchh,‚Äù I groaned the afternoon we visited, calculating the four-hour wait.
‚ÄúForget the elevator, Mom,‚Äù said Camille. ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs climb to the top. It‚Äôs a shorter line.‚Äù
It certainly was: Forty-five minutes later, we were on our way up the mighty monument. ‚ÄúOoh la la, look at Paris!‚Äù I exclaimed as we arrived at the tower‚Äôs second tier, mercifully the maximum for climbers. Feeling giddy, we took turns taking pictures in every direction.
The next day, we set out to find what my hometown newspaper calls ‚Äúthe best crepes in Paris.‚Äù On rue Cler in the 7th arrondissement, we joined a gaggle of crepe aficionados and watched a monsieur drop dollops of ivory batter onto a grill. Thirty seconds later, he flipped the bubbling batter and slathered it with chocolate. ‚ÄúNow these are real crepes,‚Äù said Camille, licking her fingers.
To get around, we purchased a Paris Visite card for unlimited bus and metro travel. The metro sprints across Paris as quickly as one can take a shower, but with a drawback: It‚Äôs underground, passing below all the sights we came to Paris to see. So, we reserved the metro for night outings or when we were in a hurry and otherwise crisscrossed Paris on city buses.
In the five years I lived in the city, I managed to avoid the Bateaux Mouches, a one-hour boat excursion that glides through the Seine with an invisible guide who booms out information about historical sights over a loudspeaker. Camille couldn‚Äôt wait to board the boat with the rest of the romantics and tourists. Afterward, we agreed it‚Äôs the fastest and coolest way to see Paris.
Eight is a grand age for kids to discover the world. They‚Äôre not tied to a parent‚Äôs hip, and they make friends easily. They‚Äôre curious and energetic, and anything new is still cool. But that doesn‚Äôt mean every day is hunky dory, even in Paris. One big challenge I faced in traveling solo with my daughter was finding moments when we could each relax in our own way. After a week on the go, tempers frayed. I reigned in the sightseeing and changed tactics, letting Camille sleep late while I savored coffee on the balcony. We discovered small playgrounds filled with children. Ultimately, I indulged my daughter in some of my favorite French frivolities.
Our feet were first on the list. Finding the perfect pair of red tennis shoes on the rue de Rivoli swallowed a chunk of one day, so afterward we skipped lunch and ordered two banana splits in the first cafe we spied along the Seine. Our most exciting moments were similarly unexpected and often free: puppeteers and musicians performing on stone bridges, skateboard competitions near monuments, and watching the Eiffel Tower light up the night like a trillion twinkling stars. One afternoon, we peeked into the pyramid at the Louvre, made a wish, picnicked in the Jardin des Tuileries, rode the Ferris wheel there three times, and conked out by 9 p.m.
We reserved one day for a country outing and chose Monet‚Äôs gardens in Giverny, arriving before the crowds on an early train. We loved the lemon-colored lilies cloaking the ponds, the family photos inside Monet‚Äôs house, and the tiny tearoom in town.
Suddenly, our days in Paris were dwindling. Sitting along the Seine savoring mango ice cream cones, we mapped out our last adventure: the five-story museum of science and technology at La Villette, which houses a planetarium, greenhouse, submarine, G√©ode, and more hands-on treasures than we could possibly experience in a day. The fluorescent anatomy section, lighting up the circulatory system, was my favorite. Camille preferred broadcasting a weather report from the museum‚Äôs television studio. I found the old-fashioned waterwheel illustrating the relationship between energy and water clever, and Camille gave the greenhouse rave reviews.
On our last night in France, we donned snazzy duds and our new shoes, took the metro to the Left Bank, and devoured a pizza in an outdoor restaurant on Boulevard Saint Germain. We topped off the evening with dessert at Deux Magots, the famous cafe where Simone de Beauvoir and Sartre often sat. It was here that Camille made her confession: ‚ÄúI love Paris, Mom, and I‚Äôd love to come with you again. There‚Äôs just one problem said my bilingual daughter : I don‚Äôt think anyone here understands you, because you speak really bad French!‚Äù
‚ÄúYou‚Äôre kidding!‚Äù I said in my best French. C‚Äôest pas vrai!
Originally published in Child Magazine.

Title: Finally coming home: why I came to hate living in Paris
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
A few years ago, sometime in late 2022, I moved to France. Paris, to be exact.
I had just been accepted into the American University of Paris. The pandemic was winding down finally, the world was opening up and I decided that I wanted to take a leap of faith and move abroad for a few years.
Like a lot of young Americans, I was deeply convinced that life in Europe ‚Äî France, to be exact ‚Äî was going to be a better experience for me than back home. Looking back now I can see my na√Øvety from a mile away but, to be fair, I had been raised on years of positive, effusive press which often overlooks the dark side of living in Europe, the less-than-ideal reality of France, and my own family members‚Äô longing(s) to escape the United States.
My first year or so in Paris were great, and fun. It was admittedly nice to be outside my comfort zone, in a place I wasn‚Äôt really all that familiar with, in a city I had only ever vacationed in. But as I began to ‚Äúsettle‚Äù into the city, I felt this lingering sense of discomfort start crawling over me. My first Parisian apartment, in the 7th, so close to the Eiffel Tower I could practically see it from my window, started to feel like an isolating prison. I felt frustrated, depressed, and mind-numbingly bored, but I wasn‚Äôt entirely sure if it was just stress from my studies or something else coming up to the surface. I think in many ways I was afraid to acknowledge the truth.
Then my mother died unexpectedly from cancer in the spring of 2024 and my life changed overnight. Home in the States for a few months dealing with her affairs, I had a lot of time to think about my life so far and whether or not I was truly following the right path.
The answer to that was a very resounding NO.
So, I made the painful but necessary decision to move back home, back to the United States, back where I really belong.
France was an okay experience, but it was not really all that people crack it up to be. There was only so much of France and Europe I think one can take before you eventually want to melt into a puddle, cease existing. I tried so hard to ‚Äúfit into‚Äù a culture that would never accept me, never see me for who I really was, that inevitably I was beginning to crack and fall apart. And I tried, very hard, even after my mom died to make it work, but one day I woke up and realized I couldn‚Äôt do it anymore. I had to leave, go home, and put my life back together correctly.
Paris is beautiful, yes, but its beauty is, I came to realize, a kind of stifling and suffocating, pretentious, superficiality. When you first move here, it‚Äôs glorious to see old Haussmanian apartments towering above you, all in various shades of black and gray, especially when coming from American suburbia. But eventually, you start to notice the decay and depressive energy emanating from these blocks of grubby cement and stone ‚Äî you see greenish mildew oozing from cracks in buildings, French doors moldering in the corners, rust chewing away at the fancy black banisters. Walking along the wide boulevards is both a dream and a nightmare, because the moment you turn down a corner you inevitably spend the majority of your time hopscotching over poopy pies (most canine but not all), puddles of fresh stinking ochre urine, and other nasty icky things like discarded underwear and who knows what else.
The food here eventually began to drive me crazy. Repetitive, bland, and boring, I began to crave, desperately, a plate of sizzling hot Thai stir fry with basil and chilis and onions and garlic. Or a delicious juicy burger with beef that tastes sweetly of grass and sunshine and not sweat and ammonia, melting in your mouth as opposed to becoming a chewy, grainy mess between your teeth. I missed the variety of produce and snacks at my local Albertsons grocery store, apples like jewels and luscious greens just beckoning to be chopped into stew, being able to make pretty much any dish I could possible think of without having to run around half of Paris to find a tiny bit of garam masala. And don‚Äôt even get me started on things like pickles. What do the French have against salty, crunchy, vinegary pickles? I hate those little petite cornichons with their mushy texture and sickly sweet aroma. Of course I could make them, as my grandmother showed me how well enough, but in my middling Parisian kitchen, it was hard to find space to fit a jar of cucumbers, mellowing away in their salted brine, amongst all the other shit I inevitably accumulated. It‚Äôs not a crime to want for convenience or simplicity; sometimes, all I wanted was to come home after a long day of classes, papers, and exams to a simple and delicious meal without feeling like I was trapped between McDonald‚Äôs and pasta in my choices.
And every time I left Paris for more than a month, I would come back feeling as though the city somehow became a little worse off than before. A little poorer, darker, more negative, less appealing. I think Parisians would like to imagine themselves a living in a bustling metropolis, √† la New York, which I find laughable having recently been in NYC myself. Paris is nothing like New York, or London, or even Tokyo or Shanghai or Los Angeles. Even fucking Toronto is more interesting than Paris.
Paris is, at best, a glorified village ‚Äî it has all the feelings of one, too. Twee and pretentious and conservative in all the wrong ways, clinging to traditions that no one cares about, turning its nose up at innovation and change as though its a crime to experiment and be creative. I found it ironic that in New York, I felt as though I could breathe. Not necessarily because the air was better, but simply because I felt like I could just be myself. No stares as I went about my day alone as apparently, being a single woman without a man or a friend in tow is somehow scandalous (who knew). No funny looks when wearing something other than the usual scarf + nappy old coat combo (the horror). Not having to glower at people over my shoulder as they clip my heels walking at super-sonic speeds down narrow and uneven streets, all to inevitably turn into a smoke shop or some coffeehouse to stand around and do nothing. Not feeling as though I need to explain, or justify my existence to anyone, or anything.
Plus, I‚Äôve had some pretty hair-raising experiences in regards to crime and general grubby, scummy behavior that have made simple things like getting a taxi or even walking down the street more anxiety inducing than I think they need be. Of course we should always practice vigilance wherever we go, but I think when it gets to point you always feel a kind of simmering nervousness about innocent people walking behind you or second-guessing whether or not your taxi driver might pull a fast one on you, something is obviously wrong. Tourists and locals laugh off the crime (and its increase) as though it was funny and quirky but deep down, again, everyone knows it‚Äôs not a good sign. Not just now but of the state of things to come.
I haven‚Äôt even touched on the racism, the prejudices you inevitably run into, the rampant xenophobia, particularly towards Americans, which begins to weigh on your psyche. As expats/immigrants, we‚Äôre given a litany of things (literally! my university would often send lists out) we can‚Äôt do in Paris, or else. You try your very best to ‚Äúfit in‚Äù and assimilate, but eventually it gets to the point where you‚Äôre just dimming your light to satisfy someone else‚Äôs mediocrity, and it actually made me angry a little. Why does everyone need to conform, go along with the crowd, not stand out, not be an individual? Have an opinion that isn‚Äôt like Jacques or Emilie‚Äôs, which also happens to be the same opinion of nearly every other person you meet? Why is it a crime to smile widely, laugh heartily, or feel passionately? I am not interested in living life in muted sepia tones all day every day, sorry! And trying to make connections with other expats was a nightmare in and of itself: I could never accept the habitual mistreatment, backhanded comments, two faced behavior, cattiness, and other bull that many American expats often put up with just to be accepted by Parisians and, in general, the French and many other Europeans. After about the second time of some random nobody making incredibly offensive and often racist personal digs at me, my intelligence, or my appearance, I had to call it quits.
I could go on, but the gist of things is‚Ä¶I eventually came to appreciate America more than I did when I first left. I missed all the wonderful things about this country we take for granted ‚Äî our humor, our food, our culture, our nature, everything. I missed the deep, deep blue skies of California, the diversity of cities like New York and Los Angeles, the beauty of states such as Wyoming or Montana. I missed the smell of the desert and the sea mingling in the air in downtown LA, the sweet humid perfume of the bayou in deep country Louisiana where my relatives live. I even missed our shitty politicians, our goofiness, our earnestness. I missed it all, so, so much, in a way that it was almost like a hunger. I longed for all those experiences, the history, and my connection it. I realized I was fine with being ‚ÄúAmerican‚Äù, and all the good and bad connotations that come along with it. I don‚Äôt have time or the energy anymore after my mom‚Äôs death to care so much about putting on airs or trying to pretend to be something I am not. Take it or leave it, it‚Äôs who I am and will always be.
Of course it took me running away for a while to see it again.
--

The tinfoil is real!

Title: Spending Time in France
Content:
Sign up

Sign up
Sign in

Share
First of all, before somebody complains, yes, France is not Paris. I am writing this as somebody who spends his time in Paris which is currently my equivalent to France.
After one week spent at the home of a friend in Chatou I moved out to have more chances discovering Paris and specifically Paris in the evening and taking care for myself. Frankly spoken, the second week (or first week after leaving my friend‚Äôs home), I spent at a hotel (Hipotel Paris Gambetta R√©publique, 20. Arr., 236 Rue des Pyr√©n√©es, 75020 Paris), so there‚Äôs not much about caring for yourself with cooking, cleaning and co.
The hotel I booked wasn‚Äôt luxurious nor exclusive. But it was charming and so was the neighborhood. And it gave me a first glimpse of what life is like there. The Rue des Pyr√©n√©es in the 20th Arrondissement is a nice street. Crowded, vibrant, and welcoming. When I left the hotel, everything you need to live was available in a radius of a five-minute walk.
In the area I had four supermarkets (supermarch√© like Carrefour City, Franprix, U Express, Picard for frozen products and other, smaller ones), bars and restaurants, stores (magasins) for e.g. fruits and vegetables, bakeries (boulangeries), butchers (boucheries), laundries (laveries), post offices, police, hospital, an elementary school (ecole) and so on.
My hotel provided a water heater for tee (and probably soups). So, without a kitchen, I used to go out dining. This, you can imagine, is not always cheap. But it was a way to discover different cuisines if it was halal.
Among others I visited an Indian restaurant, Sohna Punjab. It has been the first time I ever visited an Indian restaurant and I don‚Äôt regret it. I like spicy food and Sohna Punjab had spicy food. It was tasty and filling. Other restaurants I visited were a Turkish pizzeria and a Turkish diner across the street. Many Turkish restaurants, right? Right. I enjoy Turkish food.
Of course I didn‚Äôt just eat. I used to walk around to discover Paris. And I wasn‚Äôt looking for main attractions, but for the city itself. During my first week in Chatou, I saw the suburbs of what I would say was the middle-class or upper middle-class. Now it was about Paris itself. I most of the time walked in the 20th, 19th, 10th and 12th arrondissement.
Of course, I did it partly with my bicycle, even though I didn‚Äôt ride as often as I planned. This, I hope, is about to change.
Did I go shopping? Did I spend money on souvenirs? No, I didn‚Äôt. Apart from the fact that for future travel I don‚Äôt need more weight in my luggage, I had no interest in getting more plastics or decoration to stuff my future home. What I‚Äôve bought was a magnet for my cousin. She loves magnets and so I got her one when I ‚Äî you guessed right ‚Äî discovered Paris and ‚Äî right again ‚Äî went to a restaurant (right, Turkish).
You can walk miles and miles in Paris. You surely don‚Äôt have to. Paris offers a lot of busses, trains and subways (Metro). But I barely use them if there‚Äôs no need to. I prefer walking, with my rucksack (sac a dos) on my back. Or, of course, with my bicycle. As I have already said, I didn‚Äôt spend as much time on riding, so I only rode the bike from Chatou to the 20th Arrondissement and then, later, I cruised a bit more than 11 kilometers in the 20ths.
And this is not all. Before moving to the new apartment, I used to visit Montmartre. Montmartre is a neighborhood in the 18th arrondissement, in the shadow of the church Sacre Coeur. I went there by using my feet. This is why I walked through areas surrounding the Garre de Nord. In some guides people say these areas were the most dangerous ones in Paris. When I‚Äôve been walking in these areas, I didn‚Äôt feel threatened, but I realized that it was dirtier, poorer. It was the Paris you don‚Äôt see often in travel reports.
The contrast between the tourist hotspot Sacre Coeur and Montmartre (which lost the charm of an artist neighborhood to an overpriced tourism hotspot) couldn‚Äôt be wider. Souvenir shops, all selling the same stuff, and diners and restaurants selling over-sugared food, are welcoming tourists looking for a nice snapshot of Paris. I don‚Äôt blame the tourists, but the attractiveness of the city, I assume, is changing the identity of a city to please them with food (yes, I ate Turkish often, you‚Äôre right) which makes you feel that the city turns into a funfair. Despite that, I like Paris. And this is the reason, why I extended my stay in the city.
If you want to read more about my stay in Paris, visit my profile again. More posts are being published in the future. In the next article I will talk about living in the 17th Arrondissement, the Champs-Elysees, the Arc de Triomphe and the Eiffel Tower at night.

After planning the trip for over a year, we were finally here. Our bags having been dropped off at the hotel, my wife, Sarah, and I were on a walk through Les Marais in Paris. Yes, that‚Äôs Paris, France. I had to remind myself a couple of times on this first walk just to be sure.
Then we turned a corner and the Seine itself coursed away in front of us. Notre Dame stretched to the sky and its glory was somehow undimmed by the scaffolding that has adorned it since the fateful fire in 2019. Then finally, after walking a few miles, grabbing dinner, and taking an Uber when our legs wouldn‚Äôt carry us one step further, we saw the Eiffel Tower. We were here.
That split second of traveler euphoria was quickly squelched as ‚Äî no more than a minute after we had stepped out of the Uber ‚Äî the rain started. It was slow at first. Sun was even breaking through and splashing over the famous curved iron. But then the rains really came.
We tried to hail an Uber, but none were available ‚Äî probably because we were now part of a growing throng of people huddled underneath the measly branches of landscaped trees near the queue for the Tower. We looked at each other through rain-soaked eyelashes; our clothes were drenched.
--
--

By explorers with adventure in their DNA and a story to tell.

Title: I‚Äôve been an Englishman in Paris for 20 years. Here‚Äôs what I‚Äôve learned.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I was 32 years old when I got the email that brought me to France. By then the course of my life looked pretty much circumscribed. Like many English people I spoke no foreign languages, and there was little to indicate that I would one day live abroad, apart from a taste for subtitled films, croissants and novels in translation.
Weekday mornings I took the Tube to my mildly enjoyable job at an advertising trade magazine, picking up a copy of The Times to read along the way. At weekends I ate pub lunches and ambled in the park and spent hours buried in the Sunday papers, just like everyone else. True, I travelled quite a bit ‚Äî but nobody asked me to stay.
Then it came, out of the blue. A mail from somebody called Fran√ßois. I wish I‚Äôd kept it ‚Äî but no. Still, the essence of it was: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre launching an English-language magazine in Paris and we‚Äôre looking for an editor. Your name has come up. Interested?‚Äù
Long story short, I moved to Paris.
I arrived on the day before my birthday, so the date is easy to remember. Today, the day I‚Äôm writing this post, marks my 20th year here. And I can tell you, it‚Äôs gone by in a flash. Yet so much has happened: love, marriage, a son, changes of address and changes of fortune.
But that‚Äôs not why you‚Äôre here. What you want to know is: how does living abroad for so long change you as a person?
In essence, I think, you keep the best of your homeland and jettison the rest. And you‚Äôre also free to adopt the most appealing aspects of your new home and pretty much ignore everything else.
Becoming Franglais
Let‚Äôs start with England. I kept the sense of humour ‚Äî that was a given. I also retain an old-fashioned sense of courtesy. I‚Äôm chatty yet respectful with waiters, taxi drivers, store security guards, shop assistants‚Ä¶everyone, in fact. My (French) wife often remarks on how polite I am on public transport ‚Äî not a very Parisian characteristic. My colleagues tell me I‚Äôm ‚Äúa gentleman‚Äù. But this comes with a wariness of causing offence that can prevent me from speaking my mind ‚Äî something my wife feels is tantamount to hypocrisy. ‚ÄúIs that your real answer?‚Äù she‚Äôll say, after asking my opinion. ‚ÄúOr your English answer?‚Äù
I kept a whole roster of English-language films and books and poems that remain dear to me. And I still don‚Äôt mind the rain.
I lost my patriotism. I was never xenophobic, but learning another language has definitely made me more open. I recall stating quite often that London was the greatest city in the world, but I‚Äôve revised that opinion. We all know where the ‚ÄúBritain is best‚Äù attitude led. Living in France has enabled me to understand the cultural jigsaw puzzle of Europe and see Britain‚Äôs place in it. When that piece went missing, I was appalled.
Yet at the same time, I wasn‚Äôt entirely surprised. There is a yobbish, jingoistic subculture in the UK that has always scared and disgusted me. Those groups of drunken young men stumbling around town on Saturday nights. I was delighted to leave them behind. Along with football. ‚ÄúSoccer‚Äù, if you prefer. The first conversational gambit of almost every British male. No, I don‚Äôt support a team. No, I didn‚Äôt see the match. And no, I‚Äôm really not interested in talking about it.
Food, now that‚Äôs interesting. It doesn‚Äôt take a French person long to get onto the subject ‚Äî and I‚Äôve become like them. I can hold my own on the wine front, too. In fact I‚Äôve become addicted to bistros and brasseries, and a basket of bread with every meal.
But there‚Äôs also a particular sort of family meal here. It‚Äôs long and garrulous, with many courses and lots of debate, some of it heated. After my first dinner with my now-wife‚Äôs family, I asked her in amazement: ‚ÄúDo you always speak to your parents like that?‚Äù
Living in France has taught me a different way of being a family member. Be close. Be present. Show affection. We have dinner with G√©raldine‚Äôs parents every Saturday ‚Äî something I would never have imagined doing with my own parents, still less my partner‚Äôs.
Joie de vivre, actually
I‚Äôve developed a different relationship to work and money. Back in London, people worked hard. They arrived at work early, they grafted, their lunch was often a sandwich at their desk. I respected them for that. Living in London is expensive, and you have to earn your keep. You can always de-stress in the pub at night.
In Paris it‚Äôs different. It irritated me at first. In my neighbourhood I‚Äôd try to go to the bank and the dry cleaner at lunchtime ‚Äî and they were shut. The sandwiches on sale in supermarkets and even boulangeries were surprisingly bland: there‚Äôs only so much ham and cheese you can eat. The restaurants and the caf√© terraces, on the other hand, were packed. What was it with these people? Didn‚Äôt they have work to do?
Yes, they did. But they also had lives to live. Friends to see. Small pleasures to enjoy. In general ‚Äî and I‚Äôve just checked this with my wife ‚Äî French people are suspicious of the rich and bemused by workaholics. They are not lazy. But they don‚Äôt put work and money at the centre of their lives. One day, I got that. So instead of complaining, I decided to try their approach. The next day I was sitting on a caf√© terrace at lunchtime, eating fillet of salmon with ratatouille and sipping a glass of ros√©. I returned to work happy and motivated. I‚Äôm sorry, but the French have totally won lunchtime.
Emotionally, as well, I‚Äôve become a little more French. I‚Äôm less afraid to show sadness, or anger ‚Äî or even, indeed, fear. I‚Äôm no longer convinced that a stiff upper lip is the best expression to adopt.
I‚Äôve also come to understand the concept of loyalty, which felt somewhat abstract back home. French people don‚Äôt have the easy familiarity of Americans, or the chirpy amiability of Brits, but once they decide that you‚Äôre a friend, they‚Äôre in it for life. Restaurants here work in a similar way, oddly enough. You know that waiter you considered aloof and cold? Go back the next night. Then the night after that. He‚Äôll soon warm up. There are restaurants in Paris where I‚Äôm practically welcomed with open arms. Because I showed loyalty.
Paris, of course, is all about style. My wife thinks my personal style comes from England, as it leans heavily into tweed jackets or blazers, shirts with cufflinks and well-polished brogues. But the truth is that being an Englishman in Paris has accentuated that style. Paris gave me the urge to dress up ‚Äî England gave me the building blocks. Plus in summer I love a stripy mariner‚Äôs T-shirt, which is totally fran√ßais.
Talking of birthdays, there‚Äôs one thing I do that my wife tells me is very English. I send cards. Birthday, Christmas, Valentine‚Äôs‚Ä¶you name it. I take pride in selecting the prettiest ones. But they‚Äôre not so easy to find here, so I stock up when I‚Äôm in London.
Perhaps, in the end, that‚Äôs why I chose to settle in Paris. Culturally, it‚Äôs very different to the UK. But it‚Äôs also only a two and a half hours away by Eurostar. I really can have the best of both worlds.
--
--
British writer happily stranded in France. Author of seven books about advertising, branding and creativity.

In 2009, I left North America for the first time, to visit a place I had longed to see my whole life: Paris. Unlike most people I know, I didn‚Äôt imagine walking the streets wearing a beret with a baguette tucked beneath my arm. I didn‚Äôt care about visiting the p√¢tisseries or buying expensive, designer clothing. I wasn‚Äôt particularly interested in the museums, either.
There was one thing there that I had to see, above all else: Notre-Dame.
I can‚Äôt really explain this. I could give you a million reasons, though none fully illuminate this deep connection I have to a building I had never seen before.
For instance, I love its architecture. The flying buttresses are so beautiful, just looking at them makes my chest hurt. Then there are the gargoyles, so fiery and pagan, a strange juxtaposition to such a dignified edifice of the Catholic tradition. Then there are the rib vaults of the nave, the elegant spire, the gallery of the kings on the west fa√ßade, and of course, the beatific rose window. Its grandeur is so overwhelming to me, this building that has been standing for 857 years.

Title: Marketing is the Surprise Guest Star in Netflix‚Äôs Emily in Paris
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
(Originally written in January, 2021)
In Netflix‚Äôs new show Emily in Paris, a young woman moves to Paris from Chicago to work at a fashion PR firm and finds success leveraging experiential and influencer campaigns for her clients. As I binge watched the first season, I couldn‚Äôt help but notice how non-traditional marketing ideas were central to the storylines. While the show exaggerates reality a lot, it also makes a statement about marketing and advertising; experiential and influencer marketing tactics are the most effective ways for brands to authentically connect with audiences. Below are some of the most memorable examples of non-traditional marketing from the first season of Emily in Paris, along with some relevant real world examples for reference.
Interactive Installations (Episode 5)
In this episode, Emily‚Äôs boss Sylvie makes a pitch to H√§stens, a Swedish luxury bed company, but the client is not impressed with her traditional marketing idea. Emily then pitches her idea for an interactive campaign showing the beds at well-known Paris locations. The client likes her idea and Emily to activates a ‚Äúsocial media installation‚Äù at La Place Dalida, placing the bed on the street for audiences to engage with and share on their social channels. Emily‚Äôs idea is reminiscent of one of my favorite IKEA activations from back in 2013 when the brand turned billboards into real bathrooms, complete with actors brushing their teeth and styling their hair at Paris‚Äô Saint Lazare train station. You can read about it in this article on The Drum.
Introducing Brand Rituals (Episode 8)
In this episode Emily‚Äôs friend Mindy has friends visiting from China. When they are out partying, they celebrate by spraying each other with expensive champagne. Emily is inspired and, when she has the opportunity to pitch a potential new vineyard client, suggests they create a new ritual with their surplus of champaign. Her idea is that the vineyard should create a sub brand of Champagne that is exclusively promoted for spraying and can become the ‚ÄúSpray of Paris.‚Äù Emily‚Äôs idea of a brand creating or endorsing a ritual around their products has proven to be effective popularized by the Ice Bucket Challenge to promote awareness for ALS. Similarly Getting Iced is a ritual created to encourage drinking Smirnoff Ice.
Guerrilla PR Stunts (Episodes 9 and 10)
In episode 9, two avante-garde fashion designers who go by the name Grey Space show up to the AFL auction to bid on a dress that Emily is modeling. They proceed to pull off a publicity stunt by shooting her with paint and shocking the audience in the middle of the show. This concept is reminiscent of Banksy‚Äôs self shredding artwork at Sotheby‚Äôs last year, and shows the strength of leveraging a live stunt to generate press and talk value.
In episode 10, Pierre returns the favor to Grey Space by creating a PR stunt of his own, hijacking the outside of his former venue and presenting his new collection directly on the street in the middle of a crowd. The audience loves it, and his disruptive stunt goes viral making him the toast of Fashion Week. Pierre‚Äôs approach in this episode is reminiscent of more immersive fashion shows that have become popular over the past few years and demonstrate how more experiential and non-traditional approaches to presenting fashion are generating buzz, creating more press and translating to sales.
As the examples above indicate, Emily works with brands to tell creative stories through stunts and real world experiences that invite participation, feel culturally authentic and generate social media shares. If Emily in Paris is any indication of how Gen Z wants to be marketed to, brands should take note and put a bigger emphasis on non traditional marketing campaigns and projects in the coming year.

If Paris is the City of Light, it‚Äôs also the city of dog poop.
Anywhere you go, on any street, in any quarter, you‚Äôll be greeted by the familiar sight of a dog‚Äôs breakfast. Or at least what remains of it.
Make no mistake: Paris is a fecal minefield. And it always has been.
In a city known for its refinement, you could argue that the dog poop here is made to perfection ‚Äî so much so that canine excrement from other cities is a distant no. 2.
Because here, every dog poop is the product of hours of French savoir-faire in the art of d√©gustation, digestion and excretion ‚Äî a celebration of craft that brings the community together. After all, the best way to give a merde about society is by leaving one behind.
So to celebrate Parisian solidarity, I thought it would be interesting to document the sheer variety of dog poop in Paris, before these most humble of creations go the way of the dinosaurs.
It‚Äôs a truism that dogs are allowed to poop next to trees. At least then, people can avoid tarnishing their soles with a stranger‚Äôs gift. But what happens when this gift isn‚Äôt gifted in the streets‚Äô litter‚Ä¶

Title: Mornings in Paris
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
