It‚Äôs been a few days since I landed in Paris. I tried to write the first night, but I got about a paragraph and a half completed and had to stop because I was tired. Here‚Äôs what I wrote:
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs 7:28 pm in Paris and it‚Äôs been an interesting first day. The flight landed at around 1 pm and I partially slept on the flight. Enough that I didn‚Äôt feel that bad and that‚Äôs a pretty good way to start.‚Äù
Just a few minutes later, we went out on our first exploration of the area to walk along the canal St. Martin and happened to come across a restaurant we ate at last summer, Le Verre Vol√©. It was excellent and then we popped into a neighborhood wine shop and tried two glasses of wine that were excellent and with varietals I‚Äôve never heard of before. It was a wonderful first day.
Our second day in Paris started out by sleeping in. I didn‚Äôt sleep well that first night and was up at 3 am not able to sleep. Then, we slept in and didn‚Äôt get out until 3 pm. The next day consisted of running some errands: eating at a now favorite boulangerie, Du Pain et des id√©es, (Considered one of the best in town), getting a new French phone number, going to the Alliance Fran√ßaise to check out the process of the placement test, then walking through the most beautiful garden on the planet, Le Jardin du Luxumbourg, and then deciding to head over to the Louvre, because it‚Äôs open until 10 pm on Wednesdays and we wanted to see if we could purchase our yearly pass, Les Amis Du Louvre. We were able to purchase our passes and decided to see just one thing‚Ä¶. Marcelo gave me the choice and because he mentioned Napolean III‚Äôs chambers, which I had never seen, we went there. I think the Louve is best experienced in small doses because it‚Äôs so so big and there‚Äôs so much to see. I was actually considering blogging about going to every room in the Louvre over the next year, since it‚Äôs something that I really want to see and experience.
After walking through Napolean‚Äôs palace chambers, we found a high rated wine bar with charcuterie in the Marais which was on the way back to our airbnb that looked good. We meandered there walking through areas we‚Äôd never seen and just as we came upon the Pompidou, we turned left and had an incredible platter of rillette, two types of fromage (cheese), and jamon iberico and another type of ham. SO good.
We literally walked outside after it was over, to see a bustlingly busy bar, or street, rather, since half the patrons were outside smoking, and thought, ‚ÄúOh, this looks like a cool bar!‚Äù and started walking in only to find my one friend in Paris, there with a group of his other friends. This is a feeling I haven‚Äôt had in a long time. Walking around a place and randomly running into someone I knew. Capitol Hill in Seattle used to be like this for me.
Today, Day 3, we woke up and I had a coffee down the street at a Portuguese cafe with real Pastel de Nata (which were excellent), then we met our official translator of our Marriage Certificate to pick up our French translation to later include in my equivalent of a green card application. Then we get more pastries from aforementioned new favorite pastry shop and I went to the Alliance Francaise to register and take my placement test. We spent the evening at home, eating incredible organic cheese from the ‚ÄúBiologique‚Äù market a block away and drinking a ridiculously good cider for 3‚Ç¨.
Now that I‚Äôve had some more time to think and process, I‚Äôve come up with some things that have surprised me, awed me with their beauty, stunned me with their simplicity, and with their cost.
Easier than Expected
There were some potential hurdles that I was worried about that turned out not to be hurdles: checkin for the flight in Seattle, immigration and customs in France, and getting a phone. I was worried that a one-way ticket would sound off the alarms and that we would be detained by immigration. We even printed out the EU regulations in English and in French just in case a customs officer didn‚Äôt want to let me in the country. But, alas, they were not needed. I checked into my flight and went through immigration and customs very quickly.
Getting a phone number was also much easier than I anticipated. My husband is an Italian citizen, so he just showed his passport, and they started signing us up for our new phones. Oh, and it was also a lot less expensive than we expected. We got a phone number for 9‚Ç¨ each and then a monthly payment of 30‚Ç¨ which has unlimited calling in France and free roaming in Europe. We got prepaid phones for the first few months so that after we get our apartment, we can switch over to a package that includes internet.
I have been reading a book on Culture Shock in France and read that one shouldn‚Äôt smile too much and that Americans smile and French people find it unsettling. The woman who helped us with our phones was very kind and chatty and smiled a lot.
Misconceptions about the French
Everyone (aside from one, which I‚Äôll talk about later), has been incredibly kind and helpful. We‚Äôve had good service, helpful, smiling people in shops, and very patient people willing to help us out. Honestly, I‚Äôve had an extremely positive experience here in France every time I‚Äôve been here and running into one person having a bad day doesn‚Äôt mean that every French person is rude.
Ok, the one rude person was the checker at the nearby supermarket. I waited in line for my turn and when it was my turn, I put the shopping back on the counter so he could check my items. Apparently, I was supposed to take them out of the basket, because in a huff, he dumped the basket over, toppling out all the items and then glared at me. I didn‚Äôt laugh, but I thought about how it must be a stressful time of day since the line was long and he was the only person there. Eh. Whatever. I know now to take them out when I see him. I tested out this theory getting some groceries tonight and the woman at the other market was super nice and just stared checking the items out of the basket before I could take them out. Ok, it was just that guy.
The French don‚Äôt speak English. Wrong. We literally have to continue speaking in French to people once they realize we aren‚Äôt native speakers or we are a little slow. Marcelo is MUCH better than I am at French (speaking both Portuguese and Italian, the roots of the words are very similar) and he told me this would happen. Just keep speaking in French, even if they respond in English. I‚Äôve been tripped up a few times, but most of the time, I can follow what‚Äôs going on, even if I can‚Äôt say exactly what I want to say. So yeah, everyone has been incredibly helpful and speaks English pretty well.
Some fun cultural differences
You bag your own groceries and you always pay extra if you need a bag. Everyone carries around reusable bags to use for groceries. I still need to get one of those (I know I have one at home, but sadly, didn‚Äôt bring any with me).
Get used to waiting longer than you think. Another fun cultural difference was having at the wine and charcuterie last night. When we got to the wine bar, the one guy who was working said we could sit wherever we wanted and that he‚Äôd be right there to check on us. He gave us menus, and off we went. There were two tables available (and we had a reservation, so it was nice that we had a choice). One was cramped in between other tables and the other had more room around it, but it had dirty plates from the previous guests. We sat at the nicer table with more room, but with the dirty dishes. Surely, he‚Äôll be by soon to pick them up‚Ä¶
‚Ä¶
After about 10‚Äì15 min, we are questioning what was going on. We look over and realize he is the only person there and that he is preparing all the food for everyone. Ok, makes sense. It‚Äôs a small place, but he‚Äôs busy. We discuss whether it‚Äôs culturally appropriate to give him the dirty plates. We could smell some of the pat√© from the previous plate and well, we kinda wanted to not smell it. Marcelo thought that would be considered rude (I think generally American Type A-ness is considered rude in France), so we opted to move them to the other, sill vacant table. Marcelo took them over and then came back a mix of shocked and horrified and said that everyone in the restaurant turned to look at what he was doing. Apparently, you‚Äôre not supposed to bus a dirty table, or move them to another table.
Around 25 min after we arrived, we still hadn‚Äôt ordered. The waiter came by to say, ‚ÄúJust a minute,‚Äù and ‚ÄúWe ran out of bread so I have to go get some next door.‚Äù And then ran out of the restaurant, had a smoke break while he was chatting up the cute girl up front, then came back several minutes later to cut the bread and brought it out to the other tables.
Then, he took our order. We didn‚Äôt know how the menu worked, so we had to ask a few questions and he then had to bring another menu and we waited again for him to come back‚Ä¶ after we ordered, he put together the plate and well, the photo says it all. It was shockingly good. The rillette alone was amazing, the wine was perfect, we both had a different favorite cheese and there was a moment half way through the meal that I realized that the Jamon Iberico was most likely literally from Spain. It was excellent. And my Spanish friends out there will be proud to know that the Jamon truly represented Spain well. Love.
Nothing goes to waste. Oh yeah, I forgot the other thing about the bread. After the other table left, he picked up their bread basket and put it on our table, next to the fresh basket of bread that he brought us. Marcelo pointed out, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôd never see that happen in the US!‚Äù True that. Nope, but I didn‚Äôt mind. I‚Äôm glad it wasn‚Äôt thrown out. It would have totally been a huge waste because the bread was so good. I think Marcelo said it best when he said, ‚ÄúThis meal couldn‚Äôt be eaten without bread.‚Äù
Eggs are kept outside the fridge. Really? Yeah, really. We looked this up last week because I didn‚Äôt believe Marcelo when he said Europeans don‚Äôt refrigerate their eggs. We found this short video that explains why. But yes, it‚Äôs true:
Wine is crazy inexpensive‚Ä¶ and excellent. It was hard to find bottles over 8‚Ç¨ in the store. Tonight, we had a crazy inexpensive cider for 3‚Ç¨. We splurged to get a Morgon, (A particularly amazing Beaujolais) for about a quarter of what it would be in Seattle.
I have so much more to write about and so much more to say, but I‚Äôll leave it here for now. For those following my instagram, you‚Äôve seen more, and I promise some of that will make it into this blog too. Some of it won‚Äôt. Like how we happened to come across a game store, only to find it‚Äôs solely a Warhammer store. They kindly invited us to do a quick demo of the game and miniture painting and also directed us to another nearby board game store that sells the games we‚Äôre used to. I didn‚Äôt take a photo, but I was impressed. Games were similarly priced, or less expensive, than in the US. I seriously thought everything would be expensive, but no, life is not only much better here, it‚Äôs also less expensive.
‚ù§

It‚Äôs been a good long while since I popped on here to share anything about books and/or life, but when life gets busy I tend to get quiet. As any of your in corporate life know, the first quarter comes in like a lion with everyone ready to do All The Things as quickly as possible.
But stepping back in time to last fall, I wanted to share two special trips that Sergio and I took in 2023. Coming into 2020 we had talked about our desires to take our parents on bigger trips ‚Äî rather than looking back with regret when they were at an age when traveling was more challenging, we wanted to prioritize these trips.
One global pandemic and more than three years later, we finally made good on these plans at the end of 2023 ‚Äî a trip to Paris and Rome with Sergio‚Äôs parents and sister, and a separate trip to to Prague, Dresden, and Berlin with my parents and my brother.
Anyone who knows me at all knows I‚Äôm itchy and somewhat twitchy if I don‚Äôt have a trip planned, but a multi-generational trip was something a bit different for me. Today I‚Äôll share some highlights and what I learned from our first trip with the Ricos to Paris and Rome, but if you don‚Äôt make it any further than this, remember that planning ‚Äî along with realistic expectations ‚Äî are your best friend.
Alors‚Ä¶
I have nothing but love for Paris ‚Äî and I‚Äôm talking about pre-influencer Paris, but the Paris of 2023 is far different than my first trip to the City of Light in 2008. Back then we carefully held onto our museum passes as they were stamped one by one, made sure we had enough euros for everything, and bought packs of tiny paper tickets to use the Metro.
NO MORE MY FRIENDS, NO MORE. If you expect to show up and walk into anything, you shall spend your vacation in lines. It‚Äôs not that Paris hasn‚Äôt always been this beautiful or popular, but that international travel is more accessible to more people than ever! This is amazing, but is particularly tricky if you‚Äôre going to tour Paris with people who aren‚Äôt ready to run to and fro, this is where your planning has to start.
After spending some time re-familiarizing myself through the prolific works of St. Rick Steves, we implemented one of my favorite travel strategies when traveling in a group, What‚Äôs Your One Thing? It‚Äôs exactly what it sounds like ‚Äî what is the one thing in this particular city that you must do, that thing you‚Äôd regret skipping? Prioritization is critical on any big city trip, but when you‚Äôre considering different physical abilities or budgets, this is the best way to include the most-desired spot for each traveler (no-vetos!).
[Mine tends to be some sort of museum or cultural site because I AM ME and I could spend an entire vacation doing three museums a day and then reading alone in a hotel room at night but again, that‚Äôs just me!]
The great news? Paris has so many lovely sites and many of them don‚Äôt suffer from a repeat visit. We also tend to have similar travel preferences ‚Äî none of us were there for the nightlife or the boutique shopping or Michelin restaurants. That made it rather simple to make sure that Sergio made it to Versailles and I got (another) visit to the Rodin Museum, which really and truly is my favorite in Paris while my sister-in-law got her show at Moulin Rouge.
With your initial list of sites, I recommend putting together a shared Google Map with all of the possibilities. This is important for any trip, but we found it especially necessary for traveling with our parents (all in their 70s) to minimize the amount of walking or number of Metro transfers. This allows you to make a call on what sorts of transport make sense for a particular city.
If it is accessible to you ‚Äî and let‚Äôs be honest, a lot of it isn‚Äôt ‚Äî the Metro is the best way to get around Paris (get a Navigo pass with a photo ‚Äî it took us 45 minutes to figure it out but I was proud that we did it!). However, it‚Äôs full of steps with many stations lacking elevators or escalators. We lucked out in that we were able to make it work ‚Äî barely. The traffic in Paris can be really horrific but we did use Uber when needed instead of walking (my personal preference) to make sure that we were pacing ourselves as a group.
Thank you, Internet, for making it easy to add restaurants to our shared map as well. If you spend more time than expected in a museum, it‚Äôs tempting to stop into the nearest cafe to eat. However, a little bit of research gave us multiple options to make sure we could find different types of cuisine to try (and was helpful for me given my dietary restrictions). We also split up at times to try different spots, especially when we had differing levels of hunger (Sergio and I tend to eat 3 American Square Meals and the rest of the family follows the Latin country cadence of breakfast, late large lunch, and small or no dinner).
Another set of activities that is great for senior travelers would be bus, boat, or (in Rome) golf cart tours! These maximize the sites you can see while seated, and, if done early in your time in a city, provide a good overview. I did a lot of research to pick a good boat tour in Paris and a golf cart tour in Rome because some of these companies really cater to the unprepared, which could mean more time in lines and possibly a sub-par experience.
Random isn‚Äôt a good plan for big European cities these days ‚Äî you‚Äôll need a reservation for major sites like the Louvre or the Eiffel Tower (which we missed ‚Äî oops!) or you‚Äôll stand in a long, long, long, long line, or just be completely out-of-luck. The Paris Museum Pass helps get you into many sites, but separate entry reservations are often required. In Paris, big sites also mean security lines and possibly restrictions on bags that you can bring with you. This is where a Rick Steves guide comes in handy ‚Äî you can learn which entrance is fastest at the Louvre or how to see St Chapelle before the security line is too long.
What we ended up with was a great blend of structure and flexibility. We planned one key event each day (eg; a museum, a tour, a day-trip) and a meal together. This was usually in the morning, as getting to an attraction first thing can mean a shorter security line (sometimes). Because our hotel had a great breakfast buffet, it was easy to get up, grab something to eat, and get out off the door by 8:30 or 9:00. This generally resulted in a lunch around 1pm, which created a natural breaking point. Folks could rest or nap at the hotel, or we could go to other interesting sites or shop in the neighborhood. This left time to find souvenirs, try desserts, or find another Engligh language bookstore (hi, it‚Äôs me) or even just walk through a church or a park. It also means you‚Äôll stop by secondary sites and get to know them well ‚Äî whether it‚Äôs the very under-rated church of St. Sulpice, the Paris Zoo, the Conciergie, or Napoleon‚Äôs Tomb (aka three miles of walking that looks like three blocks ‚Äî whoops!).
Paris is much easier if you can speak some French ‚Äî and as the only sort-of French speaker on the trip, I was the one who stepped in if no-one spoke English. I find the French to be generally kind and helpful if you are polite (not a loud American) and are respectful. This means saying bonjour when you enter, asking before you handle produce at a market, etc. These are actually very simple things to do ‚Äî any good guidebook can help you! ‚Äî that show respect and create goodwill for an interaction. Most people in France can speak some English (or are completely fluent) and are generally willing to switch to English if you graciously ask, Parlez-vous Anglais, s‚Äôil vous plait? That being said, I knew enough that when we did encounter people who didn‚Äôt speak English that we were able to get by in French (think of immigrants who are newly-learning French to make their way in the country). I think with joy about a lovely woman who cooked us the best meal in France in a tiny kitchen in a market who spoke French and Arabic ‚Äî so my sad French got us through it! It‚Äôs one of my favorite memories of the trip because you don‚Äôt need that many words to share a connection with someone else. Don‚Äôt always believe the hype ‚Äî start by asking yourself how you can adapt to get the best experience and go from there.
But before too long, it was time to travel to Rome. After researching options the most cost effective ‚Äî balanced with the amount of time ‚Äî was to fly. All I will say is this ‚Äî coach seats on ITA are punishingly small and you always need an extra hour in CDG, no matter how fast you think it will be.
So, let‚Äôs keep this honest. Italy is my least favorite country in Europe.
It‚Äôs closely followed by Spain (super surprising given that I visited it with a Spanish speaker, but it was the wrong type of Spanish, the Latin-American variety‚Ä¶), but I wanted to give Rome another good try. I know so many folks who love it and it‚Äôs full of incredibly history and museums, which is perfect for me. Our previous visit was in December, which was a little bit less engaging ‚Äî and we also struck out the food. I also had travel companions that were incredibly excited for Rome, so I wanted them to enjoy it too.
Those fantastic planning skills I mentioned above? These were even more critical for Rome because holy crap was the city overrun with tourists in the second week of October and why is everyone doing a TikTok dance in front of the Colosseum? Given all of this, it‚Äôs much more important to prioritize your sightseeing and get creative with your entrance times and to make sure that you have enough shade, water, and rest for everyone, not just the elderly. There‚Äôs nothing like sweating through your entire outfit, right?
For some reason, some of the sites like the Colosseum or the Vatican Museums make it nearly impossible to get in without either buying a combo-ticket (which might include a site that you don‚Äôt want or an included meal you don‚Äôt want to eat) or joining a ‚Äúfollow-the-flag‚Äù tour. This was completely different than our visit six years ago, and it‚Äôs the absolutely worst. Most tickets are sold to resellars who maximize profit with these upsells, and even if you tried you‚Äôre not able to get these other tickets.
As a planner and an independent thinker I found this incredibly irritating and it felt to me like we had less flexibility! We had to check in more than 30 minutes early for a tour-guide who did a really poor job with the Colosseum, and without a combo ticket for a lunch we didn‚Äôt eat, we wouldn‚Äôt have been able to see the Vatican Museums or the Sistine Chapel (so you‚Äôre welcome, Pope Francis, for the extra donation to your country). Even with my months-ahead planning, we couldn‚Äôt get tickets for the Roman Forum ‚Äî but in fairness, I was probably the most disappointed about that.
My favorite site this visit was the Capitoline Museum that overlooks the Forum and the Colosseum. Sergio and I hadn‚Äôt visited it on our first trip so this was my choice for my One Thing. We did it on the hottest day as some (but not all) of the rooms were air conditioned. With incredible art, architecture, sculpture, and views, it was almost tourist-free and quite enjoyable. The tablet guides were essential as none of us spoke Italian ‚Äî and it was pure luck if you encountered someone who was fluent-ish in English. We also benefitted from an incredible cab driver who drove us around the back way so our older travel companions didn‚Äôt have to climb one thousand stairs to the top of the hill. I did appreciate the care and respect for elders that I noticed throughout the trip.
Central Rome is a rather compact, flat and walkable ‚Äî minus temperates in the 80s and 90s and no real breeze to speak of. Another challenge to keep in mind if you are traveling with older people is that there is almost nowhere to sit down in public in Rome, and if you sit on the steps someone will come and angrily ask you to stand up. I‚Äôve never been to museums where the only place you can really sit down is on a toilet when you need to use the restroom. Perhaps this is a reason so many people sit down in the church pews to rest aching legs and pray for a break!
The Metro is very limited so we used cabs to get around most days. Though they are in theory quite reasonable, we were overcharged more than once ‚Äî even official cabs ‚Äúforget‚Äù to run the meter. Because we usually had to take two cabs as we were five people, it was extremely obvious that a six to ten euro price difference in cabs that departed from and arrived at the same place one minute apart from each other were not on the up-and-up. Travel means getting ripped off sometimes, and thankfully this was the extent of it (or perhaps a slight mark-up on a dinner). We were very careful with our money and passports, especially in crowded areas, and we stayed in safe areas of the city. This is important for everyone, no matter your age, to be aware of your surroundings and know how to ask for help if you need it.
That‚Äôs not to say we didn‚Äôt have great cab experiences either ‚Äî like this man who took all of us at once, or the gentle man who drove us from our hotel to the Vatican Museums, chit-chatting nonstop in Italian, but then, at a stoplight, holding out his hand to me and saying in perfect American English, ‚ÄúHi, I‚Äôm Bob‚Äù and then right back to the Italian for the rest of the ride. Bob was good people.
These delightful local encounters are the ones I‚Äôll remember the most, whether the accommodating and helpful staff at Hotel Lancelot, the wonderful woman who led our market tasting tour, or the staff at one of the cat sanctuaries who knew cat people when they saw them and let us get our feline fix, if only for thirty minutes. We were lucky to travel with two extroverts, and my beautiful and kind sister-in-law was made for the Italian joviality and spirit! Sometimes you envy those characteristics that are so natural for some people, but not for you.
Here‚Äôs the other part of a family trip that you can‚Äôt overlook ‚Äî making space for alone time or couples time. As the most introverted person on the trip, I knew I‚Äôd do better if I built in some time for rest and relaxation. I chose not to go on a day-trip that Sergio planned for Orvieto ‚Äî which was a wild success! ‚Äî and instead visited a nearby church, had a long lunch, and napped and rested in our hotel. A part of planning is also understanding what each person needs from an energy standpoint. Do people need a midday rest or an extra hour to wind-down at night? Or do you do best with a morning coffee along before everyone else tromps into the breakfast room? Take that into account too ‚Äî speak up for what you need to manage your energy and refrain from judging the energy or rest needs of your fellow travelers. We are all at our best when we can tap into the ways that we relax and recharge, whatever they are.
I do love trying local cuisine, so I made a point of getting deeper into restaurant research and we did find some real gems, from a wine bar across the street from stores that sold habits and candlesticks to a tiny neighborhood trattoria with the best truffle pasta I‚Äôve ever had in my life. We splurged for one of Rome‚Äôs nicest old-school restaurant, complete with an incredibly kind waiter who teased and joked but provided best-in-class service and a whole plate of butter on request.
It was joyful to see these places through the eyes of Sergio and his family and to see them again in a different light for myself. I‚Äôm not naturally meant for Italy, I don‚Äôt think, but with a more positive frame of mind there were lovely things that I missed the first time around. And when you try different experiences and talk to locals, you can see a place through their experiences too.
The massive drawback to Rome was the hoards of tourists more interested in a dance or a pose in front of a fountain than learning about the two thousand years of history, culture, and all that happened in this place. It‚Äôs ROME! I wanted to yell at these folks who occupied whole sidewalks such that one had to step into traffic in the street to walk around them. This stupid sort of tourism that‚Äôs taking over places like Dubrovnik, Amsterdam, Venice, or Barcelona, not to mention the crush in smaller towns like Hallstatt, Bruges, or Porto. Of course everyone can want a photo to say, ‚ÄúHey, I went to [insert cool place]!‚Äù You‚Äôve been looking at our photos of amazing places that we visited throughout this entire blog.
But is that the attraction ‚Äî just going there? Isn‚Äôt it more interesting to see the Chains of St. Peter or The School of Athens or Trajan‚Äôs Column? I‚Äôll get down off of my cranky old person soapbox in a moment, but c‚Äômon folks! You can sample great gelato and check out some art; you can get a cute photo at the Forum and see the temples. We are lucky enough to live at a time when we know more than ever about those who came before us and we‚Äôre lucky enough to have technology to help these sites come alive. There is a world behind a screen ‚Äî so if you just want to hang out with your phone, give everyone else a break and perhaps stay home.
Where did I land with Italy? This second trip was certainly more enjoyable than the first because of my travel companions‚Ä¶ and I think I‚Äôm good for now. We‚Äôve visited about half of Europe‚Äôs countries, so I‚Äôm ready to see some of those first before another loop back to Italy.
But‚Ä¶ all-in-all, this was a fantastic trip with all sorts of experiences where we lucked out with hotels and made do with the unseasonably warm weather. The planning truly made it easier to adapt to different travel preferences and needs, and I‚Äôd say the trip was a smashing success.
And now the plot twist. Because travel doesn‚Äôt always go as expected, does it?
We had all packed and were ready for our flights back home to the United States and Mexico, respectively. We had to be out of the hotel by 5:30am to catch our flight to London to transfer for our flight home and the rest of the Ricos had an 11:30pm flight back to Mexico. I woke up in a cold sweat at one in the morning and proceeded to be violently ill for hours and hours. I am so, so, so sorry to all of the poor people on our floor who had to listen to all of‚Ä¶ that, but I was that special kind of sick where my only thought was don‚Äôt die don‚Äôt die don‚Äôt die. Sergio went down to the front desk in the wee morning hours and managed to keep our room for an extra day and change our flights with British Airways to the following day. I don‚Äôt remember much of it, but my body was shaking so hard with chills that my intercostal muscles ached for days afterwards.
This is probably a story for another blog, but I‚Äôm unfortunately much more of an expert on getting food poisoning despite how careful I tend to be with what I eat and drink. That is an unfortunate part of having an inflammatory bowel disease, but I‚Äôve learned a lot through these experiences, and in the future I‚Äôll find a non-gross, non-graphic way to share my recovery protocol.
I was very lucky to be traveling with a doctor (my father-in-law) and a nurse (my mother-in-law) and they have the world‚Äôs most tricked-out travel medicine kit that they opened to us. They were differently unlucky with their own flight delays (a late-night flight pushed eight or nine hours later into the morning)! Thankfully our second attempts at departure worked ‚Äî we flew home without incident (and, in my case, with basically no food) and though it was a wee-hours-of-the-morning connection in Mexico City, the rest of the Ricos made it home too.
What would I leave you with from this trip? Do it. Take the trip and don‚Äôt wait. Make the best of what you have now because none of us are guaranteed good health into the future. In our case, all of the planning ahead of time made the trip much easier and removed a lot of mental load while we were there and gave us time to really connect and experience these places together. Whether it‚Äôs Rome or Paris, resting on a beach, climbing a mountain, or taking a cruise, you and your family are worth that time together. I hope you take it with those you love.
Au revoir, S
P.S. See you soon with a Jan/February book review and then (hopefully) another blog about our travels to Prague, Dresden, and Berlin with my family‚Äî our first European Christmas!

Title: Spending New Year‚Äôs (Alone) in Paris

I kicked off the New Year alone in Paris with nothing to do.
It was my first ever New Year‚Äôs Eve spent out of the country, not to mention alone, and I had only a few short days to make a game plan. Right off the bat, I decided that, given the choice between an all-out nightclub with strobe lights and disco balls vs. staying home by myself with a bottle of red wine, I‚Äôd opt for the latter. But ideally I wanted to find some middle ground between the two ‚Äî maybe a quaint bistro party with sparkling conversation en fran√ßais, or possibly a sophisticated and slightly fancy family f√™te, complete with warm pork roasts, multiple rooms to roam, and a guest list of 40 people.
As soon as I started asking around, I quickly learned that local bistros either morph into club scenes or are shut down completely on New Year‚Äôs Eve. It would be hard, as a temporary city resident, to stumble upon the ideal setting and scenario on my own. I also discovered that most Parisians stay in for the ceremonious ball drop, surrounded by close friends and family, either gathering locally in the city or stead departing for their country homes. That left me with one option ‚Äî somehow get invited to a Parisian house party.
There were two fairly significant problems with this plan:
Then of course there was the question of trust. You can‚Äôt just ask anybody off the street to join them for New Year‚Äôs Eve ‚Äî there has to be some vetting factor to give yourself a little bit of security and peace of mind. So, over the next three days, I decided I needed to spend as much time as possible in local restaurants, caf√©s, and other local hangs in search of new friends to ring in the New Year.
As you know, I like traveling alone and do this with some regularity. It‚Äôs particularly fun for me to look for opportunities in social settings around me to interject myself and learn something new, and I have a few general rules that I follow when looking for the perfect hang:
With all this in mind, I set out to maximize the number of opportunities spent in these types of places over the next three days. Not going to lie ‚Äî this is not always the most comfortable social experience. Here‚Äôs why. Even after I find a location ‚Äî say, a caf√© ‚Äî that meets these criteria, the next thing to do is position myself in a location that invites conversation. If I‚Äôm at a bar or bistro bar, I will sit only one seat away from the next closest person at the bar, or sometimes even squeeze myself in as the open seat in between two smaller parties. This surprising social move, while slightly awkward for a moment, has been a pretty effective technique for me to at least trigger a small-talk conversation.
If there is nobody sitting in that area yet, the next best thing I can do is position myself in a highly trafficked location, make eye contact with everybody that walks by, and smile. In that one gesture I look for people who also happen to be showing up with a similar mission as myself: Making new fast friends. Sometimes, someone may walk in who‚Äôs meeting a friend running late, sometimes that smile may encourage somebody to sit down next to you, or sometimes I‚Äôll get roped into a small group conversation nearby. Yes, I‚Äôll be honest: This likely involves unbreaking eye contact with strangers for a few seconds longer than normal. The good news is that you can practice it and that there‚Äôs really no downside, as the chances of seeing anybody again are relatively remote.
If all else fails, I just use the resources around me and make small talk with the wait staff in French. In my case, this would inevitably throw off triggers and red flags to everyone around me that I‚Äôm not a native French speaker. Sometimes this would work to my advantage and another patron else would jump in and ask where I‚Äôm from. (People typically assume from my accent that I‚Äôm from the UK. On my proudest day ever in France, I was asked if I was from Belgium.)
But even if none of this happens and nobody strikes up a conversation with me, even if nobody sits close enough to me in order to start chatting, I have one strict rule for myself: Stay off my phone. Pulling out a smartphone at a restaurant or caf√© is the kiss of death to meeting new people. It sends an instant sign to everyone around you that you‚Äôre more absorbed with whatever it is you‚Äôre doing, reading, or responding to than the environment around you. I‚Äôve found that no matter how distractedly I fiddle with my phone, it‚Äôs still a real blocker toward meeting new friends in the real world. I try to keep it off the table and in my purse.
Instead, I carry a book. Oddly, reading a real, print book in public does not seem to have the same effect on people with regard to them keeping their distance. People seem to feel less threatened by it, and I get interrupted while reading all‚Ä¶the‚Ä¶.time. The other benefit of having a book with you is that, even if you don‚Äôt achieve the holy grail of sparkling new conversation with strangers, at the very least you can fall back on a (hopefully) good read.
So, with this in mind and book in hand, I set out to make friends and conquer Paris. Some places where I made friends included:
But as of midday on December 31, while I had managed to meet about a dozen new people with these tactics, my New Year‚Äôs options consisted of the following:
Needless to say, this was not exactly what I was looking for.
When traveling alone, it‚Äôs always important to have a backup plan in any situation. In this case, my Plan B for New Year‚Äôs Eve was as follows: Wander around the neighborhood and try to find a happening (yet sophisticated) bistro party. (Note: This plan also also included stockpiling a bottle of champagne and some food at home, just in case I was unable to find anything interesting to do and needed to toast the New Year‚Äôs alone.)
I decided to take on a stretch of bistros in the 6th arrondissement along Boulevard Raspail, within walking distance of where I was staying. My loose game plan was this: Wander slowly past bistros, peer inside to scope out the scene and the people, and see if there is a venue or group that looks inviting enough for me to join. A few blocks away, I noticed a corner with 2‚Äì3 restaurants back-to-back. I decided to check it out. One of them was just a sit-down dinner spot, with families in mid-meal. The second was a bit more lightly populated without any buzz or energy whatsoever. The third, while also mostly comprised of families dining out, had one thing the other two didn‚Äôt ‚Äî a large gathering area by the bar, which happened to be decked out with champagne flutes. Bingo.
Bypassing the crowds who were waiting for tables, I walked in, ordered myself a champagne, and waited. It was 9:30 p.m. Presently, there were two older couples at the bar and another family milling about. I guessed that more people would fill into this area as we approached midnight. I drank my champagne very‚Ä¶.slowly‚Ä¶. But nothing happened. I passed the time by vigilantly watching the jazz combo that was floating through the restaurant and performing for different tables.
Unfortunately, by 10:15 p.m. not much had changed. Multiple other folks and families had wandered in and out of the bar, but merely as a holding area prior to their seated dinner. None of them seemed interested in talking to me. I was the only person there alone. Not great.
From the bartenders, I found out that there would be dancing downstairs leading up to midnight. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre in the right place,‚Äù he assured me. We‚Äôll see about that, I thought. I looked outside. There were now easily 75 people waiting in a line to enter the building. So I decided to give it one more drink before trying my luck elsewhere. This time, I asked for a recommendation and was recommended a ‚Äúmix-your-own‚Äù champagne cocktail with infused gin, raspberry syrup, and fresh berries.
About five minutes later, another couple approached the bar, decidedly younger than most of the other patrons I had met up that evening. They spoke in French with each other quietly as they poked through the cocktail menu, but then I heard the unmistakable query directed my way: ‚ÄúExcuse me, but what is it that you‚Äôre drinking?‚Äù I turned to see the woman pointing at my mix-your-own-drink creation and explained to her in French which beverage I had tried. She thanked me and turned back to her friend. She ordered the same drink. And, had I detected a faint accent in her French?
Going on a limb, I decided to try my luck, and I asked her in English: ‚ÄúAre you traveling in Paris as well for the New Year‚Äôs?‚Äù She looked at my silently for a full 10 seconds, and I panicked thinking how rude it was for me to assume her nationality. But then she replied. ‚ÄúActually, yes. I‚Äôm working here teaching English to French children but I‚Äôm from Chicago. I‚Äôm Alina*. This is my friend, Georges*, a true Parisian, born and raised.‚Äù
This tiny intro was enough to catalyze a full-on conversation between the three of us, mostly in English, a little in French. I learned they were here because one of their good friends was the guitar player in the traveling jazz combo who had been performing around the restaurant.
‚ÄúOh bummer, you just missed them,‚Äù I remarked. ‚ÄúThey were playing all over the restaurant but stopped about 20 minutes ago.‚Äù
‚ÄúActually, they are playing downstairs now,‚Äù Alina said. ‚ÄúWe came to see them, and were supposed to be able to get in to see our friend but they told us that it‚Äôs for paying dinner guests only. We‚Äôre just waiting for them to come by the bar and let us down there.‚Äù
‚ÄúAh, so the dance party downstairs has already begun?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúGood to know. I‚Äôd love to check it out before I leave so let me know what you learn.‚Äù
We spent the next 10‚Äì15 minutes chit-chatting about my trip and their lives in Paris. He works in IT; she‚Äôs a new teacher who just moved to Paris a few months ago. They were both around my age. Georges grew up with Martin, the guitar player downstairs, and their friendship has continued to grow strong over the past decade or two. To show support for their friend, Alina and Georges left the house party to come and see their him perform. They really wanted to see the show.
At one point, Alina decides we should all make a break for it. Realizing that the entrance to the fete requires only acquiring a gold wristband at the door, we carried our cocktails and headed downstairs. Moments later, we found ourselves squarely secured inside of the jazz combo dance party, a spacious room lined on the perimeter with cocktail tables where families and couples sprinkled about. The room was bathed in a fuschia light, with the combo playing upfront. It‚Äôs decidedly classy. The lead singer fed the room‚Äôs vibe by offering us an American jazz classic; her nonchalance and easy vocalizations bounced off all of the walls.
The bar downstairs was lined with champagne flutes ready to be poured, and I headed over to investigate. But as soon as I did so, a man in a suit approached my new friends, sternly telling them in French something that appeared to make them both instantly dejected. At that, they started to head toward the door.
‚ÄúHey guys, wait ‚Äî what‚Äôs up?‚Äù I called at them.
‚ÄúWe have to leave,‚Äù said Alina. ‚ÄúApparently this party is for dinner guests only.‚Äù
‚ÄúBut don‚Äôt they know that you have a friend in the band?‚Äù I asked.
‚ÄúYes, we told them, but they are being super strict about it.‚Äù
‚ÄúHang on, that‚Äôs not fair. I didn‚Äôt have dinner here either.‚Äù
‚ÄúWell you should stay for sure!‚Äù piped in Georges. ‚ÄúIn fact, we need you to stay. Please go tell Martin how sorry we are that we weren‚Äôt able to see him.‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat? So that‚Äôs it? You‚Äôre leaving?‚Äù I‚Äôm annoyed on their behalf. These folks came all the way from the 11th arrondissement to see their friend play on New Year‚Äôs Eve.
‚ÄúTell him we‚Äôll be upstairs waiting. We‚Äôll see you up there afterward I guess too,‚Äù said Alina, eying the door. ‚ÄúWe have to go.‚Äù
And then they left, leaving me alone again. Glass of champagne in hand, I turned to face the music. But it wasn‚Äôt the same.
One of the best parts about traveling alone is that it‚Äôs pretty easy to slip through the cracks. If you walk into a packed restaurant with a line out the door, you can often cut it all on the spot by agreeing to sit in that one awkward seat at the bar. If you run into a caf√© right as they are about to close, as just one person, they might make a late dish just for you. If you‚Äôre shopping at a boutique and trying to haggle for a certain promotional offer on your purchases, it‚Äôs more likely the shopkeeper will let an exception slide by for one person, as opposed to a small group. And if you‚Äôre hanging around a bar at a fancy bistro on New Year‚Äôs Eve for long enough, the bistro owners will decide it‚Äôs not a problem for you to bypass the ‚Äúdinner guests only‚Äù rule and hang around until the clock strikes twelve.
But this time, it didn‚Äôt seem right for me to enjoy this party and the jazz combo while the friends who traveled across the whole city to see him couldn‚Äôt enjoy it too.
I considered my options:
Of the three of these, which do you think I chose?
A few more minutes passed as I assessed the scene around me. Waitstaff and bartenders were frantically darting in and out of the bar, preparing for the shift of the masses from upstairs to downstairs. But I needed a manager or head waiter of some sort. Finally, I saw a man in a custom-fit blazer race by me, monitoring the setting downstairs on his way.
‚ÄúExcusez-moi de vous d√©ranger, Monsieur, mais j‚Äôai une petite question,‚Äù I announced. Translation: Sorry to bug you but I have a small question.
‚ÄúOui?‚Äù he turned his full attention to me. I began, to the best of my ability, a French persuasive argument.
‚ÄúWell sir, as it turns out, I have two friends upstairs who at the bar who I would like to be able to join me downstairs. They are actually here because their friend is performing in the band, and they would really like to see him, but they were told that they can‚Äôt come downstairs as they did not eat dinner here. I understand this rule, but is there any way that they could come back downstairs with me to see him perform?‚Äù
He assessed me a bit more closely. I tried not to cringe at any grammar mistakes I had made in that plea. I thought about adding in one last caveat: ‚ÄúAnd since nobody here is dancing yet, I‚Äôm sure they would be up for it and liven up the room,‚Äù but decided against it, not knowing their tendencies in that area. At last, he nodded, took my champagne glass, and stowed it on the bar to be safe upon my return.
‚ÄúCome with me,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúPoint out your friends to me.‚Äù
He hustled up the stairs, with me two quick steps behind. At the top, I stood next to him and pointed out the couple, and he rushed over to them, acknowledged what we had discussed, and began to lead them back in my direction. He had the hostess take care of their coats, and walked all three of us back downstairs together, calling out what he had done to the doorman on the way in.
And with that, we were reunited downstairs. Alina and Georges were elated, albeit a little confused. To be fair, so was I. But we didn‚Äôt overthink it. And within a matter of minutes, Alina (who apparently had taken years of swing dance classes back in the U.S.) was stepping her way around the dance floor. Georges, meanwhile, whose style seems more akin to that of Danny Kaye, literally stole the show on the last number with an improv piece of pantomime and hilarity as he cheered on his friend in the front of the room. It may have been one of the funniest things I have ever seen ‚Äî it takes a truly brave soul to have no fear and to just dance with abandon like that. At the end of the set, the band got a hearty round of applause, and my new friends had their fair share of patrons run up to them and compliment their impressive dancing skills.
After the conclusion of the performance, I met the rest of the band, including Martin, the guitar player, and we spent the next 20‚Äì30 minutes chatting and dancing. But at 11:30 p.m., Alina and Georges realized that it was getting late, and they needed to head back to their other party. The three of them turned to me as they prepared to bundle up and leave: ‚ÄúWould you like to join us? We‚Äôre heading up to the 18th arrondissement with friends.‚Äù
I paused to consider my options. That was all the way across town, so if I were to attend, I would no longer be within walking distance of my return at the end of the evening. I looked back around the room again. While certainly a classy and fun party, being at this bistro alone was the epitome of finding loneliness in a crowd. Aside from Alina and Georges, nobody else had given me the time of day to chat. I decided I‚Äôd rather ring in midnight in the company of my new friends than around a group of anonymous strangers. It would be worth the trip. So the four of us hopped on the Metro.
As we approached the Concorde stop on the M8 line, my phone revealed that we‚Äôd crossed the threshold. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs midnight everyone!‚Äù I shouted to no one in particular. Our Metro car cheered. Outside we heard the roar of a collective crowd shouting and screaming somewhere above ground at Place de la Concorde. The doors closed and silenced the ceremony. Our driver gave the horn a few long ‚Äútoots.‚Äù Alina started to sing ‚ÄúAuld Lang Syne.‚Äù By 12:01 we were already at the Madeleine Metro stop, and the moment had passed. It would be close to 12:30 a.m. before we would walk into the house party with more of their friends to be greeted by a warm group of Parisians in an apartment that smelled like a mix of champagne and cigarettes. And I wouldn‚Äôt have had it any other way.
*Not their real names.

Title: A Poet, ‚ÄúIn Paris,‚Äù and a Period

Global Literary Theory (ISSN 3049‚Äì8724) brings world literatures into comparison. We elucidate the aesthetics of politics and the politics of aesthetics, and support writers from all around the world. Medium‚Äôs only quadrilingual publication. We support Palestinian liberation.

In Woody Allen‚Äôs classic movie ‚ÄúAnnie Hall,‚Äù he‚Äôs waiting in line outside a movie theatre and a pompous guy behind him is pontificating to his wife ‚Äî pompsplaining ‚Äî about Marshall McLuhan, the prophetic philosopher and educator on culture and technology. Allen gets into a heated argument with the guy, basically saying it‚Äôs ok to be totally wrong about McLuhan but just not so loud about it.
The guy self-importantly announces something like, ‚Äúwell I happen to be a professor at Columbia University and I teach a course on culture and media and I know my McLuhan.‚Äù To which Woody says, ‚Äúoh really, well I happen to have Marshall McLuhan right here,‚Äù and he pulls the actual living Marshall McLuhan from behind a screen who proceeds to tell the professor, ‚ÄúI heard what you were saying, and you know nothing of my work. How you ever got to teach a course in anything is totally amazing to me.‚Äù
Is there any better way to win an argument? ‚ÄúWell, I‚Äôve got Socrates right here and‚Ä¶‚Äù
As Woody Allen said, though, ‚Äúwouldn‚Äôt it be great if real life were like this?‚Äù Which, of course, it isn‚Äôt. In real life, deliverance in an argument is many degrees of separation away.
Except in real life I had this experience (kinda) with a Pulitzer Prize winning poet. It turns out that only two degrees of separation is enough to get a real, live, acclaimed poet to personally settle a question about a poem.
But this was not a movie. In real life, nothing was delivered. I lost the debate.
I organize several poetry reading groups for people who are poetry-curious or poetry-reluctant. I‚Äôm no professor, no academic, I‚Äôm just an enthusiast who has discovered that it‚Äôs not hard to get even poetry-averse people enthused by and often in love with a poem, if the poem is any good.
For one group, I recently gathered a selection of poems about Paris, and one was by a poet whose name and work I was unfamiliar with. I had been hunting specifically for Paris poems so I‚Äôm sure I found this one by its title: ‚ÄúIn Paris.‚Äù I was unfamiliar with the poet but instantly captured by the poem.
The poet is Carl Dennis. I figured I‚Äôd look him up to have something to say to the group. To my private (and now public) embarrassment and chagrin, Dennis was unknown to me but was hardly unknown outside my own little orbit. In 2002, he won a Pulitzer Prize in poetry, eclipsing the other two nominees, both of whom were future Pulitzer winners. His poetry has been published in many important magazines and poetry journals, including some I have occasion to read.
I also learned that Dennis taught for years in the English Department at the State University of New York at Buffalo, where the faculty included renowned poets whose names I did know and have even read, like Robert Creeley, Charles Olson, Susan Howe, Anselm Hollo, and Charles Bernstein. (Disclosure: I‚Äôm no fan of the ‚Äúschools‚Äù of poetry these poets were part of and I don‚Äôt read much of their stuff.)
To make matters even worse for me, I went to SUNY/Buffalo. And I was an English major. And I was learning there (allegedly) while Carl Dennis was teaching there. We were one degree of separation away as I walked past his classroom.
Maybe he only taught graduate students. Or may it was the early 1970‚Äôs and I was a long-haired kid from Brooklyn whose main influence was Groucho Marx and Jefferson Airplane. And Dennis really was an unknown poet back then. So our one-degree gap was all it took to keep me in the dark.
But for present purposes, I now had my intro about Dennis for the poetry group. Everyone had a good laugh when I gave this background about my unknown poet, after which I read his poem aloud.
And for a long while no one spoke. You could hear the silent re-reading, the thinking, the unsaid questioning. We were all engaged, provoked by a poem, and, since the poem was about Paris, maybe a little in love. Here‚Äôs the poem.
Today as we walk in Paris I promise to focusMore on the sights before us than on the womanWe noticed yesterday in the photograph at the print shop,The slender brunette who looked like youAs she posed with a violin case by a horse-drawn omnibusNear the Luxembourg Gardens. Today I won‚Äôt linger longOn the obvious point that her name is as lost to historyAs the name of the graveyard where her bonesHave been crumbling to dust for over a century.The streets we‚Äôre to wander will shine more brightlyNow that it‚Äôs clear the day of her deathIs of little importance compared to the momentCaught in the photograph as she makes her wayThrough afternoon light like this toward the Seine.The cold rain that fell this morning has given way to sunshine.The gleaming puddles reflect our moodJust as they reflected hers as she stepped around themSmiling to herself, happy that her auditionAn hour before went well. After practicing scalesFor years in a village whose name isn‚Äôt recorded,She can study in Paris with one of the masters.No way of telling now how close her lifeCame to the life she hoped for as she rambled,On the day of the photograph, along the quay.But why do I need to know when she herself,If offered a chance to peruse the book of the future,Might shake her head no and turn away?She wants to focus on her afternoon, now almost gone,As we want to focus on ours as we standHere on the bridge she stood on to watchThe steamers push up against the current or ease down.This flickering light on the water as boats pass byIs the flow that many painters have tried to captureWithout holding too still. By the time these boats arriveFar off in the provinces and give up their cargoes,Who knows where the flow may have carried us?But to think now of our leaving is to wrong the moment.We have to be wholly here as she wasIf we want the city that welcomed herTo welcome us as students trained in her schoolTo enjoy the music as much as she didWhen she didn‚Äôt grieve that she couldn‚Äôt stay
Time steals us all away and leaves photos as proof of existence.
This narrative poem ‚Äî a dramatic monologue ‚Äî is teeming with imagery, feeling, and thought. Time, the ephemerality of the moment, Paris, romance, obsession, the flowing Seine, sepia-toned photographs, photography‚Äôs power and powerlessness: the group discussed all these things, and more I‚Äôm sure.
The speaker is in Paris with his ‚Äî wife? paramour? friend? ‚Äî and he knows she is frustrated with him. He‚Äôs obsessed with a 19th century photograph they saw in a print shop of a Parisian street scene with a woman carrying a violin case. He can‚Äôt stop thinking of the woman, long gone from Paris, faraway from now, and lost to history.
We all could relate to both sides of the poem‚Äôs modern-day scenario. On one side of the couple‚Äôs dilemma is the seductive power that a photograph has over the narrator (and, by proxy, over us readers). The other side of the dilemma is the ‚Äúhere and now‚Äù that the narrator‚Äôs companion wants to enjoy while strolling with her man.
Reflecting the narrator‚Äôs obsession, the present-day ‚Äúshe‚Äù in the poem is barely there. We know much more about the long-gone woman in the photograph. ‚ÄúEnough already,‚Äù we imagine the living woman wants to say, but she doesn‚Äôt have a voice in the poem. The narrator simply tells us, ‚ÄúShe wants to focus on her afternoon, now almost gone.‚Äù
But wait! The woman who ‚Äúwants to focus on her afternoon‚Äù is the woman in the old photograph, not the woman in the present. This man cannot stop thinking of that ghost in the image. ‚ÄúParis is laid out in splendor before you now!‚Äù I want to shout at him. ‚ÄúPay attention to the angel in front of you!‚Äù But I cannot reach the inattentive narrator who is just a disembodied ‚Äúvoice‚Äù in a poem, just as he cannot reach the woman in a faded image from the 19th century.
Look how he can‚Äôt stop himself! He promised ‚Äî promised! ‚Äî in the poem‚Äôs first line to ‚Äúfocus on the sights before us‚Äù rather than on the beguiling antique photograph. ‚ÄúFocus‚Äù is what he says ‚Äî just like a camera does. Perhaps ‚Äúfocus‚Äù is not the reassuring word the narrator should have chosen, but it‚Äôs honest because his focus keeps returning to the camera‚Äôs subject a century earlier. He says he won‚Äôt ‚Äúlinger long‚Äù on her death, as he clearly already has and proceeds to do some more.
About halfway through the poem, the sun comes out and it seems like our haunted hero is going to come back to the present. He sees how ‚Äúthe gleaming puddles reflect our mood,‚Äù and he all but says ‚Äúhoney! I‚Äôm home!‚Äù But, no, he falls instead through the camera‚Äôs time portal back to the muddy puddles that his 19th century inamorata is stepping around as she smiles to herself. At this point in his preoccupation, the narrator exceeds the four corners of the photograph and simply creates unknowable facts about her successful audition and her musical studies.
Just as things are getting a little out of hand, the narrator ‚Äî and the poem ‚Äî asks an important question: why does he care what became of his enchantress if she herself, living wholly, didn‚Äôt care to ‚Äúperuse the book of the future‚Äù?
Why does he care? What ensnares him? Photography gives us the illusion that we can stop time right ‚Äî snap! ‚Äî now. Old photographs let us imagine more fully this vanished place in that vanished time, like the prototypical 1838 photograph of a Paris street, above. They let us meet and look into the eyes of the dead. Haven‚Äôt you looked at a photo from, say, Coney Island in the 1920‚Äôs and thought ‚Äúevery one of these people is gone‚Äù? Or from the 1960‚Äôs and wondered ‚Äúwhat became of them‚Äù?
Time steals us all away and leaves photos as proof of existence.
As if answering the question ‚Äúwhy do I care,‚Äù the poem now plunges into the river of time with its boats and flickering lights and its Heraclitean flow, never captured in art, that leads who knows where. The narrator is having, perhaps, a mini-Whitmanesque moment, crossing the Seine rather than Crossing Brooklyn Ferry, seeing the same boats the slim brunette saw (‚Äústeamers‚Äù) and the same flickering lights she saw, and knowing now he must not ‚Äúwrong the moment.‚Äù
When the narrator resurfaces, he knows it is important to be ‚Äúwholly here.‚Äù (‚ÄúWholly‚Äù is such a perfect word!) Across a century, the woman in old Paris has reminded him that we are here but briefly, like the blink of a camera‚Äôs shutter. He comes to see that the city of Paris will ‚Äúwelcome us as students trained in her school/ To enjoy the music as much as she did.‚Äù Her school? The Music School of the Holy Here.
So wake up, take your present-day companion‚Äôs hand, and watch for puddles.
But there‚Äôs a little more to my story about Carl Dennis and Buffalo, New York. Though we might easily have knocked our coffees onto each other‚Äôs plaid shirts in the makeshift English Department hallways in, say, 1972, I assumed that 50+ years on, Carl and I had drifted apart to the expected six degrees of separation, or more.
But no, we were a mere two degrees of separation away. Go know! One of the people in the poetry group, Eva, lives in Buffalo. When we read ‚ÄúIn Paris‚Äù in our group, she said, ‚ÄúHey, Carl is a neighbor of mine! He lives a couple of houses away.‚Äù Wow! So do you know him? ‚ÄúYeah, of course, but as a neighbor, not as a famous poet.‚Äù So cool!
We discussed the poem as a group for a good long time. It felt like we were on that Paris bridge, like we could see the woman in the photograph, like we knew how to be mad at our partners for ‚Äúwronging the moment‚Äù and not being ‚Äúwholly here‚Äù when presence mattered.
But then I pointed out: ‚Äúlook, this poem doesn‚Äôt have a period at the end of the last sentence.‚Äù It seemed odd to me, and I checked my source for the poem, the Academy of American Poets online. Nope, no period. See for yourself.
What does it mean to leave a poem open-ended like that? Poets don‚Äôt do this for no reason, after all. I‚Äôm sure I mentioned Emily Dickinson‚Äôs defiance of punctuation conventions.
What does the grammatical caesura do in this particular poem?
Does it hint at the continuing, endless nature of Time?
Does it signify something about indeterminacy? but of what? the moment? our relationships?
Are we intended to go back to the start of the poem, like James Joyce made us do in Finnegans Wake (mostly written in Paris!) where the final sentence (‚ÄúA way a lone a last a loved a long the‚Äù) has no period and flows like the River Liffey into the opening sentence (‚Äúriverrun, past Eve and Adam‚Äôs, from swerve of shore to bend of bay,‚Äù)?
I even checked ‚ÄúIn Paris‚Äù to see if that worked. It does, if you want it to.
Eva said, ‚ÄúI have an idea! I‚Äôll text Carl and ask!‚Äù Fantastic! And she did. ‚ÄúHey, Carl, we‚Äôre reading your poem ‚ÄòIn Paris!‚Äô‚Äù And he replied something like I can‚Äôt believe anybody‚Äôs reading that old poem. And she then asked, ‚Äúwhat does it mean that there‚Äôs no period at the end?‚Äù
And much like Marshall McLuhan, he replied, ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a mistake. It‚Äôs supposed to be there.‚Äù
So much for the River Liffey.
Ok, the sepia-toned woman, so busy with living, ‚Äúdidn‚Äôt grieve that she couldn‚Äôt stay PERIOD.‚Äù Got it. Message to the poem‚Äôs speaker from two women, one on the bridge now, one there a hundred years ago: when in Paris, be in love or at least be here now. PERIOD.
‚ÄúIn Paris‚Äù was published in Dennis‚Äôs 1993 poetry collection The Near World. Unlike the poem‚Äôs distracted narrator who was focused on the deep past, the poetry group was reading a modern poem written in our lifetimes. But we were like the narrator in one respect: we were enthralled. We were in Paris, and I think we were falling in love with this poem.
And now, weeks after the poetry group discussion, I find myself re-reading Dennis‚Äôs poem umpteen times, poring over it like a man staring at a very old photograph while I‚Äôm working on this piece. It‚Äôs taken all day, and soon my wife and I have somewhere to be. I hear her call from the other room, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs time to go. Enough with that poem already!‚Äù I am here and it is now and we do have to go.
Because the poem above is exactly what I shared with the group, you‚Äôll note there‚Äôs no period at the end. Since I have it on good authority that a period belongs there, I‚Äôm duty-bound to offer the correct last line: ‚ÄúWhen she didn‚Äôt grieve that she couldn‚Äôt stay.‚Äù Ah, so much better!
‚ÄúIn Paris‚Äù lead me to Dennis‚Äôs books of poetry which are now 14 in total plus one book of essays. I‚Äôve bought several now, including his last, Earthborn. Many colleagues and commenters describe his poetry as thoughtful, sensitive, focused on the everyday, accessible, meditative, humane. All true. But I haven‚Äôt found any mention of how funny, how deeply wryly funny, Dennis can be.
In ‚ÄúPrimitive,‚Äù he refrains from killing a spider in his house in order to avoid the slippery ethical slope toward killing a few people he knows. In ‚ÄúProgressive Health,‚Äù he advises healthy organ donors for perfectly ethical reasons not to wait another day before donating their organs. In poems like ‚ÄúEurydice‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe God Who Loves You,‚Äù you‚Äôll laugh but only to keep from crying. Find them, read them.
The God who loves me whispers that he bets that Carl Dennis likes Groucho Marx and thinks Groucho was a good a preceptor for me in college as any of Carl‚Äôs smart colleagues.

I‚Äôve strolled past dozens of brocantes (antique fairs) in my decade in France, but it was only last month that I finally had a mission which took me to one as a participant, not just as a passer-by.
I often tell friends that it‚Äôs important to commemorate milestones as you get older. When you‚Äôre younger perhaps your family or your superiors will do it for you (a graduation, a promotion) but later in life your achievements and milestones can and should be marked in some way. I tend to do this with a gift which I would ordinarily not have bought for myself, but justified because of an achievement. For example, after a month studying French in the Alps I bought myself a Mondaine Swiss Railways watch. I‚Äôve loved the design since the first summer I spent in Switzerland (2014) and was mesmerized by seeing the railway clocks at all the platforms I stood on. It wasn‚Äôt until 2018, four years later, that I ‚Äúdecided‚Äù to mark my quantum leap forward in French that I made in the Alps with this gift for myself.
That brings us to my citizenship interview of a couple of months ago and a desire to mark the end of several parts of various journeys. I have loved the classic designs of Saint James for some time now, but have put off buying one of their sweaters (jumpers, my dear UK readers) due to cost. Good, long-lasting clothing does cost more, and I‚Äôm not hesitant to pay‚Ä¶

Paris is home to the Eiffel Tower, the Louvre, the Notre Dame and many more iconic landmarks. It is the city of fashion, haute cuisine and lights. As one of the most popular tourist destinations, it exerts an enormous attraction to people all over the globe: in 2023 it received more international visitors than New York, Bangkok or Mecca.
When we think of Paris, we picture a city with grand boulevards, lined with stately buildings, between which little alleyways meander. Here locals chatter on the outdoor terraces of countless bistros and brasseries while enjoying the culinary delights.
This romantic image of the French capital is true only to some extent. It‚Äôs not something the majority of the 11 million inhabitants of the Paris metropolitan area experience in their daily lives. Paris has long outgrown its historic core: most of the people who consider themselves Parisains today live in the city‚Äôs suburbs: the banlieues.
The Paris within the P√©riph√©rique (the ring road which encircles Paris proper) is world-famous. The suburbs which lay outside it remain mysterious places.
In today‚Äôs article, I want to shine a light on Paris‚Äôs banlieues: their history, their development and their‚Ä¶

Title: 30 Days in Paris
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
How long do you have to be visiting a city before you start to feel like a local? Or, maybe it has more to do with how you spend your days rather than a length of time. When I spent a week in Paris last year with my best friend, her Apple watch clocked us at about 24,000 steps a day. We did all the usual touristy things: Eiffel Tower, Arc de Triomphe, Sacre Coeur, the Louvre, etc. But I‚Äôve always longed to visit a foreign city and live like a local instead. Getting to know a city on a deeper level is hard to do when you‚Äôre in hardcore tourist mode. So, I decided to pack up my laptop to spend a month working remotely in Paris this summer ‚Äî with the intention to live like une vrai Parisienne, at least for a little while.
One of my biggest pet peeves is looking like a typical American tourist. It can‚Äôt be helped most of the time, but there have been trips where I‚Äôve gone out of my way to avoid it. For example, when I traveled to Turkey for 10 days, I arrived with freshly dyed dark-brown hair and a carefully culled suitcase devoid of sneakers or anything made of denim. Apparently, it worked. A few times, locals spoke to me in Turkish, and a few tourists even stopped me to ask for directions.
This time around, I‚Äôm not focused on blending in, especially not clothes-wise. That‚Äôs impossible in such a fashion-conscious city filled with genetically chic inhabitants. Besides, I need my comfy shoes. Instead, I want to do more ordinary things to fill my days. Yes, there will be sightseeing on my days off, and of course I will be taking beaucoup photos. But when I walk out the front door of my flat in the 5th arrondissement, I want to ‚Äúhave the air of‚Äù a local, as the French would put it.
To me, that means heading to a farmers market to buy the week‚Äôs fruits and vegetables, going for a morning run along the Seine, reading Le Monde over my morning coffee, watching French TV, going to a movie theater, listening to French pop music on the radio, reading a book in a park, and cooking myself dinner. I thought about bringing my laptop to a cafe and working there for a few hours, but I‚Äôm afraid that it would make me look too American. I‚Äôm pretty sure Parisians don‚Äôt mix work with pleasure.
I‚Äôm hoping that mundane tasks like doing laundry will make me feel more like a local and less like a tourist. I‚Äôll have my own washer and dryer in the flat I‚Äôm renting. People don‚Äôt usually wash their clothes when they‚Äôre staying in hotels, at least not the proper way. My husband admits he once washed his clothes in the dishwasher on a business trip! I‚Äôm no better. When I was a teenager, I went on a trip to Europe with my high school, and our first stop was Paris. The bathroom in the hotel room I shared with my friends had a toilet and sink (of course). But it also had this weird ‚Äúbonus sink‚Äù that was lower to the ground and had faucets to turn on hot and cold water. My best guess, being only sixteen, was that it was for washing clothes, so that‚Äôs what I did. Not long after, I learned what a bidet was and realized in horror that I had washed my underwear and socks where previous hotel guests had washed their, um, dirty derri√®res.
Another embarrassing laundry faux pas came only about a decade later while on my honeymoon in Germany and Austria. We were in the alpine city of Salzburg, staying in this lovely hotel recommended by Rick Steves, my favorite travel writer and host of a TV travel show on PBS. We even sported Rick Steves‚Äô official backpacks that I had borrowed from a friend so that we could carry our luggage on our backs like seasoned pros. Well, it didn‚Äôt take long for me to get blisters from walking with all that extra weight. When we got to the hotel, I was definitely in the mood to treat myself to a luxury. So, when I saw a white plastic bag hanging in our hotel room closet, I decided to use the hotel‚Äôs laundry service instead of washing my socks and underwear in the sink. It wasn‚Äôt until I got everything back that I realized it was a dry-cleaning service, not laundry. I was both horrified and oddly impressed at how each pair of socks and underwear was carefully pinned to cardboard and artfully wrapped in tissue paper like little Christmas presents.
Ever since that first trip to Europe as a teenager, I yearned to live abroad someday. I had hopes of being a travel writer like Rick Steves or Bill Bryson and wanted to move to Europe. I also wanted to become fluent in Spanish, a language I had studied in school for eight years but never could master. Alas, none of that was meant to be. But as Edith Piaf would croon: Je ne regrette rien. I regret nothing. I‚Äôve had a fulfilling career as a technical writer for almost 20 years now, and I‚Äôve taken some pretty cool trips, though mostly as a tourist.
Very early in my career, I did have some luck getting a travel article published in my hometown newspaper, the Bristol Pilot. I had decided to do a work abroad program right after college and lived in London for six months on a special visa. After two weeks of pounding the pavements, I landed a job as a receptionist for World Imports, an importer of Mexican beers like Corona and Modelo Negra to the U.K. I had always known that my hometown of Bristol, Pa., was named after Bristol, England, so I decided to take a trip there one Saturday and document my experience. The article was titled ‚ÄúTales of Another Bristol,‚Äù or something like that. It was the only travel article I‚Äôve ever had published.
There was no question about feeling like a local during my London days, that‚Äôs for sure. I did mundane things every day. For one, my job as a receptionist was pretty boring. Most of the time I just sat there waiting for the phone to ring. Sometimes I would deliver faxes or make coffee for visitors. A lot of my coworkers spoke Spanish, so to kill time I would practice translating letters and have them check it. Commuting to work was another drag. There were times when I would be running late for work (yet again) all sweaty and out of breath from running for the train, with a big knot in my stomach anticipating getting in trouble by the owner, Alphonso, and I would want to just break down and cry. But I would remind myself that at least I was in London, and that seemed to make it all better.
So, this idea for a 30-day mini adventure in Paris is a small step toward fulfilling a lifelong dream of living abroad, though I‚Äôm more into learning French these days than Spanish. In fact, I‚Äôll be attending my twice-weekly French class online while I‚Äôm there. With the time difference, it won‚Äôt start until midnight! Another adjustment will be my work schedule. I plan to start at 2 p.m. so that I can still make scheduled meetings with my East Coast colleagues, which means I‚Äôll be working into the night. But the upside is I‚Äôll have my mornings free. Also, the sun doesn‚Äôt set until 10 p.m. in Paris in the summer, making the days feel longer.
Eventually, I plan to document here on Medium how it all went. Will I feel like a local after only 30 days? Will I get asked for directions while lugging home groceries or doing some other ordinary chore? Will I master the European washer and dryer and other foreign appliances without blowing any fuses? One thing is for certain: If I encounter a vintage bidet somewhere, I‚Äôll know exactly what NOT to do.
Until then, follow my stories on Instagram (@pammypez) or Facebook (@pfassett).

An aspiring travel writer who pays the bills as a remote technical writer. Currently based in the Atlanta area, USA.

Title: The Best (and Worst) Month to Fly to Paris on a Budget in 2025
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
A Data-Backed Travel Guide
After binge-watching Emily in Paris (no judgment, please), I‚Äôve been dying to stroll along the Seine, bite into a flaky croissant, and soak in the city‚Äôs magic ‚Äî art, love, history, the works. But I‚Äôm also a data nerd who loves a good deal, so I wasn‚Äôt about to splurge on flights.
I gathered flight prices from Singapore (SIN), London (LHR), and New York (JFK) to Paris (CDG) to study travel patterns from different corners of the world ‚Äî Asia, Europe, and North America ‚Äî and find the cheapest month to visit Paris in 2025. What I found surprised me: a secret sweet spot where prices drop, crowds thin, and Paris still sparkles ‚Äî plus a month so overpriced and packed it made me rethink my plans.
Paris reinvents itself with each season, and timing can make or break your trip ‚Äî especially if you‚Äôre budget-conscious. Here‚Äôs the quick rundown:
Timing matters because each season shows a different side of Paris ‚Äî and impacts your wallet.
November is your golden ticket.
Flights from LHR averaged $125, SIN $350, and JFK $300 ‚Äî the lowest I found all year. Why? It‚Äôs late fall in Paris (6‚Äì11¬∞C), meaning fewer tourists clogging up the Louvre or the Marais. My price trend plot confirmed it: November was the cheapest across the board. Sure, it‚Äôs chilly ‚Äî pack a scarf and a jacket ‚Äî but imagine this: you‚Äôre sipping hot chocolate by the Seine, golden leaves falling, and you didn‚Äôt break the bank to get there. That‚Äôs November in Paris.
If November‚Äôs too cold for you, consider September to October. My daily price trend plot showed prices stabilizing during this period ‚Äî before spiking again in late October. Wonder why the stability? Summer‚Äôs rush (think families on school break) fades, and demand drops as kids head back to school. September‚Äôs still mild (13‚Äì21¬∞C), with fewer crowds and scenic fall vibes ‚Äî perfect for a bike ride along the Canal Saint-Martin. October cools down (9‚Äì16¬∞C) but keeps the charm, with autumn colors popping in the Tuileries Garden. Just watch out for late October ‚Äî prices start creeping up as holiday travel looms.
Here‚Äôs the month I‚Äôd dodge like a tourist trap: August. My price trend plot showed a steady climb through the month, peaking near the end. Why the spike? It‚Äôs peak summer (16‚Äì25¬∞C), and Paris is swarming with tourists soaking up the sun. Plus, many Europeans (including Parisians) take their annual holidays, so the city‚Äôs packed with visitors while locals escape to the coast. If you hate crowds (and overpaying), August is a hard pass.
My price trend plot revealed a wild ups and downs from June to July. What gives? June is the tail end of shoulder season ‚Äî still warm (14‚Äì23¬∞C), but demand hasn‚Äôt peaked. Come July, summer hits full swing: school holidays kick in, Bastille Day (July 14) draws crowds with its parades and fireworks, and Paris becomes the place to be. More demand, higher prices ‚Äî it‚Äôs simple economics, but it stings.
Here‚Äôs the deal: book your 2025 Paris trip for November. You‚Äôll save big, enjoy a quieter city, and still get that Parisian magic (pro tip: pack a scarf ‚Äî it‚Äôs chilly).
Have you visited Paris during an off-season month? Did you find hidden deals, or do you think the summer hype is worth it?
