Title: Exploring Mystical Paris
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Paris, the City of Lights, is renowned worldwide for its rich culture and sophistication. It is famous for its world-class art museums like the Louvre and the Mus√©e d‚ÄôOrsay, iconic Hausmannian architecture, and manicured gardens like the Jardin des Tuileries and the Jardin du Luxembourg. Fashion, gastronomy, and fine wines are celebrated features of Parisian life.
Paris has also been a hub for major artistic and philosophical movements throughout history. Impressionism, Cubism, and Surrealism found fertile ground here, while the Age of Enlightenment and modern philosophy flourished amidst the city‚Äôs intellectual vibrancy. There is a lot to see and do in Paris, and it is one of the most visited cities in the world.
I was ecstatic when my family relocated to Paris in the summer of 2022. The City of Lights has long captivated my imagination, and moving there was a dream come true for me and my husband in many ways. We settled in our new neighborhood, with the Eiffel Tower, affectionately known as The Iron Lady ‚Äî -standing nearby. We delighted in the perfectly cooked baguettes, delectable cheese, and flaky viennoiseries and tried the traiteurs and restaurants nearby. My daughter loved discovering all the whimsical carousels scattered throughout the city. We walked along the Seine at night, significantly cooling during the warm summer nights. I visited multiple exhibits and discovered artists I had never known. The city‚Äôs offering of Classical music concerts allowed me to deepen my appreciation for Bach and Vivaldi, among many others.
Living in Paris has refined my senses. I now have an eye for Western art, an ear for classical music, a refined palate, and a newfound appreciation for architectural grandeur. I have always loved nature and did not think a condensed city would be as magnificent as it would be. But I was wrong. Paris breathed beauty, and I inhaled its beauty.
Beyond its renowned culture and sophistication, Paris unexpectedly unveiled a mystical dimension. It was mystical in that when I visited certain places (other places I will discuss in later blogs), I felt a stronger connection to the Divine, the universe, or, as some would say, God. I was filled with the same awe that had gripped me while walking amongst the Redwoods in California, exploring Sedona‚Äôs red canyons, and watching the sunset on a Hawaiian beach.
This mystical energy became clearer as I uncovered the history of Paris. Around the 3rd century BC, the Parisii, a Celtic sub-tribe of the Senones, settled along the Seine River. The Parisii were one of the many Celtic tribes that made up the larger population of Gauls. The Gauls inhabited much of western Europe during the Iron Age and the Roman Age (5th century BC to 5th century AD), including modern-day France, Belgium, Switzerland, parts of Germany, Austria, and the Czech Republic. They did not have a unified government or leadership but were composed of many tribes who could unite for large-scale military operations. They were known for their warrior culture and artistic achievements, such as metalwork, jewelry, and pottery. They built bridges and a fort, minted coins, and traded with other European riverine settlements.
The Gauls believed in many Gods and Goddesses. Their religion was deeply connected to nature, with spirits believed to inhabit forests, rivers, and other natural features. Druids, highly educated individuals with extensive knowledge of religion, law, medicine, astronomy, and other subjects, acted as religious leaders, teachers, and advisors in their community.
Based on etymological interpretations, Druids translates to the ‚Äúoak-knower‚Äù or ‚Äúknowing the oak tree.‚Äù Little is known about what the Druids were really like, and the recorded history written about them is from Roman accounts, which may not always be entirely accurate or objective. Some scholars believe women may have also played important roles within Druidic traditions, possibly as priestesses, healers, or teachers. Julius Caesar provides the most well-known Roman account of the Druids in his book ‚ÄúCommentarii de Bello Gallico (‚ÄúCommentaries on the Gallic War‚Äù).
Here is what was included in his description:
However, the Roman conquest of Gaul, which included the area of Paris, and the arrival of Christianity led to the suppression of Druidic practices. In 52 BC, the Romans conquered the Parisii and established the Gallo-Roman town of Lutetia on the central island of Paris, where the Parisii settled. Christianity took root in Lutetia during the 3rd century AD.
After the fall of the Roman Empire, Clovis I, the King of the Franks, seized control of the city and designated it as the capital of his kingdom. This began Paris‚Äô importance as a European political and cultural center.
Fast forward to the modern day, I was surprised to see Paris‚Äô Celtic history represented at the Opening Ceremony for the 2024 Summer Olympics. As part of the program, a mechanical metallic horse carrying the Olympic flag galloped through the Seine with a rider wearing a metal suit. It was captivating and left a lasting impression on me. I wanted to learn about the symbolism, and I discovered that the horse and the rider symbolized not only the Olympic spirit of resilience, peace, solidarity, and unity but also the goddess Sequana, a revered deity in Gallic mythology.
Information about the Goddess Sequana is derived from excavations performed at her sanctuary located at the principal source of the Seine River called the Fontes Sequanae, near Ch√¢tillon-sur-Seine in the Burgundy region of France. In the mid-18th century, archaeologists discovered the foundations of a massive rectangular building (57 meters by 18 meters) within a valley near the source of the Seine River, with an inscription that read ‚ÄúDEA SEQUANA,‚Äù identifying the site as a sanctuary dedicated to the goddess Sequana. In 1933, renowned artist Henri Corot made a significant discovery: the bronze statue of the goddess Seine was found near a faun statue.
Archaeological excavations in 1863‚Äì1967 confirmed that this was once a pilgrimage site for devotees. Excavations yielded an impressive collection of roughly 1,500 votive offerings crafted from stone, bronze, and wood. The offerings contained specific body parts ‚Äî eyes, limbs, sexual organs, and even internal organs ‚Äî suggesting that the pilgrims must have sought the goddess‚Äôs divine intervention to heal ailments represented by the body parts. Sculptures often depicted pilgrims presenting gifts to the goddess, such as money, fruit, or their cherished pets ‚Äî dogs and birds. Despite her Celtic origins, Sequana was eventually adopted into the broader framework of Gallo-Roman religious worship.
The Seine, a 485-mile (780-kilometer) river, flows northwest through the heart of Paris and empties into the English Channel at the Normandy coast. Lined with charming cafes and iconic landmarks, it is one of Paris‚Äô major tourist attractions.
I love going for walks along the Seine. Sometimes, I find a bench or place along the quai and sit there awhile. I stare at its beauty as the sun dances on its surface, and in the evenings, I bask in its glory as the illuminated lights of the city shimmer and sparkle like stars in its waters. Then the world slows down, and the city‚Äôs frenetic pace fades into a distant hum as I go within to a place of stillness. I feel a sense of awe, a divine feminine energy surrounding me. Sequana, with her effortless grace, invites me to pause and simply be. She reminds me that amidst the chaos of city life, there is always a place for peace and serenity where my soul can find solace.
Living in Paris, I am slowly recreating the myth that connecting to the Divine in a big, condensed city is difficult. By uncovering Paris‚Äô history and connecting to the beautiful myths of the people who once lived here, I, too, sense the magic they felt by the Seine River, the splendor of the Goddess Sequana.
Where do you live? Do you know your city‚Äôs history and myths? Do you have a place where you could be with yourself and simply BE?
--
--

Title: My Journey to France Part 2
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Helping You Adapt to Life in France

--
Listen
Share
In case you missed Part 1, I‚Äôm sharing my unique journey from I‚Äôll-never-live-abroad to nearly-10-years-in-France-and-counting.
I‚Äôm often asked how I did it ‚Äî and while several of my articles on TAIP touch on how I‚Äôve been able to stay, I wanted to write it all out in a way that could be copied by anyone reading. Okay, maybe not anyone. It took a lot of hard work to build my life here in France, and it isn‚Äôt over yet. I‚Äôll be starting my journey to citizenship next, which promises to be full of paperwork and even more determination.
But, I‚Äôm getting ahead of myself. Below I‚Äôm picking up where I left off on Part 2: I was an au pair, didn‚Äôt want to continue on as an au pair, but didn‚Äôt want to go back to the US just yet. Here‚Äôs how I figured out a way to stay.
I was always one of those people who said, ‚ÄúNever again!‚Äù after finishing my undergrad. It wasn‚Äôt that I didn‚Äôt like school ‚Äî on the contrary, I‚Äôve always enjoyed learning ‚Äî but I was sick of papers and tests and all of the other coursework that went along with it.
Famous last words. As I finished up my second year as an au pair, I didn‚Äôt have many options other than the easy-to-obtain student visa. I decided I wanted to get my master‚Äôs degree. Public education is cheap here and I knew I‚Äôd regret it if I didn‚Äôt. This time, however, I was going to study something I was actually interested in, not something that would lead to a job one day.
I settled on French Literature. I‚Äôve always loved reading and writing and I figured I might as well study the greats while I was in the city where many of them worked and lived. The only wrench in my plan? I still, after 2.5 years, could not speak or read French. In my defense, I came over here only knowing the basics, and as an American au pair, I was required to speak English with the children I took care of. At this point, I knew could understand about 75% of what was said to me, but I couldn‚Äôt speak back. It was a combination of a lack of vocabulary and confidence.
What‚Äôs more, I knew I wanted to go to a public school (again, cheap), and to do so as a foreigner I had to have a certain level of French, with a certificate to prove it. So, I looked around for some programs that would meet the student visa requirement of 20 hours per week. I found two: one at the famous La Sorbonne and one at the also famous Universit√© Nanterre. I missed the deadline for La Sorbonne so that left me with Nanterre.
I applied, got in, looked for housing (and found the deal of a lifetime: I traded 10 hours of English lessons per week for a 9m2 sardine box in the sky), went back to America for a few weeks, got my student visa, and returned to home to Paris. Back to school, I went.
And so began my year-long journey to learning French. I loved my program ‚Äî and recommend it to anyone who wants to live here long-term ‚Äî I was the only Anglophone and so the only common language my classmates and I had was (broken) French. Our teachers also insisted that we speak in French instead of our native language. It was difficult, but it also felt like the best place to do it. Everyone had an accent, and everyone was trying to learn.
I met some very kind people, finally learned French, and also discovered more about French culture. We went on field trips in Paris and the √éle-de-France region and ultimately all became quite close. Spending 20+ hours per week together will do that.
With my B2 certificate in hand, I was finally ready to apply for my master‚Äôs. I still wanted to study French Literature, and so started to look at those kinds of programs. I had a couple of informational interviews at various universities in town, before sitting down with one guidance counselor in particular.
She looked over my resume and experiences and asked why I didn‚Äôt want to study English Literature instead of French. At this point, I had started dabbling in freelance writing and had indicated that on my CV, and well‚Ä¶the whole ‚Äúnative English speaker‚Äù thing. I told her it felt silly to come all the way to France only to study English. Mais non! she assured me, and encouraged me to look into English Literature programs instead.
The meeting piqued my interest, and soon the curse of the missed deadline struck again ‚Äî but it was for the best. Nanterre University, where I completed my French course, had a bilingual English Literature master‚Äôs program. Because I was already in their system, it was very easy to apply. I was accepted almost immediately (again, native English speaker), paid my tuition (400 ‚Ç¨ for the year), and began.
I loved my teachers, loved my program, and bonded with my peers. No, I never wanted to go back to school, but completing my master‚Äôs at a French public university was one of the best experiences I‚Äôve ever had. I‚Äôll never regret it.
After my two-year program, spoiler alert, I still wasn‚Äôt ready to go home. I met my now-husband about halfway through year one and things had gotten very serious very quickly, in true French dating fashion. We were making serious plans for the future. But‚Ä¶what about my visa?
I obtained the APS visa, which gives you a year to look for work after you graduate from a French institution. I did look for a job but I knew I wanted to work in English (even to this day I can‚Äôt write in French beyond simply texting), and finding a job that aligned with that was difficult. I had no issue finding Anglophone clients, but there wasn‚Äôt a need for full-time English writers in Paris ‚Äî or at least, the jobs that I found didn‚Äôt pay very well.
The APS visa was quickly running out, so what‚Äôs a girl in a relationship with a French person to do? The marriage conversation happens. I‚Äôm lucky that I was with someone who I knew I wanted to spend my life with, visa issue or not. So, we made plans to quickly marry at the town hall so that I could obtain the vie priv√©e et familiale visa.
Long story short, I did get that visa and so my future in France was secured for life. I‚Äôm not saying that everyone needs to meet a French person and marry them in order to stay here (indeed, there‚Äôs an entire shady trade in this which we may write about in the future) ‚Äî there are a lot of other options out there including the profession lib√©rale visa, or even a long-stay visitor visa if citizenship isn‚Äôt important ‚Äî but in my unique situation, my husband is the reason I was allowed to stay.
That‚Äôs the gist of it ‚Äî a couple thousand words on my journey to France. I hope it will serve as inspiration for anyone else who may find themselves thinking, but wait, I don‚Äôt want to leave too.
Photo by Salom√© Watel on Unsplash

Title: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll Always Have Paris‚Äù: Memories are Made of Many Unexpected Things
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Fans of the film Casablanca know that when Rick comforts Lisa he means people will always have memories of people and places and moments in time.
The thing is, Paris ‚Äî partly thanks to such films as Casablanca, Midnight in Paris, and Forget Paris (and many others) ‚Äî revels in its reputation as the City of Light, the City of Love, a city rich in history and literature.
Much of that reputation lies in layers of myth, as many visitors soon learn the minute they step into the Arrivals section at Charles De Gaulle (CDG) airport.
Paris is a big, noisy, and bustling city. No two ways about it.
Rose-colored glasses soon fall to the pavement. And tourists fall victim to ‚ÄúParis Syndrome,‚Äù seeming similar to Stendahl Syndrome, a condition that visitors to Florence suffer from too much beauty. Yet there‚Äôs a difference, yes?
Regardless, I love Paris, with all its warts and issues.
Believe me, warts exist. Note that I have visited Paris at least twelve times, for varying lengths of time.
But it‚Äôs understandable how so many of the millions of yearly travelers fail to find the Paris of their dreams.
Take my most recent trip, in March/April 2023.
During the first week, I wound up dodging garbage piled HIGH, almost to American first-floor height.
Tourists crowded every nook and cranny near the city center, so much so I didn‚Äôt get inside my favorite bookstore at all: Shakespeare & Co.
Fortunately, I stayed in the relatively tourist-free 15th arrondissement, about four blocks from the Seine, south of the Eiffel Tower and Champs de Mars.
I also got a good taste of what the city is truly like near the Buttes Chaumont.
And, of course, driving from CDG to the center, you can‚Äôt miss the concrete block apartment buildings and the banlieues on the way into the city, including Drancy, of ill fame during WWII.
Speaking of the Champs de Mars brought back a memory, one that should have shredded any desire of mine to visit Paris ever again.
It‚Äôs one of my most memorable Parisian memories.
Early on a June morning, I left my closet-sized hotel room on the Avenue Emile Deschanel and started toward the Champs de Mars on my way to a two-week cooking class at the Cordon Bleu at its former Rue L√©on Delhomme location, ‚ÄúFish and Their Sauces.‚Äù Since it was June, and warm, it only felt right to wear sandals. I‚Äôd change into sturdier shoes once I opened my locker at the school. The chefs didn‚Äôt allow sandals in the kitchens. And with good reason, given the heavy pots and boiling liquids so easily dropped or spilled.
As usual, I focused my eyes on the architecture looming above me. Rounding a corner near the far end of the park, my right foot forward, I stepped into a steaming pile of fresh dog poop. Creamy, warm, and stinky.
As the feces ‚Äî likely from one of the pampered poodles of ladies living in the Faubourg Saint Germain area ‚Äî seeped between each of my five toes, I frantically searched through my purse for some Kleenex. I leaned up against a wall and scraped as much of the goop off as I could.
As I flew through the door at the Cordon Bleu, I barked a terse, de rigueur ‚ÄúBon jour‚Äù to the receptionist and hurried downstairs to the locker room. I ripped off the sandal and thrust my filthy foot into one of the sinks, pumping the soap dispenser like a farmer milking a cow.
With a half dozen paper towels, I managed to dry my foot enough to pull on a sock and the required leather shoe suitable for the kitchen. The left foot, no problem.
As for my sandals, I would never be able to get the subtle stink of dog poop out of the leather straps. I wrapped both sandals in a plastic bag and shoved them into the trash bin. Then I finished dressing in the required uniform, necessary even for short-term students.
I bought another pair of shoes from a street vendor in Montmartre a few days later. However, I never wore sandals again in Paris during any of my many future visits to the city.
Despite efforts to eliminate the French dog poop problem, it persists.
What to do?
Don‚Äôt look up before you look down first!
--
--
Cynthia D. Bertelsen is the award-winning author of ten books about food, cooking, and history. Her latest book is about WWII France: Season of the Wolf.

In these times, when supply far exceeds demand, and everyone is creating for the sake of sharing and appreciation, it‚Äôs crucial to take a step back, close your eyes, and find new perspectives. Otherwise, you might just end up bored and disinterested, since what you‚Äôre doing has probably been done before.
The unpredictable nature of street photography can be liberating, but it can also present a fog of opportunities without clear direction. You wake up in the morning, not knowing what you‚Äôll bring home, which is fine and wonderful. However, there are occasions when having clear guidelines helps, especially when you are in a not-so-familiar place but want to make the most of it.
Living in the Netherlands, reaching the ‚ÄúCity of Light‚Äù takes about a five-hour drive in an electric car. I‚Äôve visited Paris several times, but this year I combined a weekend of tourism with my passion for street photography. With limited time for both, I needed to be objective.
The solution? To participate in a photography competition with a triptych mindset.

Title: ‚ÄúA Moveable Feast‚Äù: Hemingway‚Äôs Paris Adventures
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Last year, I was in the mood to read the classics, so I picked up ‚ÄúA Moveable Feast‚Äù by Ernest Hemingway:
‚ÄúA Moveable Feast‚Äù is a memoir and a sketchbook of the time when a young and poor Hemingway lived in Paris during the 1920s.
He was a foreign correspondent at the time, and his literary career was just beginning. I hadn‚Äôt read anything by Hemingway in many years, and picking up this book reminded me how much I like his writing style.
‚ÄúA Moveable Feast‚Äù is a bit random, as you might expect from a diary-style narration.
Hemingway writes about his relationship with his first wife and the woman he cheated on her with, who later became his second wife (spoiler alert‚Ää‚Äî he had four wives in total).
He also writes about his friendships within the American expat community in the 1920s Paris, including his relationship with Scott Fitzgerald and other writers and artists of that time (spoiler alert‚Ää‚Äî Fitzgerald was an alcoholic).
The book has many interesting moments. For example, Hemingway writes about being poor and constantly hungry in Paris, which was especially hard with all the bakeries and restaurants on the Parisian streets. Apparently, this is why his novels and literary works have a bigger focus on food and drinks.
‚ÄúA Moveable Feast‚Äù is, if I‚Äôm not mistaken, the author‚Äôs last published work. It‚Äôs definitely a good read, full of stories about Paris and getting drunk with famous artists.
Beer of the day is an easy choice‚Ää‚Äî my favorite Blue Moon!
I do repeat this beer quite a lot here, but it always features different surroundings.
This picture is special as it was taken at one of the stalls during the 2024 Edinburgh Fringe festival.
It was our first time experiencing Fringe, and oh me oh my, what an experience! It was truly amazing, and felt like a month-long carnival. I definitely had a post-Fringe blues afterwards.

Title: Hell of the North
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
People will argue with me on this. For many, the race last weekend: Ronde van vlaanderen aka Tour of Flanders is the best race of the season. And indeed, in terms of spectator experience and in terms of cobbled climbs, which separate the gladiators from the men, climbs like the Paterberg, the bone shaking and long Kwaremont and the Koppenberg, it is indeed a great race to watch. Last weekend, it was the legendary Tadej Pogacar dropping his equally legendary rival, Matthieu Van Der Poel on the Kwaremont on their 3rd turn up the hill, to take his 2nd Tour of Flanders win.
But for me, the race that has always fascinated me, has had this weird combination of mystique and fear, has always left me romanticising about cycling is none other than the race I am watching while writing this blog: Paris-Roubaix, often known as the hell of the north.
A bit of cycling context, the most famous race on the cycling calendar is the Tour de France, which is a 3 week long stage race capturing the imagination of everyone who has ever ridden a bike. The stages spanning through beautiful French countrysides, ending in sprints, the battles on the slopes of the Pyrenees and the Alps, it is hard not be romantic about cycling. It evokes the primitive of emotions. It is poetry in motion. There are two other grand tours: Giro D‚ÄôItalia and Vuelta d‚ÄôEspana, both of whom hold less prestige than the Tour De France. These are the 3, 3 week stage races. There multiple 2 and 1 week stage races as well and then there are some famous one day races. Out of them, one of the key races has always been the Road World Championships which often happens at the end of the Vuelta, toward September. And then you have the 5 Classics:
If you were wondering if there are any other cyclists other than Pogacar and Van Der Poel, you can be excused. Out of the last 19 Classics, 14 have been won by these two. I am writing this part with 52.5 kilometers to go in today‚Äôs race and Pogacar, Van Der Poel and Jasper Philipsen (Winner of 2024 Milan San-Remo and Van Der Poel‚Äôs teammate) lead the race by 1'18".
Simple reason: The drama. Take a look at this picture:
And this:
The start point of Paris-Roubaix is variable, for example, in 2025 it began in Compi√®gne (Which is a bit outside Paris). But it always end up in the Velodrome of Roubaix, where the riders do 750 meters and often end up in a sprint finish. In 2025, the distance of the race was 259.2 kilometers and it is often in that range and during these kilometers, the riders go through several cobbled sections.
These sections are hundreds of years old and are maintained by ‚ÄúLes amis des Paris-Roubaix‚Äù. This group of volunteers, founded by Jean-Claude Vallaeys in 1983 maintain the cobbled sections in their pristine state so that the racers have the same conditions of the cobbles every year. The cobbles, as I mentioned before are the main point of attraction of this race. The sections are graded with stars, with the 1 star sections being the ‚Äúeasiest‚Äù and the 5 star sections being the most challenging. There are 3, 5-star cobble sections and the race has 27 cobbled sections in total. The grading is based on the quality of the cobbles and the distance on them.
The most iconic section of the cobbles, pictured above is the Trou√©e d‚ÄôArenberg aka Arenberg Forest. It is 2400 meter section of cobbles, laid down at the time of Napoleon 1. The intensity of these cobbles is mind boggling especially coupled with the fact that the entry to the cobbles was on a downhill section, causing the riders to enter the section at a speed of 60 kmph. (A highly criticised chicane was added in 2024 to reduce the speed of entry). Even so, the Arenberg forest, about 100 kilometers from the finish is the place where the first selection is made from the group of favourites. There are 2 more sectors of the 5 star variety: the 3 km long Mons-en-P√©v√®le which has 2 right hand turns while climbing steadily and the decisive Carrefour de l‚ÄôArbre, which arrives 15 kilometers before the finish line. The 2.1 kilometer section is brutal, winding and with its proximity to the finish is often where the riders make the final attack.
As you can imagine, the race gets intense as the riders jostle with each other to get the best line over the cobbles, the bike shakes and you see bottles and parts fall out. These sections are narrow and if you get a flat, it is in your benefit that you‚Äôre in the front and can get a wheel change. If not, you get stuck behind and can lose a lot of time. In the words of a former 2nd place finisher and one of the icons of Paris-Roubaix, George Hincapie: ‚ÄúThis is a war, you give them an inch, they will take a mile.‚Äù This race gets even more brutal when it rains. In the dry, the riders just inhale the dust of the cobbled sections. In the rain, they get covered in it.
If the selection hasn‚Äôt been made in the cobbles and there are still more than 1 riders in contention, the decisive move comes inside the iconic Roubaix Velodrome.
For all the twists and the Machiavellian turns, Paris Roubaix remains the best race in the spring classics for me.
In the words of the most winningest rider of the Paris-Roubaix, Tom Boonen:
The 2025 race was the surprising debut of Tadej Pogacar, who at 65 kilograms is much lighter than most of his rivals, including the pre-race favourite and 2-time defending champion, Matthieu Van Der Poel. Van Der Poel also was aiming to become the 1st man since Francesco Moser (1978, 1979, 1980) to win Paris Roubaix back-to-back, 3 times in a row.
The first selection in the race was made, as expected in the Arenberg forest with a bunch of the pre-race favourites including Wout Van Aert, Mads Pedersen, Pogacar‚Äôs teammate‚Äôs Nils Politt and Florian Vermeersch, and Van De Poel‚Äôs teammate, former 2nd place finisher Jasper Philipsen. Pogacar and Van Der Poel kept launching attacks from 100 kilometers out and it became a real war of attrition. Pogacar, who had already crashed earlier in the day, was almost got taken out by his team car.
With 55 kilometers to go, Pogacar launched an attack which left only Van Der Poel and Philipsen in his wake. As the race proceeded, another attack by Pogacar dropped Philipsen. With 30 kilometers to go, Pogacar took a strong right hand turn but didn‚Äôt slow down enough which caused him to crash into the barriers. Van Der Poel maintained a 20" gap from Pogacar until Pogacar dropped off his bike and took a new bike with 20k to go. The gap grew to over a minute, but in the Carrefour de l‚ÄôArbre, it was Van Der Poel‚Äôs turn to change bikes. The change came quickly and though he nearly crashed into a barrier, Van Der Poel was never in doubt as he rounded up the Velodrome to take his 3rd Paris Roubaix win. Pogacar finished smiling, content with his 2nd place on his 1st showing here. Behind him, in a sprint Pedersen took the last podium spot, followed by Van Aert and then Vermeersch.
Thank you for reading!

Title: Henry Miller‚Äôs really up to no good Under the Roofs of Paris.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Henry Miller is one dirty cunt. I‚Äôve never read Marquis de Sade but I imagined that Miller to be a modern day Sade, blending all the taboos he can think about (and I can think about) into one novel. Miller is no stranger to being a banned author. Tropic of Cancer was banned in the author‚Äôs country of birth until 1961, almost thirty years after it made headways in Paris via the famous publisher Obelisk Press in 1934, where modern day Shakespeare and Co. Bookshop is now.
This is the reason I bought the book in the first place, on an obligatory purchase and visit to the well-renowned bookshop. It took me at least a couple of hours to decide which book to buy from the place. In all honesty, much of the book available on the shelves of Shakespeare and Co. are available in other bookshops and for cheaper. But I‚Äôm a bit pretentious at the best of times, so I needed to pick out a book. Henry Miller, who created a career in Paris and owed the city his success was a logical choice. I have not read Miller‚Äôs erotica, so why not eh.
When Miller wrote Under the Roofs of Paris (formerly known as Opus Pistorum), he was broke, hungry and would write a dollar a page for this kind of smut. Paris was known for its erotica back in the early twentieth century, its explicit postcards (which also feature prominently in the book) and smut writing was of no place to the conservative American mind at the time. But this sexual liberation was perhaps representative of Paris at the epoch, and it took an American to crystalise that epitome of recklessness.
In the introduction to Delta of Venus, Ana√Øs Nin spoke about Miller‚Äôs venture in writing erotica, that the collector wanted more, that the writers started to exhaust their personal stories and had to look elsewheres. I wonder if Milton Luboviski who commissioned Henry Miller for this was the same collector which demanded Miller to write with less poetry in his smut.
Perhaps not. Because I don‚Äôt find much poetry in the book. What we read is explicit sex, sometimes performed by individuals who shouldn‚Äôt be having sex. Some of the age is explicit, and the protagonist, Alf, had also indulged in engaging with these minors. I do feel sick at the thought of it and it makes me wonder whether Henry Miller had the same experiences. It would certainly adjust my respect for him as a person.
In the book, our protagonist Alf took part in bukkake-like orgies, a threesome with a midget (which also involves a German shepherd with a generous phallus which I guess makes it a foursome), threesomes with Lesbians, shooting porn, and let‚Äôs not talk about his involvement with underaged girls. All these leisurely activities are implemented in an extensive possible combinations of holes, body parts and bodily fluids. This list obviously, is far from exhaustive. Miller writes from experience, and whether some of these had happened to him or his acquaintances, I don‚Äôt really know nor do I really want to care.
Yes, I can find traces of Tropic of Cancer here with its crude and detailed description of sex, which makes me doubt if I am adventurous myself in that way. Alf‚Äôs organ, John Thursday, is akin to another character that literally always rear its ugly head at the worst (or best) of times. It‚Äôs like Alf has a constant walking erection. Alf and John Jeudi seem like different characters, but forever interlinked to one another and dependent on each other‚Äôs existence. Come to think of it, all men and their wangs are like that.
After the first hundred pages, the book loses its novelty, which also made me wonder if I had grown up too much to read Henry Miller. In Malay terms, we can say it‚Äôs ‚Äújelak‚Äù which means feeling eugh after having too much of something, usually after you‚Äôre halfway through that bowl of Peter‚Äôs pork noodles and you regretted getting a large portion instead of small. But comparing Miller‚Äôs writing to a bowl of hawker pork noodles is probably not the best idea.
In fact, if I can compare the reading experience with another book, it‚Äôd be Bret Easton Ellis‚Äô American Psycho, where the violence felt too much after a while, too caricaturish, far an adaptation of what we know violence to be. The sex in Under the Roofs of Paris is of a similar nature. Never once do I feel the reality of it, however visceral or extreme the nature of it might be.
Now for the million dollar question: as an erotica, did it turn me on? Based on what I mentioned above, no. But there are bits of it that made me raise my eyebrows, and more often than not, bits of it where I‚Äôm just shaking my head and saying yeah nah in my head, impatient for the next scene to unravel. I‚Äôve read the book in my commute home in trains and over coffee, but thankful and hopeful that nobody is peering over my shoulder and basking over the gratuitous language.
On a side note, there was also the matter of Billie and Jean, the former more of a lesbian than the latter. Did Michael Jackson steal his most famous song from the characters of Miller‚Äôs work? No matter, if it was coincidental, then more power to Henry Miller. Another vignette: the book‚Äôs original title, Opus Pistorum literally translates to the work of the miller. Clever cunt, that Henry guy.
‚Äî -
On another P.S.S. read this stupendous essay on Henry Miller by Victoria Best, if you really want to dig deep into Henry Miller‚Äôs life and his past traumas.

Title: I Was Sick the Whole Time: Paris (1)
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I shouldn‚Äôt be getting into the habit of enjoying Easter holidays (or any holidays, Christian ones especially) and annual leave just in case I didn‚Äôt make it to extend my work visa, but truth be told? I do enjoy holidays as a normal person does and should.
For Easter this year, I went to Paris. When I received the job offer last September, I thought it would be proper that I started visiting some other great museums of ethnology or anthropology, so I could learn for my work. A great example is indeed, the Quai-Branly Museum in Paris, which I had heard several times when I was at school. This museum was definitely on my list of must-visit.
It wouldn‚Äôt be my first time to Paris as I went there almost a decade (2015) ago, during which I embarked on a less-than-72-hour marathon of ‚Äúticking the tourist‚Äôs boxes‚Äù: I was in Paris waiting for a flight back to Brno. As a poor student in one of the most expensive cities in the world, I tried to minimse my stay while trying to see EVERYTHING: Louvre? Tick. Ch√¢teau de Versailles? Tick. Champ √âlys√©es? Tick. Eiffel Tower plus climbing it? Double tick.
I was not sure if this time would be better than a marathon, but I was aiming for a rather different route, i.e. another busman‚Äôs holiday of museums and histories. Yet, as the title suggest, unfortunately I was sick the whole time. To be specific, the moment I stepped off the Eurostar at Gare du Nord, I immediately realised my Easter holiday was going to be a bit of tumbling along the way.
There are two categories for my visits in Paris: the traditional way and the interactive way. Although the numbers of places in each category seem uneven, I want to bring out the distinction between this post and the next.
I definitely had to put this museum as ‚Ññ1 on my list, as I‚Äôm trying to be more prepared for my job at the MAA. I was also guranteed by many colleagues that I ‚Äúwouldn‚Äôt regret‚Äù, ‚Äúa must-see‚Äù, and they all left highly possitive comments for this particular museum. I therefore had really high hopes.
I arrived at the museum (with a low fever that was ready to rage in the following four hours) after I visited the Sainte-Chapelle in the morning. The entrance was rather empty, with a ramp that led to the main gallery. There was a large cylindircal space built with glass in the middle of the foyer, which ran through the floors and reached the basement, and through the dark frosty glass, it seemed to be a display gallery as well. (I will come back to this cool space)
Marching along the ramp, there was light and image of water ripples cast by an over-head projector, in hindsight reminding me the ramp of ocean tides that I once walked on in National Museum of Natural Science, Taiwan.
1.1 Oceania
I found myself standing in a tall and wide space, facing towards two galleries: On my right side was Pacific and Oceania; on my left was America. Immediately I was distracted by the large objects near me, which were displayed in a way familiar to me. Many photos of MAA taken by the visitors, no matter how randomly, often feature the large totem pole (1922.265), the slit gong, or the grizzly bear. It doesn‚Äôt mean that other collections are unimportant to them, neither does it mean that they learn a lot from these three display, but that they are large enough to be representative of a nice day-out on their photo albums. I am clearly biased for that I see MAA from a behind-the-scene, research-based perspective, and also I know a lot more collections that can be iconic. If I have to choose collections that represent MAA, I probably wouldn‚Äôt choose the above three. To me, the first impression of Quai-Branly, also the most impressive collections, could be these large wooden sculptured objects (masks, boards, ceremonial tools), but it may be completely different from what the staff members‚Äô point of view.
Almost as a premonition, I stumbled across these two ‚Äúboards‚Äù in a glass case. I didn‚Äôt know that later in April, after I came back from Paris, I would be seeing a large number of Gope boards with a researcher from West Australia. However, looking back the photos I took, I could see that both Quai-Branly and MAA shared a lot of common interest in terms of collecting policy, or put in another way, both museums were formed by early anthropologists who had a close network, who naturally formed the trendy studies of exploring the ‚Äúunknown pacific islands‚Äù then.
I can recognise the very similar motifs of the face mask on the left side: heart-shape nostril, mushroom-shape dome above the head, and two dots, possibly pierced rings for decoration. All are present on the Gope boards I handled in mid-April. However, there are also a lot of features that I didn‚Äôt see on this face mask: The chevrons on relief, and the vibrant red, white, and black pigment commonly used. This object is also featured on Google Arts and Culture.
artsandculture.google.com
!! NOTICE !!
Readers discretion: Please notice that there will be images of HUMAN REMAINS (skulls) below.
Many objects on display reminded me similar collections that I once saw and handled in MAA. Strangely, through this exploration I started appreciating more my work and the reason why anthropology matters: The physical material being preserved acts not only a reminder of the culture that exists (or existed), but also as an evidence that shows that culture constantly evolves, and that artistic choices change all the time. Take the chest ornament above for example. The feathers being a crucial part in Asmat art were incorporated in a contemporary artistic creation. The handbag in MAA inherits the traditional material and presents a new usage, becoming a new tradition for the anthropologists in the next century.
It was at this point when the fever kicked in. I started feeling a cold chill spreading from my lower back, but my face felt so warm and my throat was coarse. I thought, however, that I was simply dehydrated, which was why I persevered.
Remember the huge cylindrical space mentioned before? I reached the end of the Oceania zone and met it again. Seeing through the glass, I saw shelves and storage units stacked neatly, with musical instruments arranged among them. Originally I thought it was a behind-the-scene display, allowing the public to see what a music storage house would look like. The tags on objects made sense. However, I was wrong, at least not entirely wrong. It was an exhibition ‚ÄúStorage of the unspoken‚Äù (La reserve de non-dits) by Youmna Saba, who explored the ‚Äúsonic behaviour‚Äù of the ethnographic musical instruments. In the English booklet, I shared the same frustration as the artist explained,
[‚Ä¶] a great enthusiasm, then a lack of breath, before frustration set in. What can an instrument express in a dark glass tower the public only passes by?
The irony of preserving anthropological objects is that the method to extend the life span is exact the same to stifle the purpose of its life. There comes the philosophical question that many face: What use of x, if it can not perform the function when it was created? Does it still count an x? If not, are we simply doing the formality?
www.quaibranly.fr
The paradox is especially apparent on musical instruments, as they should be appreciated with hearing instead of looking. At the MAA, whenever there‚Äôs a community person visiting to see their own heritage collections, our policy is that they could choose to handle them with bare hands (without gloves), and it is amazing to see how, for example, musical instruments, sound when they are played. It is very tricky when it comes to wind instruments such as flutes, pipes, and horns, as we are not never sure if they were in contact with historical pesticide, which can make visitors sick. Nevertheless, the spirit is that the museum should be a place where people make the material legacies alive. I would love to know if this large display allowed people to physically handle the collections (it seemed close when I visited). If yes, how would the experience proceed?
At this point, you should find out that I had reached another section, Asia. Seeing the Paiwan ancestor board was really a nice heads-up. Another thing was that my fever was getting worse and I felt even more dehydrated.
!! Notice!!
There might be human remains (ashes) in the collections in the next photo. Readers discretion.
I was thrilled to learn more about shadow puppets from the audio guide. Apparently the fantastic performanceship originated in India, rather than China, which I was told as a kid. The story and the characters indeed changed and evolved as the style migrated and spread among different Asian regions. My first experience with shadow puppets was sorting them from the Skeat collection, which were less elaborate but all the same, impressive (See Z 33667 and Z 33587). I also admire how the Quai-Branly used light box to display the puppets, bringing the colours and crafting details to the eyes.
One can tell that I sped up my visiting pace as I didn‚Äôt take that many photos in Asia section.
The monologue I had upon seeing the Benin Bronzes was probably the same when visitors came to the MAA and saw exactly the same display. I have tried to explain to friends that museums simply couldn‚Äôt ‚Äúpack them and ship them back to Nigeria‚Äù. If only it were that easy! Shame it‚Äôs not wrapping and mailing Christmas gift for Auntie Gladys. The most difficult part is never the practicality of packing and courriering, but the politics and funding that are involved in the repatriation process. Nevertheless, museums are not at liberty to share the details, which are the gap between them and the public.
I was really speeding up my visit without skipping too many collections on display, because my fever was getting a bit out of control. At one point I just felt I couldn‚Äôt get up and all I wanted was gulping water. There were at least two school groups at the same time so I used that as an excuse to proceed faster. The royal statue was the last before I moved on to the last section ‚Äî America.
If I were to commit to a specific area of expertise, the First Nationas people in North America would probably be my second choice, other than East Asia. I know very little about them, but from what I was told and saw, I can relate the history of driving the indigenous people to extinction and how their land and language were taken away.
With a curator like Anita, a lot of research visits at MAA focused on American culture. I am not a stranger to many above. I was especially surprised to see the cape as I was 100% sure there was an identical copy of it in our own gallery, and I also saw the same design on a flyer for the MA Anthropology at Sainsbury‚Äôs Centre, UEA. I asked Rachel about it, and she told me that it was a popular design, and that was why it was widely used in woven textiles as gifts.
I spent around four to five hourse in the whole museum, and was absolutely drained when I left the place. I didn‚Äôt realise how sick I was until I realised I didn‚Äôt even want to shop in the souvenir stores, which I regret because I would love to get a tote bag. I got some flu medicine on my way home.
I had wonderful impression of Quai-Branly. The level and scale are what I envision how a museum of ‚Äúworld anthropology‚Äù should be. I still don‚Äôt think any museum in the world would be fit for the title ‚Äúwold anthropology‚Äù for a simple reason: All collectors have preferences that are derived from their generations of academic focus, and those preferences are the reason why many museums don‚Äôt have the same level of attention on all cultures. Take the zeal for Oceania and Pacific Islands for example, both Quai-Branly and MAA have extensive resources and materials from the region. However, when it comes to Asia, they are usually relatively ignorant. I have to say that I do feel jealous ‚Äî if that is a fair term to use here ‚Äî because of my heritage, but I also don‚Äôt want to take away people‚Äôs attention on any minority groups.
2. Le Louvre, 29 March 2024
As I scrolled through my photo album, I realised that I did not actually like Le Louvre as a museum. If you quickly scroll through this section and compare the amount I wrote about it with Museum d‚ÄôOrsay (next), you will know which museum I prefer.
My first visit to Le Louvre nine years ago was mainly to tick the box of ‚Äúsee the Mona Lisa (La Joconde)‚Äù, which I should say was a half-tick, because I never really saw it in an appropriate distance. My impression for the rest of the galleries was a bit blurred, and this was what I planned to revisit and take a good look.
I couldn‚Äôt describe how weird I felt when I stood at the grand foyer, looking at at least three moving escalators extending and ascending to mezzanines. I couldn‚Äôt, however, describe why I felt the deju-vu unsettling until I wrote these words down: It was a memory of rushing and running through the corridors, feeling pressed and shame because I couldn‚Äôt see the paintings. I have a strange habit: If I don‚Äôt get to enjoy a good thing properly the first time, I somehow would avoid coming back and re-enjoy it again. Possibly out of guilt and embarrassment.
I studied the map a little bit and tried to figure out which galleries I possibly had visited before just to avoid them. I didn‚Äôt, so I just randomly hopped on one of the escalators and was taken to a broad court full of Roman sculptures. It was a strange space for a brief moment, but in a good sense: The court was quite far away from the early morning crowd who were sprinting towards the Mona Lisa, so I could only hear the low and muffled talking and shouting through the walls. The majority interior design, including the sculptures, was white, reflecting the light and the cloudy sky from a high glassed ceiling. There were only a few visitors and they were sitting on foldable chairs, focusing on their sketches. I guess they were art students. I felt like wondering in a giant bubble in a sci/art-fi movie. In retrospection I am glad that my visit began in a quiet corner instead of another immediate overwhelm.
My strategy for visiting route is wondering and meadering, and avoiding the Mona Lisa at all cost (which is wise for a reason). Overall, I wasn‚Äôt impressed by what I saw that day; however, I found something new and it was a nice surprise.
I hope that one day someone could explain to me how or why there is a room full of historical scientific instruments in the Sulley Gallery. For a brief moment I thought I was at the Whipple Museum French Branch, as I could point to every object and name them: Butterfield type sundial, possibly of Augsberg and French made; equinotical ring dial; diptych dial; compendium; astrolabe; compound microscope, etc.. I tried to find more information about provenance and acquisition details but there wasn‚Äôt too much about them on the Louvre website. I‚Äôm also really intrigued to find out the curatorial reason behind the public display as I don‚Äôt think they relate to any other ‚Äúartistic‚Äù collections nearby.
It was wonderful to see the gallery of Egyptian mummies and I vaguely remembered seeing them during the first visit. No surprise, it was fully packed with visitors. I felt a bit uneasy because I thought of the issues of displaying human remains, and all the discussion as a museum professional. Seeing so many visitors still not caring at all about what I thought was strangely unsettling and relaxing: I don‚Äôt think museums would ever be able to tell everyone how to behave around human remains, especially something with such high profile. A proportion of visitors will forever remain ignorant and have no regard towards any cultural sensitivity. I‚Äôm not saying that museums should stop trying to raise the awareness of respect and privacy, but to forbid a certain approach based on reasons hard to judge, i.e. whether the photos were taken out of despise/entertaiment/respect, is also a restriction of speech and could potentially create another type of dominance.
I don‚Äôt think I would want to come back to the Louvre the third time. Aesthetically it is an amazing museum, but I don‚Äôt resonate with the collections inside.
3. Mus√©e d‚ÄôOrsay, 31 March 2024
Before this trip, whenever I mentioned that I had been to Paris (ten years ago, almost), I had to say that I regretted not going to Museum d‚ÄôOrsay. Yes, I knew it was famous and a must-go, but the decade-ago me was more keen on ticking the bucket list and less a museum person.
One of my colleagues was a passionate advocat of the museum. ‚ÄúAbsolutely gorgeous‚Äù she said. And I found myself standing under an enormous arc where the train used to stop, now stood stunning marble sculptures.
It was stunning to see all three sculptures (above) displayed ensemble. The clever use of bronze for the sitters‚Äô complexion and the amazing texture of onyx for their outfits really brought out them to life. What‚Äôs more interested is the labels: All three sculptures were under different titles once, given by the artist. They were renamed to avoid outdated historical racism.
www.musee-orsay.fr
I am always a fan of watching how the westerners portrait what the world looks like to them. I started paying more attention to this type of creation when I visited the Frederiksborg Castle in Copenhagen, seeing the four corners painted on the ceiling of the Audience Room that depicted the four continents of the globe. I realised how distant it was for the artist to even grasp the concept of what Asia was: The corner painting featured a Turkish man with a turban and a glorious moustache; a camel kneeling beside him.
Contrary to putting a Turk as a representation for Asia, the bronze sculpture in Museum d‚ÄôOrsay, created in the 19th century, featured a more East-Asian-looking person, possibly because of wars and trade in East Asia. I would say this is how geopolitics are involved in art. On a closer look, as I wrote down this late journal, I noticed that the Asian representation was actually a female (the bossom) with a male braid. How bizzare and intriguing! Was this an intentional decision by the artist? Or was this simply a mixed-up?
A great deal of my visit time was spent in the exhibition Paris 1874: Inventer l‚Äôimpressionnisme, which in the beginning I didn‚Äôt plan to go. However, I couldn‚Äôt resist a free exhibition and the fabulous paintings by Monet, plus the queue was not crazy long. In the end, I made the little detour and joined the little crowd (which turned into a massive herd when I left).
I thought it was going to be a ‚Äúnice and little‚Äù exhibition featuring Monet and others (who, unfortunately, I didn‚Äôt know. That‚Äôs why I only named Monet). Have I been more wrong than this? Probably not. It was an exhibition about impressionism, but it provided a profound historical context on the social change and artistic evolution that led towards the familiar style we know today. There were lots of sketches, photos, and archives that scafolded the beginning of impressionism before I finally saw the Sunrise painting. During the visit I sometimes felt quite embarrassed because I clearly was not up for such in-depth cultural education, especially I was planning on visiting a niche museum later that day.
Every time I see a chinoiserie style in a painting or as an interior design, I always feel surreal. As a child I felt that Eastern elements were strictly limited in Asia, and to see them in a western setting was like seeing an ostrich among chickens ‚Äî odd and distinctive. Questions like ‚ÄúDid they already know where China and Japan were?‚Äù, ‚Äúhave they seen our stuffs already?‚Äù and ‚Äúdid they know any Asian person?‚Äù will always be in my head. I wonder if it‚Äôs the same surreal feeling for a westerner to see late Qing court paintings, which were profoundly influenced by Jesuit missionaries.
That was the last painting I took picture of in the exhibition. It was extremely crowded and noisy so it was a good time to get out of the place.
I became a fan of C√©zanne during my teenage time. I appreciate the saturation of colour as well as the clear boundary lines he used.
‚ÄúLes √Çges de l‚Äôouvrier‚Äù was a gem among all the artworks that I took picture of. F√©d√©ric was a symbolist painter, which means that his artworks usually contained hints and audience needed to read between the lines. The painting is presented in a triptych, which resembles a traditional religious arrangement. Among the children playing cards (symbolising vice and greed) is a boy, behind who a basket at his head position resembles a saint‚Äôs halo.
I finally acscended to the second floor where I was surprised to find a large crowd at the restaurant, and an even larger crowd straining their necks in front of, not just anyone‚Äôs, but VAN GOGH‚Äôs famous painting of the yellow room. I am never a fan of Van Gogh, so I used this as an excuse and skirted through the gallery.
I was glad to finish my first visit to the Orsay with Monet‚Äôs most acclaimed artworks. It was definitely a brief visit, but I made sure I had time to go through all the galleries. If there was any regret, I would say it was that I didn‚Äôt get a tote bag (but I bought a T-shirt with Monet‚Äôs artwork!).
Overall, I like Museum d‚ÄôOrsay. It‚Äôs incredibly large with amazing artworks; everyone is going to find a piece of art that they like. I appreciate the map and directions that point to the highlight for a quick visit. The audio guide was insightful, though I was hoping for a more flexible touch, such as the one I had in the Rijksmuseum, Amsterdam. The gift shop was nice (I only realised the importance of a good gift shop after this visit and I may come up with a short post about why they are important) but the location was quite awkward.
4. Mus√©e Fragonard, 31 March 2024
I left Museum d‚ÄôOrsay about two o‚Äôclock. Rather early for me; I usually reserve a whole day for just one museum visit. However, I was on a mission to a special museum before I left Paris ‚Äî Mus√©e Fragonard.
Make no mistake, this is not the Perfume Museum and it has nothing to do with Fragonard the perfumist. I believe that the name Fragonard is a coincident, that this oldest veterinarian school in France happens to have the same name with the perfume brand.
The museum isn‚Äôt in the city centre and I had to spend almost an hour from Panth√©on (a small detour after Museum d‚ÄôOrsay) on bus. It was pouring and I felt like the bus was waddling through a sudden flood in Paris, but gladly the tempest died when I finally arrived. I spent some time asking around because I found myself in the middle of a college on a Sunday, when no one stayed in the classroom. Two ladies pointed me the way.
People who know me can always be certain that I‚Äôm a big fan of medicla museums. I was definintely gutted to learn later that Mus√©e de l‚ÄôHistoire de la M√©decine was not open due to Easter holiday, but I still had the chance to visit something related ‚Äî animal anatomy, or vet science.
The Fragonard Museum was definitely a quirky place that can be easily recognised as a university museum: It is tucked away in a humble teaching block; except a few signs and a sleepy security guard 500 meters away, there was no sign to direct the visitors.
I was, nevertheless, amazed by the enlarged teaching models neatly arranged in the display cases. I had never been to a historical vet science museum, so it was a little bit overwhelming at first (especially I only had two hours before the museum closed, and I intended to listen to every.audio.episode.)
Not to sound like a Y2K emo teen but I love anything that associates with death. The rituals that human plan and do in order to mark, remember, relieve, and avoid death are remarkable‚Ä¶ They are the last chance for the dead to look back the living world, and the living to forsee what it will be like when we step into the unknown. Object that we study in order to understand death are similar to that. Is this the reason why museums now talk more about resepcting human remains? I wonder; but if bones of human beings are to be treated differently, how come we don‚Äôt apply the same attitude towards other animals‚Äô bones? I also think about the lines between collections treated in a scientific and anthropological manner: If a human skull was collected for scientific racism study, it would migrate to repatriation based on anthropological reason. However, animals that sacrifice or were intentinally made ill for scientific purposes were less likely to be treated with anthropological sensitivity.
I wish that there were more textual labels along the display, as the audio guide did not help memorise (it was great content, though, very informative). Or perhaps I just need to find another way to record what I heard on the audio guide.
However, I managed to remember one thing from the audio guide. The pictures above showed the signature on one of the anatomical models, E. Petitcolin, dated 1901. It stands for Eug√®ne Petitcolin, the preparator and model maker of the vet school.
My experience at the Whipple Museum left a valuable lesson in my mind, that all of the great scientific achievement would not have been possible were it not for the tool makers, publishers, etc.. Our education focuses a lot on the theories proposed by the great theoretician and philosophers, but not much time is spent on what compliment their success. Take Auzoux‚Äôs papier-m√¢ch√© human model for example: Hundreds of thousands (an underestimation) of medical students would not have become doctors if there hadn‚Äôt been a chance to test their knowledge before practicing on patients. Some of the model makers even took their craftmanship to the next level: Not only were they accurate and precise, but the colour and material made these models, though mass produced, artistic, offering inspiration and perspective on life and the wonder of it.
Petitcolin worked his whole life for the vet school and was a pioneer in model making and preservation. I appreciate how the museum preserved these historical teaching tools, and it was wonderful that he gets to be featured in the tour. I think all museums should, if given chances, reflect upon the assistants and technicians that did the bidding. One example that I feel right is the rooms at the Centre of Material Culture (of MAA), which are named after Clare Isobel Fell (archaeologist, 1912‚Äì2002), Samuel Cowles (museum assistant), and Maureen M. O‚ÄôReilly (assistant curator), who were women and assistant dedicating their lives to the work, but not necessarily remembered in the history.
However, this is not the highlight of the Fragonard Museum.
! Attention!
The photo below contain human remains. Readers‚Äô discretion advised.
These are √©corch√©es, or the flayed collections. Made by Honor√© Fragonard (1732‚Äì1799), who used to teach anatomy in the vet school, these are considered the treasures of the museum. The technique that Fragonard employed is still not fully understood. I could see that this was dry specimen, and I assumed that the material involved a lot of wax, hence the shiny gloss on the surface. My impression was proved right when I read later, that these creations were made not based on anatomical studies, but more for a theatrical performance. I definitely felt the intense glare from the first standing man, Goliath. I feel very fortunate that I am not bothered by such beautiful creation because I can imagine many people shying away, and I understand that.
This is probably the longest post I‚Äôve written in English so far. I‚Äôve waited a long time before I even started writing it, and procrastinated several times because life since April has been like being strapped on a rocket while skating on icy road, totally chaotic.
I have a mixture of positive and negative views on Paris as a city and the two visits I‚Äôve made so far. I think it is a wonderful metropolitan: sleek, chic, vibrant, and everyone can have a place; and yet I don‚Äôt feel like I can find a place there, just as I feel about London. However, this is not a travel blog.
As for museums, I absolutely give them a five star overall. During this trip, I have ticked more boxes on my bucket list, without loosing the quality and depth that I was looking for. The regret that I didn‚Äôt get to visit Museum of the History of Medicine is a strong reason to bring me back to this city.
--
--

Paris: where Love, Creativity, and Perfection Converge.
This day one year ago,
we were admiring the perfectly planned lanes of Paris while standing on the famous,
brilliantly marketed,
iconic Eiffel Tower
We watched Paris basking in the golden glow of the setting sun,
and then it all started to twinkle and looked even more beautiful and serene as evening descended.
Damn!
I admired the vision through which the city was planned.
I also read about its history, even though we walked over 15,000 steps a day. Human creativity and vision know no bounds.
At that time, I wasn‚Äôt sure if it was pressure, punishment, or reward, but they designed a freakishly beautiful city that endures even after you leave it.
So, as you stroll through the lanes of Paris, it dawns on you that something this grand can be created with stunning detail.
Perfectionism isn‚Äôt just a term;
It‚Äôs something that can and should be pursued.
If you do so,
you can create something that stands out
and remains eternal
for ages to come.
And even though it‚Äôs a big crazy city, with constant traffic and crowded metro rides,
there is love in the air!
There‚Äôs something so (geographically!) blessed about the air that it heals you.
You immediately miss someone in Paris and want to return with them. (This could be true for any city in Europe though!)
I met my husband after a month in Paris;
he stayed for two weeks longer than I did.
The first thing I said when he picked me up at the airport was, ‚ÄòThis air is so healing.‚Äô As the quote says ‚Äî
‚ÄúBreathe in Paris, It nourishes the soul‚Äù ‚Äî Victor Hugo
So the air and city itself is enough to fill your heart, and yeah, it leaves a strong impression that you‚Äôd wish to witness this grandness again.
‚ÄúA walk in Paris will provide lessons history, beauty, and in the point of life.
We did talk about history and astonishing beauty,
What is the point of life that you see by looking out from the Eiffel Tower?
One takeaway for me is that boundless creativity and perfection exist.
There is nothing wrong with obsessing over perfection.
You might as well build something resembling Paris!
--
--
I write to solidify my believes, to question, to understand the world within and around. May reading it helps you too!

I returned to Paris last week, still feeling bruised by the US election. I had volunteered for the Harris campaign in Pennsylvania in the month leading up to Nov 5., and I was so relieved that Teresa my beloved spouse and I were at last able to resume our carefree life as fl√¢neurs in Paris. Fl√¢neur is a most delightful French word that means to wander about without specific purpose, just observing the world.
Relieved, yes. But I still felt a lump of dread in the pit of my stomach like an undigested rotten sausage.
The weather was grey and rainy ‚Äî not surprising for mid-November in Paris, but not really conducive to long walks or for lifting one‚Äôs mood. Teresa, however, needed some replacement light bulbs. So one afternoon last week, a trip to the hardware store was mandatory. The rain was not stopping, so finally, I just said fuck it, and headed out into the drizzle.
The route to the hardware store lay along one of my favorite walks, the Coul√©e Vert, or ‚ÄúGreenway.‚Äù It‚Äôs a disused tram line that has been repurposed and replanted as an urban garden path ‚Äî if you‚Ä¶

Title: I Grew Strong
Content:
Sign up

Share
Revoir Paris | Essay Three
I spent a month in Paris, this time, and could simply be there, live there, and revisit places and experiences that I have loved.
Mostly it didn‚Äôt rain.
As the days passed under skies of blue or mother-of-pearl, and I relearned the layout of favorite boulevards and quarters and how to take buses everywhere, and eventually mastered how to make it back to the hotel tucked into a sidestreet without first overshooting the mark, Paris began to feel more familiar than ever it had before.
Perhaps I could finally live there because in previous visits I had ticked the tourist sites off the list, and made the big-ticket historical, artistic, and literary pilgrimages, and thus had no further itch to scratch.
Or perhaps it was because while there I turned seventy (which was the idea) and brought to the adventure a mellowing soul.
I think it was the latter reason, mostly, but also because I had flown to peacetime Paris from a war zone and could remind myself viscerally and experientially of what I know intellectually: that a whole, beckoning world exists that is not at war, and that in the absence of war, life can be brilliant, creative, and happy.
Paris has not always been at peace, of course.
Some people know about the Hundred Years‚Äô War between England and France (1337‚Äì1453).
Everyone in the world has heard about the French Revolution (1789‚Äì1799) ‚Äî and some know of the Franco-Prussian War (1870‚Äì71) and the Paris Commune (1871). [1]
Many people know about the high price in blood paid by the French in WWI; some would argue that this led a still shell-shocked populace to follow WWI hero Philippe P√©tain into WWII collaboration with Hitler.
If you notice shrapnel-pockmarked building facades from the Nazi era, or memorial signage on buildings, you will learn of Vichy (French) police roundups of Jews and Gestapo executions of Resistants in the very heart of Paris. [2] & [3]
But on this day especially, the world ‚Äî my whole world ‚Äî became a jewel box (the Th√©√¢tre du Palais-Royal [4]) nested within a coffer (the Domaine national du Palais-Royal) nested within a treasure chest (the Palais-Royal quarter of the 1st arrondissement).
I paused at the southern entrance to the Jardin du Palais-Royal to admire Paravent Girls [5], an Art Basel Paris bronze installation by Egyptian multimedia artist Ghada Amer [6], and then fl√¢nered the lovely garden‚Äôs length.
I was on my way to the Th√©√¢tre du Palais-Royal to meet my cousin and her husband at a performance of L‚Äôextraordinaire Destin√©e de Sarah Bernhardt:
The stage goddess (b. 1844 ‚Äî d. 1923) lived a hard-working, celebrated life, [7] and like today‚Äôs rock stars and pop divas, toured the world ‚Äúcollecting men and animals, having a baby with a prince. . . and doing it all with extravagance, humor, and unfailing commitment.‚Äù [8]
The producers were wise to stage the show in so sumptuous a playhouse! Seated on red velvet ‚Äî or velour? ‚Äî inside so gilded and plush a venue, one can‚Äôt pretend for a second that one has not come to lose oneself entirely in theatrical magic.
Now it is Saturday night at dusk in sharp weather. Night is rapidly falling as my cousin‚Äôs husband, Alain, shepherds us across Place Colette, where a crowd couples-dances en plein air to a live jazz and blues orchestra.
We wait on a curb at a red light in a drizzle. From afar, shimmering ice-blue diamonds jet and spill up and down the height of the Eiffel Tower [9]; the Tuileries‚Äô Roue de Paris (ferris wheel) glitters like a diamond-studded hoop suspended in air.
Alain hails us a cab on Avenue de l‚ÄôOp√©ra; the grand thoroughfare pulses with neon signage and street lamps and head and tail lights that shimmer off the wet pavement as if they are sequins and gemstones: rubies, diamonds, emeralds!
A switch flips in my neurocircuitry already buzzing from having been to the theater. But now outside in the dark amid festive crowds, the myriad lights have jolted me even more widely awake and strongly alive.
Sparklers go fizzing and blazing through my arteries. My whole bloodstream effervesces! If I weren‚Äôt bundled in a fleece jumper and down vest, my skin would be emitting visible sparks.

When I was in college, I was part of a student organization whose goal is to facilitate the onboarding of international students by organizing meetups, dinners, and events.

This bond wasn‚Äôt just about shared interests or hobbies; it went deeper, touching on I believe shared values, philosophies, and outlooks on life.

I met more than twenty French students in college. Not all at the same time. But I‚Äôve always found myself spending time with them. Hanging out. Going out. Drinking at a local bar. Eating at a Chinese restaurant.
As a matter of fact, my go-to friend group in college consisted of 60% French. I‚Äôve always felt home with them. Always felt happy with them.
It‚Äôs funny because a lot of Americans dislike French people as they can come off as rude or uptight. Some even complain about how they reek of cigarettes. I even have friends of mine who had terrible experience when they visited Paris because of these and some say it‚Äôs overrated.

And I‚Äôm (finally) okay with that.
I‚Äôve done my fair share of traveling ‚Äî much more than I ever would have thought I would when I was much younger. I‚Äôve been to many more than half of the states in the United States. I have been to Europe a handful of times and have enjoyed the sights and sounds of at least ten countries over there. I‚Äôve been to Canada and Mexico. I‚Äôve been to a significant number of islands in the Caribbean.
Sounds pretty good, if I do say so myself.
It‚Äôs just that there has been this one location ‚Äî this one place ‚Äî this one dream vacation spot of a lifetime, that has eluded me for lo these many years.
That locale ‚Äî the stuff of fantasy and romance ‚Äî is, of course, Paris.
These weren‚Äôt postcards from places I had actually seen. Nope, as a child my family‚Äôs annual vacation destination was our local zoo.
These were postcards I begged for from friends, family, friends of the family and the family of friends.
Anyone, going anywhere, all I asked was a cool shot of something tourist worthy. For the most part, I was indulged in my requests.
