Title: (France) Paris: Where Art Meets Life ‚Äî My Journey Through the City of Lights
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Hey there, travel buddies! It‚Äôs your girl back with another adventure that literally broke my blog last month (100K visitors in one day? I‚Äôm still in shock!). So grab your favorite drink, get comfy, and let me take you through the cobblestone streets of Paris ‚Äî a city that feels both exactly like and nothing like what you‚Äôd expect.
I‚Äôve been to 47 countries, but there‚Äôs something about Paris that keeps pulling me back. Maybe it‚Äôs the way the light hits the Seine at sunset, or how the smell of fresh baguettes seems to follow you everywhere. Or maybe it‚Äôs just because I‚Äôm a total art nerd who can spend hours staring at one painting (spoiler alert: I did exactly that at the Orsay).
Let‚Äôs start with the Mus√©e d‚ÄôOrsay, which honestly deserves its own fan club. First things first ‚Äî this place used to be a train station! I mean, talk about a glow-up, right? The moment you walk in, you‚Äôre hit with this incredible ceiling that makes you wonder why we ever stopped building beautiful things.
I arrived at opening time (pro tip: always, ALWAYS arrive at opening time) and made a beeline for the Impressionist galleries on the top floor. The thing about the Orsay that nobody tells you is how the natural light changes everything. Van Gogh‚Äôs self-portrait at 9:30 am hits completely different than at noon.
I spent a ridiculous three hours just on the fifth floor. No regrets. Standing in front of Monet‚Äôs water lilies, I literally forgot I had a flight to catch the next day. Some American couple next to me was arguing about where to have lunch, and I wanted to shake them and say, ‚ÄúDO YOU NOT SEE THIS MASTERPIECE RIGHT IN FRONT OF YOU?!‚Äù But I kept it cool. Mostly.
After the Orsay, I desperately needed caffeine, so I ducked into this tiny caf√© called Le Petit Cler that wasn‚Äôt in any guidebook. The barista took one look at my camera and said in perfect English, ‚ÄúAnother tourist who thinks they‚Äôll find the real Paris?‚Äù I laughed and asked him in my terrible French where the real Paris was. He smiled, wrote down an address on my receipt, and said, ‚ÄúGo there after the Louvre. Trust me.‚Äù
(Spoiler: I did go, and it was this incredible little jazz bar where I ended up dancing with an 80-year-old Parisian gentleman who told me stories about meeting Picasso when he was a child. Some experiences you just can‚Äôt plan!)
After my mystery caf√© recommendation, I headed to the Louvre. Listen, this place is MASSIVE. Like, you-could-spend-a-week-here-and-not-see-everything massive. I‚Äôve been three times now and I‚Äôm pretty sure there are entire wings I haven‚Äôt discovered yet.
Here‚Äôs my controversial Louvre take: skip the Mona Lisa on your first visit. I KNOW, I KNOW. But hear me out. The crowd around her is insane, you‚Äôll barely see her, and there are literally thousands of other incredible pieces that you can actually get close to and enjoy without someone‚Äôs selfie stick in your face.
Instead, I wandered through the Egyptian antiquities section and found myself completely alone with artifacts that are over 4,000 years old. ALONE. With HISTORY. In what universe does that make sense while hundreds of people are fighting for a glimpse of La Joconde?
But the real magic of the Louvre happens when you get lost. Seriously, put away the map for 30 minutes and just wander. I turned a random corner and stumbled upon The Winged Victory of Samothrace with no one else around. Just me and this 2,200-year-old masterpiece having a moment together. I may have teared up a little.
The thing about Paris that my Instagram can never fully capture is what happens between the museums. Walking from the Orsay to the Louvre along the Seine, I watched an elderly couple dancing to an accordion player near Pont Neuf. They must have been in their 80s, moving slowly but with such grace that several tourists (myself included) just stopped to watch.
Later that afternoon, I got completely lost near Le Marais and found myself in a tiny square where local children were playing soccer while their parents chatted on benches. One little boy kicked the ball my way, and before I knew it, I was in an impromptu soccer game with a bunch of French kids who thought my terrible footwork was hilarious.
These moments ‚Äî the ones between the famous sites ‚Äî are what make Paris magical. The way light falls through tree branches onto century-old buildings. The sound of church bells mixing with scooter horns. The smell of rain on warm pavement outside a bakery. You can‚Äôt plan for these things, but they‚Äôre what you‚Äôll remember most.
Alright, time for some real talk about cash. Paris has a reputation for being expensive, and yes, it absolutely can be if you‚Äôre not careful. But it doesn‚Äôt have to break the bank!
Between the Orsay and the Louvre, I spent an entire afternoon at Caf√© de Flore, just watching Paris go by. Three hours, two coffees, one glass of wine, and approximately 5,000 interesting characters later, I realized I‚Äôd just had one of the best experiences of my trip without doing anything at all.
A fashionable elderly woman at the table next to mine noticed me watching everyone and said in accented English, ‚ÄúThe best art in Paris is the people, yes?‚Äù We ended up chatting for an hour about how she modeled for Dior in the 1960s. Marie, if you‚Äôre somehow reading this, you were the highlight of my trip!
Here‚Äôs what surprised me most: Paris isn‚Äôt perfect. And that‚Äôs what makes it perfect.
The metro sometimes smells questionable. Some waiters really are rude (though most aren‚Äôt if you attempt even terrible French). There are tourist traps and pickpockets and overpriced caf√©s.
But there‚Äôs also the bookseller along the Seine who gave me a free vintage postcard when I bought a worn copy of Hemingway. The baker who threw in an extra pain au chocolat ‚Äúbecause you look hungry.‚Äù The stranger who walked me to my hotel when I got lost after midnight.
Paris isn‚Äôt a postcard; it‚Äôs a living, breathing city with mood swings and secrets and stories. It‚Äôs not always beautiful, but it‚Äôs always authentic. And that‚Äôs why I keep coming back.
So friends, has this convinced you to book that flight yet? Drop me a comment about your Paris dreams or questions, and I promise to answer every single one. Next week, I‚Äôll be sharing my fool-proof packing list for a week in Paris with just a carry-on (yes, it‚Äôs possible, even for a chronic over-packer like me).
Until next time, remember what the French say: ‚ÄúLa vie est belle, mais Paris la rend extraordinaire.‚Äù Life is beautiful, but Paris makes it extraordinary.
√Ä bient√¥t! ‚ú®

Title: Why I Love Paris, Even Though The Japanese People Don‚Äôt
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

The place where travelers and adventurers share their experiences so we can explore the world and learn about other cultures from our couch.

--
11
Listen
Share
toThe term ‚ÄòParis Syndrome‚Äô was created in 1986 by professor Professor Hiroaki Ota. He explained it as ‚Äòa severe shock that can require hospitalisation‚Äô.
Wait, there‚Äôs more.
According to this article from Huffington Post,
‚ÄúThe Japanese Embassy in Paris now has a 24-hour hotline for Japanese tourists suffering from the syndrome, whose symptoms can range from depression and anxiety to acute delusional states, dizziness, sweating, hallucinations and ‚Äúfeelings of persecution.‚Äù
The reason?
According to professor Mathieu Deflem from the University of South Carolina, it‚Äôs because of drastically different cultures and ‚Äòunmet romantic expectations‚Äô.
I even have friends who‚Äôve told me that they were disappointed in Paris, but here‚Äôs why I still love the city.
My first experience in Paris was when I was 21. My uncle and I were travelling to Paris and Milan, but I arrived a day early and was alone in Paris for the day.
What happened next was an incident that changed my life forever.
Going to cut the long story short.
I met a Syrian man via Couchsurfing. We met at the banks of the river La Seine where the locals were chilling. We just looked at the river and spoke. Between us was his airbag with local cheese, wine, homemade beetroot and classic hummus and pita bread.
He was a journalist and told me how he‚Äôs lost his home and a lot of his family.
In the middle of talking about the refugee incidents he has experienced and covered at work, what struck me was this particular sentence,
‚ÄúYou think your life is hard? Think about sitting in a boat and not knowing if you‚Äôll ever see land again. Do this for days, and that life is hard.‚Äù
It changed my perspective on everything.
Here‚Äôs a detailed article about it if you want to read it later.
Even back then, there were certain challenges.
The menu was entirely in French. People wouldn‚Äôt respond in English. But you know what? I don‚Äôt see an issue with it.
I‚Äôm from India. And it‚Äôs painful to see how talking in English is a way of social stratification today. You‚Äôre automatically ‚Äòcool‚Äô and ‚Äòwell educated‚Äô if you can talk fluently in English.
I mean‚Ä¶ this is like Stockholm Syndrome.
When I visited Edinburgh Castle in Scotland, I saw how most jewels there belonged to the kings and queens of India. We were looted and ripped off so bad that we‚Äôre relatively poor even today. Yet, we cannot get out of our colonisation by pitting against each other.
The world doesn‚Äôt need to be fluent in English.
And here‚Äôs a trick that works if you really want the French to be nice to you.
Something that amused me was ‚Äî each time I spoke in broken French, I got answers in fluent English.
But when I spoke in English, I just got cold nods.
It‚Äôs funny, but it underlines how showing a little bit of respect that you‚Äôre at least trying to talk in their language warms their heart. Warms mine too, when I see a foreigner speaking in Hindi.
Just saying ‚ÄòBonjour‚Äô can help.
Like everything else, it‚Äôs always the little things, isn‚Äôt it?
Another thing that helps regardless of the city is to be a traveler instead of a tourist.
Ditch tours, hop-in-hop-off, and the big shiny spots.
Walk into lanes of Montmartre, eat local breakfast, and let go of expensive tickets for the Eiffel view because the view is best enjoyed for free‚Ä¶ by the river.
My mum and I visited Paris this August and sat here with some ros√© and snacks and had a beautiful time watching the Eiffel light up at night. We also witnessed two proposals!
You don‚Äôt see this stuff paying 300 euros for an ‚ÄòEiffel view‚Äô table.
Talking about food, ditch your Instagram famous cafes.
I promise you, the bread you eat at a local boulangerie would be to die for. It‚Äôll be fresh, soulful, and unlike any bread you‚Äôve ever had.
I went to the famous cafe, Ladur√©e, and ordered eggs benedict. I paid 3.5 euros extra for spinach. Do you know what I got? Two brioches with a diameter of 2 cm and one small leaf of spinach on each.
It was such a tiny meal!
Meanwhile, here‚Äôs a local breakfast at a cafe:
France has made me fall in love with breads so much that I tried to find local bread in the 5 other countries I visited during my trip in August.
It‚Äôs worth the hype.
Paris is notorious for thefts and being unsafe. But each place has a reputation and as somebody who has solo travelled, I recommend you to follow the basics that you would anywhere else:
I‚Äôd follow this in Amsterdam, Berlin, and Melbourne too.
Doesn‚Äôt matter where you go, but being responsible for your own safety is better than being sorry later and blaming others.
Lastly, I‚Äôd like to end by ‚Äî give everything a chance instead of dwelling on preconceived notions.
My biggest lesson while solo travelling at 21 was to view the world as a blank slate and let experiences fill in the colour.
I met a woman at a bus stop in Stockholm, Sweden. She was American-Chinese and first asked me if I‚Äôll be ‚Äòallowed‚Äô to wear the dress I was wearing right now in India. I affirmed that obviously, I am. Why would I not be?
She told me that she‚Äôs always wanted to visit India, but it‚Äôs portrayed as being unsafe.
I swear, if you follow some protocols, it‚Äôs not unsafe at all. But if you do things which as a local even I won‚Äôt do, then it‚Äôs inviting trouble.
Paris is still romantic for couples and lovely for a family holiday. The people are warm, and the bread is even warmer.
Yes, some streets are dirty. But I‚Äôve heard the same goes for New York and San Francisco.
Hop on to the other side, Champs-√âlys√©es is so gorgeous.
Give places and people a chance. Don‚Äôt let media or a few bitter experiences fill your head.
Finally, try to explore like a local. That‚Äôs what differentiates tourists from travellers, in my opinion.

Title: Part I: The Paris Mismatch
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
‚ÄúIt has bothered me all my life that I do not paint like everybody else.‚Äù
On the first Monday of summer, June 5, 1905, the Gare de Lyon train station teemed with fashionable Parisians preparing for their annual journey to the south of France. Only they preferred C√¥te d‚ÄôAzur ‚Äî like it was a club with an admissions committee, an invited guest list, a velvet rope, and a charming hostess waiting to welcome them. To them, paradise was a familiar word, wrapped in the routine and privilege of their opulent lives. They imagined strolling arm-in-arm down sunlit promenades, exchanging knowing glances with others who happened to look, dress, and speakl just like them. It was so comforting to be seated at seaside caf√©s, secure in one‚Äôs place ‚Äî and equally certain that, beyond their tiny polished circle, little else really mattered. They were happy people, perhaps ridiculously so.
A different story awaited in the third-class compartment: thirty-six-year-old Henri Matisse wasn‚Äôt chasing the sun; he was escaping ruin. Although he too was once welcomed in Parisian society, he now wore a corduroy suit like a prison uniform, faded to a reddish-brown, and blending into the threadbare seat beneath him. He looked more vineyard worker than artist ‚Äî save for the paintbox and collapsible easel at his feet. His face was etched with lines from sleepless nights and empty pockets, carrying the weight of three years of failure and rejection. This was the new Henri Matisse, one who had aged and fallen. Had you whispered to his fellow passengers that one day he would shake the art world to its core the laughter would have been raucous and infectious.
Even his wife, Am√©lie, who sat next to him, would give you a skeptical glance. Even her expression was tense with quiet concern, and this was no leisurely getaway to the Riviera. The couple wasn‚Äôt bound for seaside promenades serenaded by Mediterranean breezes. They had no home to go to, and no friends when they arrived. In fact were escaping a life that had unraveled, fleeing to a place that might offer at least a reprieve from despair if not the justice system.
Matisse‚Äôs fall from grace had been sharp. The Parisian art world once welcomed him with cautious optimism, but now turned its delicate pale back. Friends disappeared, patrons closed their wallets, and a once-promising career had sputtered. It was his fault, too. Rumors of a financial scandal hovered around him like a thick fog, deepening his isolation. Once a successful lawyer, Matisse abandoned that career to follow his passion for painting, but now even that seemed as enticing as a wet pavement.
As the train pulled out of the station, leaving behind the familiar smells of crusty baguettes, pungent cheeses, and steaming bowls of oxtail soup, Matisse cast a final glance at his former home. He was leaving behind more than Paris; he was abandoning a world that seemed so full of promise, now reduced to broken dreams. Yet, as the train chugged along the tracks, his mood astonishingly began to lift. Amid the despair, a quiet resolve began to take root. The storm within him receded as Matisse made a vow ‚Äî he would find his voice again, silence the doubts, and reclaim his life on his own terms.
No matter how long it took.
Which is what is so ironic about the story of Henri Matisse in Collioure. Little did he or anyone else realize that in just 100 days, this trek south would not only transform his career but reshape the entire art world, leading to one of the most revolutionary periods in the history of painting.
In fact, Paris would never look at a canvas the same way again.
But what was about to happen wasn‚Äôt a miracle nor an act of faith. It was something deeper and perhaps more fundamental to the human condition. Henri Matisse was about to discover a Thrive Zone ‚Äî a place where the spirit is liberated, creativity reignited, and the soul is fully restored. These are places where we become ourselves in spite of the rest of the world telling us not to be.
This is the story of how one summer in a small fishing village in the south of France set the stage for a transformation that would forever alter Matisse ‚Äî and leave an indelible mark on the world of art.
‚ÄúThere are flowers everywhere for those who want to see them.‚Äù
A cynic would say every form of refuge has its a price. For Henri Matisse, his career suffered from entrapment in the bleak industrial landscape of Normandy. As a young boy growing up there, life was marked by the unrelenting grayness, suffocated by coal dust. He believed the world was colored in sodden skies, and monotony was the color of choice. Matisse would later recall, ‚ÄúWomen wore black, and everyone wore a hat. It is a place where people don‚Äôt expect too many strangers.‚Äù
Even Art historian Hilary Spurling noted this was true, his early works were ‚Äúrestrained and traditional,‚Äù lacking the spark that would later come to define his painting. Only the public wasn‚Äôt interested in somber landscapes ‚Äî it craved beauty, spectacle, and illusion.
Desperate for cash, Matisse even offered one of his canvases to his brother Auguste for 100 francs. The reply was as frigid as the Norman winter: ‚ÄúI‚Äôd rather have a new bicycle.‚Äù But the struggle was about more than selling paintings. Matisse was caught in a larger battle, a fight to find his place in a world that seemed hopelessly duplicitous and divided. He valued integrity in expression more than wealth, but now he was bereft of both.
Born in 1869 during the twilight of the Victorian era, Matisse‚Äôs formative years spanned the Belle √âpoque ‚Äî a time of shimmering contradictions. Paris, the ‚ÄúCity of Light,‚Äù was both a beacon of modernity and a place of deep inequality as well as rigid social structure. The elite lived in the glow of freshly minted francs, while the working classes toiled in the shadows. The surface gleamed, but underneath, resentment simmered.
It was into this paradoxical cauldron, where new industrial fortunes clashed with the remnants of old-world aristocracy, that Matisse and his wife Am√©lie found themselves thrust ‚Äî while the working classes ‚Äî barely literate, and so barely counted ‚Äî were left to their laughter, tobacco pipes, and homemade plum wine. The glittering surface of society masked deep divisions ‚Äî while the elite flaunted their wealth, resentment simmered among the lower classes.
It was how the Matisse‚Äôs became collateral damage in one of the most infamous financial scandals of their time ‚Äî the Humbert Affair. A master manipulator named Th√©r√®se Humbert had defrauded thousands through an audacious Ponzi scheme, borrowing nearly 100 million francs based on the collateral of a fictitious inheritance. By sheer misfortune, the Matisse family became entangled.
Matisse‚Äôs father in law was arrested, and the artist, a former lawyer, came to his defense. He wasn‚Äôt a conspirator, but the scandal stained his reputation and he became swept up in the deluge. And as the Humbert empire crumbled, so too did the Matisse‚Äôs stature. He found himself facing public outrage and financial ruin.
Stripped of dignity and resources, the couple with their inlaws had to fleeParis, no longer sure of their place in the world. Yet, what they sought in the south wasn‚Äôt luxury ‚Äî it was something else, renewal it would turn out. Matisse was no longer simply searching for a place to escape; he was searching for a space to thrive.
‚ÄúWe ought to view ourselves with the same curiosity and openness with which we study a tree, the sky or a thought.‚Äù
Th√©r√®se Humbert was the architect of one of the most notorious frauds in French history. Her rise to the top of Parisian society had been built on audacious lies, and equally fake noble lineage. To bolster her imagined wealth, she concocted an elaborate story about saving the life of a fictional American millionaire, Robert Crawford, who, according to her story, had gratefully left her a vast fortune. For over two decades, Humbert borrowed millions against this supposed inheritance, living a life of luxury while her lenders, many of them ordinary citizens, were left in the dark.
Through a web of deceit that had gone undetected for years ‚Äî protected by her father-in-law, a Minister of Justice ‚Äî Humbert finally acquired a newspaper owned by Armand Parayre, Henri Matisse‚Äôs father-in-law. This tangled connection dragged the Matisse family into the scandal‚Äôs orbit, even though they were unwitting victims themselves. But when the supposed inheritance was revealed to be nothing but a single red brick, the scandal erupted and scapegoats were needed.
France was outraged. The Humberts fled, leaving ruin in their wake. And while Matisse and his family although not accomplices, were tainted by their association. It took very little time before they found themselves swept up in the aftermath of one of the country‚Äôs largest Ponzi schemes.
The financial ruin, public scandal, and professional rejection that surrounded Matisse pushed him further toward collapse. No longer able to support his family or continue his art with any hope of stability, Matisse felt crushed by the weight of his failures. The Parisian society that had once nurtured his ambition now seemed intent on devouring him.
Yet, in the face of this disaster, the fall became the prelude to something greater.
The seeds of transformation were planted.
‚ÄúI would like to recapture that freshness of vision which is characteristic of extreme youth when all the world is new to it.‚Äù
Sometimes, utter rejection is the precursor of renewal. For Matisse, this state of affairs forced him to seek refuge not just from scandal and poverty, but from the creative limitations he had unknowingly imposed on himself. Desperate and exhausted, Matisse and his wife Am√©lie left Paris for a small fishing village near the Spanish border.
Collioure wasn‚Äôt St. Tropez as they couldn‚Äôt afford the luxuries of the French Riviera that Paris‚Äôs elite were accustomed to. Instead, they found themselves in a fishing village hit hard by economic ruin and the collapse of its anchovy trade and vineyards, ravaged by the Phylloxera plague. The town, at first glance, appeared worn, scarred by decline and poverty.
Yet to Matisse, it held something far more precious than wealth.
‚ÄúThe light here is different,‚Äù Matisse would later say.
It wasn‚Äôt just an illusion either. Collioure had unfiltered Mediterranean light that revealed colors that Matisse had never seen before‚Ää‚Äî due to the only East facing coastline in France where the Pyranees majestically seem to dive into the water. The reflections of the sea, the interplay of light and shadow, the vivid hues that soaked into the village streets ‚Äî became his metaphor. A light which casts no shadows and eradicates contrasts. It was a new artistic language, one that spoke to him in a way that Paris never could.
Where others saw a town in decline, Matisse saw a world bursting with possibility. The decay of the fishing industry and the blighted vineyards faded into the background. For the first time in years, Matisse felt a spark of creative energy return. His focus shifted away from survival and toward the rediscovery of beauty.
The transition was profound. In Paris, Matisse had been trapped in a world of muted tones, of compromise and caution. But in Collioure, he began to embrace boldness, color, and exuberance. The sun-drenched hues of the Mediterranean landscape ‚Äî lavenders, blues, deep reds, and oranges ‚Äî burst into his work, freeing him from the restraint that had shackled his earlier paintings.
This was no accident. Collioure had become more than just a change of scenery; it had become Matisse‚Äôs personal Thrive Zone.
A Thrive Zone isn‚Äôt just a place to live or work; it‚Äôs a place where one‚Äôs potential is not only nurtured but liberated. It‚Äôs an environment where time takes on a different momentum, allowing creativity, growth, and transformation to flourish.
In Collioure, Matisse found exactly that ‚Äî a space where the constraints of his old life could no longer bind him, where his art could breathe and expand beyond anything he had imagined in Paris.
‚ÄúWhat I dream of is an art of balance, of purity and serenity, devoid of troubling or depressing subject matter, something like a good armchair.‚Äù
The pinnacle of this transformation came in the form of one of Matisse‚Äôs first works of the summer of 1905 appropriately titled, Open Window, Collioure. It wasn‚Äôt just a painting ‚Äî it was a declaration of freedom that overcame him as he gazed from his hotel window.
In this work, Matisse blurred the boundaries between interior and exterior, between the familiar and the unknown. The colors ‚Äî vivid and alive ‚Äî reflected his internal transformation. Where traditional art sought to mimic life, Matisse‚Äôs work was life, vibrating with the energy of the Mediterranean.
Gone were the muted tones and tight brushstrokes that had once defined his work. In Collioure, Matisse embraced a radical new approach to color and form. His brushstrokes were loose, unrestrained, and alive. This work wasn‚Äôt just a product of technique, he was the same artist he had been in Paris just a week earlier ‚Äî it was the product of an environment.
The vibrant colors of Collioure found their way into the depth of Matisse‚Äôs discouragement, and for the first time in his life, he felt free to paint in a way that was entirely his own. The shift was so dramatic that it left the Parisian art world stunned. Open Window and the thirty other paintings Matisse completed that summer heralded the birth of Fauvism, a revolutionary movement that would redefine modern art.
In one summer in 1905 he would paint over 50 pieces, and three of the ten greatest works of his life. Of course, the critics in Paris, accustomed to the soft realism of the old masters, were appalled. Matisse‚Äôs use of color was too wild, his forms too chaotic. His work was dubbed ‚ÄúFauvism,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúwild beasts,‚Äù a derogatory term meant to criticize the audacity of the movement.
But Matisse, like the light of Collioure, was undeterred. He had found his Thrive Zone, and he would never again return to the constraints of his old life.
‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt help getting old, but you can help becoming old.‚Äù
Henri Matisse once said, ‚ÄúThere are flowers for those who want to see them.‚Äù But perhaps the deeper question isn‚Äôt why we see flowers ‚Äî but who plants them in the first place. In Collioure, Matisse found not just refuge but renewal. Freed from the biting skepticism of Parisian critics who had dismissed his work as ‚Äúscribblings of a wild beast,‚Äù he discovered a simpatico community ‚Äî comrades who shared his love of nature and painted alongside him, as well as villagers who embraced his curious habit of standing before a canvas all day. Among them, he painted with abandon, as if creating art were play, not work.
For him, the humble fishing village was more than a refuge from Parisian humidity or a place of cheap lodgings. It was where the ‚Äúflowers‚Äù of creativity were planted ‚Äî a nurturing environment that welcomed his restless, rebellious spirit and spoke to his innermost feelings and beliefs.
Mornings spent painting in a modest studio overlooking the beach flowed effortlessly into afternoons of fish stew and Picpoul de Pinet. The Mediterranean light transformed the village‚Äôs modest facades into shimmering mosaics of lavender, red, and blue. Even the coarse shouts of fishermen, carried on salt-laden breezes in ancient Occitan, held an unexpected poetry.
What Matisse found in Collioure wasn‚Äôt merely an inspirational technique ‚Äî it was a shift in his approach to life and art. He was no longer bound by the expectations of Parisian society or trapped by the weight of public opinion. The unpretentious simplicity of the village loosened the grip of doubt, reigniting his confidence and freeing him to create on his own terms. In this overlooked corner of the Mediterranean, Matisse found his muse, his sanctuary, and, ultimately, his transformation.
Not long after, he settled permanently in nearby Nice, drawn by the same energy that had unlocked his potential in Collioure ‚Äî a place where he would spend the rest of his days until age 84.
Matisse‚Äôs story exemplifies a universal truth: the right environment can unlock potential in ways that talent or ambition alone cannot. It is the fusion of place, purpose, and opportunity that creates the conditions for extraordinary success. Yet finding such a place is only part of the journey. Liberating oneself from the constraints of our current environment ‚Äî from the doubts, the criticisms, the expectations, and the customs that bind us ‚Äî is often the greater challenge. To do so requires stunning independence and personal leadership.
Matisse left Paris at age 36 a struggling artist. He returned three months later transformed ‚Äî his confidence renewed, his technique revolutionized, and his reputation on the rise.
Within a season, he had become a rival to Picasso. Collioure was more than a village; it was the point where talent and opportunity converged, where greatness and place became inseparable. Collioure, then, was not just a haven ‚Äî it was Matisse‚Äôs Thrive Zone.

There are places so legendary that we all make a story about them without even experiencing them in reality. We see them in photos, make movies about them, and we can name their main sights just by catching a glimpse of them. And all of these, without putting a foot on their ground.
One of these places is, naturally, Paris. When I think of Paris, I hear Edith Piaf singing about ‚ÄúLa Vie en Rose.‚Äù I sense the scent of freshly baked croissants and Chanel 5, and I see myself wearing a scarf near the Eiffel Tower on a rainy spring afternoon. This is my screenplay after watching too many French movies as a child.
If I had been born years after, Emily and her perception of Paris would probably have influenced my imagined memories, and I‚Äôm not sure this is real.
The French say Paris isn‚Äôt that authentic France; it‚Äôs dirty, crowded, and expensive ‚Äî not that the rest of France isn‚Äôt, I might add.
Still, I discovered my Paris on a different note. First of all, it wasn‚Äôt love at first sight. Oh, not at all. It was that feeling when finally meeting after years and years an old clandestine lover. Even if he lost some of his rich hair and wasn‚Äôt that young anymore, that spark that brought the lovers together didn‚Äôt fade despite the odd circumstances.

Content:

We came to France to visit Nantes, where my son lives. But I would love to travel to Paris too, so we will stay here for two days and then go to Nantes. We must stop in Paris and taste it again. But we end up in a food coma. We are going to cram Paris in just two days. But this time around, I found something unexpected.
The skies were clear as we landed at Charles de Gaulle airport. Our United flight 990 was unexpectedly impressive. They fed us terrible food the entire time, but the staff was friendly. Get a cab to town next; don‚Äôt take the Metro with all your heavy bags after the long trip. We did that once and deeply regretted it. Make sure you find the official ones, which are found at sortie 24. Don‚Äôt fall for the gypsies.
We rented an Air B&B in Le Marais at Rue Vielles de Temple. Usually, the pictures look better, but this one was the exact opposite. If you rent an Air B&B when you travel to Paris, remember to arrange for the owner to meet at the door because, unlike in the United States, you can‚Äôt just get there, get a code, and get in. In most cases.
After settling in the apartment, we walked through Le Marais. It was quite an experience because you find yourself in a different world, and the contrast back home gives you a buzz‚Ä¶

Yesterday I went across Paris with a driver called Abderrazak. I had to go from Paris Orly airport all the way to Charles de Gaulle on the other side of the city, where the international airport is located and stay overnight before taking our Cathay Pacific flight back to Hong Kong.
My daughters fell asleep after a long day travelling from the Canary Islands, so I started to chat with the stranger in command. I am usually guilty of pulling out my iPhone every time I have a break but this time, I decided to live in the real world, and leave my digital life in my pocket.
I found out Abde was born in Paris to Algerian parents who emigrated from Oran to France for a better life, like many others in the 60‚Äôs, once the French occupation of Algeria ended.
Although he feels French and has only been to Algeria on holidays, he said people are not satisfied when he says he is French.
Even though his passport says his place of birth is Roissy (in Paris), his darker look and Arab name raise suspicious eyebrows.

I‚Äôm sitting at the Air France Lounge at Charles De Gaulle, pulling down episode two of Studio 60 over the wi-fi so I can watch it on the flight back, and figured I‚Äôd do a little blogging while I‚Äôm at it. I‚Äôve been in Paris the past two days to do a speech for Disney, which means, of course, that I fly all the way from New York to Paris and then I‚Äôm immediately taken to Paris Disneyland, where they‚Äôve put me up in the ‚ÄúNew York‚Äù hotel. Of all the Baudrillardian ironies‚Ä¶
I‚Äôve done a lot of these two day trips to foreign cities in recent years: Lisbon, Hong Kong, Paris, Hamburg, Amsterdam, London many times. They can be a little exhausting, but I‚Äôve grown fond of the routine. There‚Äôs no time to actually try to see anything systematically, no time even to really acclimate to the place. So I basically just try to take a half day and evening, and just walk around with no real destination, letting the natural flow of the city direct me. In cities that I know quite well, like London or Paris, the fun of it is in figuring out the limits of my knowledge, in others it‚Äôs more of a process of discovery. And I always try to have some new music that I‚Äôve just downloaded, to listen to on the iPod as a soundtrack. It embeds this lovely ‚Äî and enduring ‚Äî connection between the music and the memory of a place‚Ä¶
But enough about all that ‚Äî SARAH JESSICA PARKER is sitting right next to me in the Lounge!! Does Gawker have a Paris edition?

Over two decades, I‚Äôve reviewed more books about France than any non-English speaking country. So, I suspect, have most critics.
Writers were heading for the caf√©s and boulevards of Paris more than a century before Snoop Dogg carried the Olympic torch through the streets of the City of Light, and literature is the richer for it.
James Baldwin went there to escape American racism. Ernest Hemingway arrived as a correspondent for the Toronto Daily Star. Edith Wharton first visited the city as child and eventually felt so at home that she spent the last three decades of her life there. She explained the allure of Paris with a line that translates to, ‚ÄúI have it in my blood.‚Äù
So many writers have had the same blood disease that the city has inspired good books in a vast number of genres of fiction and nonfiction for adults or children. The abundance could make you say: Mon Dieu!
Where do you start looking for one?
Other critics might urge you to begin with a masterwork. But I never finished Proust‚Äôs In Search of Lost Time after‚Ä¶

The Petit Palais in Paris is only a hundred and twenty years old ‚Äî give or take half a decade. It was built, along with the Grand Palais across the street, for the Exposition Universelle of 1900. Two years later the Petit Palais was designated a museum, and today it is part of the glorious collection of free museums of the City of Paris.
So nobody has ever lived in the palace. But one can dream.
The Petit Palais is on the right bank of the Seine, a pleasant twenty minute walk from my home, and often along the path to or from another destination. It is easy to wander in and out again, particularly if you use the ground floor entrance where there is almost never a line as you pass through security.
Gustave Courbet‚Äôs Le Sommeil (The Sleepers, 1866), my favorite erotic painting of all time, is housed in one of the large galleries, along with a number of Courbet‚Äôs other nineteenth-century masterpieces. I‚Äôve copped to my fondness for this extraordinary painting in another story.

When I moved to Paris in 2013 one of the first things I did was obtain a Navigo card and after a couple months of buying monthly passes manually via machines I switched to an annual pass and have not had to think about topping up again. The metro was the way I moved about Paris.
But after getting to know the Metro fairly well you realize that it‚Äôs often just as easy to walk to a certain location and you start making choices about what form of transportation makes the most sense given the weather, your mood, what you‚Äôre carrying, and what else you still need to accomplish. Velib was already around when I arrived in 2013 and the shared bike boom followed by the rise in trottinette usage meant that options for transport have only multiplied since then. The one form of transport that has received an explosive infusion of support from local government is bicycles.
Now that bike lanes are so well-established in Paris, I wonder how so many of us were brave enough to ride with vehicle traffic for many years prior. Cars and their drivers, convinced that everyone but them were simply ‚Äúintruding‚Äù on their entitled space, didn‚Äôt make life easy for those of us on bicycles, but we figured that was simply the way it would be. I mean, this wasn‚Äôt Amsterdam after all. But little did most of us know that the Dutch model was‚Ä¶

I stepped out on a cold, damp January morning to walk to the nearby supermarket for groceries. When I reached, I realized I had forgotten my phone.
My language handicap gnawing at me as I needed the French-English translation app I was using.
I didn‚Äôt speak a word of French, which wasn‚Äôt ‚ÄòBonjour‚Äô, ‚ÄòMerci‚Äô or ‚ÄòAu revoir‚Äô back then. I was looking for salt at the supermarket.
It was the start of 2016. I had just moved to Paris. For a couple of months, my husband‚Äôs MBA hostel became our abode. He was pursuing his MBA at HEC Paris back then.
And I was tagging along while continuing to do my old job from Paris.
‚ÄúThere is but one Paris and however hard living may be here‚Ä¶the French air clears up the brain and does one good.‚Äù- Vincent van Gogh
The HEC campus was brilliant. I got a first-hand insight into the top MBA college experience.
There were parties, partner engagement group activities, gym, and lectures. With time, we found an elite group of friends to hang out with. This brought in the feeling of ‚Äòa home away from home‚Äô.

‚ÄòYou have any idea if I can use this coupon or do I have to put a coin in?‚Äô
‚ÄòMa‚Äôam I‚Äôve got no idea. I‚Äôm just trying to get to the toilet.‚Äô
Apple pay worked on the second try, and the turnstile swung open to the sordid men‚Äôs room of the Gare du Nord station. I paid and I pissed. I rejoined mum in the queue for the self-operated ticket machine, which we eventually summitted, only to find all 3 out of order. Stranded in the underground of one of Paris‚Äô busiest stations, fearing for our lives, we sought concord by the help desk.
I‚Äôd had far from a glowing first impression ‚Äî I figured I was already starting to buy into the Paris syndrome ‚Äî the heightened expectations. The inevitable letdown.
I had hardly been won over on the way here. The views from the Eurostar had been, actually, short of spectacular.
‚ÄòI‚Äôm pretty sure we just popped out the tunnel in France. Looks like England but worse.‚Äô
What I didn‚Äôt realise, as I complained to my girlfriend about the Merville countryside, was that France doesn‚Äôt just look like England. Just like home, France is a parasite. Slums feeding off the prestige of the capital. Like London, Paris is a very rich city attached to an otherwise lacklustre country.
I‚Äôd seen and dismissed the outskirts, the prefabs enlivened by graffiti and the‚Ä¶

Title: The Toilet Culture of Paris
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
Share
Paris is one of the most visited cities in the world, but you will enjoy your stay more if you understand the complicated toilet culture. Parisien toilets are almost as diverse as the French cheeses, and the etiquette for using them can be confusing for a first-time visitor. I have taken 20 student groups to Paris, and I always tell my students to use a bathroom when they see one so there are fewer emergency situations.
Let me help you with what you need to know.
In the Louvre. In the main lobby under the stairs there are free bathrooms. The bathroom at the food court costs 50 centimes, and there is a bathroom that claims to be the cleanest in Paris. This bathroom is the most expensive. Obviously, you should use the free bathroom, but it helps you to know what to expect from the other two.
In the Luxembourg gardens. There are free bathrooms in the front to the left, at the back, and in the middle near the tennis court. It is expected for you to leave a small tip at the counter. I usually leave 20‚Äì50 centimes.
Public street bathrooms. There are public bathrooms on the street that look like spaceships. You will need change. They self-clean in between use, so wait for the green light.
In Caf√©s. If you need to use the bathroom in a caf√©, you should buy something. You usually don‚Äôt need to pay in a caf√©. Sometimes the owner will give you a jeton to use as a coin.
Although they are a rarity now, you might find a type of bathroom called Napoleon. It is two feet separated by a hole. When you flush make sure to step away from the feet because the water will wash over the feet.
I hope these suggestions help you to understand the bathroom culture.

Title: The Legacy of Paris Fashion Week: How It Shapes Global Trends
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Paris may be known as the city of love, but it‚Äôs also a city known for its fashion, if Emily in Paris has anything to say about it. As one of the ‚ÄúBig Four‚Äù fashion weeks (alongside New York, Milan, and London), Paris has cemented its legacy as the epicenter of haute couture and ready-to-wear collections.
Paris Fashion Week is an event that kickstarts trends off the runways and into retail stores and wardrobes globally. Here‚Äôs what you should know about it:
Paris Fashion Week wasn‚Äôt always as famous as it is now. Back in 1973, the French Fashion Federation established it as an official event to showcase the country‚Äôs unparalleled sartorial talent. But you‚Äôd be surprised to know that Paris‚Äôs love affair with high fashion goes back a long way.
In the 17th century, Louis XIV, also known as the Sun King, played an influential role in elevating France‚Äôs reputation for luxury fashion. The monarchy‚Äôs patronage of the textile industries and ateliers established Paris as a global destination for style and sophistication.
By the 19th century, the arrival of Charles Frederick Worth (considered to be the father of haute couture) solidified France‚Äôs dominance when it came to fashion. His maison became a pilgrimage site for royalty and aristocracy. It also ended up laying the groundwork for Parisian fashion houses that are revered today ‚Äî including Chanel and Dior. French fashion dresses became the trend, stemming from the fact that France became known for its quality, style, and elegance.
Paris Fashion Week might be synonymous with sophistication, but its real value lies in its diversity. It‚Äôs where avant-garde designers share the stage with heritage brands, creating a rich tapestry of styles and narratives. The event has two objectives: to present haute couture and ready-to-wear styles that speak to elites and everyday fashion enthusiasts, but also to set the tone for trends in the coming year.
Haute couture, which Paris exclusively champions, is an art form in itself. Each piece is generally handcrafted, taking hundreds of hours in craftsmanship alone. Designers like Christian Dior redefine feminine forms and designs, while other designers challenge history and society‚Äôs rules for what fashion should be. In the ready-to-wear segment, Paris outshines many other fashionable cities, due to designers pushing boundaries while maintaining elegance and structure in their clothing.
Paris Fashion Week‚Äôs influence on global trends is unparalleled. Each season, designers debut collections that reflect cultural shifts, technological advancements, and environmental consciousness. From the rising popularity of gender-neutral fashion and artisanal clothing to the integration of sustainable practices, Paris runways are a microcosm of broader societal ideals.
Think about the past Paris Fashion Weeks ‚Äî there was a time when fashion was all about the classic silhouette. But during Fashion Weeks in the 2010s, this notion was dispelled. Designers like Maria Grazia Chiuri and Virginie Viard breathed new life into traditional forms, blending history with modernity while retaining sophistication. Paris Fashion Week is also an event where it is consistently proved that fashion isn‚Äôt just about wearable clothing ‚Äî it‚Äôs also about conceptual art.
Many people believe that Paris Fashion Week is only about showcasing French designers, but that‚Äôs not the case at all. It‚Äôs a global platform that celebrates talent from around the world. Many designers see it as an award of sorts because it is the ultimate stage to attain recognition. This is also a stage for established brands to reaffirm their status and gain brand retention among their customer base.
The event also acts as a launchpad for emerging designers. Initiatives like the ANDAM Fashion Award spotlight fresh talent. It gives budding designers the opportunity to present their work to an audience of industry leaders, buyers, and journalists. These platforms are monumental in shaping the next generation of fashion, making sure that Paris will forever remain at the forefront of innovation.
In the past few years, especially after COVID-19, technology has transformed the way many experience Paris Fashion Week. Live-streamed shows, virtual reality experiences, and social media have democratized access, allowing millions to view this event while it‚Äôs occurring. Social media platforms have become integral to the event, with influencers and brands using them to amplify their audience reach.
But despite its long legacy and renown, Paris Fashion Week is not a stranger to challenges. From rising calls for sustainability to accessibility, there are many areas where progress is being made. The rise of digital fashion ‚Äî virtual garments and NFTs ‚Äî poses both a challenge and an opportunity. Paris Fashion Week has begun to explore these frontiers, as well as others, in an effort to remain relevant even during changing times.
Considering Paris Fashion Week‚Äôs history, it‚Äôs clear how important it has become in the fashion world. It‚Äôs not just that it‚Äôs a legacy event; it‚Äôs an event that sets standards for fashion everywhere in the world. It‚Äôs a cultural phenomenon that dictates how we perceive and engage with fashion, even on a daily basis. The colors, styles, and fits that are all the rage today were on the runways at some point in time, showing just how influential this event is.
--
--
Tess DiNapoli is an artist, freelance writer, and content strategist. She has a passion for yoga and often writes about fitness & wellness, as well as fashion.

Title: My Journey to France, Part 1
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Helping You Adapt to Life in France

--
Listen
Share
I‚Äôve lived in France on and off since 2014. I‚Äôm often asked, ‚ÄúHow did you do it?‚Äù The short answer is a lot of determination and a refusal to take non as an answer. But, I know a lot of our TAIP readers hope to live in France permanently one day (or are already here and want to know how to stay), so I want to share, step-by-step, my own journey to France and how I made it all work.
Let‚Äôs get right into it.
I never imagined I‚Äôd ever study abroad, never mind live abroad. One day, when I was still in Rhode Island completing my undergrad, a friend of mine had to pick up some paperwork from the study abroad office. We had plans after so I decided to tag along. While I waited for her, an advisor approached me and asked if I was interested in learning more about my options. I shrugged and said, ‚ÄúWhy not?‚Äù (if you‚Äôve been in France a while, you‚Äôll also find that this is a very frequently used idiom that indicates French willingness to try something new‚Ä¶another topic for another article) and joined him in his office.
I was studying fashion merchandising at the time, so after taking a look at my transcript he told me that my best options would be Milan or Paris. Was I interested in leaving for an entire semester? (no). Okay, how about the J-term in between the fall and spring semesters? (maybe‚Ä¶). He started pulling out pamphlets and I absentmindedly leafed through them.
At the time, I had a steady job at a local boutique and a long-term boyfriend. I thought all of that was way too important to leave, even for just a few months. But, as the advisor continued to sell me on my options (do these people get a commission on sign-ups or something?) I slowly started to warm up to the idea. He asked me again, ‚ÄúMilan or Paris?‚Äù Without really thinking about it I said Paris ‚Äî I‚Äôd seen movies, read books, heard about the French capital. I knew what it looked like at least, as compared to knowing nothing about Milan ‚Äî a few taps on his keyboard as he took a closer look at my transcript and he told me that if I wanted to graduate on time, a full semester was my best bet. ‚ÄúWhat do you think?‚Äù
Again, without really thinking about it I said, ‚ÄúOkay. How do I sign up?‚Äù
I didn‚Äôt even have a passport at the time and thoughts of my job and boyfriend fluttered through my mind; to be honest, even to this day I don‚Äôt know what made me say yes. Unlike some expats, I never had a lifelong dream of living in Paris, and yet, something urged me to do that semester abroad back in 2012.
I ended up having the best six months of my life, completely fell in love with the city, French culture, the food‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm sure half of my readership knows exactly what I mean. A group of four of us even ended up staying for an extra month down in Cannes because none of us were ready to leave. Alas, I did have to go back to the US to finish my undergrad, and that I did. Dreams of living in France full-time slowly but surely disappeared as I slipped right back into my former life. I graduated, got promoted at the boutique, and moved into a new apartment with my best friend. Life was ‚Äúgood,‚Äù though I couldn‚Äôt shake the feeling that something wasn‚Äôt right.
In the winter of 2013 I was still working at the boutique and was, to be frank, miserable. So what do miserable people do when they‚Äôre bored at work? They scroll through Facebook, naturally. A message popped up ‚Äî it was from a girl whom I studied abroad with who had never left after our semester. She decided to stay to be an au pair with a Franco-American family because she wasn‚Äôt ready to go back to the US.
We were just chatting, catching up, when my curiosity got the best of me. ‚ÄúHow were you able to stay?‚Äù I asked. Was it difficult? I can‚Äôt stop thinking about Paris myself‚Ä¶
She filled me a bit and then told me that in fact, she planned on leaving her au pair position in May of next year. She loved the family (and had been with them since June 2012. It was November 2013 at this point) and was helping them find her replacement. She ultimately wanted it to go to someone she knew ‚Äî she really cared about the kids ‚Äî was I interested? I hesitated. Maybe. I told her I‚Äôd think about it.
Life got busy with the upcoming holiday season and I soon forgot about the conversation. Fast-forward to March 2014 and my friend messaged me again. Did I have time to think about coming back to France as an au pair? The family still hadn‚Äôt found a replacement. Like most young women my age, I had plenty of babysitting experience and I even nannied for a few summers when I was a student.
Just like that fateful moment in the study abroad office a year and a half earlier, without really thinking about it, I said, ‚ÄúOkay. What‚Äôs next?‚Äù
While I‚Äôm the first to admit that I stayed in my English-speaking-au-pair bubble for longer than I maybe should have, living and working in France was much different than studying abroad. I had to navigate French culture much more often (I was living with a French person and French children, after all), and learning how to adapt was difficult at times.
I was often homesick after the first six months and the initial excitement wore off ‚Äî I also struggled to find a core group of friends. But, I did adapt, grow, learn, and eventually, thrive. My years as an au pair were some of my favorite that I spent in Paris and when I did find my people I felt like I truly belonged.
The caveat(s)? I still couldn‚Äôt speak French, my au pair contract was running out, I knew I didn‚Äôt want to work in fashion anymore, and I also knew I wasn‚Äôt ready to go back to my life in Rhode Island.
I had to figure out a way to stay.
Well, I did figure it out, but that story will have to wait until Part 2.

Title: I survived the Siege of Paris and all I got was this token.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Okay, let me start by saying that the title of this post is sort of a joke. I am going to talk about a commemorative souvenir token that people who lived through the 1870‚Äì1871 Siege of Paris could buy, but the ‚Äúall I got‚Äù part isn‚Äôt at all how most of them would have thought of it.
As France continued to lose the Franco-Prussian War and the month of September, 1870, progressed, Parisians (and visitors to Paris) realized that the Prussian army would soon surround the city. In a short time, Paris would be cut off from the rest of the world and besieged. And so, many residents and visitors left the city as quickly as they could. An understandable decision, of course, and one that many of them were probably grateful for, since those who stayed in Paris experienced hunger, extreme cold, disgusting bread and other food choices, and even a month of heavy bombardment by the Prussians for those who lived on the Left (South) bank of the Seine.
That said, it wasn‚Äôt always easy for those who fled the city, either. In addition to sometimes being separated from family members and friends, they also often hadn‚Äôt packed what was really necessary. For instance, a letter in Paris‚Äôs Mus√©e de la Poste (Postal Museum) that was delivered by pigeon post includes a complaint about not having brought warm enough clothes. This was probably because most Parisians thought the Siege, which started on September 19, 1870, would only last a month or two, if that. And then there was the fact that no one could have predicted that the winter of 1870‚Äì1871 would be one of the coldest in recorded history.
Still, the Parisians and foreigners who stayed behind in the city had a great deal of pride that they saw the Siege through, especially when they compared themselves to those Parisians in the upper class or government who had evacuated.
The Siege of Paris had its humorous side. Satirical cartoons were a huge thing during that time, not to mention funny songs. But there was also an overwhelming, often excessive sense of patriotism. Read even a few accounts of the Siege and you‚Äôll easily find a number of examples. One of the most interesting ones I‚Äôve come across recently was recorded by Francisque de Bioti√®re in his memoir Paris dans les caves, √©pisode du si√®ge 1870‚Äì71 (Paris in the Basements, an Episode of the 1870‚Äì1871 Siege). He writes about how mothers would teach their babies to blow a kiss when someone said ‚ÄúPour les Fran√ßais ! ‚Äù (‚ÄúFor the French!‚Äù) and to make a fist when someone said Pour les Prussiens ! (‚ÄúFor the Prussians!‚Äù).
This was actually one of the more light-hearted manifestations of patriotism during the Siege. You can see the other extreme in things like the arrest of General Ambert, whose ‚Äúcrime‚Äù was yelling ‚ÄúVive la France!‚Äù during a battle, instead of ‚ÄúVive la R√©publique!‚Äù What was probably just a slip in the midst of a life-threatening situation was perceived by many Parisians as a sign of dissension towards the the newly created Third Republic, which had been proclaimed on September 4.
Even those Parisians who didn‚Äôt become fervently patriotic often felt a sense of pride for having endured the Siege. While I don‚Äôt understand the hysterical patriotism, I do understand that latter feeling. And after all, we still make and buy souvenirs today that commemorate things like surviving a hurricane and its aftermath or, on a lighter note, getting through a particularly difficult sport-related challenge or hike‚Ä¶or pub crawl.
The 1871 answer to this was a commemorative coin, called a jeton de pr√©sence (token of presence). I was surprised and delighted to discover that there are at least two contemporary descriptions of the tokens in newspapers ‚Äî one in Le Monde Illustr√©, and another from the Moniteur du Puy de D√¥me, a newspaper from a region very far from Paris.
The French Minist√®re des Arm√©es‚Äô Chemins de M√©moire blog includes a direct quote from the Moniteur du Puy de D√¥me (my English translation follows):
On a frapp√© √† Paris une m√©daille comm√©morative du si√®ge, uniquement destin√©e aux personnes qui n‚Äôont pas quitt√© la capitale au moment du danger. Elle est en bronze, sur l‚Äôune des faces se trouve un groupe symbolique repr√©sentant Paris repoussant l‚Äô√©tranger, sur l‚Äôautre on lit : R√©publique fran√ßaise, jeton de pr√©sence. Un espace libre permet √† chaque citoyen d‚Äôy faire inscrire son nom.‚Äù
Frapp√© par la Monnaie de Paris en argent et en cuivre, ce jeton pouvait √™tre acquis par les civils ou militaires qui avaient √©t√© pr√©sents lors du si√®ge.
(In Paris, a commemorative medal of the Siege has been struck, solely intended for those people who didn‚Äôt leave the capital during this dangerous time. The medal is made of bronze, on one of is faces is a symbolic group of figures representing Paris fending off the foreign threat, on the other [face] one can read: French Republic, token of presence. There is a blank space [below this] where each citizen [who‚Äôs purchased a token] can have his or her name engraved.
Struck by the Paris [National] Mint in silver and in copper, this token can be acquired by civilians or military personnel who were present during the Siege.)
Le Monde Illustr√©‚Äôs mention of the token is sort of like a companion piece to this. It‚Äôs an advertisement, and shows, among other things, that the token was available in other materials as well: white metal (I‚Äôm assuming this would be a cheap alloy that looked like silver) and imitation gold, in addition to silver and bronze. There‚Äôs no mention here of a copper option, so maybe the two reddish-gold metals were used interchangeably by the writer of the Moniteur du Puy de D√¥me article.
Interestingly, the ad for the jeton was published on January 21, 1871 ‚Äî a week before the Siege ended. Although most Parisians knew the end of the Siege was inevitable at that point, it‚Äôs interesting that some were already producing commemorative souvenirs. There is a sense of opportunism, but maybe it was also a sort of consolation ‚Äî ‚ÄúAt least we got through it,‚Äù or ‚ÄúFrance may have lost, but we Parisians were tough and held out as long as we could.‚Äù
In all of my research on the Siege of Paris and its aftermath, I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve ever heard about jetons de pr√©sence ‚Äî or if I have, I guess it didn‚Äôt stick with me. They are legit, though; even the Mus√©e Carnavalet, Paris‚Äôs delightful history museum, has one in its permanent collection.
And then, one day, I came upon some present-day ads for jetons de pr√©sence, on Le Bon Coin. A very popular site in France today, Le Bon Coin is sort of like Facebook Marketplace, where you can find anything ‚Äî including some really interesting antiques. In fact, it‚Äôs where I found my beloved Siege of Paris bread souvenir.
From time to time, I‚Äôll head over there and do a search for ‚ÄúSi√®ge de Paris 1870‚Äù and see what comes up. In late February, a few jetons de pr√©sence were among the results.
Although they aren‚Äôt the most iconic Siege souvenir (at least, not for me ‚Äî that honor definitely goes to bread souvenirs), the significance of them, that sense of pride that they‚Äôre so closely associated with, and that universal idea of wanting to commemorate something we‚Äôve been through, really stuck with me. The more I thought about it, the more I wanted to buy one.* One day, a new jeton de pr√©sence ad appeared. Unlike most jetons I‚Äôve seen, this one actually had a name engraved on the back, and, rarer still, it was a woman‚Äôs name: Blanche La Jousse.
I loved this connection to a real person, and something about the fact that she was a woman made it even more moving to me. I thought of Claire, one of the main characters of my novel Hearts at Dawn.
But whether or not the name had been that of a man or a woman, the fact that someone had purchased this token and then taken on the additional trouble and expense of having it engraved is a powerful sign to me of how much their experience mattered to them and how much they didn‚Äôt want it to be forgotten.
‚Ä¶Although a part of me wonders if it was a misguided gift that had been given to them by someone else. Maybe Blanche La Jousse just wanted to move on from the Siege, and didn‚Äôt care about having an engraved coin to commemorate the experience. It‚Äôs one of those things we‚Äôll never know.
Jetons de pr√©sence are often bought and sold by coin collectors, and in fact, when I reached out to the person who was selling this one**, he told me that he dabbled in coin collecting and had bought it at the March√© aux Puces de Saint-Ouen (a huge antiques and flea market just outside Paris) a decade or so ago. He didn‚Äôt know much about the Siege of Paris but had been attracted to the coin for the image on the front.
It‚Äôs a compelling one: (Likely) on the wall that then surrounded Paris, an allegorical personification of Paris is defending the city with a spear she‚Äôs holding out in one hand. In the other, she holds a flag. She‚Äôs surrounded by soldiers. There‚Äôs impressive detail in their uniforms; we can see the typical uniform of a member of the Garde National, but also the sailor-like uniform some artilleryman/gunners wore. Many of these men were recruited from the navy. We can also see barrels and other materials that reinforced the National Guards‚Äô posts along the city wall. You can spot many of these in photos like this one. Despite all of these details, though, the face of the Paris figure isn‚Äôt sharply defined.
Beneath the group, we have the words ‚ÄúSI√àGE DE PARIS‚Äù and the year 1870 in Roman numerals.
The back of the token is far less elaborate, with R√âPUBLIQUE FRAN√áAISE written around the top rim, in a curved box with a five-pointed star at the outside of each end. The bottom of the token has the same sort of curved box along the rim, but nothing is written in it. At the top center of the token‚Äôs back are the words ‚ÄúJETON DE PR√âSENCE‚Äù, followed by a small decorative symbol. The rest of the jeton‚Äôs back would have been left intentionally blank, and many jetons de pr√©sence you find today remain so, but here we see that as was intended, Blanche La Jousse had her name engraved in the blank space.
I like the back of the jeton best, since it has this unique, human touch.
I didn‚Äôt expect to learn more about Blanche La Jousse, but when I received the coin, my husband, who‚Äôs an experienced genealogy researcher in his spare time, suddenly had an idea. He called me over to his computer. To my astonishment, he‚Äôd found a record of her burial in Paris‚Äôs Cimeti√®re du Montparnasse. You can see the two full pages of the ledger here. Blanche La Jousse‚Äôs name is the seventh on the list. Here‚Äôs a closeup of the line with information about Blanche:
The cemetery‚Äôs records gave us some insights into Blanche‚Äôs life. She died in 1917 at the age of 75, meaning she was 28 at the time of the Siege. I was amazed that this made her only a few years older than Claire in Hearts at Dawn. Not that this is the most important thing, of course. Still, it was a moving coincidence.
According to the records, Blanche lived in Paris‚Äôs 7th arrondissement (7th Ward). We don‚Äôt know where she was born, or if she ever lived in other places or even other arrondissements, but this means that at the very least, she was living in Paris during the Siege and was back in the city (which was once again undergoing a war and bombing), at the end of her life in 1917. Maybe she was a lifelong Parisian. If she wasn‚Äôt, I hope she was happy about returning here.
It‚Äôs doubtful that she‚Äôs still in the burial plot listed for her, since Parisian cemeteries tend to remove people‚Äôs remains to a charnel house after a certain number of years. But there are exceptions ‚Äî for instance, family mausoleums or people whose descendants continue to pay for the plot. Whatever the case, we plan to go to the cemetery one of these days and see if we can find her gravesite.
I wish I knew more about Blanche La Jousse than this. I hope she likes being mentioned here, and thought about. I know that, like everyone who stayed in Paris during the Siege, she had a difficult four months. I hope she didn‚Äôt suffer too much. I hope she liked her jeton de pr√©sence and carried it with pride or kept it in a place of pride. The fact that it wasn‚Äôt found at the March√© aux Puces till recently makes me wonder if it was kept by her descendants for a few generations. That‚Äôs something I‚Äôll never know, either.
But I hope she thinks it‚Äôs funny that her jeton left Paris with a collector and now is back in the city, with a family who wonders about her from time to time and admires her for getting through one of the hardest times in Paris‚Äôs history.
~~~
*If you‚Äôd like to get a jeton de pr√©sence of your own, you can find them for sale on various coin collector websites, as well as on eBay. Most jetons de pr√©sence, engraved with a name or not, tend to be sold for around 25‚Äì35 euros (about 27 to 28 US dollars).
**Special thanks to the man who sold the jeton to me and answered my questions about where he got it. The photos he took of the jeton de pr√©sence are the ones I‚Äôve used in this post, since my phone‚Äôs camera just could not get that level of definition. I would have asked if he wanted to be credited by name, but once I told him that my husband and I were going to look for Blanche‚Äôs grave, he stopped responding to my messages ‚Äî I think he thought that was creepy.
~~
A Beauty and the Beast retelling set during the 1870‚Äì1871 Siege of Paris, Hearts at Dawn has been selected as a Historical Novel Society Editors‚Äô Choice book. It‚Äôs currently available in Kindle and paperback formats and is part of the Kindle Unlimited Library. I hope you‚Äôll give it a read!
