A ‚Äújournal‚Äù of our year long trip away from Vancouver.

--
Listen
Share
‚Äú‚Ä¶Is to know a great deal.‚Äù ~ Henry Miller (controversial author)
Paris is a place of lore. After years of listening to people I love and respect talk endlessly about Paris, we had arrived. Albeit, only for a long weekend. It wasn‚Äôt enough time.
It‚Äôs not only clients or friends. Paris has been revered throughout history as an artist‚Äôs haven.
‚ÄúAn artist has no home in Europe except in Paris.‚Äù ~ Friedrich Nietzsche
A divine place of historical significance, beauty and culture.
‚ÄúA walk about Paris will provide lessons in history, beauty, and in the point of Life.‚Äù ~ Thomas Jefferson
And of course, surrealism and the ann√©es folles or the golden twenties. The birth of pop culture. The modern development of fashion and style. A melting pot of American influence, tremendous economic growth, film, theatre, and athletics.
Many of my favourite writers and artists have lived in Paris at some point in their career.
‚ÄúParis was always worth it and you received return for whatever you brought to it.‚Äù ~ Ernest Hemingway
For the novice traveller, Paris comes with quite the r√©sum√©.
Dare I say it is the the most over-hyped city I‚Äôve ever travelled to. My feelings are more mixed than history‚Äôs. Possibly due to over-saturation and cost of living. Which is saying a lot coming from Vancouver (another high cost of living city). Then again, it could be because I don‚Äôt have any Parisian friends to show me around.
It‚Äôs the 3rd most visited city in the world, but the average dollar amount spent by tourists is double the top two cities (Bangkok/London). $301/day USD compared to $153‚Äì173.
It‚Äôs extremely expensive, and shockingly packed with tourist destinations.
You can‚Äôt walk more than a few hundred meters without tripping over the next museum or historical landmark. Seriously I can throw a rock from the Louvre to Saint Chapelle.
We saw the outside of pretty much everything on day one. Then we were left wishing we had planned some skip the line excursions. Getting ready to leave and Oktoberfest were so busy we forgot to plan things that weren‚Äôt accommodation. Even in October, it was crowded with tourists!
Yes, I understand the irony of that statement, being that I‚Äôm a tourist. No matter how I may like to pretend I‚Äôm not, or try to experience places as locals do. I remain an ignorant tourist.
I can only wonder how @#%@ing crazy Paris is in the summertime.
Paris, has a population of ~2.3 million. The majority of the city is composed of five story walk-ups. Making it the most densely populated metropolis in a developed country and it‚Äôs geographically tiny!
Vancouver is tiny, at only 115 km¬≤. We build towers exceeding thirty stories and have a population of only 600k. San Francisco, another tiny city, is 121 km¬≤ and 800k people. I‚Äôm amazed by the density of Paris without the need for many tall buildings.
Paris is a mere 105 km¬≤ with triple or quadruple the people. That means it‚Äôs chaotic. Very walkable, with an somewhat outdated and packed metro system. At least it covers a great deal of the city and they post hilarious signs in it.
And my personal Fav‚Ä¶
Are misunderstood. I had full on expectations of being forced to stumble through my poor French. While the person I‚Äôm attempting to communicate with snickers behind my back about it.
You hear stories. Few of them true.
The service doesn‚Äôt suck, it‚Äôs just not Americanized. It‚Äôs supposed to be felt and not seen. They are not coming to check on you every 5 minutes. They are not coming by to crack jokes and entertain you for tips. They want you to enjoy your meal or coffee or whatever. When you‚Äôre done, ask for the cheque s‚Äôil vous pla√Æt and you‚Äôre off.
I kind of like it. I‚Äôm not fond of being waited on.
People are not rude. But you should keep an eye on your stuff and your wallet when travelling on packed transit. As you should in any major city.
People are fashionable. I should have brought a scarf. A concern Jenny and I both have about travelling to Europe, is only obvious in Paris so far. Not that I‚Äôm fashionable to begin with. I have for the better part of twelve years worked in shorts, a sweat-wicking shirt and maybe a track suit of sorts.
There is a pervasive feeling in any country about the largest city. Canadians outside of Toronto like to hate on it. The French outside of Paris also seem to hate on Paris. I get the feeling Parisians are in love with their city.
There is an air of smugness. I feel the same way about Vancouver. The French tend to think that Parisians never shut up about Paris when they leave it. Everything is better in Paris! I don‚Äôt feel this way about Toronto but I know some who do.
I‚Äôm choked I missed the Catacombs. Things were so crazy before we left and at Oktoberfest we forgot to book any tours.
The only non-negotiable thing for me was the Louvre. I‚Äôve had a fascination with Leonardo Da Vinci since I was a kid and seeing the Mona Lisa was a top priority.
It‚Äôs true that no matter where you stand in the room, it feels like she‚Äôs staring just at you. A special technique Da Vinci used. Of course the world‚Äôs most famous painting is so famous due to the mystery surrounding it.
There are many other famous works in the Louvre like Venus De Milo, Winged Victory, The Coronation of Napoleon, Dying Slave and Liberty Leading Leading the People. Michelangelo. Delacroix. Who cares? I‚Äôm all about Da Vinci right now. üòú
We crushed a few kilometers of walking every day. I thoroughly enjoyed taking it all in. You could have a great weekend without going into a single tourist venue.
We stayed near the Eiffel tower. Had a bottle of wine on the grass during one of the hourly light shows. Roamed through a beautiful market. Rolled down Champs-√âlys√©es past the Arc de Triomphe and the Louvre.
I know French food is amazing but we cooked in our tiny AirBnB more often than not. Who can resist French cheese and charcuterie?
After a costly Oktoberfest, we‚Äôre attempting to be a little more budget conscious here. It seems more likely we‚Äôll be back to Paris than Munich anyway.
I‚Äôm just going to say it. If you like red wine, it‚Äôs the best in France. End of story. I‚Äôm convinced they don‚Äôt ship any of the good stuff to Canada.
Oh and don‚Äôt forget about the street art and a surprising coincidence. An Alphonse Mucha exhibit was on when we were there! One of the few pieces of art we own is a print of Zodiac. I‚Äôm a much bigger Mucha fan leaving Paris.
That‚Äôs our world-wind tour of Paris. It isn‚Äôt my favourite city yet but I can see the charm and appeal. We‚Äôll be back for the catacombs.
It was the weekend so neither of us worked which was nice, Bordeaux will be different. Back to work...ü§ò

Title: My Paris Encounters: A City Where Anything Is Possible
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Here you can publish stories and feelings about anything from real and honest perspective. Our motto: Write just the way you are. It‚Äôs okay to be imperfect. Don‚Äôt worry to be different. We all respect your opinion.üöÄ We have Weekly Boost Stories!ü§ì

--
8
Listen
Share
Some cities you simply visit, while others visit you. Paris is one of the latter. It doesn‚Äôt just stay in your memory; it returns through people, through unexpected messages years later. As if it still cares.
‚Äî Grandma, Paris is so beautiful!
I‚Äôve been there several times, and each time it felt as if the city was waking up from a dream just for me. The Seine‚Äôs embankment was bathed in bright sunlight, boats gliding across the water, and the streets filled with women showcasing that elusive French chic ‚Äî something indescribable that makes their outfits unforgettable.
I sang La Marseillaise in a taxi, much to the bewilderment of the driver, and my cheerful mood helped me meet new people.
One day, not knowing French, I walked into a caf√© and decided to greet the waitress with a phrase from Moulin Rouge:
‚Äî Voulez-vous coucher avec moi ce soir?
She first looked surprised, then narrowed her eyes and smirked, as if evaluating whether I was naive or just bold. Only later did I learn that this meant, ‚ÄúWould you like to sleep with me tonight?‚Äù What a way to start a conversation!
By the way, my coffee arrived unusually fast.
I met a girl on the plane. She was kind, talkative, and suggested we meet up in the city. We sat on the terrace of a caf√© near our hotel, drinking beer at a leisurely pace. She told me about her divorce, her family, and I just listened, smoked, and enjoyed the moment.
There are moments when the right place, the right person, and the right drink come together to create pure bliss. That‚Äôs Paris.
The next day, we both got food poisoning from oysters at a restaurant. After that, she distanced herself a bit, but we still keep in touch.
Sometimes I wonder ‚Äî if not for those oysters, would we have met again? Or did Paris give us exactly what we needed and nothing more?
The Louvre was packed with people. Leonardo da Vinci‚Äôs works were breathtaking in their original form, but my heart was captivated by Murillo‚Äôs paintings. His beggar boy picking lice from his hair ‚Äî wasn‚Äôt just a painting, it was a whole life captured on canvas.
In Versailles, I befriended an IT guy. He was shy, stuttered a bit, but I introduced him to two beauty-industry girls who radiated pure fun. During our tour of Versailles, we drank champagne at the back of the bus. The IT guy loosened up, and later, we all posed among the gardens, mimicking classical statues.
Turns out, life is beautiful when you‚Äôre surrounded by warm, tactile, and kind people.
Parisian skies are a work of art on their own. Impressionist painters knew how to capture their shifting tones, and their works fill the former train station ‚Äî now the Mus√©e d‚ÄôOrsay.
Though I still find Gauguin‚Äôs escapades in Tahiti unsettling, I can‚Äôt deny the raw brilliance of his paintings from that period. They hold a special place in my heart. There‚Äôs something about them, wouldn‚Äôt you agree?
I met two sisters ‚Äî one of them was a model, tall, slender, playful. We laughed a lot, I invited them to the museum, and later, we took pictures in front of the elephant statue.
I was small, she was like a fairy from a storybook, and her sister stood in between us. Paris creates strange yet unforgettable moments.
We drank beer right in front of the Arc de Triomphe, and then the younger sister let me take hundreds of photos of her in a gray coat with her blonde hair cascading down. When she lay on her back on the Pont Alexandre III, I realized that happiness is just a feeling of the moment.
The Loire Valley is a world of its own. Medieval halls, enormous vases overflowing with flowers, and the stories of marquises who lived extravagantly. That‚Äôs where I met a little girl traveling with her grandmother. She dashed through castle corridors, demanding that I take pictures of her in the most unexpected places ‚Äî on rooftops, beside water lilies, even standing on her head.
On the bus, she insisted on sitting next to me, looked at me with her dreamy eyes, and said:
‚Äî Let‚Äôs sleep!
She was seven. It was both funny and surreal.
I wonder ‚Äî if I met her ten years later, would I recognize her?
Paris allows you more freedom than other cities. You can sit in a caf√© late into the night, talking.
‚Äî And sit as long as you want, thank God! ‚Äî says a Notre Dame gargoyle.
At one caf√©, an old man joined our table. He had worked with Tarkovsky, but now he was a hotel porter. His stories about cinema were mesmerizing, though we suspected he had once played for ‚Äúthe other team.‚Äù
At some point, he invited us to a nightclub. We went.
The music was strange ‚Äî acid techno! One French guy from our group drank too much and was supposed to stay at our hotel because he missed his train. At first, we were happy for him, then we were worried ‚Äî he disappeared.
I hope he just got on another train and now tells his friends about the eccentric group of travelers he met that night.
Paris is always fun, unpredictable, and exciting. It‚Äôs best not to plan anything ahead, because new people and places will always find you.
Some cities leave a mark on you.
Ten years later, the little girl from the bus found me.
‚Äî I‚Äôve been looking for you, and I found you! How have you been?
I smiled. I guess she wants me to remind her of the phrase she said to me on the bus. No doubt about it.
Paris never says goodbye.
Paris always gives you a sequel.
Every moment spent with Ni unveils new dimensions of grace and mystery. Dive deeper into her world in:
Silent Observer
--
--
8
Here you can publish stories and feelings about anything from real and honest perspective. Our motto: Write just the way you are. It‚Äôs okay to be imperfect. Don‚Äôt worry to be different. We all respect your opinion.üöÄ We have Weekly Boost Stories!ü§ì
I stay awake through the night ‚Äî not to fight it, but to greet the morning.

Title: The Pulse of Paris
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Trying to get at those travel stories about the verve and the swerve. Not your typical source for travel advice. These are stories about how travel changes you and unfolds you, not how best to be pampered and coddled.

--
Listen
Share
Our interest in travel has something to do with our need to find the swerve. The led-by-the-nose tours suit some but not us. We set out to build adversity and surprise into our personal all-inclusive package. We want to be able to remind ourselves that things like sitting between train cars as a result of thinking it was a good idea to save nine Euros on unassigned seats is nothing more than a gift from heaven to enhance our lives.
The hitches and unforeseen hesitations are the swerves that create the pulse of travel.
This was our plan as we set off to grab a slice of Northern Europe. I have never been to this part of the world and neither has my wife. It was a gap in our travels that we needed to fill. And it was the draw of meeting friends in Paris and Switzerland and the Netherlands that set the outlines for our itinerary.
Our overnight flight left me wide awake with excitement while Stefanie was able to snooze a bit. The route to Paris ran first to Frankfort with its awkward funnel through customs that a weary business traveler commiserated with us on, ‚ÄúThe worst!‚Äù he said. No ranks of Uzi toting police at the airport as I was led to believe. Then on a jump flight to Charles De Gualle arriving in Paris in the early morning.
We got help with our transit connection from a group of young travelers who like us were trying to find the best and cheapest mode to city center. The bus into town seemed promising but more expensive then the Metro so we found our way to the train station and rode into Paris.
The outskirts were unimpressive. But when we popped out of the subway tunnel into city center we emerged onto that glorious limestone and Mansard roofed landscape of Paris I‚Äôve known from pictures and film. Cafes seemingly every three storefronts, busy Parisians hustling off to work, we spilled onto these streets with our luggage in tow and tried to get our bearings.
Promises of easy access to free wi-fi went unfulfilled (as they would continue to be) so we asked the kind shop steward for directions to Petite de Champs, the address of our lodgings. He pointed us off on a tramp of about ten blocks which we accomplished and proceeded to turn down the street that had Petite de Champs in the name. We found the address over a door that was supposed to be green but wasn‚Äôt. Door locked. Asked at the cafe if we could borrow his phone to call the lady and she described her place in variance to what we were seeing. We should have known something was up.
She said the key was upstairs under the mat. Since we couldn‚Äôt get in the street door the cafe guy somehow produced a key and let us in. We lugged our travel belongings up four flights and upon winded arrival found no key under the mat as promised. We collapsed in the hall and a dog bark inside one of the flats brought a young lady to the door. Yes, address and apartment number were correct, no she didn‚Äôt know our host‚Äôs name. This is truly weird. We were clearly missing a piece to this puzzle.
Back we go down to the cafe to discover through a second call and the cafe man‚Äôs astute observation that there were TWO Rue Petite de Champs. This one was Rue Croix Petite de Champs (‚Äúthe road that crosses‚Äù our Petite de Champs). So off we march to find the correct Rue and the aforementioned green door and all the details familiar to our host‚Äôs descriptions. Our first swerve.
To get to our real Paris abode we climbed another four flights of well worn stair treads to the sound of our screaming calf muscles and behold, find the key under the mat! Our room was tidy and totally sufficient to our needs. We managed to contact our friends who had been if France now touring alredy for a week and made a plan to meet that afternoon. After a long travel day with swerves large and small we settled in for a snooze.
That didn‚Äôt last long because we were in Paris and the city was waiting just out there! Off we went to find our friend‚Äôs lodgings which were in the same area of Paris, the First Arrondissement north of the Seine. We mapped out the walk to get there but to no avail, missing a turn and requiring further instructions from yet another in our chain of kind shop owners who served us so faithfully. Turning down Rue de Hyacinth we were greeted by our friend‚Äôs ‚ÄúBonjoir‚Äù from his second floor balcony. We reunited with our good friends Wolf and Charlotte from San Miguel de Allende and Charlotte‚Äôs son Ethan. Sat in their salon (this is Paris after all) to catch up and make our plans for the next few days.
We launched off for an afternoon walk through the gorgeous and immense Louvre courtyards where a cellist was busking under an arch that led towards the pyramid.
Great acoustics there that did his talents proud. We lingered a while to listen and became acquainted with the magic that is The City of Lights. Then down to the Seine to see Notre Dame in one direction and Musee d‚ÄôOrsay in the other. Our original lodging was to be on a barge in the Seine in front of the Musee but our host there had to cancel due to some hitch with periodic maintenance. Sadly, it was not to be for us but we had moved on. Walking back through the Louvre courtyard back into our neighborhood we found our dinner restaurant. I had duck confit which was fittingly outstanding. The waiter helped me learn to say ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt speak French‚Äù so I could beg off as needed. I was using ‚Äúno parlez vous‚Äù which accused the person opposite me of not speaking the language. I was also working hard on my ‚ÄúRavi de vous rencontrer‚Äù (‚Äúnice to meet you‚Äù) which served as my only accomplishment of a multi-word French phrase during our stay in France.
The next day Stefanie and I went back to the Louvre, this time actually going inside. We entered through the pyramid and sat down to map out our visit since this most enormous of art museums requires a strategy to trim the seemingly infinite possibilities. We headed first to the French and Italian painting of the 16th and 17th centuries. We were both stopped dead in our tracks in front of the Holbein portraits. Soft and pulsating flesh that has actual blood flowing through it as best I can tell. Firm and telling hands. Eyes that beg conversation. These people emerge from the years as fully alive and unburdened by any mists of obscurity history presents.
We found an amazing veiled bust of a woman in the Egyptian wing that stood our neck hairs on end. She had all the mystery of the ages wrapped in her half hidden face and could easily have been mistaken for the work of a modern master.
Rooms and rooms of paintings. On through early Renaissance Italian works where Stefanie called me back to pause because I had rushed by a bit. She was right as usual. These were delicate and everyday human renditions that broke from the religious/aristocratic subject matter.
Then rooms and rooms of furniture for the era of the the King Louis‚Äô. Seemingly endless collections of amazing craftsmanship but largely vacant of people who, including me, find the style overbearing and fusty. All that effort by expert furniture makers who I‚Äôm sure thought their efforts were proffered in a style that represented the pinnacle of everlasting beauty.
Finally, and more by chance than design we crossed by the famous ‚ÄúWinged Victory‚Äù to the more populated wing where the icon of all things art resides. ‚ÄúThe Cult of the Mona‚Äù was in full throng and the packed room focused their cameras on the tiny, charming, sedate portrait that causes people with only a nodding familiarity with art to change their life‚Äôs course in order to view. The painting looks just like the reproductions and is just about poster sized as well. Nice but I wasn‚Äôt exactly moved to tears by the encounter.
‚ÄúThe Cult of the Mona‚Äù throng who were taking pictures, on the other hand, were more interesting to me. The cultural anthropologist in me was interested in expanding on the theory of large groups as they relate to cultural icons. I also wondered how time will operate on this painting. Will we ever actually get over it? Is there life outside the cult? In my picture of the swooning multitudes I counted three who where actually looking with their own eyes at that particular moment.
The next room is where I found my true joy. Against a side wall in a room full of absolute masterpieces was the monumental ‚ÄúRaft of the Medusa‚Äù by Theodore Gericault. Depicting the crisis moment after an apparent shipwreck in tossed seas (based on an actual shipwreck with tragic loss of life), the painting presents the survivors huddling and comforting each other while the more intact denizens of this piece of flotsam raise a red cloth to signal a far distant ship. An image of human struggle to maintain hope in the face of nature‚Äôs imposition of mortality.
We headed to our rendezvous (Paris thing again‚Ä¶) with our friends in front of Notre Dame Cathedral. We were late but they were later. Our plan was to walk into Sain Germaine across the Seine and time was getting way from us. That and the long line into Notre Dame led us away to cross the river leaving the famous Cathedral for our next visit to Paris.
The West Bank of the Seine is where we came upon the well known green boothed book sellers called ‚Äúbouguinistes‚Äù. We strolled the Seine‚Äôs bank and examined the wonderful contents of each booth. Some had the uninteresting plastic tourists mementos but most had great old posters, postcards and photographs tracing the history of Paris. Several vendors were selling truly beautiful etchings and lithographs, many with cityscape and landscape subjects from the past centuries.
We turned back to review the stands once more because our target was the famous Shakespeare Booksellers shop. This landmark of Paris was owned by the person who first published James Joyce‚Äôs ‚ÄúUlysses‚Äù and did it while others were still scratching their heads over it. Tight little aisles and racks of books new and old. And full of my favorite variety of human beings; those who read actual books!
Upstairs were small nooks and rooms like comfortable pockets with chairs stuffed right for a relaxed afternoon read. Quiet people with heads pointed towards some tome of literate fantasy or other account of the human project.
Outside we sat on a bench for a little refreshment and it turns out our choice was a famous place of repose. A group of tourists wanted to sit and have their pictures taken there. I obliged, by getting up and saying ‚ÄúWhat, did Hemingway sit here?‚Äù which seemed to amuse them. I‚Äôll have to dig into the bench‚Äôs provenance.
We then walked into the neighborhood of Paris that took the prize from us both: Sain Germaine. Here is the true pulse of Paris; in the voices from the cafes and in the silence from old churches, in the beat of the people strolling at ease in the slanting rays of the sun, in the rhythm of five and six story grey limestone edifices capped with the Mansard roofs rising up to shout ‚ÄúParis!‚Äù. I did not want this episode of our travel to end. The pulse had become my own.
--
--

Title: What is Paris?
Content:

Listen
Share
Paris is commonly used in music lyrics. Why is such a popular subject? What does Paris mean in these lyrics? How do people perceive Paris?
The Chainsmokers define it as
‚Äú1: A sentimental yearning for a reality that isn‚Äôt genuine.
2: An irrecoverable condition for fantasy that evokes nostalgia or day dreams.‚Äù
Paris gives a sense of fantasy that people don‚Äôt have in their mundane life.
‚ÄúWe were staying in ParisTo get away from your parents‚Äù
‚Äî The Chainsmokers
It‚Äôs a place to runaway. It‚Äôs a place where you don‚Äôt have worry about all the problems.
‚ÄúBut how I‚Äôd love to go to Paris again‚Äù ‚Äî The 1975
It‚Äôs a romantic and satisfying place that people want to go but never got to go.‚Äù
‚ÄúYou and me in ParisFree to be who we arePrisoners of desire‚Äù
‚Äî Karen Souza
It‚Äôs a place of freedom.
‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt need a fancy townOr bottles that we can‚Äôt pronounce‚ÄôCause anywhere babeIs like Paris in the rainWhen I‚Äôm with you‚Äù
‚Äî Lauv
Anywhere can be Paris if you are with the right person. This indicates that Paris is a romantic place filled with love. I have to agree that Paris in the rain is memorable. There aren‚Äôt many people with umbrelllas.
‚ÄúI got Paris Blue hung over my shoulder‚Äù ‚Äî Frequent Flyer
It‚Äôs a place that can bring sad and happiness at the sametime.
‚ÄúApril in ParisThis is the feelingNo one can ever reprise‚Äù
‚Äî Ella Fizgerald
Lyrics just say so much but it seems like it‚Äôs necessary to go now. It‚Äôs a place that cannot be reprised.
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre so Paris when we kissed, when we kissed‚Äù ‚Äî One Direction
It‚Äôs more than a place now. It‚Äôs a description of how romantic people can be.
‚ÄúWhy oh why do I love Paris Because my love is here
She‚Äôs there, she‚Äôs everywhereBut she‚Äôs really here‚Äù
‚Äî Frank Sinatra
It‚Äôs back to the definitions of all of the above. It‚Äôs a fantasy place. This is my favorite song among all songs about Paris.
What‚Äôs so great about Paris? I had the same question until I saw the Tour Eiffel blinking at me at 11PM. (It felt like it was winking at me.) Walking around the streets at night with the wind blowing through your hair makes you forget about everything. Seeing Giuseppe Acrimboldo‚Äôs Four Seasons at the Lourve, you find out how paitings can communicate to you. Drinking a cup of espresso on the sidewalk makes you love coffee more than ever. Looking at all those famous people buried in Cimeti√®re du P√®re-Lachaise makes you realize how at the end we are all at the same destination. As people said in thousands descriptions, ‚ÄúYou need to see it to know what I mean.‚Äù
It‚Äôs a place that seems unreal and ideal.
Paris is the best representation of fantasies.
I‚Äôd like to live in the Paris for awhile.

Title: How to Move to Paris : The Homefront
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

An American software developer packs up and lives the remote work life with his family in Paris

--
3
Listen
Share
What you have to do to prepare to move from San Francisco to Paris in three months.
So, you‚Äôve decided to move from the United States to Paris, France.
Perhaps like myself you made this decision more or less on a whim with no real planning going into it before the decision was made, or perhaps you took a longer, more reasonable approach to the problem. Either way, you now have a series of things to do before you board that airplane.
Now, I should preface this by saying that I‚Äôm not a lawyer and I‚Äôm not a travel agency. I did find it useful, however, when I was planning my move to read through the notes of other people who had done roughly the same thing. There are only a handful of them on the internet (here are some) and if you‚Äôre seriously considering doing this, read them all in addition to this. Your mileage is certain to vary.
What is amazing about this process is that most of it is dictated by government agencies, and yet nearly every step of the process is insanely vague. Therefore, I feel that sharing what we experienced could be hugely helpful to someone else trying to accomplish the same thing. Reading through the consulate docs are one thing, hearing the story of what real people went through is a bit different. Again, this is not a how-to, this is a how-we-did-done.
Well, first things first, getting a French visa. In order to live in France for longer than the normal 3 months a tourist visa gets you, one has to get a long stay visa of some kind. There are several different types of long stay visas you can get, though most are super specific ‚Äî being a student or an au pair, or marrying a French person. The one that seemed to fit us best was the ‚ÄúD‚Äù visa or long stay ‚Äúvisitor‚Äù visa. This is actually a little confusing to everyone involved, because I‚Äôm going to be working from home essentially, but not for a French company and not doing business in France.
The ‚ÄúD‚Äù visa essentially asks you to prove that you can live in France without ever being in danger of getting a job at a French company. I believe it‚Äôs normally for people who sort of want to long-vacation in France or semi-retire there, but working for a strange company that lets you work from anywhere fortunately and also occasionally frustratingly blurs the lines. Countries don‚Äôt really know what to do with people like me. However, this is the best option I could find that fit me.
Now then, there are 14 steps to the visa application process.
Most of these were actually fairly simple. Some pictures at the Kinkos, fill out the visa form, get your passports, birth certificates and marriage certificate together, etc.
There were, however, some difficulties. Many of which may have been easier had this blog post existed for me.
The first was the ‚ÄúLetter promising not to engage in any employment‚Äù. I have no idea what this means. What‚Äôs even more confusing about it is that the next thing you need is a ‚ÄúLetter of employment‚Äù. This is one of those many instances where language is really quite vague. What I ended up taking this to mean, and which I basically had to specifically verify with the Visa Officer at the French Consulate, is that they mean ‚ÄúWe need a letter saying you won‚Äôt get a job at a French company, depriving a Frenchman of a job, so prove to us that you have your financial shit together‚Äù.
Figuring out what that letter was supposed to say in order to get it signed and notarized was also a little frustrating. There are no templates or anything. We ended up just writing:
‚ÄúI, <your name here>, promise not to engage in any employment in France.‚Äù
And then signing it. And then notarizing it. And then getting weird looks from the Notary Public because why the hell would you notarize that? We got it notarized at the Post and Parcel in Potrero on 18th St. They were super nice and patient with us, I highly recommend them.
The letter of employment was sort of weird, since I‚Äôm a cofounder and board member at my company so I was unsure who I was supposed to get to sign it. ‚ÄúDear France, I work for me. Love, Scott‚Äù.
I assume, however, that most people don‚Äôt have that issue. They ended up not accepting it anyhow because it didn‚Äôt state that the company planned to continue to employ me once I was in France, which is what the consulate was looking for. If you do this, be sure to get that in the letter, in addition to your salary and title. In my case, the proof of means of income was enough that they didn‚Äôt much care about the employment letter ‚Äî basically as long as they don‚Äôt think you‚Äôll try to get a job for a French company or that a Frenchman could get, it doesn‚Äôt seem to concern them that much.
Proof of medical insurance was a pain for me, but mostly because it‚Äôs fairly rare for a US worker to move overseas and need to transition to expat insurance. Most of this was handled by our insurance broker eventually, but coming up with our medical history and whatnot took up most of a day. I ended up going into the consulate with emails saying I was going to get expat insurance and that I had travel insurance currently and they ended up being fine with that. I should do another blog post at some point about how ridiculous the American health care system is and how insane it is that we don‚Äôt really own our own medical records, but that‚Äôs for another time.
Proof of accommodation and the e-ticket were interesting requirements because they both require you to expend a rather grand amount of money to apply for a visa that in theory you may not be granted. I‚Äôve heard on other blogs that you can get hotel accommodations and a refundable ticket to hedge your bets, but we actually rented a furnished apartment through Lodgis and bought our one way tickets before applying for the visa. Needless to say, I‚Äôm pretty glad we ended up actually getting it.
While we‚Äôre on that subject, here‚Äôs a quick tip. If you move to Europe for a year, buy round-trip tickets. Technically you can‚Äôt get a return ticket a year out, so I‚Äôm not saying figure out when to come back. I‚Äôm saying burn the return ticket.
I didn‚Äôt even think about it and one-way tickets were about $2200 each on United so I ended up getting us tickets on Canada Air with a stop in Toronto for about $800 per ticket through some super-shady seeming Kayak referral company. I was fairly certain we were going to get to the airport and the flight wasn‚Äôt going to exist.
However, if I had selected a round-trip flight with pretty much any return date, I could have gotten non-stop flights to Paris through United for like $1100 per ticket. Basically adding the extra 15 hour flight home saves you half of your ticket price, contrary to all rational possible logic.
For the love of God, buy round-trip tickets.
We also had to get Josie a new passport since we got her one when she was only a few months old and they only last five years. The passport you have when you apply has to be valid a few months past the end of your stay. Since Jo was almost five when we applied, the passport would have expired during our stay in France.
Getting a new one for her was pretty interesting. We had to do it in person since she‚Äôs a minor and appointments were all months away so we had to use the first-come line at the Post Office on Sutter.
There is basically a single place you can get same day passport appointments in San Francisco and it‚Äôs pretty much a total shit show. The office opens at 8:30a and by 8:32a there are 15 people in line for a single person working the Passport counter and each applicant takes at least 10 minutes. If you‚Äôre there the second the office opens you still have a 45 minute wait. The first time we showed up, I forgot a document too, so we had to do it a second time. Make sure you have everything before you go. Or plan this far enough ahead of time that you don‚Äôt need to go into a no-appointment passport office.
So we made the visa appointment about a month and a half in advance and set to work doing all of that, which was pretty easily do-able within that time. Other than the health insurance issue, which ended up being fine, we had no other real problems with any of the requirements.
The visa appointment itself almost could not have been easier. For one, we lived in San Francisco, so we could easily go there in person without having to travel or anything. I had also heard that it could be difficult or confrontative, but everyone we met was really patient and nice to us. Some consulates ask for a ‚Äústatement of purpose‚Äù I‚Äôve heard, but the San Francisco one did not and honestly I think the French are generally like ‚ÄúOf course you want to live in France, France is awesome!‚Äù
The only problem that we had was that we physically had our documents in the wrong order. They want them all in exactly the order listed, per person. We had something like ‚Äúone for me, one for her, next for me, next for her‚Äù, etc. They wanted everything for me in order, then everything for her in order. We had to stand there and reorder everything and I don‚Äôt think the consulate officer was super happy with us about that. So, make a note if you‚Äôre doing this with your family.
Also, minors don‚Äôt need visas. Obviously we would have had to get her a new passport anyhow, but we didn‚Äôt need to pay the application fee or get her photos or anything. They ended up processing it for her and surprisingly actually issued her a visa (which the officer said they normally don‚Äôt do for minors), but it wasn‚Äôt necessary. It turns out if the parents get visas, they let their children come with them.
The next step was to find a school for Josephine. This was actually one of the first things we started looking for, but it took us a while to choose, apply for and finalize. It was also pretty stressful looking for a school when you can‚Äôt really visit any of them, communicate or search very well in French.
I first started emailing schools in early May, before we had really decided to move. Getting Jo into a school that we felt comfortable with was a prerequisite to moving at all.
It was actually a pretty interesting juggling act, because we wanted to find an apartment, a school for Josie and a language school for Jessica and have them all be relatively close or commute-able. We decided to start with Jo‚Äôs school and we narrowed it down to six schools that have at least some English instruction (we had heard that it can be very stressful for English-speaking children in fully French schools as they‚Äôre basically special needs children and we‚Äôre not citizens ‚Äî it gets confusing).
A lot of the choices came from an article on EasyExpat.com and a few other searches. We basically ended up deciding based on the fact that only two of the six schools got back to my email at all and one of them was very responsive and easy to communicate with. Perhaps not the greatest way to choose a school, but possibly not the worst way either and it seems to be working out well for her. They do French about half the time and English the other half.
If you are considering moving to Paris and have a child, the following school was personally recommended to us by a local as a great bilingual school for kids who speak English: L‚Äô√âcole active bilingue Jeannine-Manuel in the 15th arrondissement. They also recommended √âcole Alsacienne in the 6th, which is on the EasyExpat.com list, while Jeannine-Manuel is not.
We ended up finding an apartment that took cats (whom we decided to try to take with us, more on that later), had an extra room for me to work in and was furnished. It is also nicely close to a Metro line that goes almost directly to Jo‚Äôs school. Finally, it was only a short walk to a great language school that Jess decided to enroll in. Everything‚Äôs comin‚Äô up Millhouse!
So now that we have a place and schools and plane tickets and visas, we‚Äôre really moving! Now the problem is what to take with us. Since the apartment is furnished and it‚Äôs going to have to be difficult to ship stuff to France, we decided to basically try to store almost everything. Like, everything we‚Äôve accumulated through 12 years of marriage and 5 years of having a child. However, there were some children's books, technology and clothes and things that would certainly be more than we could check and didn‚Äôt really want to re-buy, so we decided to try to ship a couple of boxes.
So now the question is, how do you get a few boxes of stuff shipped to France? Turns out that it‚Äôs not actually very easy.
I found out that there is an International Flat Rate 25kg (about 50 lbs) box that you can, in theory, ship to France relatively easily. So we picked up four of them and packed them full and just stored everything else in our lives. This is sort of an interesting philosophical game within your family ‚Äî what can you live without? At about $300 per box, it‚Äôs a really compelling question.
Well, I thought we could just show up to the FedEx with these boxes and pay the flat rate and boom. Nope. Turns out that the boxes are going through customs so you have to declare everything in the box on a form. Literally everything. If you have 5 pairs of shoes you have to list them one item at a time and put how much they‚Äôre worth and where they were made and where you got them. For each pair of shoes. I had fucking USB cables and shit in there.
This was incredibly frustrating because we had tons of stuff in these boxes. How much is a jacket you got 3 years ago at Marshall‚Äôs worth? I got super frustrated and came damn close to just walking out of the FedEx in a huff when Jessica stepped in and just went through all their hoops. Because she‚Äôs a better person than me. So anyhow, if you want to ship something this way, figure out what‚Äôs in each box exactly and be prepared for literally hours worth of paperwork at the FedEx office.
We are not smart people. We‚Äôve adopted three FIV-positive rescue cats during our marriage, two of whom are still with us. Technically they‚Äôre feral rescues, but only one of them acts like it.
So one of the earliest conversations was what to do with the cats. Do we give them up? Do we see if we can get a family member to watch them? Do we take them with us?
This was actually a pretty difficult conversation because there is no way anyone would ever want these cats. They‚Äôre both super sweet, but they‚Äôre also FIV-positive which means they have occasional (or in the case of the one, constant) health problems. Problems which can sometimes be expensive. We are literally the only humans on the planet that would continue to keep these cats alive.
What made things a little easier is that it turns out, contrary to what we had both believed, domestic cats don‚Äôt have to go through a quarantine process. It‚Äôs actually somewhat simple to move to another country with them, process-wise.
You have to get sky kennels that meet the USDA and IATA requirements for shipping live animals. We initially got ones that were way too small for international travel and had to buy new ones. You have to get a vet that is licensed by the USDA to check the animals and they have to be chipped with an international chip and get a rabies vaccine booster. Then within a week of leaving you have to make an appointment to go to the USDA/APHIS office and present all of the forms that your vet gave you.
We went to the APHIS office at 389 Oyster Point Blvd, Suite 2 in San Francisco (really far south, by the airport). The USDA person there was super nice and everything went pretty smoothly. Our vet at the Mission Pet Hospital in San Francisco was able to put all the documentation together for us, including the French forms.
You can find most of this online, but in several different places and it can be a little confusing. We thought that we had to take the cats to a special USDA vet or something, but that wasn‚Äôt the case ‚Äî our long time vet was able to do it and we just had to take the forms to the USDA/APHIS office.
Finally you have to call your airline and make sure they have an animal hold on the flight you want to book. Actually, technically, you want to do this first, since the rest of this is done in the last weeks before you take off. Then on the day of, you have to go to the cargo area of the airport and drop them off, present the forms the USDA gave you and off you go. When you land, you pick them up from the cargo area there. Not the easiest, certainly, but not impossible.
You can also bring smaller animals on the plane with you sometimes, but I thought our scaredy-cats would be less stressed if there weren‚Äôt a thousand people around.
Then it was just the moving process. We hired horrible movers who took forever, like multiple days, and still didn‚Äôt finish everything. Which means we ran out of time and I had to hire DeliverSF to come to our house after we had flown away to finish up everything.
We got an AirBNB in the last few days to stay in while we coordinated all the moving out and cleaning up.
Strangely, the morning we were to leave there was a 6.0 magnitude earthquake that woke me up a little early. I guess San Francisco didn‚Äôt really want me to leave. Finally, we got up and took a cab from the AirBNB in the early morning to the airport.
It‚Äôs actually pretty jarring to leave. All three of us have lived in California for our entire lives. Jess and I both grew up in Ventura and both went to college here. We moved to the Bay Area basically exactly the time we got married. Our entire 12 years of marriage, all of our real adult lives in truth, have been spent here. It is a world we know and a world we love. Stepping outside this zone of incredible comfort and support for us is harder than I thought it might be, the lure of adventure aside. However, I think it‚Äôs the right choice. Stepping into the uncomfortable is the only way to ever do anything truly amazing.
So, au revoir, San Francisco and hello, Paris! I hope you treat us well.

It‚Äôs been a good long while since I popped on here to share anything about books and/or life, but when life gets busy I tend to get quiet. As any of your in corporate life know, the first quarter comes in like a lion with everyone ready to do All The Things as quickly as possible.
But stepping back in time to last fall, I wanted to share two special trips that Sergio and I took in 2023. Coming into 2020 we had talked about our desires to take our parents on bigger trips ‚Äî rather than looking back with regret when they were at an age when traveling was more challenging, we wanted to prioritize these trips.
One global pandemic and more than three years later, we finally made good on these plans at the end of 2023 ‚Äî a trip to Paris and Rome with Sergio‚Äôs parents and sister, and a separate trip to to Prague, Dresden, and Berlin with my parents and my brother.
Anyone who knows me at all knows I‚Äôm itchy and somewhat twitchy if I don‚Äôt have a trip planned, but a multi-generational trip was something a bit different for me. Today I‚Äôll share some highlights and what I learned from our first trip with the Ricos to Paris and Rome, but if you don‚Äôt make it any further than this, remember that planning ‚Äî along with realistic expectations ‚Äî are your best friend.
Alors‚Ä¶
I have nothing but love for Paris ‚Äî and I‚Äôm talking about pre-influencer Paris, but the Paris of 2023 is far different than my first trip to the City of Light in 2008. Back then we carefully held onto our museum passes as they were stamped one by one, made sure we had enough euros for everything, and bought packs of tiny paper tickets to use the Metro.
NO MORE MY FRIENDS, NO MORE. If you expect to show up and walk into anything, you shall spend your vacation in lines. It‚Äôs not that Paris hasn‚Äôt always been this beautiful or popular, but that international travel is more accessible to more people than ever! This is amazing, but is particularly tricky if you‚Äôre going to tour Paris with people who aren‚Äôt ready to run to and fro, this is where your planning has to start.
After spending some time re-familiarizing myself through the prolific works of St. Rick Steves, we implemented one of my favorite travel strategies when traveling in a group, What‚Äôs Your One Thing? It‚Äôs exactly what it sounds like ‚Äî what is the one thing in this particular city that you must do, that thing you‚Äôd regret skipping? Prioritization is critical on any big city trip, but when you‚Äôre considering different physical abilities or budgets, this is the best way to include the most-desired spot for each traveler (no-vetos!).
[Mine tends to be some sort of museum or cultural site because I AM ME and I could spend an entire vacation doing three museums a day and then reading alone in a hotel room at night but again, that‚Äôs just me!]
The great news? Paris has so many lovely sites and many of them don‚Äôt suffer from a repeat visit. We also tend to have similar travel preferences ‚Äî none of us were there for the nightlife or the boutique shopping or Michelin restaurants. That made it rather simple to make sure that Sergio made it to Versailles and I got (another) visit to the Rodin Museum, which really and truly is my favorite in Paris while my sister-in-law got her show at Moulin Rouge.
With your initial list of sites, I recommend putting together a shared Google Map with all of the possibilities. This is important for any trip, but we found it especially necessary for traveling with our parents (all in their 70s) to minimize the amount of walking or number of Metro transfers. This allows you to make a call on what sorts of transport make sense for a particular city.
If it is accessible to you ‚Äî and let‚Äôs be honest, a lot of it isn‚Äôt ‚Äî the Metro is the best way to get around Paris (get a Navigo pass with a photo ‚Äî it took us 45 minutes to figure it out but I was proud that we did it!). However, it‚Äôs full of steps with many stations lacking elevators or escalators. We lucked out in that we were able to make it work ‚Äî barely. The traffic in Paris can be really horrific but we did use Uber when needed instead of walking (my personal preference) to make sure that we were pacing ourselves as a group.
Thank you, Internet, for making it easy to add restaurants to our shared map as well. If you spend more time than expected in a museum, it‚Äôs tempting to stop into the nearest cafe to eat. However, a little bit of research gave us multiple options to make sure we could find different types of cuisine to try (and was helpful for me given my dietary restrictions). We also split up at times to try different spots, especially when we had differing levels of hunger (Sergio and I tend to eat 3 American Square Meals and the rest of the family follows the Latin country cadence of breakfast, late large lunch, and small or no dinner).
Another set of activities that is great for senior travelers would be bus, boat, or (in Rome) golf cart tours! These maximize the sites you can see while seated, and, if done early in your time in a city, provide a good overview. I did a lot of research to pick a good boat tour in Paris and a golf cart tour in Rome because some of these companies really cater to the unprepared, which could mean more time in lines and possibly a sub-par experience.
Random isn‚Äôt a good plan for big European cities these days ‚Äî you‚Äôll need a reservation for major sites like the Louvre or the Eiffel Tower (which we missed ‚Äî oops!) or you‚Äôll stand in a long, long, long, long line, or just be completely out-of-luck. The Paris Museum Pass helps get you into many sites, but separate entry reservations are often required. In Paris, big sites also mean security lines and possibly restrictions on bags that you can bring with you. This is where a Rick Steves guide comes in handy ‚Äî you can learn which entrance is fastest at the Louvre or how to see St Chapelle before the security line is too long.
What we ended up with was a great blend of structure and flexibility. We planned one key event each day (eg; a museum, a tour, a day-trip) and a meal together. This was usually in the morning, as getting to an attraction first thing can mean a shorter security line (sometimes). Because our hotel had a great breakfast buffet, it was easy to get up, grab something to eat, and get out off the door by 8:30 or 9:00. This generally resulted in a lunch around 1pm, which created a natural breaking point. Folks could rest or nap at the hotel, or we could go to other interesting sites or shop in the neighborhood. This left time to find souvenirs, try desserts, or find another Engligh language bookstore (hi, it‚Äôs me) or even just walk through a church or a park. It also means you‚Äôll stop by secondary sites and get to know them well ‚Äî whether it‚Äôs the very under-rated church of St. Sulpice, the Paris Zoo, the Conciergie, or Napoleon‚Äôs Tomb (aka three miles of walking that looks like three blocks ‚Äî whoops!).
Paris is much easier if you can speak some French ‚Äî and as the only sort-of French speaker on the trip, I was the one who stepped in if no-one spoke English. I find the French to be generally kind and helpful if you are polite (not a loud American) and are respectful. This means saying bonjour when you enter, asking before you handle produce at a market, etc. These are actually very simple things to do ‚Äî any good guidebook can help you! ‚Äî that show respect and create goodwill for an interaction. Most people in France can speak some English (or are completely fluent) and are generally willing to switch to English if you graciously ask, Parlez-vous Anglais, s‚Äôil vous plait? That being said, I knew enough that when we did encounter people who didn‚Äôt speak English that we were able to get by in French (think of immigrants who are newly-learning French to make their way in the country). I think with joy about a lovely woman who cooked us the best meal in France in a tiny kitchen in a market who spoke French and Arabic ‚Äî so my sad French got us through it! It‚Äôs one of my favorite memories of the trip because you don‚Äôt need that many words to share a connection with someone else. Don‚Äôt always believe the hype ‚Äî start by asking yourself how you can adapt to get the best experience and go from there.
But before too long, it was time to travel to Rome. After researching options the most cost effective ‚Äî balanced with the amount of time ‚Äî was to fly. All I will say is this ‚Äî coach seats on ITA are punishingly small and you always need an extra hour in CDG, no matter how fast you think it will be.
So, let‚Äôs keep this honest. Italy is my least favorite country in Europe.
It‚Äôs closely followed by Spain (super surprising given that I visited it with a Spanish speaker, but it was the wrong type of Spanish, the Latin-American variety‚Ä¶), but I wanted to give Rome another good try. I know so many folks who love it and it‚Äôs full of incredibly history and museums, which is perfect for me. Our previous visit was in December, which was a little bit less engaging ‚Äî and we also struck out the food. I also had travel companions that were incredibly excited for Rome, so I wanted them to enjoy it too.
Those fantastic planning skills I mentioned above? These were even more critical for Rome because holy crap was the city overrun with tourists in the second week of October and why is everyone doing a TikTok dance in front of the Colosseum? Given all of this, it‚Äôs much more important to prioritize your sightseeing and get creative with your entrance times and to make sure that you have enough shade, water, and rest for everyone, not just the elderly. There‚Äôs nothing like sweating through your entire outfit, right?
For some reason, some of the sites like the Colosseum or the Vatican Museums make it nearly impossible to get in without either buying a combo-ticket (which might include a site that you don‚Äôt want or an included meal you don‚Äôt want to eat) or joining a ‚Äúfollow-the-flag‚Äù tour. This was completely different than our visit six years ago, and it‚Äôs the absolutely worst. Most tickets are sold to resellars who maximize profit with these upsells, and even if you tried you‚Äôre not able to get these other tickets.
As a planner and an independent thinker I found this incredibly irritating and it felt to me like we had less flexibility! We had to check in more than 30 minutes early for a tour-guide who did a really poor job with the Colosseum, and without a combo ticket for a lunch we didn‚Äôt eat, we wouldn‚Äôt have been able to see the Vatican Museums or the Sistine Chapel (so you‚Äôre welcome, Pope Francis, for the extra donation to your country). Even with my months-ahead planning, we couldn‚Äôt get tickets for the Roman Forum ‚Äî but in fairness, I was probably the most disappointed about that.
My favorite site this visit was the Capitoline Museum that overlooks the Forum and the Colosseum. Sergio and I hadn‚Äôt visited it on our first trip so this was my choice for my One Thing. We did it on the hottest day as some (but not all) of the rooms were air conditioned. With incredible art, architecture, sculpture, and views, it was almost tourist-free and quite enjoyable. The tablet guides were essential as none of us spoke Italian ‚Äî and it was pure luck if you encountered someone who was fluent-ish in English. We also benefitted from an incredible cab driver who drove us around the back way so our older travel companions didn‚Äôt have to climb one thousand stairs to the top of the hill. I did appreciate the care and respect for elders that I noticed throughout the trip.
Central Rome is a rather compact, flat and walkable ‚Äî minus temperates in the 80s and 90s and no real breeze to speak of. Another challenge to keep in mind if you are traveling with older people is that there is almost nowhere to sit down in public in Rome, and if you sit on the steps someone will come and angrily ask you to stand up. I‚Äôve never been to museums where the only place you can really sit down is on a toilet when you need to use the restroom. Perhaps this is a reason so many people sit down in the church pews to rest aching legs and pray for a break!
The Metro is very limited so we used cabs to get around most days. Though they are in theory quite reasonable, we were overcharged more than once ‚Äî even official cabs ‚Äúforget‚Äù to run the meter. Because we usually had to take two cabs as we were five people, it was extremely obvious that a six to ten euro price difference in cabs that departed from and arrived at the same place one minute apart from each other were not on the up-and-up. Travel means getting ripped off sometimes, and thankfully this was the extent of it (or perhaps a slight mark-up on a dinner). We were very careful with our money and passports, especially in crowded areas, and we stayed in safe areas of the city. This is important for everyone, no matter your age, to be aware of your surroundings and know how to ask for help if you need it.
That‚Äôs not to say we didn‚Äôt have great cab experiences either ‚Äî like this man who took all of us at once, or the gentle man who drove us from our hotel to the Vatican Museums, chit-chatting nonstop in Italian, but then, at a stoplight, holding out his hand to me and saying in perfect American English, ‚ÄúHi, I‚Äôm Bob‚Äù and then right back to the Italian for the rest of the ride. Bob was good people.
These delightful local encounters are the ones I‚Äôll remember the most, whether the accommodating and helpful staff at Hotel Lancelot, the wonderful woman who led our market tasting tour, or the staff at one of the cat sanctuaries who knew cat people when they saw them and let us get our feline fix, if only for thirty minutes. We were lucky to travel with two extroverts, and my beautiful and kind sister-in-law was made for the Italian joviality and spirit! Sometimes you envy those characteristics that are so natural for some people, but not for you.
Here‚Äôs the other part of a family trip that you can‚Äôt overlook ‚Äî making space for alone time or couples time. As the most introverted person on the trip, I knew I‚Äôd do better if I built in some time for rest and relaxation. I chose not to go on a day-trip that Sergio planned for Orvieto ‚Äî which was a wild success! ‚Äî and instead visited a nearby church, had a long lunch, and napped and rested in our hotel. A part of planning is also understanding what each person needs from an energy standpoint. Do people need a midday rest or an extra hour to wind-down at night? Or do you do best with a morning coffee along before everyone else tromps into the breakfast room? Take that into account too ‚Äî speak up for what you need to manage your energy and refrain from judging the energy or rest needs of your fellow travelers. We are all at our best when we can tap into the ways that we relax and recharge, whatever they are.
I do love trying local cuisine, so I made a point of getting deeper into restaurant research and we did find some real gems, from a wine bar across the street from stores that sold habits and candlesticks to a tiny neighborhood trattoria with the best truffle pasta I‚Äôve ever had in my life. We splurged for one of Rome‚Äôs nicest old-school restaurant, complete with an incredibly kind waiter who teased and joked but provided best-in-class service and a whole plate of butter on request.
It was joyful to see these places through the eyes of Sergio and his family and to see them again in a different light for myself. I‚Äôm not naturally meant for Italy, I don‚Äôt think, but with a more positive frame of mind there were lovely things that I missed the first time around. And when you try different experiences and talk to locals, you can see a place through their experiences too.
The massive drawback to Rome was the hoards of tourists more interested in a dance or a pose in front of a fountain than learning about the two thousand years of history, culture, and all that happened in this place. It‚Äôs ROME! I wanted to yell at these folks who occupied whole sidewalks such that one had to step into traffic in the street to walk around them. This stupid sort of tourism that‚Äôs taking over places like Dubrovnik, Amsterdam, Venice, or Barcelona, not to mention the crush in smaller towns like Hallstatt, Bruges, or Porto. Of course everyone can want a photo to say, ‚ÄúHey, I went to [insert cool place]!‚Äù You‚Äôve been looking at our photos of amazing places that we visited throughout this entire blog.
But is that the attraction ‚Äî just going there? Isn‚Äôt it more interesting to see the Chains of St. Peter or The School of Athens or Trajan‚Äôs Column? I‚Äôll get down off of my cranky old person soapbox in a moment, but c‚Äômon folks! You can sample great gelato and check out some art; you can get a cute photo at the Forum and see the temples. We are lucky enough to live at a time when we know more than ever about those who came before us and we‚Äôre lucky enough to have technology to help these sites come alive. There is a world behind a screen ‚Äî so if you just want to hang out with your phone, give everyone else a break and perhaps stay home.
Where did I land with Italy? This second trip was certainly more enjoyable than the first because of my travel companions‚Ä¶ and I think I‚Äôm good for now. We‚Äôve visited about half of Europe‚Äôs countries, so I‚Äôm ready to see some of those first before another loop back to Italy.
But‚Ä¶ all-in-all, this was a fantastic trip with all sorts of experiences where we lucked out with hotels and made do with the unseasonably warm weather. The planning truly made it easier to adapt to different travel preferences and needs, and I‚Äôd say the trip was a smashing success.
And now the plot twist. Because travel doesn‚Äôt always go as expected, does it?
We had all packed and were ready for our flights back home to the United States and Mexico, respectively. We had to be out of the hotel by 5:30am to catch our flight to London to transfer for our flight home and the rest of the Ricos had an 11:30pm flight back to Mexico. I woke up in a cold sweat at one in the morning and proceeded to be violently ill for hours and hours. I am so, so, so sorry to all of the poor people on our floor who had to listen to all of‚Ä¶ that, but I was that special kind of sick where my only thought was don‚Äôt die don‚Äôt die don‚Äôt die. Sergio went down to the front desk in the wee morning hours and managed to keep our room for an extra day and change our flights with British Airways to the following day. I don‚Äôt remember much of it, but my body was shaking so hard with chills that my intercostal muscles ached for days afterwards.
This is probably a story for another blog, but I‚Äôm unfortunately much more of an expert on getting food poisoning despite how careful I tend to be with what I eat and drink. That is an unfortunate part of having an inflammatory bowel disease, but I‚Äôve learned a lot through these experiences, and in the future I‚Äôll find a non-gross, non-graphic way to share my recovery protocol.
I was very lucky to be traveling with a doctor (my father-in-law) and a nurse (my mother-in-law) and they have the world‚Äôs most tricked-out travel medicine kit that they opened to us. They were differently unlucky with their own flight delays (a late-night flight pushed eight or nine hours later into the morning)! Thankfully our second attempts at departure worked ‚Äî we flew home without incident (and, in my case, with basically no food) and though it was a wee-hours-of-the-morning connection in Mexico City, the rest of the Ricos made it home too.
What would I leave you with from this trip? Do it. Take the trip and don‚Äôt wait. Make the best of what you have now because none of us are guaranteed good health into the future. In our case, all of the planning ahead of time made the trip much easier and removed a lot of mental load while we were there and gave us time to really connect and experience these places together. Whether it‚Äôs Rome or Paris, resting on a beach, climbing a mountain, or taking a cruise, you and your family are worth that time together. I hope you take it with those you love.
Au revoir, S
P.S. See you soon with a Jan/February book review and then (hopefully) another blog about our travels to Prague, Dresden, and Berlin with my family‚Äî our first European Christmas!
