Share
‚ÄúIt has bothered me all my life that I do not paint like everybody else.‚Äù
On the first Monday of summer, June 5, 1905, the Gare de Lyon train station teemed with fashionable Parisians preparing for their annual journey to the south of France. Only they preferred C√¥te d‚ÄôAzur ‚Äî like it was a club with an admissions committee, an invited guest list, a velvet rope, and a charming hostess waiting to welcome them. To them, paradise was a familiar word, wrapped in the routine and privilege of their opulent lives. They imagined strolling arm-in-arm down sunlit promenades, exchanging knowing glances with others who happened to look, dress, and speakl just like them. It was so comforting to be seated at seaside caf√©s, secure in one‚Äôs place ‚Äî and equally certain that, beyond their tiny polished circle, little else really mattered. They were happy people, perhaps ridiculously so.
A different story awaited in the third-class compartment: thirty-six-year-old Henri Matisse wasn‚Äôt chasing the sun; he was escaping ruin. Although he too was once welcomed in Parisian society, he now wore a corduroy suit like a prison uniform, faded to a reddish-brown, and blending into the threadbare seat beneath him. He looked more vineyard worker than artist ‚Äî save for the paintbox and collapsible easel at his feet. His face was etched with lines from sleepless nights and empty pockets, carrying the weight of three years of failure and rejection. This was the new Henri Matisse, one who had aged and fallen. Had you whispered to his fellow passengers that one day he would shake the art world to its core the laughter would have been raucous and infectious.
Even his wife, Am√©lie, who sat next to him, would give you a skeptical glance. Even her expression was tense with quiet concern, and this was no leisurely getaway to the Riviera. The couple wasn‚Äôt bound for seaside promenades serenaded by Mediterranean breezes. They had no home to go to, and no friends when they arrived. In fact were escaping a life that had unraveled, fleeing to a place that might offer at least a reprieve from despair if not the justice system.
Matisse‚Äôs fall from grace had been sharp. The Parisian art world once welcomed him with cautious optimism, but now turned its delicate pale back. Friends disappeared, patrons closed their wallets, and a once-promising career had sputtered. It was his fault, too. Rumors of a financial scandal hovered around him like a thick fog, deepening his isolation. Once a successful lawyer, Matisse abandoned that career to follow his passion for painting, but now even that seemed as enticing as a wet pavement.
As the train pulled out of the station, leaving behind the familiar smells of crusty baguettes, pungent cheeses, and steaming bowls of oxtail soup, Matisse cast a final glance at his former home. He was leaving behind more than Paris; he was abandoning a world that seemed so full of promise, now reduced to broken dreams. Yet, as the train chugged along the tracks, his mood astonishingly began to lift. Amid the despair, a quiet resolve began to take root. The storm within him receded as Matisse made a vow ‚Äî he would find his voice again, silence the doubts, and reclaim his life on his own terms.
No matter how long it took.
Which is what is so ironic about the story of Henri Matisse in Collioure. Little did he or anyone else realize that in just 100 days, this trek south would not only transform his career but reshape the entire art world, leading to one of the most revolutionary periods in the history of painting.
In fact, Paris would never look at a canvas the same way again.
But what was about to happen wasn‚Äôt a miracle nor an act of faith. It was something deeper and perhaps more fundamental to the human condition. Henri Matisse was about to discover a Thrive Zone ‚Äî a place where the spirit is liberated, creativity reignited, and the soul is fully restored. These are places where we become ourselves in spite of the rest of the world telling us not to be.
This is the story of how one summer in a small fishing village in the south of France set the stage for a transformation that would forever alter Matisse ‚Äî and leave an indelible mark on the world of art.
‚ÄúThere are flowers everywhere for those who want to see them.‚Äù
A cynic would say every form of refuge has its a price. For Henri Matisse, his career suffered from entrapment in the bleak industrial landscape of Normandy. As a young boy growing up there, life was marked by the unrelenting grayness, suffocated by coal dust. He believed the world was colored in sodden skies, and monotony was the color of choice. Matisse would later recall, ‚ÄúWomen wore black, and everyone wore a hat. It is a place where people don‚Äôt expect too many strangers.‚Äù
Even Art historian Hilary Spurling noted this was true, his early works were ‚Äúrestrained and traditional,‚Äù lacking the spark that would later come to define his painting. Only the public wasn‚Äôt interested in somber landscapes ‚Äî it craved beauty, spectacle, and illusion.
Desperate for cash, Matisse even offered one of his canvases to his brother Auguste for 100 francs. The reply was as frigid as the Norman winter: ‚ÄúI‚Äôd rather have a new bicycle.‚Äù But the struggle was about more than selling paintings. Matisse was caught in a larger battle, a fight to find his place in a world that seemed hopelessly duplicitous and divided. He valued integrity in expression more than wealth, but now he was bereft of both.
Born in 1869 during the twilight of the Victorian era, Matisse‚Äôs formative years spanned the Belle √âpoque ‚Äî a time of shimmering contradictions. Paris, the ‚ÄúCity of Light,‚Äù was both a beacon of modernity and a place of deep inequality as well as rigid social structure. The elite lived in the glow of freshly minted francs, while the working classes toiled in the shadows. The surface gleamed, but underneath, resentment simmered.
It was into this paradoxical cauldron, where new industrial fortunes clashed with the remnants of old-world aristocracy, that Matisse and his wife Am√©lie found themselves thrust ‚Äî while the working classes ‚Äî barely literate, and so barely counted ‚Äî were left to their laughter, tobacco pipes, and homemade plum wine. The glittering surface of society masked deep divisions ‚Äî while the elite flaunted their wealth, resentment simmered among the lower classes.
It was how the Matisse‚Äôs became collateral damage in one of the most infamous financial scandals of their time ‚Äî the Humbert Affair. A master manipulator named Th√©r√®se Humbert had defrauded thousands through an audacious Ponzi scheme, borrowing nearly 100 million francs based on the collateral of a fictitious inheritance. By sheer misfortune, the Matisse family became entangled.
Matisse‚Äôs father in law was arrested, and the artist, a former lawyer, came to his defense. He wasn‚Äôt a conspirator, but the scandal stained his reputation and he became swept up in the deluge. And as the Humbert empire crumbled, so too did the Matisse‚Äôs stature. He found himself facing public outrage and financial ruin.
Stripped of dignity and resources, the couple with their inlaws had to fleeParis, no longer sure of their place in the world. Yet, what they sought in the south wasn‚Äôt luxury ‚Äî it was something else, renewal it would turn out. Matisse was no longer simply searching for a place to escape; he was searching for a space to thrive.
‚ÄúWe ought to view ourselves with the same curiosity and openness with which we study a tree, the sky or a thought.‚Äù
Th√©r√®se Humbert was the architect of one of the most notorious frauds in French history. Her rise to the top of Parisian society had been built on audacious lies, and equally fake noble lineage. To bolster her imagined wealth, she concocted an elaborate story about saving the life of a fictional American millionaire, Robert Crawford, who, according to her story, had gratefully left her a vast fortune. For over two decades, Humbert borrowed millions against this supposed inheritance, living a life of luxury while her lenders, many of them ordinary citizens, were left in the dark.
Through a web of deceit that had gone undetected for years ‚Äî protected by her father-in-law, a Minister of Justice ‚Äî Humbert finally acquired a newspaper owned by Armand Parayre, Henri Matisse‚Äôs father-in-law. This tangled connection dragged the Matisse family into the scandal‚Äôs orbit, even though they were unwitting victims themselves. But when the supposed inheritance was revealed to be nothing but a single red brick, the scandal erupted and scapegoats were needed.
France was outraged. The Humberts fled, leaving ruin in their wake. And while Matisse and his family although not accomplices, were tainted by their association. It took very little time before they found themselves swept up in the aftermath of one of the country‚Äôs largest Ponzi schemes.
The financial ruin, public scandal, and professional rejection that surrounded Matisse pushed him further toward collapse. No longer able to support his family or continue his art with any hope of stability, Matisse felt crushed by the weight of his failures. The Parisian society that had once nurtured his ambition now seemed intent on devouring him.
Yet, in the face of this disaster, the fall became the prelude to something greater.
The seeds of transformation were planted.
‚ÄúI would like to recapture that freshness of vision which is characteristic of extreme youth when all the world is new to it.‚Äù
Sometimes, utter rejection is the precursor of renewal. For Matisse, this state of affairs forced him to seek refuge not just from scandal and poverty, but from the creative limitations he had unknowingly imposed on himself. Desperate and exhausted, Matisse and his wife Am√©lie left Paris for a small fishing village near the Spanish border.
Collioure wasn‚Äôt St. Tropez as they couldn‚Äôt afford the luxuries of the French Riviera that Paris‚Äôs elite were accustomed to. Instead, they found themselves in a fishing village hit hard by economic ruin and the collapse of its anchovy trade and vineyards, ravaged by the Phylloxera plague. The town, at first glance, appeared worn, scarred by decline and poverty.
Yet to Matisse, it held something far more precious than wealth.
‚ÄúThe light here is different,‚Äù Matisse would later say.
It wasn‚Äôt just an illusion either. Collioure had unfiltered Mediterranean light that revealed colors that Matisse had never seen before‚Ää‚Äî due to the only East facing coastline in France where the Pyranees majestically seem to dive into the water. The reflections of the sea, the interplay of light and shadow, the vivid hues that soaked into the village streets ‚Äî became his metaphor. A light which casts no shadows and eradicates contrasts. It was a new artistic language, one that spoke to him in a way that Paris never could.
Where others saw a town in decline, Matisse saw a world bursting with possibility. The decay of the fishing industry and the blighted vineyards faded into the background. For the first time in years, Matisse felt a spark of creative energy return. His focus shifted away from survival and toward the rediscovery of beauty.
The transition was profound. In Paris, Matisse had been trapped in a world of muted tones, of compromise and caution. But in Collioure, he began to embrace boldness, color, and exuberance. The sun-drenched hues of the Mediterranean landscape ‚Äî lavenders, blues, deep reds, and oranges ‚Äî burst into his work, freeing him from the restraint that had shackled his earlier paintings.
This was no accident. Collioure had become more than just a change of scenery; it had become Matisse‚Äôs personal Thrive Zone.
A Thrive Zone isn‚Äôt just a place to live or work; it‚Äôs a place where one‚Äôs potential is not only nurtured but liberated. It‚Äôs an environment where time takes on a different momentum, allowing creativity, growth, and transformation to flourish.
In Collioure, Matisse found exactly that ‚Äî a space where the constraints of his old life could no longer bind him, where his art could breathe and expand beyond anything he had imagined in Paris.
‚ÄúWhat I dream of is an art of balance, of purity and serenity, devoid of troubling or depressing subject matter, something like a good armchair.‚Äù
The pinnacle of this transformation came in the form of one of Matisse‚Äôs first works of the summer of 1905 appropriately titled, Open Window, Collioure. It wasn‚Äôt just a painting ‚Äî it was a declaration of freedom that overcame him as he gazed from his hotel window.
In this work, Matisse blurred the boundaries between interior and exterior, between the familiar and the unknown. The colors ‚Äî vivid and alive ‚Äî reflected his internal transformation. Where traditional art sought to mimic life, Matisse‚Äôs work was life, vibrating with the energy of the Mediterranean.
Gone were the muted tones and tight brushstrokes that had once defined his work. In Collioure, Matisse embraced a radical new approach to color and form. His brushstrokes were loose, unrestrained, and alive. This work wasn‚Äôt just a product of technique, he was the same artist he had been in Paris just a week earlier ‚Äî it was the product of an environment.
The vibrant colors of Collioure found their way into the depth of Matisse‚Äôs discouragement, and for the first time in his life, he felt free to paint in a way that was entirely his own. The shift was so dramatic that it left the Parisian art world stunned. Open Window and the thirty other paintings Matisse completed that summer heralded the birth of Fauvism, a revolutionary movement that would redefine modern art.
In one summer in 1905 he would paint over 50 pieces, and three of the ten greatest works of his life. Of course, the critics in Paris, accustomed to the soft realism of the old masters, were appalled. Matisse‚Äôs use of color was too wild, his forms too chaotic. His work was dubbed ‚ÄúFauvism,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúwild beasts,‚Äù a derogatory term meant to criticize the audacity of the movement.
But Matisse, like the light of Collioure, was undeterred. He had found his Thrive Zone, and he would never again return to the constraints of his old life.
‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt help getting old, but you can help becoming old.‚Äù
Henri Matisse once said, ‚ÄúThere are flowers for those who want to see them.‚Äù But perhaps the deeper question isn‚Äôt why we see flowers ‚Äî but who plants them in the first place. In Collioure, Matisse found not just refuge but renewal. Freed from the biting skepticism of Parisian critics who had dismissed his work as ‚Äúscribblings of a wild beast,‚Äù he discovered a simpatico community ‚Äî comrades who shared his love of nature and painted alongside him, as well as villagers who embraced his curious habit of standing before a canvas all day. Among them, he painted with abandon, as if creating art were play, not work.
For him, the humble fishing village was more than a refuge from Parisian humidity or a place of cheap lodgings. It was where the ‚Äúflowers‚Äù of creativity were planted ‚Äî a nurturing environment that welcomed his restless, rebellious spirit and spoke to his innermost feelings and beliefs.
Mornings spent painting in a modest studio overlooking the beach flowed effortlessly into afternoons of fish stew and Picpoul de Pinet. The Mediterranean light transformed the village‚Äôs modest facades into shimmering mosaics of lavender, red, and blue. Even the coarse shouts of fishermen, carried on salt-laden breezes in ancient Occitan, held an unexpected poetry.
What Matisse found in Collioure wasn‚Äôt merely an inspirational technique ‚Äî it was a shift in his approach to life and art. He was no longer bound by the expectations of Parisian society or trapped by the weight of public opinion. The unpretentious simplicity of the village loosened the grip of doubt, reigniting his confidence and freeing him to create on his own terms. In this overlooked corner of the Mediterranean, Matisse found his muse, his sanctuary, and, ultimately, his transformation.
Not long after, he settled permanently in nearby Nice, drawn by the same energy that had unlocked his potential in Collioure ‚Äî a place where he would spend the rest of his days until age 84.
Matisse‚Äôs story exemplifies a universal truth: the right environment can unlock potential in ways that talent or ambition alone cannot. It is the fusion of place, purpose, and opportunity that creates the conditions for extraordinary success. Yet finding such a place is only part of the journey. Liberating oneself from the constraints of our current environment ‚Äî from the doubts, the criticisms, the expectations, and the customs that bind us ‚Äî is often the greater challenge. To do so requires stunning independence and personal leadership.
Matisse left Paris at age 36 a struggling artist. He returned three months later transformed ‚Äî his confidence renewed, his technique revolutionized, and his reputation on the rise.
Within a season, he had become a rival to Picasso. Collioure was more than a village; it was the point where talent and opportunity converged, where greatness and place became inseparable. Collioure, then, was not just a haven ‚Äî it was Matisse‚Äôs Thrive Zone.

Paris ‚Äî the city that has inspired poets, artists, and dreamers for centuries. During my recent 3-day trip to this enchanting metropolis, I found myself swept away not only by its breathtaking landmarks and rich history but also by the subtle yet fascinating retail trends that reflect the Parisian way of life. From cobblestone streets lined with boutiques to bustling markets showcasing local craftsmanship, Paris offers a perfect blend of tradition and modernity.
In this article, I‚Äôll take you through my 3-day itinerary while highlighting the travel insights and retail observations I made along the way. Whether you‚Äôre planning a trip to Paris or simply curious about the city‚Äôs evolving trends, this guide will give you a taste of what makes Paris so timeless ‚Äî and yet so contemporary.
My journey began in Montmartre, the bohemian heart of Paris. This historic district, perched on a hill overlooking the city, is a haven for artists and romantics alike. Walking through its winding streets felt like stepping into a painting.
Montmartre is home to an eclectic mix of vintage shops and contemporary boutiques. What stood out to me was how these stores seamlessly blend old-world charm with modern sensibilities. From retro-inspired dresses to handmade jewelries, Montmartre‚Äôs retail scene celebrates individuality ‚Äî a hallmark of French fashion.
If Day 1 was about soaking in Montmartre‚Äôs artistic vibe, Day 2 was all about exploring Paris‚Äôs iconic landmarks and indulging in its culinary delights.
The Latin Quarter offers a treasure trove of independent bookstores (like Shakespeare & Company) and artisan shops selling everything from handmade soaps to custom stationery. What struck me most was how these small businesses prioritise authenticity and quality over mass production ‚Äî a trend that seems to resonate deeply with both locals and tourists.
For my final day in Paris, I ventured beyond the city centre to explore some royal grandeur and hidden gems that added new dimensions to my understanding of Parisian culture.
The Marais district stood out for its diversity ‚Äî it‚Äôs where high-end fashion boutiques coexist with vintage stores and quirky concept shops. This juxtaposition reflects a broader trend in Parisian retail culture: catering to diverse tastes while maintaining an emphasis on quality and craftsmanship.

We came to France to visit Nantes, where my son lives. But I would love to travel to Paris too, so we will stay here for two days and then go to Nantes. We must stop in Paris and taste it again. But we end up in a food coma. We are going to cram Paris in just two days. But this time around, I found something unexpected.
The skies were clear as we landed at Charles de Gaulle airport. Our United flight 990 was unexpectedly impressive. They fed us terrible food the entire time, but the staff was friendly. Get a cab to town next; don‚Äôt take the Metro with all your heavy bags after the long trip. We did that once and deeply regretted it. Make sure you find the official ones, which are found at sortie 24. Don‚Äôt fall for the gypsies.
We rented an Air B&B in Le Marais at Rue Vielles de Temple. Usually, the pictures look better, but this one was the exact opposite. If you rent an Air B&B when you travel to Paris, remember to arrange for the owner to meet at the door because, unlike in the United States, you can‚Äôt just get there, get a code, and get in. In most cases.
After settling in the apartment, we walked through Le Marais. It was quite an experience because you find yourself in a different world, and the contrast back home gives you a buzz‚Ä¶

Content:

Follow publication

I‚Äôm sitting at the Air France Lounge at Charles De Gaulle, pulling down episode two of Studio 60 over the wi-fi so I can watch it on the flight back, and figured I‚Äôd do a little blogging while I‚Äôm at it. I‚Äôve been in Paris the past two days to do a speech for Disney, which means, of course, that I fly all the way from New York to Paris and then I‚Äôm immediately taken to Paris Disneyland, where they‚Äôve put me up in the ‚ÄúNew York‚Äù hotel. Of all the Baudrillardian ironies‚Ä¶
I‚Äôve done a lot of these two day trips to foreign cities in recent years: Lisbon, Hong Kong, Paris, Hamburg, Amsterdam, London many times. They can be a little exhausting, but I‚Äôve grown fond of the routine. There‚Äôs no time to actually try to see anything systematically, no time even to really acclimate to the place. So I basically just try to take a half day and evening, and just walk around with no real destination, letting the natural flow of the city direct me. In cities that I know quite well, like London or Paris, the fun of it is in figuring out the limits of my knowledge, in others it‚Äôs more of a process of discovery. And I always try to have some new music that I‚Äôve just downloaded, to listen to on the iPod as a soundtrack. It embeds this lovely ‚Äî and enduring ‚Äî connection between the music and the memory of a place‚Ä¶
But enough about all that ‚Äî SARAH JESSICA PARKER is sitting right next to me in the Lounge!! Does Gawker have a Paris edition?

The Petit Palais in Paris is only a hundred and twenty years old ‚Äî give or take half a decade. It was built, along with the Grand Palais across the street, for the Exposition Universelle of 1900. Two years later the Petit Palais was designated a museum, and today it is part of the glorious collection of free museums of the City of Paris.
So nobody has ever lived in the palace. But one can dream.
The Petit Palais is on the right bank of the Seine, a pleasant twenty minute walk from my home, and often along the path to or from another destination. It is easy to wander in and out again, particularly if you use the ground floor entrance where there is almost never a line as you pass through security.
Gustave Courbet‚Äôs Le Sommeil (The Sleepers, 1866), my favorite erotic painting of all time, is housed in one of the large galleries, along with a number of Courbet‚Äôs other nineteenth-century masterpieces. I‚Äôve copped to my fondness for this extraordinary painting in another story.

PORTLAND IS MY PARIS
This weekend the city isn‚Äôt an option. My head needs to be cleared by things green and blue and misty, so the men on East 80th rent me a cherry-juice Kia Forte and I merge onto Manhattan‚Äôs rush hour traffic. It‚Äôs been three days since I picked the spot, arranged for a car and room and a brief search on things to do. Half-because a music producer told me it‚Äôs a nice place, half-because it‚Äôs a 6-hour drive if I go toll-free, which I like.
I pull off in Worcester for relief and caffeine. Sky-high dark and stormies have been chasing me since my tires hit the Massachusetts state line, and I am counting on the break for them to sort themselves. I corner off on Madison Street. Memories of grey-blue Renegades, rolling bike paths, Mormon propaganda on flat screens, the spindly tree on State St, 50+ missed calls go by - I am on the wrong side of the station for the rental‚Äôs pump, despite looking directly at the dash.
Ghosts living and dead have been following me lately; my life has turned into a marathon of goodbyes. I passed a man identical to Owen by Union Square after work yesterday ‚Äî my brain remembered he‚Äôs been dead since January only after it recognized the face. (I‚Äôm editing this now in Boston, a stone‚Äôs throw from where we went on drives, where I clasped a golden chain twice looped around his wrist).
Returning the comically-large restroom key, jostling against the counter with its grotesque embody, I trade the phosphorescent lovingly-scratched lotto ticket I won back in February, cashed in for two cokes and a fistful of change, and don‚Äôt think about how much has changed since then, either. There are narratives you choose, to save most of your mind from obsession. There are words I take care not to write as doing so risks more of me than I could take. I post that I like to keep my cash options in winning tickets and send my dad the new ETA, pushed back 10 minutes.
(The coffee machine in my hotel room is haunted. It‚Äôs gurgling foaming with hot water but none goes to where my grounds are. Half-done, trying, hot, not enough. I put the mug with a tea bag in and dump the hot water from the mouth of the machine in, scalding some fingers and toes. Get it done, be creative, keep it moving).
Pulled from a drunken slumber, bedsheets indented into my cheeks, I gather hot coffee from the lobby to save myself further scorching, and wander cobblestone-padded streets, my shoes fitting not-to-neatly between the stones. Not much is open so early but enough are awake, townies and regulars who are glad for the company and small talk chatter. My list of places to visit grows, although I know readily I won‚Äôt see so much as half of them, it‚Äôs a bit addicting to play the part of traveler. I appreciate feeling temporary.
After reassurance from the daughter of a shop-owner that the rain, if anything, enhances the landscape more than derails - I swing into the cherry-red and take myself out to lighthouses and state parks, $7 for outsiders. My dad chats with me on the way, he‚Äôs seemed worried about me as of late and I can‚Äôt quite stop his fears from spilling over. It‚Äôs raining and I am pleased and calm and miserable altogether.
There isn‚Äôt an easy way to explain how I‚Äôm doing, and most people don‚Äôt ask beyond politeness. I tell confidants what I believe to be my best wording. I say I wish I could control the pain, let the psychedelic-drunk swinging punches into transit air land one, let the bruise prove. They say to stop, that I‚Äôm no longer being funny.
I can‚Äôt find the right order of words to explain how untrue it is that I‚Äôm doing well, because I have not adopted the socially acceptable behaviors of someone not doing well. I work, I shower, but I am not there. I am tethered by a thread - the kind one absentmindedly pulls at on their knit sweaters or worn skirts, slowly raveling around a finger until the pressure snaps. The base is rooted in the platelets spanning my hips, right where my spine becomes body.
My mind plans for when my body no longer does what it should. For when it morphs into the shapeless entity folks imply I am not when they say, ‚ÄúYou seem to be handling all of this well.‚Äù I don‚Äôt need compliments, I need someone to want to sit with me in the madness under pale moons. I fear I rip the good things in my life to prove I can, and in flashes I see it happening. All I‚Äôve been feeling lately is silent.
A, another, before and after has formed. My life as thin as Bible pages, divided into histories, plays, songs, poems, scrawled pages of repetitive obsessive YOU ARE ALIVE as a mantra to remember I don‚Äôt have a choice but continue. Divisions occur and I am spectator and recipient, captivated by my continual disbelief in how I‚Äôve gotten it wrong, I have lost a little bit more once again, nothing was mine to begin with.
My fingers freeze around a half-fist, curled around my umbrella (the one I‚Äôll forget in a coffee chain by Union Square a week later), before I decide to call it quits and head back to the hobbled groupings of urban life within Portland. I have been (perhaps, in-error) working to keep the love I have, is what I‚Äôm gathering, that in American fashion I believe the luxuries of complacency can only bring calamity. Rosy-cheeked angels in rustic basement bars will warp into stonewalls, I should let them thin out the strings of this thread if that‚Äôs what they‚Äôd like to do.
I drink, and some more at Papi Portland. I shake off two dirt smeared men who follow me across Fore and Congress streets. I get two steps into a speakeasy before giving up at the third, unable to bring myself to swinging open unmarked doors. A psychic calls me back, meets me twenty minutes later to tell me what I already know, but she‚Äôs kind and doesn‚Äôt push too hard her enrollment program to unearth my generational curse. Now knowingly burdened with ancestors' fuckups, I trod along.
I bring the girl with me back to Brooklyn, who had such pleasures in bringing ghosts‚Äô particulars by frame in conversations with strangers. I have built up an instinct that must now go ignored, muscles I‚Äôve worked for years. I‚Äôm not promised anything, comforts or friends or family, do I close myself off for reprieve? How do I take this in, swallow and be someone I like?
I succumb to a sense of shyness once I feel known; how bold I am as a stranger, how timid I am the more I open. How do I feel destined for apathy but have hope for more?
There is a strip club, Mickey‚Äôs, directly on the border of the Rhode Island state line. Beer buckets advertised on-sale, void parking lots. Middle of a suburban neighborhood, some moments feel significant for nothing. Escape is temporary, my loves and losses circle back as haunting, as companions. But I have time and myself, constant motion brings perspective across the multitudes of lives as deep and complex, horrible and lonely as I fear mine to be.
I follow ghosts back, I live where my mother was born. I look at shelves Owen, inky bare skin and the kindest smile crinkled-eyes, installed in my room less than a year before, I don‚Äôt think about moving. The mind isn‚Äôt forever, either - I‚Äôll forget eventually, the street names and phrasings and fights. I hope I won‚Äôt forget what I‚Äôve loved, immortalized in menial tombs.
Life is patient back in Brooklyn for me to see the bigger picture, to see the schism of light. I daydream about when I crack, as foretold, as if that will bring understanding through manmade anxieties. I envision it‚Äôll unlock something, unlodge so I feel lighter, free fall with ribbons of my grief momentarily wings. The day will come, I promise, I‚Äôm hoping for Revelations.
--
--

It was the start of 2016. I had just moved to Paris. For a couple of months, my husband‚Äôs MBA hostel became our abode. He was pursuing his MBA at HEC Paris back then.
And I was tagging along while continuing to do my old job from Paris.
‚ÄúThere is but one Paris and however hard living may be here‚Ä¶the French air clears up the brain and does one good.‚Äù- Vincent van Gogh

I had hardly been won over on the way here. The views from the Eurostar had been, actually, short of spectacular.
‚ÄòI‚Äôm pretty sure we just popped out the tunnel in France. Looks like England but worse.‚Äô
What I didn‚Äôt realise, as I complained to my girlfriend about the Merville countryside, was that France doesn‚Äôt just look like England. Just like home, France is a parasite. Slums feeding off the prestige of the capital. Like London, Paris is a very rich city attached to an otherwise lacklustre country.

Title: The Toilet Culture of Paris
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
Share
Paris is one of the most visited cities in the world, but you will enjoy your stay more if you understand the complicated toilet culture. Parisien toilets are almost as diverse as the French cheeses, and the etiquette for using them can be confusing for a first-time visitor. I have taken 20 student groups to Paris, and I always tell my students to use a bathroom when they see one so there are fewer emergency situations.
Let me help you with what you need to know.
In the Louvre. In the main lobby under the stairs there are free bathrooms. The bathroom at the food court costs 50 centimes, and there is a bathroom that claims to be the cleanest in Paris. This bathroom is the most expensive. Obviously, you should use the free bathroom, but it helps you to know what to expect from the other two.
In the Luxembourg gardens. There are free bathrooms in the front to the left, at the back, and in the middle near the tennis court. It is expected for you to leave a small tip at the counter. I usually leave 20‚Äì50 centimes.
Public street bathrooms. There are public bathrooms on the street that look like spaceships. You will need change. They self-clean in between use, so wait for the green light.
In Caf√©s. If you need to use the bathroom in a caf√©, you should buy something. You usually don‚Äôt need to pay in a caf√©. Sometimes the owner will give you a jeton to use as a coin.
Although they are a rarity now, you might find a type of bathroom called Napoleon. It is two feet separated by a hole. When you flush make sure to step away from the feet because the water will wash over the feet.
I hope these suggestions help you to understand the bathroom culture.

Title: The Legacy of Paris Fashion Week: How It Shapes Global Trends
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Paris may be known as the city of love, but it‚Äôs also a city known for its fashion, if Emily in Paris has anything to say about it. As one of the ‚ÄúBig Four‚Äù fashion weeks (alongside New York, Milan, and London), Paris has cemented its legacy as the epicenter of haute couture and ready-to-wear collections.
Paris Fashion Week is an event that kickstarts trends off the runways and into retail stores and wardrobes globally. Here‚Äôs what you should know about it:
Paris Fashion Week wasn‚Äôt always as famous as it is now. Back in 1973, the French Fashion Federation established it as an official event to showcase the country‚Äôs unparalleled sartorial talent. But you‚Äôd be surprised to know that Paris‚Äôs love affair with high fashion goes back a long way.
In the 17th century, Louis XIV, also known as the Sun King, played an influential role in elevating France‚Äôs reputation for luxury fashion. The monarchy‚Äôs patronage of the textile industries and ateliers established Paris as a global destination for style and sophistication.
By the 19th century, the arrival of Charles Frederick Worth (considered to be the father of haute couture) solidified France‚Äôs dominance when it came to fashion. His maison became a pilgrimage site for royalty and aristocracy. It also ended up laying the groundwork for Parisian fashion houses that are revered today ‚Äî including Chanel and Dior. French fashion dresses became the trend, stemming from the fact that France became known for its quality, style, and elegance.
Paris Fashion Week might be synonymous with sophistication, but its real value lies in its diversity. It‚Äôs where avant-garde designers share the stage with heritage brands, creating a rich tapestry of styles and narratives. The event has two objectives: to present haute couture and ready-to-wear styles that speak to elites and everyday fashion enthusiasts, but also to set the tone for trends in the coming year.
Haute couture, which Paris exclusively champions, is an art form in itself. Each piece is generally handcrafted, taking hundreds of hours in craftsmanship alone. Designers like Christian Dior redefine feminine forms and designs, while other designers challenge history and society‚Äôs rules for what fashion should be. In the ready-to-wear segment, Paris outshines many other fashionable cities, due to designers pushing boundaries while maintaining elegance and structure in their clothing.
Paris Fashion Week‚Äôs influence on global trends is unparalleled. Each season, designers debut collections that reflect cultural shifts, technological advancements, and environmental consciousness. From the rising popularity of gender-neutral fashion and artisanal clothing to the integration of sustainable practices, Paris runways are a microcosm of broader societal ideals.
Think about the past Paris Fashion Weeks ‚Äî there was a time when fashion was all about the classic silhouette. But during Fashion Weeks in the 2010s, this notion was dispelled. Designers like Maria Grazia Chiuri and Virginie Viard breathed new life into traditional forms, blending history with modernity while retaining sophistication. Paris Fashion Week is also an event where it is consistently proved that fashion isn‚Äôt just about wearable clothing ‚Äî it‚Äôs also about conceptual art.
Many people believe that Paris Fashion Week is only about showcasing French designers, but that‚Äôs not the case at all. It‚Äôs a global platform that celebrates talent from around the world. Many designers see it as an award of sorts because it is the ultimate stage to attain recognition. This is also a stage for established brands to reaffirm their status and gain brand retention among their customer base.
The event also acts as a launchpad for emerging designers. Initiatives like the ANDAM Fashion Award spotlight fresh talent. It gives budding designers the opportunity to present their work to an audience of industry leaders, buyers, and journalists. These platforms are monumental in shaping the next generation of fashion, making sure that Paris will forever remain at the forefront of innovation.
In the past few years, especially after COVID-19, technology has transformed the way many experience Paris Fashion Week. Live-streamed shows, virtual reality experiences, and social media have democratized access, allowing millions to view this event while it‚Äôs occurring. Social media platforms have become integral to the event, with influencers and brands using them to amplify their audience reach.
But despite its long legacy and renown, Paris Fashion Week is not a stranger to challenges. From rising calls for sustainability to accessibility, there are many areas where progress is being made. The rise of digital fashion ‚Äî virtual garments and NFTs ‚Äî poses both a challenge and an opportunity. Paris Fashion Week has begun to explore these frontiers, as well as others, in an effort to remain relevant even during changing times.
Considering Paris Fashion Week‚Äôs history, it‚Äôs clear how important it has become in the fashion world. It‚Äôs not just that it‚Äôs a legacy event; it‚Äôs an event that sets standards for fashion everywhere in the world. It‚Äôs a cultural phenomenon that dictates how we perceive and engage with fashion, even on a daily basis. The colors, styles, and fits that are all the rage today were on the runways at some point in time, showing just how influential this event is.
--
--
Tess DiNapoli is an artist, freelance writer, and content strategist. She has a passion for yoga and often writes about fitness & wellness, as well as fashion.

Title: A Layover Into Memory
Content:
Sign up

Sign up
Sign in

Follow publication
Member-only story
--

Fifty kilometers northwest of Paris the green fields roll gently in the early morning dew.
I glance at the sun rising over the horizon through the lozenge window of my tiny, black Renault Twingo, and feel around the passenger seat for my sunglasses, eyes on the road.
The windshield clouds and I have to keep raising the defrost and turn on the wipers ‚Äî it‚Äôs that early in the morning in July. Mist drifts in the hollows.
I‚Äôm all alone on the road, but for a singular vehicle in a highway lane on the opposite direction speeding across my line of vision, and the always present trucks that appear as if born from the topography.
In open green fields, stucco and tile farmhouses interrupt the eye, draw it in and I wonder about the length of time these places have been here, memories buried deep in the stone. You feel the age of the land, its harmony ‚Äî but you know great disharmony got them here, to this moment.
I feel as if I‚Äôve been here before. I haven‚Äôt ‚Äî but it feels that way, a kind of in-between reality, a memory I didn‚Äôt know I had and the newness of the place pressing up against one another.
What is the place of memory in a story, any story? What is the place of memory in a life? What constitutes memory?

Content:

I lived in Paris for a year as an exchange student, and have developed a huge affection for the city; not least the food on offer.
I‚Äôm confident that if you‚Äôre here for a short city break, you‚Äôll find your own favourite bakery, creperie, and caf√©, and there are countless lists of wonderful restaurants that will cost more than ‚Ç¨50 a person, so look elsewhere for your treat meals!
Here is a list of places I‚Äôve been to more than once, and can always count on.
For fondue, go to Pain, Vin, Fromages (3 Rue Geoffroy l‚ÄôAngevin). You must reserve, as it‚Äôs only open for a limited dinner service. Get the M√©ridionale which is a standard fondue with mixed herbs, and if you eat meat go for the bourguignonne which is cubes of steak that you cook at your table with a delectable salad.
For a cheap French brasserie experience go to Bouillon Chartier (7 Rue du Faubourg Montmartre). The wait staff are comically rude, but you‚Äôll pay something like ‚Ç¨1 for a soup and less than ‚Ç¨15 for a delicious fish dish. Get the salade fris√©e aux lardons I don‚Äôt know what they put in the dressing but I‚Äôd take shots of it if I could.
For an unusual lunch, try Jyujiya (46 Rue Sainte-Anne) in the Japanese district. They claim to be the first to bring Japanese bent≈ç to Paris, and they‚Äôre stunningly authentic and really good value for money. Save room to get a treat at Aki (same street) which does incredible Franco-Japanese desserts. The matcha melonpan is just perfect.
For a slightly more upmarket and significantly smaller scale bistro experience than Chartier, then try Le temps des cerises (31 Rue de la Cerisaie). If you see Caf√© Gourmand on a desert menu in France then it‚Äôs usually worth getting ‚Äî it‚Äôs typically a selection of small portions of the place‚Äôs best desserts served with coffee. Here it is a must try. French onion soup (here they just call it onion soup!!!!!) is also to die for.
For a very French fast food, try King Marcel (various locations). Fries and sides are weak, and to be honest it‚Äôs not my favourite style of burger at all. But it‚Äôs very high quality, and not a style of big thick burger I‚Äôve found elsewhere. The bun is arguably too delicious for its own good.

Title: Black Americans, Paris Has a Surprise for You
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

19
Listen
Share
It was an evening like any other. My uncle Simplice gathered my brother, my two cousins and me around the fire that he often had us light after dark in the courtyard of his house. It was in August, during the school vacation period. I was about 8 or 9 years old, my cousin Vieux was the same age, while my little brother and my other cousin Papi were 5 or 6 years old. We had finished dinner and, as was often the case in many villages in Cameroon, the boys were invited to join the men to listen to tales full of wisdom and stories about the history of our ancestors, while the girls often stayed with the women. This separation, which was in no way reflective of the social hierarchy, dated back centuries. It was through these evenings that the wise men passed on their knowledge. Africa, for centuries, was a continent giving priority to oral culture, hence the importance of a griot, a word used for an older African tribal storyteller.
That evening, my uncle Simplice had shed his relaxed side that made him our favorite uncle. We all loved his dilettante side which made him one of the fiercest hunters in the village. He knew how to put you at ease when you had your baptism of fire in the initiation to hunting in the forest at night. That evening, we all looked at each other, as his serious and almost solemn appearance was so disconcerting. We weren‚Äôt used to seeing him like this. He opened the session as he often did with his singular cry.
ÔÄ≠ ‚ÄúAudience,‚Äù he urged.ÔÄ≠ ‚ÄúSilence,‚Äù we responded in unison.
The custom was for this ritual to be performed three times. It concluded with ‚ÄúDo tell.‚Äù Only after that could the wise man start the story. That evening would not be like any other, my uncle warned us.
ÔÄ≠ ‚ÄúWe are going to talk about the history of all Cameroonians, regardless of their tribe. It‚Äôs a common history that binds us,‚Äù said my uncle, who spoke in a Bantu dialect.
He had married my mother‚Äôs older sister and his village, Ekali II, was located about thirty kilometers from Yaound√©, the capital of Cameroon.
My uncle, who was a teacher at the local high school, then spoke to us about colonization. The story was devoid of moral teachings, which often flooded the stories he had told us in the past. He used the word ‚Äúwhite‚Äù to refer to the colonists. He explained to us that, for a long time, our ancestors had lived with the idea that white people were immortal. This was what the settlers had propagated, he said.
ÔÄ≠ ‚ÄúThey said that their God had made them immortal. They had guns to kill us, while we had nothing. We ended up believing them. Guns were believed to be divine weapons to punish anyone who dared to rebel against them.‚Äù
ÔÄ≠ ‚ÄúAnd how did you discover that they were mortal?‚Äù I dared to ask.
ÔÄ≠ ‚ÄúAt the end of the First World War,‚Äù he replied. ‚ÄúWhat happened was that some of our brave men were taken to Europe to fight in the war alongside white men. They saw them die. They then said to themselves that the white man could also die. The survivors came to tell what they had seen. Little by little, the way we looked at white people changed, but we had to wait until the end of the Second World War for the myth of the white immortal colonist man to finally evaporate.‚Äù
This awakening, which dates to the end of the 1940s, coincides with the exacerbated aspirations for independence in the colonies. One of the very first colonies to become an independent country was Ghana in 1957, followed by Guinea in 1958. The rest had to wait until the 1960s. Until today, we even speak of neocolonialism in certain countries, because the former colonial powers continue to pull the strings behind the scenes to put in power the president of their choice and to exploit the continent‚Äôs resources with the help of corrupt local elites.
For more than 30 years, I buried deep inside me the words from my uncle about the immortal colonist, as this image had horrible consequences for millions of Africans and for Africa in general, because it was a weapon to subjugate and enslave us. I preferred to look forward. But the past and its images caught up with me a few days ago during the exhibition ‚ÄúThe Harlem Renaissance and Transatlantic Modernism,‚Äù currently on display at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.
The Harlem Renaissance is undoubtedly the artistic expression of the chronicling of the modern daily life of black Americans by black Americans in the midst of the Great Migration, which corresponds to the period from the 1920s to the 1940s. During this period, many black Americans were leaving the rural, racist and segregated South for the North. The exhibition, which is a dive into the New Negro artistic movement, introduces us to painters, artists and intellectuals both known and unknown. Among these artists is the painter Archibald Motley, who lived, for a short period of time in Paris and in the south of France. In the text which accompanies Motley‚Äôs paintings, created during his French period, it is recounted that many Harlem Renaissance artists often stayed in Europe and more particularly in France, which was one of the European artistic centers of the time. This European passage was seen as ‚Äúan essential part of their artistic training.‚Äù
The text also raises one of the biggest dichotomies between black Americans and black Africans. This sticking point is at the center of the discord that has fueled our disagreement for decades: ‚ÄúThe artists associated with the New Negro movement also described feeling a sense of greater personal freedom in countries that, despite oppressive rule in overseas colonies, did not have legalized racial segregation within their own borders,‚Äù one of the texts reads.
This sentence suggests that the United States was, at the time, more racist than Europe, and particularly France. This is still repeated today by black Americans who visit Europe or live in France, let alone Paris. For them, France, like certain European countries, is less racist. This is entirely contrary to the daily experience of black Africans and other minorities, particularly Arabs, living in Europe.
I understand well that this sentence aims to summarize the experience of black Americans in France and beyond in Europe, where they were better received and, above all, seen as full human beings, whereas in their own country, they were perceived as subhuman.
Racial segregation was legalized and took the form of the Jim Crow laws which separated blacks from whites in transportation, housing, employment, education, bathrooms, hospitals, churches, prisons, funeral homes, cemeteries, etc. This ‚Äúinferiorization‚Äù of black Americans was legitimized and made official by a decision of the Supreme Court in 1896. The famous decision of May 18, 1896 on Plessy v. Ferguson ruled that the State of Louisiana was entitled to classify Mr. Plessy among the ‚Äúpeople of color‚Äù because of his one-eighth black blood and that Judge Ferguson could consequently prohibit him from accessing the wagons reserved for whites!
There was certainly no law rendering blacks and other minorities inferior in Europe, but in fact (and this is the European particularity) the racial hierarchy was omnipresent and still is today in a very subtle way. In the 1920s to 1940s, to which the Harlem Renaissance exhibition is focused, almost no country in sub-Saharan Africa was independent. Very few blacks lived in Europe and in France. France did and continues to do everything to hide the horrors of colonization. Just a small example that took place during the Harlem Renaissance period was the Thiaroye massacre, which took place in Senegal in December 1944.
In November 1944, France was being gradually liberated from the Nazi occupiers. After four years of war, 1,300 West African riflemen (Tirailleurs as they are often referred to) were repatriated by the French army to Thiaroye, in a military camp in the suburbs of Dakar. They were demanding payment of their captivity balances, as well as various bonuses which had not been paid to them. At dawn on December 1, gunfire broke out in the camp. The French army said it was a mutiny that it had to repress bloodily. However, many gray areas remain.
For several years, the official French position was that the ‚ÄúThiaroye affair‚Äù was a ‚Äúheavily armed rebellion and a hostage-taking‚Äù requiring a ‚Äúresponse‚Äù with disastrous results. But in November 2014, the French President Fran√ßois Hollande on a visit to this Dakar suburb, said that France must ‚Äúrepair an injustice and salute the memory of men who wore the French uniform and on whom the French had returned their rifle.‚Äù
The Thiaroye massacre, according to historians, was the consequence of France‚Äôs decision to ‚Äúwhitewash‚Äù its troops by replacing riflemen from Senegal, Dahomey (present-day Benin), French Sudan (present-day Mali), C√¥te d‚ÄôIvoire, Oubangui-Chari (present-day Central Africa), Niger, Chad, Gabon and Togo, by ethnic French soldiers.
The Harlem Renaissance exhibition also celebrates artists like Jos√©phine Baker who became a superstar in France. The success of one black individual in no way erases the treatment received by many others. At the same time as Paris celebrated Baker, the remains of Saatje Baartman, a South African slave whose body had been dissected and cast, her brain, her genitals and her posterior preserved in formalin, were exhibited at the Musee de l‚ÄôHomme in the same city of light.
Born in South Africa in 1789, Baartman was exhibited as a human monster in Europe, notably in London and Paris. She was the first modern freak. She had been nicknamed the ‚ÄúHottentot Venus‚Äù for her atypical physique. The name already constitutes a testimony to the way Europeans viewed black Africans. Venus refers to the Greek goddess of beauty, but was used here to mock her body which Europeans found disproportionate due to its exuberant forms which visitors fiddled with like an animal. ‚ÄúHottentot‚Äù refers to her origin (she was from the Khoikhoi or Hottentot tribe).
The famous French zoologist Georges Cuvier, who was responsible for dissecting her body after her death in Paris in 1815, had concluded that she belonged to the same species as the white race, but that did not prevent him from classifying her at the very bottom of the human scale, barely above the chimpanzee and the orangutan. A place that the Hottentots shared with the Bushmen, the Pygmies, the ‚ÄúCaribbeans‚Äù and the Australian Aborigines.
What is striking in Motley‚Äôs paintings in Paris, is that the bars and caf√©s are full of white people, an indication of the place of black people in French society. That hasn‚Äôt changed much today. We are considered second-class French citizens. Racial discrimination is subtle but pervasive. Renting an apartment in a large French city is a challenge when you are black African or Arab; finding work that matches your level of education and abilities is also a challenge. No minority is running a large French company. Young minority graduates are forced to go into exile to find work that matches their level of education and skills.
How many blacks and Arabs live in Paris? The presence of black Africans and Arabs in tourist places and neighborhoods is an illusion. They don‚Äôt live there. For a long time, part of the 18th arrondissement of Paris, towards Barb√®s-Ch√¢teau Rouge, was the landmark and meeting point for black Africans. Black Africans could buy products imported from Africa there. While the market remains and black Africans are still present, almost none live there because of gentrification.
Before declaring Paris and France as less racist, black Americans would benefit from taking a quick trip to the suburbs around Paris, where minorities are segregated. Seine Saint Denis, which is one train stop from Paris, would give you an example of the true living conditions of blacks and Arabs in France. Basically, ten minutes by train, getting off at Stade de France, will allow you to really see France in its true light. When you are a black African or Arab, police checks are part of your daily life, as are racist clich√©s.
The latest controversy in France: French pop star Aya Nakamura, who is of Malian origin but grew up in the Paris suburbs, doesn‚Äôt really speak French to sing at the opening ceremony of the Paris 2024 Olympic Games, say the right and the far-right. A rumor spread that the singer, currently the best known outside French borders, would sing in the ceremony. She immediately received numerous racist insults, simply because she mixes dialects, from foreign languages, with French in her music.
ÔÄ≠ ‚ÄúYou can be racist but not deaf,‚Äù Nakamura responded on Twitter on March 10. ‚ÄúWhat do I really owe you?‚Äù
73% of French people think that Nakamura does not represent ‚ÄúFrench‚Äù music, according to a poll, while 63% oppose the idea of her headlining at the opening ceremony. This says a lot about the state of racism in France.
For black Africans, north Africans (Algerians, Tunisians, Moroccans) and other minorities, racism is our reality in France and Paris. Black Americans are seen as American visitors. White France‚Äôs relationship with them is different from what it is with us. It goes back to General Charles de Gaulle, the French hero of the Second World War, who always wanted to distinguish France from the United States, by offering an alternative to the American model in the world stage. Seen from this angle, welcoming black Americans who are ostracized in their country is a form of affront to the American rival. Except that, in reality, France does not treat its blacks and minorities very differently.
I asked some of my black American friends why they had this impression that France was less racist.
ÔÄ≠ ‚ÄúThe only thing that comes to mind is that many [African Americans] are just unfamiliar with French history,‚Äù my black American friend Bruce replied.
--
--
19

Title: The Paris Beyond the Postcards
Content:

The problem with Paris is not that it‚Äôs a living clich√©, but that it isn‚Äôt one. That‚Äôs not to say that many ideas about the city don‚Äôt have an element of truth. But the city is so big and contains so many multitudes that it can be tiring to challenge them all the time.
When I think about my life in Paris, I would say that many of the ideas about the French capital that get perpetuated online feel so distant from my reality. It‚Äôs almost like they belong to another city entirely ‚Äî one that doesn‚Äôt exist anywhere on Earth.
But just writing about the problem with stereotypes isn‚Äôt always that helpful. So today I thought I would take you on a photo walk just to give you another side of Paris ‚Äî one that tourists seldom see.
We‚Äôre in the 19th arrondissement in the north-east of the city, which is about as far removed from Postcard Paris as you can get. It‚Äôs the kind of neighbourhood that you‚Äôd never see in Emily in Paris, for the simple reason that it‚Äôs not particularly glamorous. When a show is about projecting a fantasy, a place like this would only counter the narrative.
There‚Äôs no denying that the 19th arrondissement is one of the poorer areas of the capital. But that doesn‚Äôt mean that it doesn‚Äôt‚Ä¶

Title: I Was Sick the Whole Time: Paris (2)
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
There were a few places I went during my holiday in Paris. Practically they were not museums, but the visiting experience was worth being noted.
The free entry was included in my Go Paris card, and I was intrigued by the description mentioning the final days of Marie-Antoinette, so I stepped into the old prison. I didn‚Äôt have really high hopes as I saw some photos online, and I wasn‚Äôt impressed. However, one small thing was a real game changer.
The Histopad!
I am not too keen on incorporating technology in museums as part of the tour. It doesn‚Äôt sound sensible and I know how I sound: Not everyone can ‚Äúappreciate‚Äù or ‚Äúlearn‚Äù with traditional method, which is purely visual observation. Technology like AR (augmented reality) VR (virtual reality) to me are distractions, and I feel like they sometimes lack the profoundness, i.e. content, and therefore they are more like tokens or trophies.
However, if I hadn‚Äôt toured the Concierge with the Histopad, I would have left with great disappointment. There were pods around the place where people scanned them with the pads, which initiate the augmented reality of what could the place look like in the 15th century. The animation was made fine and it really provided a lot more information on the historical context, such as the people who dined, walked, how they dressed, etc.. What I liked the most was the hidden treasure that visitor could collect if they really aimed to click every possible button in the AR. I managed to find 5 out of 6, failing to find the last one. I was a bit bummed because I was very curious to learn what prize I could have!
2. Mus√©e Parfum ‚Äî Fragonard
I visited this place because as part of my Go Paris card deal, there was a mini workshop provided by the Fragonard Perfume Museum where tourists could make their own perfume. A few months prior to the visit, I finished reading the book, : Elixir: A Story of Perfume, Science and the Search for the Secret of Life, by Theresa Levitt. The name Fragonard was mentioned multiple times, as he was an important figure not only in the perfumery business, but also in the history of chemistry.
www.amazon.co.uk
Unfortunately I didn‚Äôt take any picture during the quick guided tour after the workshop. It was basically a brief look at the history of the Fragonard brand, including the classic best-seller smell and the design of the bottles.
I had a great impression on the visiting experience: It was hands-on, multi-sensory (the whole museum and shop smelled amazing), and the environment was beautifully designed. What I want to highlight is that this is another type of museum ‚Äî Corporate/Brand museum.
dotdotdot-it.medium.com
I once joked with friends that there should be a law or policy that regulates what places could call themselves ‚Äúmuseums‚Äù, which is a term frequently used by private collectors, hoarders, and people with niche interests. I‚Äôm not putting the term museum on a high altar; instead, I want museums to follow standards so audience could have an appropriate expectation when they step into a place that is labelled ‚Äúmuseum‚Äù. Standards should include: If the collections on display are sourced ethically; if the display is from one single private collector; and if the place is funded by a publicly-known corporate and brand.
If a museum is about the history and archival perspective of a corporate, it is highly possible used as a white-washing front, distracting or misguiding the public from truth and creating a parallel narrative. A museum should be a place where voices of different backgrounds are curated to reflect the public and the community, and if any exhibition or institution fails to do so, they should not be called a museum but a display.
3. Paris Catacombs
I wasn‚Äôt aware of the catacombs until an advertisement popped up on my social media feeds. A walk among the deads‚Äô bones? Yes! Within a heartbeat I booked myself a visit to it.
It was a well oriented and executed place with many signs of direction. The audio guide provided painted a great picture of the history and how the catacomb was conserved in modern times. For some, the environment definitely was spooky, but I was really happy to learn how the dead was treated in history.
!! Attention!!
Pictures of human remains. Readers‚Äô discretion is advised.
A minor thing worth noting is that there would be staff checking visitors‚Äô bags to prevent people smuggling the bones and skulls.

My time in Paris during the Olympics was filled with the odd, the ironic, and the sublime.
I had my first bad meal in Paris, and it briefly crushed my spirit. Like many people, I have long romanticized this city whose history and magic are etched in literature and film. ‚ÄúThere are only two places in the world where we can live happy: at home and in Paris,‚Äù Ernest Hemingway said.
Dozens of famous quotes profess such homage, none more succinct than Maurice Chevalier‚Äôs character in the 1958 film Gigi asking incredulously, ‚ÄúLeave Paris?‚Äù Audrey Hepburn got to the point: ‚ÄúParis is always a good idea.‚Äù Victor Hugo put it more eloquently in his 19th-century novel Les Mis√©rables: ‚ÄúTo breathe Paris preserves the soul.‚Äù
This is the beguiling image travelers bring when they visit Paris, and the city generally delivers. Fashion windows are more inviting than in New York or London. The storefronts dare you not to linger. Stunning centuries-old architecture fills the frame in every direction. Surely that is part of what Hugo breathed in.
Even the city‚Äôs graveyards boast elegance with a literary flair. P√®re Lachaise Cemetery is the final resting place of poets and artists from Chopin to the famously troubled Doors frontman Jim Morrison, whose tomb bears Greek words that approximate ‚Äúthe one who fights his demons.‚Äù

Content:

Sign up
Sign in

Seeking joy in all the geek places. Join a scifi nerd, professor, and podcast dork on his journey to find and share joyful thoughts on all the genre goodness!

Member-only story

1

Perhaps the most potent problem of our modern era is its obsession with nostalgia. In its least malignant form, nostalgia becomes an excessive love of art and fashion playfully removed from the socio-political conditions of its creation. In its most malignant form, nostalgia turns people into cult-like fascists who desire a return to a time that never really existed. Most nostalgia travelers rest somewhere between: fantasizing about going back to something that felt more familiar, even at the expense of the present. And then there‚Äôs Midnight in Paris (2011), which seems to relish in misery, imagination, and nostalgia at varying points and for varying purposes. What ultimately does the film say about nostalgia, then?
Midnight in Paris follows Gil (Owen Wilson), a Hollywood script doctor disgruntled by the artlessness of his work, who visits Paris with his fianc√© Inez (Rachel McAdams) and her parents, all wealthy socialites. Utterly in love with the city and its Modernist past, Gil fantasizes about moving there to make an honest go at becoming a novelist, much to the chagrin of Inez, who cannot fathom a life outside of the United States. They eventually run into the horrifically pedantic Paul (Michael Sheen) and his wife Carol (Nina Arianda) and are coaxed on several sightseeing trips. In frustration, Gil wanders Paris‚Ä¶

Title: Living the Parisian Life: An Expat‚Äôs Experience of 17 Years
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Sweet and sour stories about expat and immigrant life.

--
8
Listen
Share
Yesterday I phoned one of my dear friends. She is French, but she moved to Madrid 3 years ago.
We talked about our lives, about how she does not have the time to fully learn Spanish, and how difficult it is to make local friends without speaking the language.
It made me think about my ¬´ d√©buts ¬ª in France.
I came to Paris when I was 19 years old to study law. I thought I would stay a year or two to change from Austria, but here I am, 17 years later.
Today, I would like to share my story about being an adult expat, the difficulties I faced and how to overcome them.
I grew up with the idealized image of Paris, which we see in the movies and cartoons ‚Äî the city of lights and love, with happy people full of wonders and artists.
I am half embarrassed to say that even at the age of 19, I almost thought things in Paris were the way they were shown in the cartoon Anastasia: happy people dancing around the city on the pavements and going up the Eiffel Tower to scream their joy of being French.
Let me burst your bubble right now, and I am sorry for that: Paris might be the city of arts, lights, and love, but it is definitely not full of joyful people. Quite the opposite, to be honest.
It is a wonderful place to visit, and it is one of the most beautiful cities I have seen so far. Starting to live here, though, was a challenge, and still is sometimes.
French people are known for loving good food, good wine, and‚Ä¶ complaining. It is not a legend, a true French will always find something to be unhappy about: politics, weather, wages, the food, the wine, the prices, the subway, the trains, the airplanes‚Ä¶ You name it. If you watch the international news, you might know France is also the country of strikes.
Let me summarize the French art of striking: for the last 77 years (even more, but we lack archives), the national railway company called SNCF has been striking, mostly every summer and Christmas holiday every year. Yes, you read it the right way. Every year. For the last 77 years.
I must admit I find this art of being constantly unhappy quite charming, at least sometimes. Unless it impacts my daily life, which will then become the moment when I hate living in France. I suppose after 17 years, I became a bit French myself and adopted the unhappy philosophy!
Now, let us imagine you are an expat in France; you try to adapt. Is it hard? Yes and no. At least in Paris, the capital, people are used to foreigners, so they will not be shocked. But that does not mean they will accept you with open arms right away.
The first difficulty you would encounter is the language. French is not the easiest language to learn, and to grasp the French accent is quite difficult. Of course, you could just learn to speak it without trying to imitate the French accent. You could even become bilingual in French over the years, like I did; but do you think that would be enough?
After 17 years, I still get jokes and comments on my accent, although I am bilingual. I studied law at the Sorbonne, and I practiced as a lawyer for several years, so you can imagine I even know very technical terms an average French would not know. Without the perfect accent, all that does not count.
To my despair, it is the only country I know of where you make an effort to speak the language, and people will criticize your efforts instead of being happy.
While many appreciate your efforts, others will comment on your accent or correct your grammar ‚Äî perhaps because they love their language so much they can‚Äôt resist pushing you toward perfection.
Finding true friends is challenging, too, as in every country. It was easier when I was a student, of course, but I learned that there is no age to find new friends. It is always possible. The secret?
Do something you love ‚Äî join a class, an association, or a group related to your passion. You‚Äôll find that French people are much more welcoming when you share common interests, even if you‚Äôre not fluent in French.
It seems contradictory, I know, but the thing is, a French will not make too much effort for a complete stranger, but if you want to join a group, things change. Just pick your passion and go for it!
Now that we have mentioned the less-than-happy parts of living here let‚Äôs get to the interesting part: Why come to France?
First of all, food and wine. It might sound clich√©, but living here, or even visiting for a couple of days, opens new perspectives and changes your way of visualizing eating. For French people, food is sacred, so even the lunch breaks are quite long compared to other countries. Eating a sandwich in front of your computer is not the norm here.
People love enjoying the food, and it‚Äôs contagious. Before you know it, you will eat with your eyes before eating with your mouth. You will start enjoying every bite. You will start looking for new ideas for your cooking. You will start enjoying eating and tasting different foods. And thus, you will start enjoying life itself.
As for the wine, you will not find a better country to learn about it, taste it, and want to become an expert.
Living in Paris will also open your cultural chakras. Many artists and writers have found inspiration in this city. I could walk for hours around Paris without even noticing it; every street is worth the while. So many different cultural and fashion events take place in Paris, we never get bored.
My favorite neighborhood is the 5th arrondissement*. Hemingway used to live there, on the Rue Mouffetard, which is also my favorite street in Paris (and one of the oldest, too). You can find Gallo-Roman ruins, beautiful old churches, the Pantheon, and many other things in this arrondissement. It is also a student hideout because of its proximity to the Sorbonne.
If you ever visit the city, do not miss it!
It is always beneficial to try to understand the local culture. If you can get help doing so, it would be even better. I never thought I would change my career path the way I am planning to, but here I am today, hesitating to propose coaching services to expats who come to France.
It took me years to really start grasping the complexity of French culture and‚Ä¶ bureaucracy. It also took a Master‚Äôs in law to better understand how to navigate the administrative system. From opening the first bank account to finding a school or nanny for the kids, it is quite the journey for an expat. It is also difficult to find people speaking enough English to really help you.
I will always preach the benefits of having help when moving to a new country because I suffered a lot of isolation and lack of proper communication during my different expat experiences.
To finish, here is a list of important things to know, even as a tourist. The ¬´ dos ¬ª and ¬´ don‚Äôts ¬ª are quite a few, so I will write another article about the topic.
In the meantime, keep in mind:
Adapting to life in Paris was challenging at first, but the city has a magic that always draws you in ‚Äî even when times are tough. Over the years, Paris has taught me to slow down, savor the moment, and enjoy life. And I‚Äôm still learning every day.
Please let me know in the comments if you have visited Paris or planning to do so. I would love to hear about your experience!
* arrondissement is the translation of ¬´ districts ¬ª
--
--
8

Ex-lawyer, proud mum and burn-out survivor. I write stories that blend folklore, creativity, mindfulness, and the art of communication into journeys.

Every now and then, I‚Äôll see an image of the Eiffel Tower or Notre Dame, and I will think about going to Paris again. Or I‚Äôll think about some great work of art at the Louvre that I missed my first time around that I want to see in person.
But, if I‚Äôm being honest with myself, I don‚Äôt think I could bring myself to go back. It happens to many travelers, where one bad experience in a city or country ruins their impression of it. This is also not a case of Paris Syndrome because I did not go in thinking I would be dazzled by the city.
I visited Paris on the last leg of my student trip in 2019. We had spent a week in Ireland, Scotland, and England. We had the option of a two-day extension in Paris, so I figured I would not be another country off my list. In hindsight, we should have just flown home after London.
